HEADLINE: Uniting the Feudal Lords at Citicorp

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
JOHN S. REED, chairman of Citicorp, is facing the executives who run the company's 15 operating divisions. They barely know each other.
The 15, most of whom have flown in from posts abroad for the two-day meeting at the Citicorp Center in Manhattan, are used to running their businesses as separate empires, answerable only loosely to a multi-tiered hierarchy in New York. But it is early 1992 and the banking giant is in trouble, drowning in bad real estate loans and runaway costs. Mr. Reed asks each of the 15 to put something into the hat, as part of a mired two-year rescue plan to trim expenses by more than $1 billion. 
 Eventually, it is James Bailey's turn. Mr. Bailey runs Citicorp's credit card operation and branch system in the United States, the most profitable business in the sprawling company. In the cocky and freewheeling Citicorp of old, Mr. Bailey was encouraged to invest those profits pretty much any way he pleased.
Now, he is being asked to subordinate his needs to those of the entire company. He sighs and says he will delay opening three new branches in Connecticut that are sure to attract a flock of affluent commuters.
And he does so knowing that one of the executives sitting across from him, Rana Talwar, head of Citicorp's much smaller consumer banking business in Asia, is going to get a green light to open new branches in booming Taiwan. A new branch in Taipei will make money sooner than one in Greenwich or Stamford, Mr. Bailey concedes.
The hat keeps going around the table and the others also make "contributions" for the commonweal, one of the key turning points in Mr. Reed's desperate, and apparently successful, effort to make over Citicorp's culture, a me-first mentality that encouraged bravado and hubris and brought the bank to the brink during the recession.
"We were like a medieval state," said Mr. Bailey in a recent interview. "There was the king and his court and they were in charge, right? No. It was the land barons who were in charge. The king and his court might declare this or that, but the land barons went and did their thing."
That stopped in January 1992, when Mr. Reed purged his court, firing or pushing aside most of his key New York-based aides, including the bank's president, Richard S. Braddock, and invited the barons to join him at a U-shaped version of the Round Table. In the dramatic reorganization, Mr. Reed declared that the 15 "barons" -- all men, 10 of them 50 years of age or younger -- would report directly to him.
Since then, Mr. Reed has convened what has come to be called the Group of 15, or G-15, every month in what amounts to a war council. The G-15 members, through fiat, peer pressure and new compensation arrangements, have been forced to work together to slash costs, cut loan losses and find new business. The group does not make big policy decisions. Instead, its proposals must be approved by a separate six-member committee of the remaining senior executives, including Mr. Reed, who sit in on their meetings.
 
A Big Payback
 Two years after G-15 first began to meet, Citicorp is enjoying a striking recovery. Late last week, the company said it earned about $2.2 billion in 1993, a record for an American bank. Citicorp's loan losses are down, and it has raised enough capital so that it is expected to pay a dividend this year, the first since 1991. And Mr. Bailey has even opened two of the branches he wanted in Connecticut.
"We have gone from feudalism to a nation-state," he said. "We are all running the same company."
The discussion these days at G-15 meetings -- the next one will be held this Wednesday -- now includes more talk of growth. Mr. Reed has been asking each of the executives to say where they would invest money if they got some of the limited capital that is now available. He has also been asking for ambitious new ways to cut costs even more. Last Monday, Mr. Reed's smaller group of senior executives, known as the G-6, approved a package of new cost-cutting proposals from the G-15 that will result in a $425 million charge against earnings in the fourth quarter of 1993. This latest cost-cutting campaign, announced on Thursday, is being coordinated by Christopher Steffen, the former Chrysler and Kodak executive Mr. Reed hired in May to ride herd over expenses as the newest member of the G-6.
To be sure, the G-15 meetings are hardly the only reason for the turnaround. Mr. Reed raised capital by selling stock and he pruned some money-losing businesses. Just last week, for example, Reuters Holdings P.L.C. acquired Citicorp's troubled Quotron financial information computer service, on which it had lost an estimated $1 billion since buying the business in 1986. What's more, the real estate market stabilized, allowing Citicorp to unload the office buildings and shopping malls it had repossessed from bankrupt developers. And the European currency turmoil has led to record profits from trading.
Still, the shift to a more collegial culture could be the most important and long-lasting contribution to Citicorp that Mr. Reed, chairman since 1984 and now 54 years old, will make, because it may keep the bank from getting in trouble again.
 
The Old Way
 The old culture, defined by Walter B. Wriston, the former chairman, emphasized autonomy, internal competition and risk taking and allowed Citicorp to become the most aggressive and innovative player in a stodgy industry.
But that culture also produced a strangling duplication of efforts, resulting, for example, in 11 different computer systems for checking accounts in the United States alone. And because the emphasis was on building revenue, and not assessing overall risks, Citicorp wound up with the biggest portfolio by far of bad real estate loans -- not to mention the billions in bad loans to the third world racked up earlier in the 80's.
In many ways, Citicorp has emerged from the experience shaken and humbled. Gone is the grandiosity that assumed it could dominate businesses ranging from insurance to computer systems. Gone as well is the arrogance that spurned conventional practices, such as adopting industry norms for sufficient levels of capital and loan-loss reserves.
Yet Citicorp is still enormously ambitious. Mr. Reed boasts he has kept its "crown jewels," operations in more than 90 countries, with a range of incredibly profitable specialties, from credit cards to currency trading to a unique presence in the developing world. So while most American banks search for a strategy in what is generally thought to be a shrinking industry, Citicorp has a clear, if vast, mission: to take advantage of its unmatched global reach.
But the critics of Mr. Reed question whether he has the tenacity to continue his new management focus and keep the land barons from again breaking free once the forced discipline of circumstance wanes. And while Mr. Reed has borrowed his new, flatter organization chart from the General Electric Company, even his admirers suggest he does not have the knack that G.E.'s chairman, Jack Welch, has for controlling a decentralized organization.
 
Bringing It Back
 "John admits he took his eye off the ball and didn't watch the loan portfolio; Jack is so obsessed, he would never take his eye off the balance sheet," said Noel M. Tichy, a business professor at the University of Michigan who has studied both companies.
Nonetheless, Mr. Tichy said that Mr. Reed has taken significant steps toward emulating G.E.'s ability to delegate authority yet control risks. "I'm betting that Reed can do it, as long as he doesn't get unfocused or bored," he said. "He wants to be the guy that brought the place back."
Mr. Reed declined to be interviewed for this article. He stopped talking to the press a year ago as the bank's fortunes began to improve. Somewhat like a superstitious baseball player, he has apparently decided to keep silent, lest the good results come to a halt. Nonetheless, Mr. Reed authorized interviews with other senior executives, including members of the Group of 15.
In the interviews, the executives said the seeds of Citicorp's recovery were sown in what was its darkest hour, January 1992.
Losses from the bank's $22 billion portfolio of real estate loans kept mounting. Just before Christmas, the company's stock had slid to $8.50, one third the price of two years earlier. And the banking industry was filled with rumors that Mr. Reed -- whose two-year rescue plan, begun in January 1991, was not working fast enough -- would be fired. He was certainly under substantial pressure from his board and the Government to show he was in charge.
He responded by scrapping the existing operational system, in which divisional heads reported to seven New York-based executives who reported to Mr. Braddock, Citicorp's president, who reported to Mr. Reed. He replaced that with the G-15.
"The G-15 was a big leap for John," said one member of the new group. "It required him to take the president of the bank and put him to the side, not because Rick had done anything wrong, but because John had to get control of the company directly and personally."
Mr. Reed had largely spent his time on strategy and external relations, delegating day-to-day operations to others.
"John is not a hands-on manager, not a lender, not a capital markets guy," said one former top executive. "He's a visionary. It was beneath him to cut costs or read loan files."
For his part, Mr. Braddock joined the G-6 and supervised cost-cutting. But this didn't prove satisfactory to him. After he returned from a trip to Asia in the summer of 1992, he met with Mr. Reed to discuss his role. By several accounts, Mr. Reed became angry at Mr. Braddock during the meeting, criticizing him for not responding quickly to losses in the mortgage division, and abruptly fired him. (Neither man would comment on the incident.)
Mr. Reed's reorganization and purges left him clearly in charge with no obvious successor. That fact could only help bolster his job security at a time when chief executives were being tossed out at General Motors, I.B.M. and American Express.
The G-15 executives, however, have been energized by the new power delegated to them. The group contains several men regarded as rising stars, including Alan MacDonald, who now runs the corporate and investment banking business in the United States, and Victor Menezes, head of consumer banking in Europe. Reflecting the company's international scope, eight of the group's members were born abroad -- one in Pakistan, one in Japan and two each in Argentina, Germany and India.
 
At the Beginning
 When they started, the meetings of the G-15 began at 8 A.M. on the third Thursday of the month and lasted two grueling days. (They are still generally held on the third Thursday but now last only until early afternoon.)
Mr. Reed's version of hands-on management is not so much to bark specific orders but to articulate a clear set of goals and make sure that everyone contributes to them.
Executives first take turns discussing the quality of their loan portfolios and what they are doing to work out any problems. Then they go around the room to talk about how they are raising capital, then again for cutting costs and finally for increasing revenue. To emphasize that the meetings are cooperative rather than a competitive endeavor, no one is allowed to talk about the profits of his individual area.
"We took away the show-and-tell aspect," said Alan Weber, a fast-rising New York-based member of the G-15 in charge of the bank's business with other financial institutions and its huge computerized money transfer operation.
Early on, the repeated rounds of cost cutting produced the most tension. "It was like a poker game," said Mr. Weber. "Everybody coughed up things they didn't want to do."
Sometimes people bluffed. At one early meeting, Mr. Braddock went around the room looking to close a $30 million shortfall, recalls Dennis Martin, who then ran corporate banking in Asia and now has the same role in Latin America.
"He said, 'Dennis, it's great what you did for me yesterday. What can you do for me in the next 10 days?' I said, 'I'll give you $500,000,' then I went home to Singapore thinking, 'How the hell can I get $500,000 fast.' " His answer: sell some of the bank's Asian equity investments and move the Bangkok office into smaller quarters.
Not surprisingly, morale suffered among the ranks of mid-level executives, especially those in businesses that were doing well and had no part in the bad real estate loans. "It's human nature to say, 'Hell, the problems are in New York, why should I suffer here in Malaysia or India?' " said Mr. Martin.
Yet an increasingly upbeat mood developed among the G-15 members. For the first time, they were in regular direct contact with Mr. Reed, and they were shown internal financial statements for all of Citicorp.
 
'A Lot Less Spin'
 "There is a lot less spin," explains Mr. Talwar, the head of consumer banking in Asia. "Before, I had my own agenda, what I wanted to communicate to my boss in my monthly review. A couple of weeks later, I'd see his package to his boss, and it got so sanitized that it lost a lot of substance. The culture now is, it is better to surface problems early. If I screw up, it is my name on the line."
And if peer pressure wasn't enough, Mr. Reed changed the way bonuses would be calculated to emphasize teamwork.
Several years ago, an executive's pay was largely tied to the profits of his business unit. "Now the G-15 is being paid to a great extent on how well the whole is doing," said Guenther Greiner, who is in charge of Citicorp's relationships with the world's 200 largest companies. "Remuneration is not a bad way to influence people's thinking."
Ironically, for a company that has suffered from loose controls, Mr. Reed decided to delegate much more authority to the 15 executives. The size of the loans that they could approve increased sharply, as did their ability to authorize expenses.
"It's much more fun because you have less bureaucracy," said Ernst Brutsche, head of European corporate banking. "I know where the buck stops now. I have only myself to blame if things don't work. I can't say the head office in New York did it."
But while the bank's central credit policy office scrutinizes individual loans less, it is far more vigilant than before at assessing the bigger picture, guarding against too much exposure in certain industries or regions.
Now, with the crisis behind him, Mr. Reed has replaced his financial rescue plan with some intermediate goals. By the end of 1995, he wants the bank to have a double-A credit rating (up from single-A today), to be seen as strongly capitalized and to have its stock selling for twice book value, which is now $25 a share. The stock closed at $42 on Friday, five times what it was worth two years ago, and up 11 percent for the week on news of the record earnings and the latest effort to cut costs.
Mr. Reed now faces perhaps his biggest test as Citicorp's finances allow him once again to take bigger risks. Soon, it will be clear whether he has been able to institutionalize the cultural changes born in the bad-loan crisis. Even members of the G-15 are not sure that has happened yet.
"It's not easy to change 25 years worth of culture in a company, especially when someone as strong as Walt Wriston encouraged an independence that led to fiefdoms and internal rivalries," said Mr. Talwar. "John has decided that is no longer the way, and I can honestly say there has been change at the top. But further down, is everyone being as friendly and collegial as we are at the top? Probably not yet."
 
 
 
CITISPEAK: THE DIALECT TURNS COLLEGIAL
 As the culture at Citicorp has changed, so has the banking giant's lexicon of buzzwords and jargon. Known as Citispeak, the language used to be loaded with terminology reflecting a buccaneering approach to banking. But now, following the company's near-death experience with bad real estate loans, Citispeak's vocabulary carries a more cautious and cooperative message.
 
OLD CITISPEAK
 
PROFIT CENTER EARNINGS: The profit calculated for each of Citicorp's 250 businesses. P.C.E. was the main determinant of promotions and compensation. Businesses were encouraged to compete with each other -- as well as with other banks, of course -- in search of profits.
 PARADISING: Executives creating their own back office and computer facilities in search of perfection and a larger empire. Spending was encouraged because it was assumed the company could earn $2 for every $1 in expenses.
 DEVELOPMENT DIVISION: The ultimate paradise, this vast research and development department spent as much as $100 million a year on long-term projects, such as building a computer-screen telephone.
 ACTUARIAL BASE: The premise that executives were free to take large risks, because the bank was so big and diverse that any problem would be more than offset by successes in other areas. With such a safety net, the thinking went, there was no need for central controls or for the financial cushion of capital.
 FIVE-I: Shorthand for the company's agenda, under the former chairman, Walter Wriston. Citicorp, he declared, would be in five businesses: individual, institutional and investment banking as well as insurance and information.

 NEW CITISPEAK

 OPERATING MARGIN: A calculation of the entire company's pretax profits. Executives are now rewarded for their contribution to building total revenue and to cutting expenses and bad loans, rather than being measured solely by their own unit's profits. Internecine warfare is now discouraged.
 CONTINUOUS IMPROVEMENT: Cost cutting as a way of life. Executives now must share computer systems and support staff such as auditors. Since 19TK, Citicorp has eliminated 14,000 jobs, leaving about TK,000, and cut $1.9 billion in annual expenses, leaving a budget of $ TK billion. Christopher Steffens, formerly of Chrysler and Eastman Kodak, has been hired to cut another $1 billion.
 SUCCESS TRANSFER: The discovery that good ideas occur in Citicorp operating units around the world that could be useful in other places. The development division is defunct.
 WINDOWS ON RISK: New ways to gauge -- and limit -- the company's total exposure to regions, industries and financial markets, a change that flowed from the realization that losses on $20 billion in real estate loans could not be offset by anything. Just in case the windows prove opaque, Citicorp is raising a lot more capital.
 GLOBAL, UNIQUE. John Reed's description of his new, more limited strategy based on only one "I": international. Nearly all of Citicorp's efforts now are to take advantage of the company's unmatched presence in more than 90 countries.

PUB-DATE: January 16, 1994

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1920 words

HEADLINE: Finding New Ways To Strengthen Athletes' Marketing Muscles

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

DATELINE: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

 BODY:
MENTION potato chips, and Frank Vuono thinks of quarterbacks.
Mention sneakers, and Frank Vuono thinks of three-point shooting guards. 
 Mention soft drinks, and Frank Vuono thinks of linebackers.
A Princeton graduate with an industrial-strength Rolodex amassed in seven years as vice president of National Football League Properties' retail licensing division, Mr. Vuono and his partners, Steve Rosner and Fred Fried, created a business eight months ago that is finding new ways to sell the star appeal of athletes, teams and other sports organizations to businesses looking for marketing prowess.
In the months since it began work, Mr. Vuono's firm, Integrated Sports International, has helped strike a number of deals that attest to the growing sophistication with which sports icons are being deployed to make money for themselves and others:
* It created an unusually wide-ranging marketing strategy for the San Francisco 49ers that the team lacked the resources to plan and implement. It includes an off-season fantasy camp (where die-hard fans can suit up and take the field with current and former players), a collectibles and memorabilia business, events to finance a team charitable foundation, producing and selling television and radio shows, and hawking scoreboard advertising at Candlestick Park. I.S.I. is helping to execute the plan.
"The impetus for this was when Steve Young's deal was being negotiated, the 49ers were faced with how they'll get enough money to pay their players," Mr. Vuono said, referring to the quarterback who signed a five-year contract for $26.75 million.
* I.S.I. helped create Coca-Cola's $14 million "Monsters of the Gridiron" television, print and radio campaign last fall, which starred 28 National Football League players as monstrous characters. Six of the players were secured by I.S.I. Assembling such a bevy of players is rare and illustrates the type of group deal I.S.I. lusts to broker.
* The company renegotiated a local television deal for Warren Moon, the Houston Oilers quarterback, that reaped Mr. Moon three times what he got when the station paid him a flat fee. I.S.I. eliminated the fee and instead reached an agreement under which Mr. Moon is paid out of advertising revenues from his show. Three of the companies for which Mr. Moon does endorsements are contractually required to buy spots on the show. Mr. Rosner said the deal will be a model for similar agreements for Mr. Young and the Dallas Cowboys quarterback Troy Aikman.
* I.S.I. crafted a relationship for Boomer Esiason, the New York Jets quarterback, with Frito-Lay Inc. that cast him as the star of a commercial with several other players last fall and made him the first player to have his face on a potato-chip bag. I.S.I. also persuaded Frito-Lay to contribute to the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation (Mr. Esiason's son, Gunnar, has the disease) and sponsor his 15-minute radio appearance each Friday of the season on WFAN-AM in New York City.
* I.S.I. has handled delicate negotiations among the National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing, star drivers, car owners and race-team sponsors to create a Nascar Drivers Club to sell merchandise pitched by some of the nation's top stock-car drivers. (The deal is nearly complete.)
HE idea of new uses for sports in marketing is by no means I.S.I.'s alone. The Walt Disney Company used its popular children's hockey film, "The Mighty Ducks," to spawn a professional hockey team, the Anaheim Mighty Ducks, whose retail merchandise is sold at Disney's theme parks and its chain of retail stores. H. Wayne Huizenga, chairman of Blockbuster Entertainment, acquired a chunk of a football team, the Miami Dolphins, and the stadium in which it plays, then bought a baseball team, the Florida Marlins, and a hockey team, the Florida Panthers. Each part of his sports empire promotes his chain of video stores.
And none of what I.S.I. does is unique. Sports management firms like the International Management Group and ProServ perform similar roles, but only on behalf of players they already represent for salary negotiations and financial planning.
I.S.I.'s singularity lies in its being free to represent any athlete whose agent is willing to hand over the marketing reins. I.S.I.'s sole desire is to market players, not to be an agent in salary talks. "We're open to anybody," Mr. Vuono said. "We're not exclusionary."
I.S.I. operates like a football free safety, roaming the field, seeking engagement. But it could have a problem if prospective clients are scared away by the potential for favoritism toward the interests of its investors. Besides the three principals, the key backers of I.S.I. are Leigh Steinberg, the Newport Beach, Calif., agent who represents 23 N.F.L. quarterbacks, including Mr. Aikman, Mr. Young and Mr. Moon; Logo 7, an Indianapolis-based apparel manufacturer and a leading sports licensee; and Apex One, a footwear and apparel manufacturer based in Piscataway, N.J.
Some agents worry that Mr. Steinberg's clients may be favored in deals I.S.I. concocts, beyond the usual pay differences between, say, quarterbacks and running backs.
Mr. Steinberg said that his ownership stake in I.S.I. should not scare off other agents and that he exerts no management role at the firm. "The point is not to narrow the scope of the athlete," he said, "but to expand it."
I.S.I. insists it has no biases. It cites deals made with several unaffiliated agents and an agreement with Adidas struck even though Apex, a footwear rival, is an I.S.I. investor.
Terry Bender, the agent for the Philadelphia Eagles quarterback Randall Cunningham, agreed. "Business is business," said Mr. Bender, who advised his client to join the "Monsters of the Gridiron" when Mr. Aikman was injured, Mr. Young declined because he eschews caffeine and a third quarterback, Dan Marino of the Miami Dolphins, was rejected because he had once done a commercial for Pepsi.
Another concern expressed by competing agents is that I.S.I. will promise athletes whom it can't deliver. "Sometimes you don't know how a deal came about or if they volunteered a player they don't have for a deal," said Ralph Stringer, Mr. Marino's agent.
One agent who probably won't be doing any business with Mr. Vuono is Leonard Armato, who represents Shaquille O'Neal, basketball's 7-foot-1, 304-pound backboard-shaking marketing phenomenon. Mr. Vuono worked on Mr. O'Neal's deals while he was employed at N.F.L. Properties.
Mr. Armato said I.S.I. exaggerated its connection to the marketing of Mr. O'Neal. "I read some blown-up things about what I.S.I. was doing with Shaq," Mr. Armato said. "But they did nothing for Shaquille."
Mr. Vuono said: "Leonard's done a great job with Shaq. I might have done some things differently."
Mr. Vuono and his partners have managed to blend three disparate talents into a fast-growing new business. Mr. Vuono was one of the sports-licensing industry's most powerful figures, running the highest-profile division of N.F.L. Properties. The retail licensing division produced sales of N.F.L. merchandise estimated at $2.5 billion last year. He masterminded successful product extensions like the Quarterbacks Club, an amalgamation of 19 signal callers that sells a line of merchandise.
"It was probably a shock to his boss, John Bello, that most people thought Vuono ran N.F.L. Properties," said Bob Carr, editor of Inside Sporting Goods, an industry newsletter. "With Frank there, no one knew Bello existed."
Mr. Fried, who specializes in marketing, helped devise the early marketing plans for Michael Jordan during his five years at ProServ, the sports management firm, and orchestrated the selling of Mr. Esiason when he quarterbacked the Cincinnati Bengals.
Mr. Rosner, as an agent, represented Lawrence Taylor, the New York Giants linebacker; Carl Banks, the Washington Redskins linebacker, and two dozen others.
The trio has connections. There is also some bravado. "With us, one plus one plus one plus equals ten," Mr. Fried said.
I.S.I. operates out of a 15th-floor suite in a building overlooking Giants Stadium here. On one recent day, Mr. Vuono gave Mr. Taylor advice on a new licensing deal and confirmed a Cadillac endorsement. Peter Moore, the president of Adidas America, discussed plans for a deal with John Starks, the New York Knicks guard, and apparel deals for groups signed by Rough House, a rap music label that retained I.S.I.
I.S.I.'s relationships traverse the sports world: players like Mr. Taylor and baseball's Will Clark, members of the United States World Cup soccer team (for whom I.S.I. got an Upper Deck sports card deal), leagues like the N.F.L. and the Association of Volleyball Professionals, and sporting-goods makers like Adidas and Gatorade. The firm claims 1993 revenues of a few million dollars.
HOWEVER, the bigger the picture gets, the greater the potential management risks for I.S.I. The firm will have to expand aggressively outside its acknowledged expertise in football to other sports, and find ways to promote and market players who aren't top-of-the-line stars.
After all, quarterbacks will always be easy to get commercial deals for, but what about, say, the grittier offensive or defensive players, most of whom lack the flash of Deion Sanders, the Atlanta Falcons cornerback?
A client like Cortez Kennedy, a 300-pound defensive tackle for the Seattle Seahawks, is a case in point: a great player on a small-market, mediocre team. "He's a tough sell, even if he was Defensive Player of the Year last year," Mr. Rosner said. "The market doesn't help. But we'll try to align him regionally, then include him with other players in some national deals. But to be honest, not everybody is marketable."
 
 
 
COMING SOON: THE COCA-COLA GIANTS?
 THE grand vision at Integrated Sports International is of sports blending seamlessly with the business, music and entertainment worlds, where each needs the others to sell more tickets, soda, compact disks or movies.
"That's the future, where sports will come together with the corporate world, and ultimately we'll have the Coca-Cola Giants," said Frank Vuono, president of I.S.I.
That's not so farfetched. Japanese baseball teams are named for the corporations that own them. And major league baseball, with its escalating player salaries and financial woes, is trying to forge closer ties with companies to buy advertising on television and radio and in ballparks.
"It's going to happen," Mr. Vuono said. "The economics of running a team will dictate it. Team owners will only be able to get their return on investment through that kind of integration."
I.S.I.'s dream deal is to expand its sports and corporate connections and begin a league "where we put together the players, the owners, the sponsors and the broadcasters and manage the league," Mr. Vuono said.
How likely is that? If I.S.I. develops enough contacts in a sport, through its connections with agents representing players and broadcasters, and through its work with corporations that would own or sponsor teams, it could act as the chief broker of talent and money for a new league. It is the quantity of I.S.I.'s affiliations that would make or break such a venture.
Speculation about new leagues has centered on football, but Mr. Vuono, who is cagey, declined to say he is involved with such a project. I.S.I.'s affiliations with soccer and volleyball may also portend leagues. "And lacrosse is a fast-paced, energetic sport."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Steve Rosner (left), Frank Vuono and Fred Fried, who began Integrated Sports International eight months ago, in their office overlooking Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: At Work;
A Firing for Cause, or for Abortion?

BYLINE: By Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
WHEN Robin Flanigan found out she was pregnant, late in 1990, she was 21, unmarried -- though engaged -- and new at her hairdresser's job at the Revelations in Hair Design salon in Columbia, Md. She was not ready to have a baby. Ms. Flanigan comes from a devout Christian background. "Abortion is against our religion," she said, so she contemplated that path with intense ambivalence. "It's something I thought I would never do," she said. "But I knew basically I was going to do it."
For making that decision -- and following through in early December of 1990 -- Ms. Flanigan contends she was harassed and fired from her job. Late last year, she filed a civil suit alleging wrongful dismissal against her former employers, Robin and Patrice Davidson, the salon's owners. The crux of the complaint, which is to be served shortly, contends the Davidsons tried to interfere with a statutorily protected activity. 
 Through their lawyer in Baltimore, Susan R. Green, the Davidsons maintain they fired Ms. Flanigan "for cause," namely, poor performance; a bad, even threatening, attitude, and a refusal to meet with them to discuss her shortcomings.
Thus the case is either an example of a new, especially Orwellian employer intrusion into the private life of an employee -- or a travesty of the legal process.
There have been half a dozen complaints around the country of women being fired for ending their pregnancies, according to Lewis Maltby, director of the workplace rights office at the American Civil Liberties Union in New York. One, in Michigan, ended in favor of the plaintiff; most of the others faded without reaching court. Employers who dismiss women who have abortions are "using their power to hire and fire to enforce their own moral values," Mr. Maltby said. "It's just one more example of employers sticking their noses into people's private lives."
In Ms. Green's view, the Flanigan suit isn't an example of anything other than opportunism. "Our belief is that the public will feel very used when all the facts come out," Ms. Green said. "Employees' rights -- the ability to work in a workplace free of interference -- are important. It is important that cases be based on fact."
The facts according to Ms. Flanigan: When the Davidsons learned she was pregnant in November 1990, they launched, in the words of the complaint, "an endless assault against the plaintiff to coerce her and intimidate her into not having the abortion." The campaign, Ms. Flanigan contends, ranged from offers to help with the baby to letters, calls to family members and interruptions at work. At one point, someone hung photos of aborted fetuses at her work station, the complaint says.
Ms. Flanigan ended her pregnancy on Dec. 11, 1990. On Dec. 15, she was dismissed. "It's too much of a close nexus for me to believe that abortion wasn't a very large concern of the Davidsons," said David B. Shapiro, Ms. Flanigan's lawyer. She applied for unemployment benefits and was turned down twice before a state panel ruled in her favor in 1991.
Ms. Flanigan simmered with anger, sought counseling and finally decided last year -- having let opportunities to file a discrimination claim with a government agency lapse -- to sue. "It is a very personal issue. I was not sure how I would feel about doing it," Ms. Flanigan said of the delay. "I am still very upset and emotional. I have had nightmares for over a year about pictures of dead babies." She is now married and is working again as a hairdresser. She is seeking $3.7 million in damages from the Davidsons.
REACHED by telephone at his salon last week, Robin Davidson declined to talk about the case, on orders, he said, from Ms. Green, his lawyer. Ms. Green, who said she prefers to keep her clients on ice until she has received the complaint officially and had a chance to respond, issued a blanket denial of Ms. Flanigan's complaints.
"We don't deny that Ms. Flanigan approached Patrice for counsel," Ms. Green said. "Patrice was asked for an opinion. Ms. Flanigan knew she was . . . ." Ms. Green hesitated. Pro-life, a reporter asked? Ms. Green declined to characterize the Davidsons as "pro-life," though they have been quoted as describing themselves that way in print. The term "pro-life" has elusive connotations, Ms. Green suggested. "It's an individual trying to promote one stance," she said. "I can't classify them that way because they have flexibility that includes sensitivity to other people's choices."
Ms. Flanigan distorted the offers of help from the Davidsons, Ms. Green said, and it was relatives of Ms. Flanigan who called the Davidsons, not vice versa. As for the fetus pictures, they were "not placed by the Davidsons or at the request of the Davidsons," Ms. Green said. She credits Mr. Shapiro with a "creative cause of action" doomed for defeat. She intends to file a counterclaim against Ms. Flanigan.
If the dispute is resolved in Robin Flanigan's favor, will the case be seen as a victory for reproductive rights or for the right to privacy? Mr. Maltby of the A.C.L.U. says that is a false dichotomy. "I don't see it as being about abortion at all," he said. "The reason it's wrong to fire someone is not because abortion is a good thing. It's just as wrong as firing someone for refusing to have one."
 
 
 
TRYING TO DEFINE DISCRIMINATION
THE deadlines on filing discrimination complaints at various Government agencies had passed by the time Robin Flanigan decided to take formal action against her former employers, who she says fired her because she had an abortion. But it's not clear she would have had a strong discrimination claim in any case.
"You have a constitutional right to have an abortion. It seems peculiar to say if you exercise your rights, you can't work here," said Stuart Comstock-Gay, director of the Baltimore chapter of the A.C.L.U. But, he said, "What does it fall under? Under the Pregnancy Discrimination Act? Under general gender discrimination laws? So far as I know, the issue has not been fully litigated."
Lewis Maltby, of the A.C.L.U. in New York, went through a similar catalogue of possible remedies before concluding that women who lose their jobs over abortions are not part of a protected class. A stronger argument may be that employers should stay out of employee life-style decisions that don't affect work. "It's not the abortion that's the issue," Mr. Maltby said. "It's an employer using economic muscle to force an employee to make a decision."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robin Flanigan, plaintiff, in Baltimore. "I am still very upset and emotional," she said. (Marty Katz for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Russian Truck Maker Becomes a Lab for U.S. Deals

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: NABEREZHNYE CHELNY, Russia

 BODY:
BY the late 1980's, Nikolai I. Bekh was fed up. As head of the vast Kamaz truck factory here, Mr. Bekh felt shackled by the Soviet Union's central planners, who cared little about his efforts to develop new products, improve quality and increase exports.
So, in an almost unheard-of step, Mr. Bekh went to Moscow with a request that Kamaz, the world's largest maker of heavy-duty trucks and one of the nation's largest industrial enterprises, be freed from state control. Even more remarkably, the Government agreed. In 1990, Kamaz became Russia's first big company to become private. 
 Since then, as political support for economic change has ebbed and flowed, Kamaz has pressed steadily ahead with a sweeping program to remake itself for a free market. Today it stands as a prototype for post-Soviet industry, and its experience is being studied closely in Moscow as Russia begins the process of sending its 14,000 other big state-owned enterprises -- some even larger than Kamaz -- into the capitalist fray.
Moreover, Kamaz has become a testing ground for a handful of pioneering companies from the United States that are gaining invaluable experience operating in Russia through joint ventures and other deals with the truck maker.
Its future is by no means assured. Mr. Bekh and Kamaz employees -- 130,000 here in this bleak company town 700 miles northeast of Moscow and 40,000 more scattered around the former Soviet Union -- continue to struggle not just with the nation's political spasms, but with huge business challenges.
Kamaz needs hundreds of millions of dollars of outside investment to finance new products. It must begin to reduce employment to hold costs down, a politically tricky step. It needs to shuck off responsibility to reluctant local and regional governments for financing and running schools, hospitals, mass transportation and other services that have traditionally been provided by big Russian enterprises.
It has had to build a marketing department from scratch and totally recast its financial accounting. Trade with the former Soviet republics has become more difficult, complicating relationships with key suppliers and customers. On top of everything else, a fire destroyed the company's engine factory in Naberezhnye Chelny (pronounced NAH-bir-izh-ni-yeh chil-NEUH) in April, crippling production for months.
But Kamaz has come a long way toward its goal of looking and acting like a Western company. Government ownership has been reduced from 51 percent right after the privatization to 20 percent as more stock is distributed to suppliers, customers, managers, workers and investors.
Production workers say they have come to understand that their futures depend on working hard. Junior executives are busy attending seminars on quality control. Engineers are preparing for a diversification into bus production. And Mr. Bekh is already talking about tripling truck exports, to 40,000 a year, or about a third of Kamaz's total truck production, to compete against European and Asian rivals.
"When the Government distributes your profits and the ministry decides your future, the motivation to work is missing," Mr. Bekh said in a recent interview. "At least now, when I hold a board meeting, we're trying to focus on the right issues. All of Kamaz is now involved in adopting world standards."
One yardstick of progress is the crowd of Western joint-venture partners, suppliers, consultants and potential investors found at the "House of Foreign Specialists," the company-run dormitory on the frozen plains of Tatarstan that is as close as the business traveler can come to a Hilton.
Kamaz has already agreed to a $300 million venture to build engines with the Cummins Engine Company, of Columbus, Ind. The Rockwell International Corporation, of Seal Beach, Calif., is negotiating to supply or coproduce a wide range of vehicle components and is already selling factory automation equipment to Kamaz. Daimler-Benz has expressed interest in a joint venture. Deloitte & Touche, the accounting and consulting firm, is working with Kamaz to develop Western-style financial systems.
"They've got a ton of difficulties," said Donald Beall, Rockwell's chairman, who traveled here in the fall to meet Mr. Bekh. "But it's our judgment that whenever and however this thing shakes out, they're going to be producing a lot of trucks and buses, and we'd like to help them."
MOREOVER, the speed and the sheer scale of Kamaz's effort to remake itself is giving Western companies a rare opportunity to learn the nuts and bolts of doing business in Russia.
"We're embarking into uncharted waters," said Harold S. Swann, a senior vice president at the American Re-insurance Company of Princeton, N.J., which was hired by Kamaz to develop its first property insurance program -- the first for any large Russian enterprise -- after last spring's fire left the company with hundreds of millions of dollars in uninsured losses. "Our hope is that this will be a model for future activity in the former Soviet Union," Mr. Swann said.
Kamaz's fate rests largely with Mr. Bekh, a burly 47-year-old engineer. He is starting from a stronger position than managers of most other huge Russian enterprises. Founded in 1972, Kamaz has more modern equipment than most, and its products, sold to nearly every company in Russia that needs trucks to haul freight or raw materials, have a reputation for reliability and durability.
Domestically, Kamaz has a near-monopoly on heavy trucks and a well-developed distribution and service network that could allow a Western partner to sell its vehicles throughout the former Soviet Union. Abroad, Kamaz benefits from its low wage and materials costs, which allow it to price a middle-of-the-line truck for $14,000, a third or less the price of similar Western makes.
Its biggest export markets have been China, Cuba and Eastern Europe, but the company is increasingly trying to crack the Western European market. Kamaz is the world's biggest producer of trucks capable of carrying more than seven tons and is the eighth-largest truck producer over all, slightly behind Daimler-Benz.
Still, Mr. Bekh is having to rebuild the company almost from top to bottom. As a production company, Kamaz makes nearly all its own parts, including engines. But until being privatized, it lacked departments to handle functions like marketing and sales, which are integral parts of Western corporations.
Having always been judged on a single criterion -- its ability to meet production quotas -- Kamaz, with the help of Deloitte & Touche, has had to develop and put in place entirely new accounting systems to provide managers with information about prices and costs, not to mention alien principles like return on investment and profitability. (It is profitable but at least partly because raw-material and energy prices remain artificially low.)
It has begun trying to inculcate its production workers and managers with Western concepts of quality, initiative and responsibility for the inevitable day when Kamaz faces competition both at home and abroad.
It clearly has a long way to go. On one recent night, the production line in one cavernous assembly plant was shut down because of a parts shortage, and workers sat idly, griping about Russia's economic woes. But in one group of half a dozen workers, all said they were working harder to secure Kamaz's future. "It's our jobs, and our bread," said one.
Under a new quality program, all engines, vehicles and major components are numbered, and the company's 200 service centers around the former Soviet Union now keep detailed service histories for each truck. Records are regularly sent back to the factory so managers can analyze problems and find ways to address them.
As the company's designers develop new models, Mr. Bekh for the first time has them consulting market research to learn what potential buyers want in a truck. Many Russian customers, for example, are for the first time paying attention to fuel consumption as energy prices are deregulated.
"In three to five years we're going to have closer price comparisons with the West, and those with whom we compete are going to flock here, so we have to be ready," he said.
KAMAZ is clearly relying on its Western partners to equip it to survive that impending competitive onslaught. Indeed, looking at Kamaz through the eyes of Western companies gives a sense of the scale and difficulty of the task facing Mr. Bekh and of the business opportunity represented by Kamaz -- and by Russia generally.
Cummins, for example, first made contact with Kamaz in 1987 as it began exploring how it could crack the Soviet Union's huge market for diesel engines. In 1991, after the privatization, Cummins signed a 50-50 joint venture deal with Kamaz that, typical of Western companies, was based on a go-slow approach.
Initially, Cummins was to supply engines built at its plant in Britain, primarily engines that met strict Western European emissions requirements for trucks being exported by Kamaz or being used by Russian customers who want to drive them to and from the West. But it would only gradually invest money in production here in Naberezhnye Chelny, with coproduction of engines limited to around 20,000 a year by the end of the decade.
The fire last spring, however, made a larger and faster-moving engine venture a top priority for Kamaz. The truck maker has already been able to rebuild part of the engine factory, but needs additional investment to build new, more efficient engines.
After the fire, Kamaz held talks with 12 engine companies around the world. Ultimately, it stuck with Cummins after the American company agreed to drop its go-slow approach and pursue an expanded and accelerated deal to coproduce 50,000 engines a year, with production to begin around 1996.
The April fire also forced Kamaz to deal with a need it had never before addressed: insurance. Under communism, the country had no insurance industry to speak of (the state, as the owner of all property, absorbed all losses). But potential Western partners insisted that the plant be insured, despite the near-total lack of coverage within Russia.
American Re-insurance had advised the Russian Government on drafting an insurance law. After being hired by Kamaz, it sent in a team to determine whether the factory was designed well enough and had enough safety equipment, like sprinklers, to be considered insurable for fire damage by Western standards.
The answer, Mr. Swann said, was yes. So American Re-insurance is now trying to line up other Western insurers to share the risk. In the long run, Mr. Swann said, American Re-insurance would like to help Kamaz identify other insurance needs. And then it would like to use the experience gained with Kamaz to do business with other Russian companies.

The company hopes to foster initiative and responsibility among workers. Employees played dominoes during a production line problem. (Photographs by Gleb Kosorukov for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE WORLD: The Missile Pact's Problem;
Fear of Russia Is a Way of Life for Ukraine

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: KIEV, Ukraine

 BODY:
FOR three centuries, almost without interruption, the Russians ruled much or all of Ukraine, often brutally. They patronizingly called Ukrainians "little Russians."
So when a referendum was held in 1991 on whether Ukraine should be an independent nation, 90 percent of the 52 million people living there voted for freedom from Moscow, a status they thought would propel them out of the Russian sphere of influence and into the rest of Europe. "A new country has appeared on the map of Europe," President Leonid Kravchuk declared. 
 But as the economy dramatically worsened -- Russia now looks like a haven of economic stability by comparison -- and as ultranationalists gained ground in Moscow, Ukrainians came to worry more about Big Brother. This is why it is difficult for many Ukrainians, even those who favor nuclear disarmament, to accept the elimination of the country's missiles as envisaged by the pact agreed upon last week by the leaders of Russia, the United States and Ukraine. For one thing, some Ukrainians don't want to be without nuclear weapons if Russia still has them. For another, the Ukrainian missiles would be shipped back to Russia itself for dismantling.
These fears are felt unequally in different sections of the country. In the more Catholic west, where ties to Poland are strongest, resistance to things that seem Russian, whether the Orthodox Church or the Soviet state, has always been more strident. In the eastern mining region around the Don River, much of the population is Russian and anti-Russian sentiment is muted.
The Clinton Administration, aware of the Ukrainian jitters about the Russians and about their own vulnerability, has tried to cajole with financial assistance, compensation for the nuclear material and an offer to take part in the Partnership for Peace, the emerging form of association with NATO for Eastern Europe. An invitation to President Kravchuk to visit Washington was thrown in. And Russia is to cancel most of the huge debt Ukraine owes for the Russian oil it depends on.
All this, the Americans told the Ukrainians, would secure their independence, not undermine it; a nonthreatening, stable Ukraine would be easier for Russian leaders to accept. By signing the accord in Moscow Friday, Mr. Kravchuk implicitly accepted the thesis.
But many Ukrainians, particularly the noisy nationalists in Parliament, say history tells them such tactics do not work. Russian domination was dramatized in 1709 when Ivan Mazepa, the Cossack hetman, or leader, allied with King Charles of Sweden against Russia's Peter the Great, was beaten at a famous battle at Poltava. Catherine the Great completed the suppression by disarming the Ukrainian leader Zaporozhie Sich in 1775. She also claimed the Crimean Peninsula for Russia.
 
A Brief Independence
 Ukraine had a brief fling with independence after World War I but its eastern lands were reabsorbed into the Russian empire as a Soviet republic, and the west was added at Poland's expense after World War II.
Stalin's collectivization drive was more destructive in Ukraine than anywhere else; in the man-made famine of 1933, millions of Ukrainian peasants starved to death. Ukrainians often blame the Russians, even though Stalin was a Georgian and the Communist Party engineered it. In a moving testimony to Ukraine's new independence from Moscow, a memorial was recently erected in a pine forest outside Kiev where thousands of victims' bodies were dumped in a mass grave.
Today, as the Ukrainian economy barely sputters along, Ukraine's leaders put much of the blame for the chaos on Russia, even though there seems plenty of evidence that they need a scapegoat for their own mismanagement, corruption and resistance to reform. Russia made matters worse this winter when it raised the price of its oil to Ukraine almost to world prices.
Provocative actions by the Russian Parliament don't help either. In a long-running argument over who owns the Black Sea Fleet, the Russian Parliament last year passed a motion reclaiming Sevastopol, the base for the fleet in Crimea, as Russian territory. The Crimean Peninsula has been considered part of Ukraine since 1954, when Nikita Khrushchev returned what Catherine the Great had annexed.
Many Western experts see a denuclearized and economically assisted Ukraine as essential. One of these is Zbigniew Brzezinski, who was Jimmy Carter's national security adviser and whose son Ian is on the council of advisers to the Ukrainian Parliament. The elder Mr. Brzezinski has criticized the Clinton Administration's emphasis on Moscow and has been encouraging more attention to Ukraine. "If we don't want the Russian empire restored we have to have a strong Ukraine," he said. This meant, he added, not just removing the weapons but insuring some economic plums that would make Ukraine feel as wanted as Russia.

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Mr. Clinton, Meet Mr. Assad (And Never Mind His Past)

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
HAFEZ AL-ASSAD didn't show much enthusiasm a few weeks ago, when Secretary of State Warren Christopher told him in Damascus that President Clinton wanted to meet him. He had to check his calendar, the Syrian leader said, and he telephoned aides to make sure there was no scheduling conflict. Even then, he told Mr. Christopher that he needed more time.
The incident says a lot about the man who ultimately decided he could find time for Mr. Clinton, and who is to meet with him today in a Geneva hotel -- one more step in the American effort to draw Mr. Assad closer to peace with Israel. Even though Mr. Assad had lost his Soviet patrons, even though he felt betrayed when Yasir Arafat started bargaining with Israel on his own, Mr. Assad felt in a position to keep the President of the United States in suspense. 
 By all accounts, the 64-year-old Syrian, who has ruled his country since 1970, is still the charming raconteur who dazzled Henry A. Kissinger with what the former Secretary of State once called a "first class mind allied to a wicked sense of humor." But Mr. Assad is also a tired, sick man, a dictator who ordered the massacre of 20,000 Syrian civilians in the city of Hama 12 years ago, and whose country remains on the State Department's list of terrorist countries for giving support and safe haven to a dozen terrorist groups.
In meeting him today, Mr. Clinton is gambling that he will find a bold statesman unwilling to resist a chance to make history in his remaining years as Syria's President, and therefore poised to make peace with Israel. That is why Mr. Clinton has chosen to sit down with Mr. Assad -- the wise and far-sighted Mr. Assad, that is, rather than the cunning and brutal Mr. Assad. "Forget about all the issues between us and Syria," Mr. Clinton told a group of columnists this month when he was asked what justified the meeting. "Let's just talk about the peace process now."
The American side does not see the meeting as an occasion for make-or-break bargaining. Rather, it is an opportunity for Mr. Clinton to establish trust with Mr. Assad by hearing him out, and to dispel any doubt about this Administration's commitment to a comprehensive Middle East peace. The meeting is also an opportunity to jump-start the stalled peace talks that began in Washington nearly two years ago after Mr. Assad agreed to hold direct negotiations with Israel.
Administration officials rattle off a number of indications that Mr. Assad has made a strategic choice for peace with Israel, including his decision not to sabotage the Israeli-Palestinian accord as he did the American-brokered Israel-Lebanon agreement a decade ago; his statements about the possibility of making progress at different speeds on different peace tracks; his tentative steps to prepare his ruling Baath Party and his army for a coming peace; his willingness to help locate Israeli servicemen missing in Lebanon.
The American side has reason to expect that the personal chemistry in Geneva will be good. In his memoirs, Jimmy Carter said that in Geneva in 1977, he found Mr. Assad to be "quite gracious, completely relaxed, humorous in his remarks and extremely interested in my efforts to arrange peace negotiations." Mr. Clinton will find a man so disciplined that he can sit for hours without moving his legs, so jocular that he laughs loudly at his own jokes. And like Mr. Clinton, he has an extraordinary passion for talking issues to death. After four hours of conversation last month, he asked Mr. Christopher if he wanted to invite in his group for a larger meeting. "Frankly, Mr. President," Mr. Christopher replied, "I'm hungry."
"My strongest reaction to Assad is he always seems to have all the time in the world," said Richard N. Haass, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace who dealt with Middle East issues for the Bush White House. "Meetings with him are not negotiations. They are sizing-up sessions to make points and get reactions. Assad will use this meeting to impress Clinton and try to take Clinton's measure. It's Assad buying time for the day when Israel is ready to deal with Syria."
Not everyone is convinced Mr. Assad is ready to be flexible. The French Foreign Minister, Alain Juppe, suffered through a long monologue justifying Syria's domination of Lebanon when he met Mr. Assad in November. The Turkish Foreign Minister, Hikmet Cetin, has found Mr. Assad unresponsive to Turkey's concerns about Syria's support for a Kurdish terrorist group that trains in a Syrian-controlled area in Lebanon.
"We're not very much impressed by Assad any more," said a senior French official. "Sure, he was charming, smiling, talkative, but he looks old and tired and tense. He talked about how he had to take into account public opinion in Syria which did not tolerate Syrians killed in Lebanon. He also said what a financial sacrifice it was for Syria to be in Lebanon. We couldn't believe our ears."
The personable gloss aside, American policy makers, particularly Mr. Christopher, understand that Mr. Assad has not suddenly transformed himself into a benign grandfather. Whenever Mr. Christopher has raised the issue of Syria's support for terrorism, he gets a standard, well-rehearsed and unhelpful response. And the charm evaporates when tough issues are raised.
During a discussion with Mr. Christopher last month about the economic opportunities that would accompany peace, Mr. Assad digressed with an observation that the Syrian merchants were the best in the Middle East because of their patience. While others say take it or leave it, he said, Syrian merchants gently welcome potential customers, woo them with coffee and urge them to take their time, or come back another day. "The very best of the merchants happen to be the Syrian Jews, and of course, you want them to leave," Mr. Assad said, reminding Mr. Christopher of the American demand that all Syrian Jews be allowed to emigrate.
When Mr. Christopher seized the opportunity to remind Mr. Assad of the importance the United States puts on freedom of choice, Mr. Assad turned stone cold, and the easy banter suddenly ended.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: America's Automotive Fashion Statement;
Forget Sleek and Sexy. The Boxy and Bulky Look Is In.

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
VERY soon, the car in the average family's garage isn't going to be a car at all; it's going to be a truck.
Small trucks -- pick-ups, vans, four-by-fours -- were once a symbol of blue-collar grit, but like pre-washed blue jeans, they are now the upscale dream. A whole new class of small trucks, for which the industry has invented a new term, the "sport-utility vehicle," has sprung up, and they threaten dominance over the car; from Impalas to Pintos, cars now seem like something to be herded away by the Rodeos, Wranglers, Explorers and Blazers. 
 Every decade has its automotive style. The 1950's models had swagger and fins, reflecting the cocksure certainty of the post-war age. In the early 60's, gas was cheap and baby boomers were plentiful, so there were muscle cars. Then came the first oil crisis, in 1973, and environmentally correct compacts with their fuel-efficient engines. Although Cadillacs downsized a little in the 80's, that decade generally returned conspicuous consumption to style with a binge of sleek luxury models.
Maybe the 90's will be easier to characterize in retrospect, but from this end of the decade, the back-to-basics cliche seems to hold, and people seem ready for the bulky and boxy, from the amiable practicality of mini-vans to the rugged four-wheel-drive models, which seem to be an automotive echo of the mountain bike.
Though increasing concern for health and safety may extend to the automotive realm, in truth the trucks may not be any healthier than other vehicles. They do not quite meet the same emission standards as cars nor all of the same crash standards, although their safety features are improving.
Still, these are not the battered, rough-and-tumble vehicles of the Marlboro Man. The term truck, in fact, barely fits, giving rise to Detroit's hyphenated coinage, sport-utility. They are air-conditioned and carpeted; most can be ordered with leather interiors. Dodge Ram pickups, once touted for toughness, are now advertised as being triple-sealed to keep out irritants like wind noise, and are available with a "business console" that includes cellular phone and auxiliary power outlet.
The trucks have shed some of their sluggishness; according to the Environmental Protection Agency, the average 0-60 time last year was 12 seconds, a mere half-second slower than for cars. Some of the vehicles surely get driven off the paved road, but most spend their lives in traffic jams and on urban freeways.
 
The Eddie Bauer Edition
 Many of these vehicles look like something out of an upscale catalogue; the Ford Explorer even comes in an "Eddie Bauer edition." The others could probably be described as the "Walter Mitty" editions, except that the term is perhaps too gender-specific. Women are often the buyers, and for the most expensive models they constitute half of the purchasers. They get what men get, a feeling of mastery over the road. For the commute between high-stress job and hectic home, it may be more mastery than people get at either destination.
Overall, among all the "light duty" vehicles sold in the 1993 model year, more than 34 percent were trucks, including sport-utilities and mini-vans, according to the E.P.A., up from 19 percent in 1975, when the agency started keeping track. Families have not gotten larger, nor have roads gotten less paved; it is almost entirely a matter of taste. The prospect is for more growth. Chrysler found that 3 percent of customers who own trucks plan to replace them with cars while 9 percent of those who own cars plan to replace them with trucks.
"People want to express themselves in a vehicle, they want to make a statement and they want a vehicle to fit their lifestyle," said A.P.G. Richards, the general product manager at Chrysler's Jeep & Truck Business Operations, at a recent conference of the American Society of Automotive Analysts. Drivers want to sit higher up off the road, said John McElroy, editor in chief of Automotive Industries magazine. "It imparts a feeling of security," he said.
It makes the automakers feel secure, too, especially after fruitless years of trying to sell small cars at a profit. According to Adrian T. Dillon, vice president of planning at Eaton Corporation, which manufactures car parts, if sales to rental fleets are factored out, retail sales of cars have been "declining one half percent per year for a very long time." But light truck retail sales are gaining at 5.5 percent per year, he said.
Better yet, only 4 percent of the light trucks are imported and only another 8 percent are built by "transplants," Japanese or European companies assembling vehicles in this country, he said. "Detroit invented this business and retains it," he said.
But there is a disadvantage: fuel. The 1993 cars averaged 28 miles per gallon compared with 20.8 gallons for light utility vehicles. Both figures are just above the Corporate Average Fuel Economy standards that Washington mandates. There is another reason for manufacturers to like it when a customer picks, say, a four-by-four over a station wagon: the big wagon would drag down the company's corporate average fuel economy, but the van fits comfortably into the light truck standard. Repeated over and over again, such decisions will have a major effect on fuel consumption. Picking an Explorer over a Taurus wagon, for example, means going to 20 miles per gallon on the highway instead of 28, comparing both vehicles with the largest available engine.
But this is hardly a public policy issue lately. In fact oil imports are of so little general interest that Americans for Energy Independence, a lobbying group that opened its doors shortly after the Arab oil embargo of 1973, closed last month, citing "energy apathy."
At the laboratory in Ann Arbor, Mich., where the E.P.A. calculates fuel economy, Karl H. Hellman, the chief of the technology development branch, said that when the oil crisis hit and Congress imposed fuel economy regulations, "cars did the job." But the saved fuel is gone, he said. "Trucks ate it."

of wealth; 1980's: The Cadillac offered scaled-down geometry and glamour; 1990's: The Ford Explorer, on its way to replacing the family station wagon.

HEADLINE: Treading Gently;
Clinton and Europe Face Their Fears

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY

DATELINE: BRUSSELS

 BODY:
HAVE the Western democracies entered a new era of appeasement? The question has been in the air since the war in Bosnia began, and it remained in the air here last week despite all the talk by President Clinton and the other NATO allies about welcoming Eastern Europe and Russia into a new Partnership for Peace.
Since the war against Iraq three years ago, the Western democracies have seemed willing to do anything for the principles they stand for except fight for them. Neither the United States nor any Western European country has been willing to do what it would take to stop the appalling daily atrocities in Bosnia -- to send in combat troops to stop the war, and leave them there as long as it took. Instead, the allies have merely threatened the Serbs with bombs that never dropped. They threatened them again in Brussels last week, and the fighting raged on unabated. 
 In Asia, too, there has been saber-rattling. Last month, the United States and South Korea edged toward a military confrontation with North Korea, seeking a pledge to open seven nuclear sites for international inspection, but then they backed off. Now, it appears, the West may be satisfied if the North Koreans open two sites for a one-time look.
 
A Strategy
 Mr. Clinton would argue that any judgment that he had fudged the fundamental foreign-policy problems, rather than leading the search for a solution, was deeply unfair. He was, after all, elected on pledges to work on domestic problems; abroad, he had focused on matters of trade. Now he must also give direction to an alliance that lost its bearings when the cold war ended.
Last week, journeying to Brussels, Prague, Kiev, Moscow and Minsk, he brought the message that the best hope for keeping Europe from falling back into the abyss of ethnic conflict and nationalist aggression is to integrate the security of both East and West, with strong American backing. "Our security in this generation will be shaped by whether reform in these nations succeeds in the face of their own very significant economic frustration, ethnic tensions, and intolerant nationalism," he told the NATO allies. "If democracy in the East fails, then violence and disruption from the East will once again harm us and other democracies."
The partnership program Mr. Clinton offered is designed to buy time, with commitments that were as noncommittal as possible; the Eastern European democracies that want to join NATO right away were told they will have to wait a few years. In the meantime, both they and the Russians can gradually work more closely with the alliance.
The underlying assumption is a huge strategic gamble, a bet that the success of democracy in Russia is what counts most, and that concessions to wounded national pride there will keep the wounds from becoming malignant. Critics argue that this is simply appeasement, and that the result could be exactly the opposite. At least it is a strategy; NATO does not have one in Bosnia. The threat to bomb the Serbs if they keep strangling Sarajevo and other cities was, as Mr. Clinton himself pointed out, meaningless unless the allies seriously intend to carry it out this time. But despite their effort to sound resolute, the European allies were growing desperate last week. France and Britain are wearying of keeping thousands of troops in the United Nations peacekeeping force, in a land where none of the combatants now wants peace on the terms available.
Thus the renewed threat to bomb (carefully hedged by provisos about United Nations approval). What the allies will do if the Serbs continue to ignore their threats, even they did not really know.
Mr. Clinton's grand strategy has been urged on him by his old friend Strobe Talbott, soon to become Deputy Secretary of State. The plan is to avoid entanglement in immediate problems like the war in Bosnia or Eastern Europe's desire to join the West right away, and concentrate on the Big Picture and the future instead.
Clearly the worst thing that could happen in Europe in coming years would be if what went wrong with Yugoslavia also went wrong with the former Soviet Union. In such a nightmare scenario, if the hardships of transforming the Communist economy to the free market became too much for the Russian electorate, nationalist extremists like Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky could take over, virulent Russian nationalism could turn into war between Russia and Ukraine, and the Red Army could overrun the "near abroad" again.
In Mr. Talbott's view, the best way to try to prevent that is to do nothing to make the Russians feel cornered now. Letting Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary or other Eastern European countries join NATO, in this view -- encouraged not by Mr. Zhirinovsky but by President Boris N. Yeltsin and his Government -- would be seen in Moscow as a threat, despite all the assurances of friendship from the alliance over the past four years.
 
A Plea for Patience
 This is why Mr. Clinton went to Prague to tell Vaclav Havel, Lech Walesa and other Eastern European leaders that they would have to be patient about NATO membership -- but that some day the allies would let them in if they worked toward that goal within the Partnership for Peace.
But there is also a case to be made for letting them in sooner: that the proper response to Russian paranoia is not to make concessions to it at a time when the Russians are weaker than they have been for 75 years, but to deter any thought of aggression by firm support for the Eastern European democracies. Mr. Clinton came closer to doing that when he was in Prague, saying he thought it likely that the allies would defend the Eastern Europeans now if they were attacked. Right now, there is no such danger, and nobody in Moscow is bullying Eastern Europe.
Technically, making concessions to wounded Russian pride in order to discourage a return to bullying cannot be called appeasement. Nor is it technically appeasement to impose a devastating economic embargo on Serbia and talk tough about bombing if aggression does not stop.
But the practical effect of empty threats is the same. One reason the Europeans are so desperate about Bosnia is that they concluded after the American debacle in Somalia last year that, on the ground in the Balkans, they are really on their own. Would Mr. Clinton really send 25,000 troops as NATO peacekeepers in the event of a truce? He said yes last week. But that was easy to say; a settlement was nowhere in sight.
History measures statesmen, as it measured Neville Chamberlain and Winston Churchill, by results more than promises. William Jefferson Clinton demonstrated last week that he understands the challenges that lie ahead, and has ideas for dealing with them. The ideas may turn out to have been the right ones. Or perhaps they will turn out to be prescriptions for more trouble.

HEADLINE: THE NATION: Curbing the Urge to Give;
Where the Beggars Meet the Begged

BYLINE: By MELINDA HENNEBERGER

 BODY:
LAST week, posters appeared in New York City subway cars as part of a campaign to discourage riders from giving to panhandlers: "Uh, oh," thinks the straphanger in the ad. "Come on, not me. Oh pleeeeze don't come and stand in front of me asking for money. . . . Look, I feel bad. I really do. But hey, it's my money. And how do I know what you'll spend it on anyway? I don't. Sorry, no money from me."
As in cities across the country, where a variety of anti-vagrancy laws have recently been passed or enforced with new vigor, New York transit officials are getting tough with subway panhandlers, threatening to jail the most aggressive beggars and asking riders, whose complaints provoked the crackdown, to do their part by refusing to hand over spare change. 
 The plan was quickly denounced by some advocates for the homeless, who said it was mid-winter meanness encouraged by the city's new Republican administration. But academics who study urban problems said the new policies have less to do with a backlash against the homeless than with a communal survival instinct driving residents to reclaim public space in parks, plazas, subways and train stations.
Across the country, "there's real concern that public spaces have essentially been taken over by homeless vagrants and are no longer accessible to other people," said Larry Ledebur, director of the Center for Urban Studies at Wayne State University in Detroit.
But some of the most draconian measures are being taken in cities that have been the most tolerant. Seattle's all-Democrat City Council recently made it illegal to sit down on public sidewalks in the business district during working hours. And San Francisco police have begun arresting homeless people for sleeping on public property, blocking sidewalks or urinating in public.
New Yorkers traditionally got "a kind of perverse pleasure from their reputation as people who could withstand anything," said George L. Kelling, a professor of criminal justice who teaches at Northwestern and Harvard universities. "But now you've seen in liberal bastions like New York and San Francisco, where things went the farthest, now they're leading in saying we've got to get back some reasonable right to be left alone."
Mr. Kelling said there is little subway panhandling in Boston because "the city has always had more emphasis on public decorum." And in Washington, which passed an ordinance against aggressive panhandling last summer, there has never been much begging in subways because until recently few stations were located in low-income areas. "The D.C. system was gerrymandered and wrong," he said, "but more democratic systems mean you ultimately need more rules and regulations."
Over time, frequent run-ins with aggressive panhandlers have made residents of many cities feel neighborhood life is threatened. "Big cities only function successfully where people meet in parks and on the streets in neighborhoods," said James Q. Wilson, a professor of management and public policy at U.C.L.A. "When you have public spaces taken over, you can't have an urban village, and when we retreat behind gates and doors we are cut off from any kind of communal life."
Homeless advocates who do support the tougher policies say public attitudes about the causes of homelessness have changed. And they say the new policies are not the end of compassion, but of credulity.
In the 1980's, when the homeless problem first received widespread attention, many homeless advocates and reporters tended to spotlight those people who had lost their jobs or been evicted, fearing perhaps that the public would be less sympathetic to the large number of homeless people who suffer from alcoholism, drug addiction or mental illness. The prevailing wisdom then held that we were all "just a paycheck away" from winding up on the street.
"We spent the better part of a decade pretending this was primarily a housing problem," said Fred Siegel, a professor of history at Cooper Union. Homeless advocates, he said, were much too slow to admit that most chronically homeless people had other serious problems so homelessness was considered a purely economic problem and the public health crisis was largely ignored.
Ultimately, daily contact with homeless people in clear need of alcohol or drug treatment and mental health services left many residents feeling misled about the nature of the problem. Hustles from scam artists convinced them that many of the most threatening panhandlers were not in fact homeless. And the growing recovery movement and its 12-step programs made some residents feel that giving money to those who suffer from an addiction is only "enabling" their illness.
Decisions about if and when to give money to beggars are morally complicated, and no drug treatment expert claims that addicts who panhandle for drug money will necessarily decide to seek treatment just because the donations dry up. But over the last several years, most homeless advocates have changed their emphasis somewhat, conceding that access to affordable housing will not, by itself, solve problems of the many homeless people who also need drug and mental health treatment and a host of other social services.
Some of those who provide services for the homeless say they fear that the growing perception that spare change does more harm than good will become an excuse for inaction. "It allows people a philosophical justification for doing nothing about the problem," said Joan Alker, assistant director for the National Coalition for the Homeless in Washington.
But other homeless advocates have expressed support for programs like the New York subway crackdown, which includes a provision for more services to homeless people. "Our feeling is that people who give money to panhandlers are perpetuating people living on the street," said Richard Salyer, president of the Greater New York chapter of the Volunteers of America, which runs three homeless shelters in New York. "The reaction of communities to reclaim public spaces is legitimate" and perhaps inevitable, he said, "as long as that's not the end of the story. These people are sick and in pain and they still need somewhere to go."
