HEADLINE: As Whitman Nears Inauguration, Deficit Complicates Tax-Cut Vow

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 15

 BODY:
For Christine Todd Whitman, the hard part is about to begin.
When she becomes New Jersey's 50th governor on Tuesday, Mrs. Whitman will sit down at a desk figuratively piled with daunting tasks: A school financing quandary that has defied solution for decades. A surging prison population. Cities cut off from the rest of the state, and full of despair. 
 But at the center of her agenda, and overshadowing all others, is the challenge that Mrs. Whitman pledged herself to meet in her Republican campaign for governor, and that helped bring her a narrow victory over Jim Florio, the Democratic incumbent: to cut income taxes by 10 percent a year for three years, or by $1.4 billion at the end of that period.
 
$1 Billion Deficit Built In
 To do so, Mrs. Whitman will have to pour money out of a bag that already has a hole in the bottom. Next year's budget, which begins on July 1, has a built-in deficit totaling at least $1 billion, and revenues for the current year are running behind budgeted forecasts. During her four-year term, the new Governor will also have to deal with a tripling of debt interest payments because of bonds issued under the Florio administration; the costs of complying with the Federal Clean Air Act, and the likelihood of court-ordered increases in state aid to poor school districts.
Yet Mrs. Whitman is undismayed. She has never lost an opportunity to repeat her promise and has gone on to say she will not resort to employee layoffs, will not raise other state taxes to compensate for those that are cut, and will not require local governments to make up her cuts. But she has given no specifics on how she will do this.
Mrs. Whitman, 47, the state's first female Governor and one of four female Governors in the nation, will attempt this feat on a national as well as a local stage. Her come-from-behind victory over Mr. Florio has had a transmuting effect on the way taxes are being viewed in the 36 other governors' races this year.
When Mr. Florio seemed headed for re-election, Democrats from the Clinton White House to the local level were ready to claim a vindication for bold executives who raise taxes, since the $2.8 billion in taxes Mr. Florio increased his first year was almost the only weapon Mrs. Whitman used against him in the campaign.
"Now the message of Whitman's election is exactly the opposite," said William Schneider, an analyst of election politics at the American Enterprise Institute. "The message is, taxes are still poison, and everybody is getting the message. Cuomo certainly got it, Wilson got it in California, and so is everyone else."
Ten days ago, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, a Democrat, struck a perennial Republican theme, a call for cuts in business taxes, in his State of the State address. On the same day in Sacramento, Gov. Pete Wilson of California, a Republican, proposed state income-tax cuts that nearly match Mrs. Whitman's. Both are running for re-election this year.
Since her victory, Mrs. Whitman has traveled the state and answered questions on five radio and television appearances with unfailing good cheer, flashing a warm smile and radiating good humor. Governor Florio never became "Jim" to the people of New Jersey, but Mrs. Whitman is "Christie."
 
Testing Her Good Cheer
 Mrs. Whitman's cheer will be tested in problems like these:
*By the end of April, the state must either remove some 3,000 state convicts who are housed in county jails or pay the counties more than the current rate of $58 a day per prisoner, a state court has ordered. But the state prisons are already overcrowded by a third, and it would take $300 million in new prison construction over the next four or five years to keep adding cells at the current rate.
*The Federal Clean Air Act will take effect in 1996, and by then the state needs to have in place $100 million to $200 million in new testing equipment while introducing New Jersey's prickly motorists to a longer and more complicated annual inspection. Moreover, the act will in all likelihood result in shutting thousands of private auto inspection stations, which many drivers find more convenient than the clogged state inspection sites.
*The fuel tax that finances the state's road-building Transportation Tax Trust Fund expires in June 1995 and will require renewal plus about 5 cents a gallon more, on top of the current 11.5 cents a gallon, to meet the state's construction obligations.
Overshadowing all these problems, however, is the question of school financing, a decades-old issue that is a compound of several politically toxic elements, including questions of race and class, taxes and New Jersey's rigid suburban territoriality.
 
School Ruling Is Near
 The State Supreme Court is expected to rule this spring in the third challenge by urban school districts to the way Trenton divides its school aid. A Superior Court judge, Paul G. Levy, has already agreed to the plaintiffs' claim that $450 million more in state aid to city schools is needed to close the school spending gap between the cities and the suburbs.
Mr. Florio tried to shift about $300 million more to urban schools, but was blocked by the Legislature, which redirected the money to offset school property taxes statewide.
At the same time, the state teachers' union, the New Jersey Education Association, has served notice to Mrs. Whitman that it will not tolerate education cost-cutting moves like the ones that Mr. Florio tried, like shifting the costs of local school district pensions to the districts themselves.
That move was blocked by the Legislature's Republican majority, with teachers' union backing, and Florio administration members are convinced that the union, by showing itself ready to work for either party, was ultimately responsible for the loss of the Legislature in 1991 and Mr. Florio's defeat last year.
 
Teachers 1, Florio 0
 "The lesson of the Florio years," a Florio Cabinet member said on condition of anonymity, "is that they took on the teachers, and they lost."
Mrs. Whitman and her transition team have been pondering these numbers and lessons for nearly two months. She is to present her spending plan to the Legislature on March 15, but has so far shared only fragments of her thinking.
She is critical of the practice that allows state agencies to keep the fines and fees that they collect, instead of turning this revenue over to the Treasury's General Fund.
Several agencies derive most of their income from these sources: the Department of State receives $600,000 in tax support, but it takes in, and keeps, $18 million annually from such sources as incorporation fees and business licenses.
 
State Workers May Object
 The department's unionized work forces may object to Mrs. Whitman's idea of making each department justify its entire budget, instead of just a part of it, each year.
Mrs. Whitman has also said she can save some $150 million by turning some state duties over to private contractors and by ending double insurance coverage for spouses who both work for the state.
Mrs. Whitman may also be lucky. On Thursday Mr. Florio's Treasury announced that an end-of-year audit discovered an unexpected $288 million surplus, an amount that may help cover a projected shortfall for the 1994 fiscal year. In addition, a stronger economic recovery would raise sales and income-tax receipts.
In the absence of clear directions from Mrs. Whitman, Republican lawmakers have remained loyal to her tax-cut pledge while leaving themselves some room to maneuver on its timing and other details.
 
Allies Try to Soften Pledge
 On Tuesday, for example, Donald T. DiFrancesco, the Senate President, bluntly suggested that the tax cut be deferred until next January, instead of beginning with the new budget year on July 1, as Mrs. Whitman continues to promise. Mrs. Whitman ignored his suggestion. Yet the idea of a delay has already become an article of faith with many.
"There's always a sense of immediacy in the public mind that something like this is going to be done overnight, and some people were even talking about making the tax cut retroactive to January of this year," said Rodney P. Frelinghuysen of Harding Township, who leads the Assembly Appropriations Committee.
"But the logistics of implementing a tax cut in the middle of the tax year are very complicated, and we will have to look at the Senate President's ideas on that."
One clear reason for Republican caution lies in the odd symmetry that promises to lie in the first months of the Florio and Whitman administrations. Like Mr. Florio, Mrs. Whitman is meeting a Legislature controlled by her own party, with a plan to remake state government, his to greatly expand its obligations, hers to cut taxes and costs.
Before Mr. Florio's effort cost him his job, it ended the careers of numerous seasoned Democrats in the Legislature in 1992, when the Republicans, in full cry against the tax increases, seized a veto-proof majority of both houses. Some Republicans are concerned that if Mrs. Whitman's cuts provoke a union or voter protest, the same thing could happen to them.
"It's the same scenario, but from opposite poles," said Senator Richard J. LaRossa, a Republican from Trenton who was first elected in the anti-Florio wave. "The only way it's going to happen again is if we act like a bull in a china shop. It has to be done surgically, not with a meat ax."
Mr. LaRossa, who represents many state workers, has already staked out his minimums: No layoffs and go slow on privatization.

HEADLINE: CHINA PROMISES U.S. TO TRY TO IMPROVE ITS HUMAN RIGHTS

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 15

 BODY:
President Jiang Zemin today told a Congressional delegation led by the House majority leader that China "is going to make an effort" in coming months to meet President Clinton's concerns about the country's human rights record.
Mr. Jiang repeated Beijing's objection to linking human rights with China's trade relationship with the United States, as Mr. Clinton has done by making China's favorable trade status contingent on improvement in human rights. But the delegation took the Chinese President's positive tone as an encouraging sign. 
 Mr. Jiang's remarks to the majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, and five other House members came at a crucial time, just before the release of a State Department human rights report that is critical of China and could affect its trade status as a most favored nation. His remarks also came in the middle of important talks with Washington on China's textile imports.
 
An Unusual Response
 Although Mr. Jiang did not present any detailed course for improving China's human rights record, his remarks were significant in that Chinese officials almost never respond directly or positively to any admonition from foreigners about their human rights record. In public statements, Chinese officials uniformly reject American intercessions on human rights as interference in China's internal affairs.
In Washington, a State Department official said today that Mr. Jiang's comments, as reported by the delegation , were "very, very encouraging."
The official said that several recent developments suggested that China understood Western concern about its human rights practices. But he said the United States was looking for more evidence.
 
'Let's See What Happens'
 "Today's meeting was quite positive and encouraging, but let's see what happens," the official said.
At a news conference, Mr. Gephardt praised the extensive diplomatic engagement that is under way with China and said he hoped that it would lead to a resolution of disputes.
"We are hoping for progress on human rights," Mr. Gephardt said. "To date there has not been sufficient progress, but we are not at the end of the process. We have another six months to go."
 
Chinese Seriousness Seen
 After the news conference, Mr. Gephardt said the most positive aspect of his visit was that he felt for the first time that the Chinese leadership was "really serious" about resolving its most contentious issues with the United States, beginning with human rights.
"We have a number of important differences," Mr. Gephardt said, "but we are working hard to resolve those differences."
The delegation members, who said they were in Beijing at Mr. Clinton's request, also met with China's economic czar, Zhu Rongji.
The visit is part of the torrent of diplomatic contacts between Washington and Beijing aimed at averting a confrontation later in the year over China's poor human rights record.
China has until June to demonstrate "overall, significant progress" in human rights or Mr. Clinton has threatened to end China's most-favored nation access to the American market, which entitles Chinese companies to export their goods to the United States at very low tariffs.
Human rights abuses also played a major role in the rejection of China's bid to be the host of the Olympic Games in the year 2000, despite a vigorous campaign by Beijing.
In case the Chinese did not get the message from Mr. Gephardt, the White House is sending Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen here this week.
 
Bush on Private Visit
 The sometimes blunt exchanges with Mr. Clinton's emissaries were overshadowed in the Chinese press by coverage of former President George Bush's private visit to Beijing.
"I think the U.S.-Chinese relationship is very, very important," Mr. Bush told the Chinese President. "It's very important to stay on track."
Officials at the United States Embassy said they were unaware of any coordination between Mr. Bush and the White House over his visit, though former Presidents as a matter of courtesy often carry messages and report on the results of their trips.
American officials said that before leaving the United States, Mr. Bush was briefed by the State Department and the staff of the National Security Council, but that he is carrying no official messages.
Mr. Bush also met with the Chinese Prime Minister, Li Peng, whom most American officials avoid because of his role in ordering the military crackdown that led to the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989.
Mr. Clinton issued his conditions for continued favored trade status in a May 1993 executive order, and Mr. Gephardt's visit to China is part of the "midterm" review of its progress on human rights.
In deciding whether to extend China's trade privileges, American officials said they would use criteria specified in Mr. Clinton's executive order. At a minimum, there must be greater freedom of emigration and less use of prison labor. In addition, the Administration will consider whether China has made progress on other human rights issues, including respect for the religious and cultural heritage of Tibet.
A member of Mr. Gephardt's delegation, Representative Norm Dicks, Democrat of Washington, and the American Ambassador, J. Stapleton Roy, both described Mr. Jiang's statement to the delegation.
Mr. Roy said the Chinese leader's remarks were consistent with other recent positive responses senior Chinese officials have been making to American officials regarding the human rights abuses that routinely occur at the hands of China's security services and the judicial and prison authorities.
 
Talks With Red Cross
 Chinese officials also told the Congressional delegation today that China would begin detailed discussions this weekend with the International Committee of the Red Cross on a program that could allow the first Red Cross visits to Chinese political prisoners in the history of Communist rule.
Western diplomats here said the release this week of two Tibetan human rights campaigners was also an important development indicating that the Chinese leadership is taking some early steps on Tibet, where larger issues of autonomy and freedom of expression are proving very difficult to solve.
American officials saw the release as a good-will gesture coming before Secretary of State Warren Christopher meets with China's Foreign Minister, Qian Qichen, in Paris on Jan. 24 and 25, but some human rights groups cast it as a move timed to coincide with the State Department's annual human rights report. A draft of the report, which is to be released in the coming week, states that China has not made substantial progress on human rights.
The remarks also coincide with last-minute talks to prevent a trade war over a threat by Washington to cut Beijing's textile export quota by 25 to 35 percent. China has said it will strike back if the United States proceeds with the plan.
Besides Mr. Dicks, the House members accompanying Mr. Gephardt here are George Miller of California, Mike Synar of Oklahoma, Chet Edwards of Texas and Rosa DeLauro of Connecticut, all Democrats.
 
'Mixed Message' Possible
 Mr. Gephardt acknowledged that some members of Congress are opposed to canceling China's trade privileges at a time when American companies are seeking new markets in China's booming economy, and he said the Chinese leadership might be receiving a mixed message from Washington.
"Anyone who observes the United States for any period of time will always be able to get a mixed message," Mr. Gephardt said, but he added that "it would be a grave mistake for anyone to think" that China's trade privileges "could not be stopped."
The delegation also delivered a list of 19 political prisoners who are reported suffering from medical problems and asked that they be released on parole.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN EUROPE;
Good Works And Prayers

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MUSCAT, Oman, Jan. 15

 BODY:
At the meeting of the American Chamber of Commerce in Moscow last week, the American business executives had a Protestant minister open their luncheon by delivering a prayer for the Russian economy. "Dear God," he intoned, "we pray for this land. For wise decisions. Do not let us lose hope."
It was a fitting way to begin their session and a fitting summary of American economic diplomacy toward Russia today, which relies almost as much on prayer as on policy.
It is not that there is no substance behind the American approach to Russia today. There is. And it is not that there is no money behind it, either. It is that no more money will be delivered, or make a substantive difference, unless President Boris N. Yeltsin puts together a viable, concrete plan to restructure his budget in a way that will curb inflation, end subsidies to unprofitable state industries and create a body of laws to support a free market.
 
Bear Hugs and Vodka
 That was President Clinton's message to the Russian leader this week. It was sugarcoated in a number of ways, with many bear hugs and vodka toasts, but underneath there was always the same theme: "More money for Russia, more quickly, but only after more reform." 
 That is where prayer comes into play. American officials left Moscow after the summit meeting feeling that Mr. Yeltsin's Government was at a "critical phase," as Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen put it.
"I am convinced there is a strong desire by Yeltsin to follow through, but I think he will have to do a substantial amount of bargaining and trading with the Parliament," Mr. Bentsen said as he flew from Moscow to Indonesia today with a stop in Oman. "It is going to be a tough transition. It is going to be a combative Parliament."
American officials said they were reassured that on the question of economic changes, Mr. Yeltsin's heart was still in the right place. The Russian leader uttered a strong "nyet" when asked whether he intended to abandon some of his tough economic measures in view of his supporters' poor showing in recent parliamentary elections.
 
Reformers' Role Uncertain
 The fact that Mr. Yeltsin just reappointed Deputy Prime Minister Anatoly B. Chubais, the powerhouse behind his privatization program, put some muscle into that "nyet."
But the role of other reformers in the new Cabinet is still uncertain. And what no one in the American delegation can be sure of is whether Mr. Yeltsin will carry through on his promises once Mr. Clinton is out of sight. Even if Mr. Yeltsin wants to, will conservatives in the fractious, newly elected Russian Parliament let him do so?
A reformist lawmaker, Grigory A. Yavlinsky, said such uncertainty was why the West should hold off pouring more money into Russia until it is clear that there is "an appropriate government, an appropriate program and an appropriate will."
The Americans needed no convincing. Indeed, Russian-American economic relations have entered a new phase with the summit meeting. The initial phase, which involved enlisting donations from the West and international lending institutions in return for the early tentative steps of Russian reform, is over.
It brought some $28 billion in promises of export credits, technical assistance, privatization grants and loans, of which only $5 billion was delivered. It also produced some results on the ground: inflation in Russia came down in the last year from 1,000 percent to about 260 percent, the dollar value of Russian wages tripled and virtually all state-owned small businesses were put into private hands.
But for these achievements to be sustained -- and for the rest of the $28 billion promised to be delivered -- Russia has to enter a second phase. It requires that Mr. Yeltsin put together a more comprehensive reform program, including a body of contract law to regulate a capitalist economy and a radically different budget that can deliver long-term relief from high inflation, so Russians will want to save rubles and Russian businesses now exporting will be ready to bring their profits home.
Russia's basic problem today is that the Government is running a budget deficit of about 9 percent of its gross national product. Because the Russian Government cannot finance that deficit with Treasury bills -- no one here would buy them -- and it can only raise a limited amount in new taxes, it is covering its deficit largely by printing new rubles, thereby stoking inflation.
 
Subsidized Industries
 The only way for the Government to avoid printing so many rubles is to halt its subsidies to major industries like coal mines, state farms and military factories. The problem Mr. Yeltsin faces is that these state-subsidized factories not only provide work for millions of Russians but, more important, provide social services ranging from health care to pensions to cheap groceries.
When Mr. Bentsen visited a chocolate factory in Moscow, he found a shoemaker working in the middle of the plant. The factory manager said the cobbler was there to make and repair his workers' shoes while they made chocolates, saving them time and money.
Mr. Yeltsin is reluctant to cut the subsidies for fear that too many people will be deprived, not of products they want to buy, but of social services they desperately need. What the Americans told him was that subsidizing an inefficient tractor factory was a terrible way to provide social services, since the tractors are so bad that Russia could get more money selling the raw steel that goes into them on the world market than it can for the finished tractors.
What the Americans want the Russians to do instead is stop the subsidies, and use part of the savings to reduce the deficit and part to cushion the workers who would be unemployed by assuring them pensions, unemployment insurance and relocation and retraining programs. That is what American officials mean by "economic reform." But what those two words mean in real life, the Moscow Tribune said, is that "the only effective solution will be to allow at least half the economy to go bankrupt."
Can Mr. Yeltsin sustain the politics of such a move? So far, he does not even have a budget for the first quarter of this year.
The new Parliament is preoccupied with infighting, and the Speaker of the lower house, Ivan P. Rybkin, has warned Mr. Yeltsin that when it comes to the economy there must be no more "shocks" -- meaning no bankrupt factories -- a view echoed by Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin.
President Clinton left Moscow today clearly feeling that he had charted a path for Mr. Yeltsin, but that the rest was now in the hands of the gods and the Russian Parliament. As Mr. Clinton put it: "These folks are just getting started on what will be a great and exciting journey. And I think we ought to wish them well and see what happens."

HEADLINE: Tokyo Trade Pact: Dotting the I's Proves Difficult

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 15

 BODY:
When President Clinton concluded his last-minute trade deal with Japan here last July, his Administration hailed it as not just another in a 20-year string of agreements but a new kind of agreement.
The American negotiators, just a few months in office, insisted that they had found the key to reducing Japan's yawning surpluses in forcing the Government to promise explicit increases in imports and not just the removal of barriers. 
 "What you have is something that goes far, far further toward explicitness and clarity and deadlines and schedules than anything you have ever seen before," exulted W. Bowman Cutter, deputy director of the National Economic Council and the chief negotiator.
And when Morihiro Hosokawa, a young politician preaching change, became Prime Minister in August, the Clinton Administration grew even more confident that the old pattern of bitter disputes and meager results was a thing of the past. It was just a matter of hammering out the details with a like-minded Government, the Administration seemed to say.
 
Talks Going Nowhere, U.S. Says
 Such buoyant expectations made the spectacle to which the Japanese were treated this week that much more telling. Sounding both angry and befuddled, senior Administration officials complained here that the follow-up talks to the basic agreement were going nowhere, even as Japan's surplus with the United States was rising. It was more than $50 billion in 1993.
Discussions about getting Japan to buy more American automobiles, auto parts, medical and telecommunications equipment and insurance policies "haven't moved an inch," said Jeffrey E. Garten, Undersecretary of Commerce for International Trade.
It has been a harsh lesson in the tenacity of Japan's bureaucracy, which manages the negotiations. It also points to the fundamental differences between the two economies, a gulf that warm feelings between two young leaders cannot paper over.
President Clinton is to meet Mr. Hosokawa on Feb. 11 in Washington to sign the next phase of their trade deal. But the American negotiators say the two sides remain so far apart that they are still battling over the concepts rather than the details.
 
Following Old Pattern
 Perhaps their most painful admission was that despite the new "framework," the negotiations are following the old pattern of struggling down to the wire and concluding an ambiguous truce. Even the efforts by the American officials to apply pressure on the Japanese by going public with their grievances follow the old style.
"We had thought this framework was different in several ways," lamented Joan E. Spero, Undersecretary of State for Economic and Agricultural Affairs. "We really saw this Government as moving toward the same kinds of goals as we were. We feel disappointed. We are back to the old formula."
Of the continuing debate over what methods to use to attack Japan's surpluses, Mr. Garten commented: "We've been having a sterile, metaphysical debate. We want results."
The Administration describes its approach as results-oriented rather than focused purely on opening markets and letting the chips fall.
The Japanese agreed that future trade agreements would use "objective criteria" like measurements of market share or import levels to guarantee that, one way or another, more American goods would be purchased and the surpluses would decline. At least, that is the American interpretation.
 
Another Point of Frustration
 What the negotiators have discovered is that the "results-oriented" approach represents just one point on a continuum of trade frustration, no matter how much rapport President Clinton felt the two leaders shared.
In their more candid moments, negotiators from both sides concede that some kind of agreement is still likely to be produced come Feb. 11, but they also agree that an accord is likely to retain much of the ambiguity that President Clinton had vowed was a thing of the past.
At the core of the dispute is what American officials had regarded as the major innovation -- the agreement to set explicit goals for Japanese imports of various American products and services. The basic agreement refers to "objective criteria" to measure progress. It also commits Japan to take measures to bring about a "highly significant" reduction of its trade surplus "over the medium term."
Even while the Americans were crowing about these inclusions last July, the Japanese were making it clear that, in their reading, they had certainly not agreed to set targets for future purchases of American-made goods. That approach has been rejected by the Japanese as a brutish attempt to interfere in the workings of the marketplace.
"Our understanding is that that understanding is not included" in the framework, said Sozaburo Okamatsu, the Deputy Minister for International Trade and Industry. He explained that the only "objective criteria" Japan would permit would be evaluations of past data to determine whether progress has been made, not to set goals for importing American goods.
 
Kantor Blames Bureaucracy
 The United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, wrote a letter last month to a Japanese newspaper in which he sought to blame the bureaucracy for the stalemate, thereby deflecting attention from Mr. Hosokawa.
But that seems like wishful thinking. Mr. Hosokawa was reported in recent days to have told the heads of the country's most influential business lobbying groups that he would not budge on the question of import targets.
The American side has responded by banning the word target from its vocabulary, arguing that its position is being distorted by the Japanese.
The Japanese bureaucracy has gone further, though, arguing that Japan's economy is more open than that of the United States and that it is Washington that must open up.
In a paper issued last week, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry created a sort of parallel universe, suggesting that the low market share for imported goods and the minuscule level of direct business investment by foreign companies in Japan were signs of how well the free market is operating here.
Claiming the moral high ground, the Japanese Government has seized on Washington's insistence on setting import goals to declare that Japan is resisting not American imports but an attempt to thwart the free market.
Such intransigence is standard in important negotiations, especially when billions of dollars in sales and perhaps even jobs are at stake.
In fact, that is how President Clinton himself has characterized the new world order. Whether or not he has persuaded other Americans of this, his trade negotiators have learned that the Japanese Government never lost sight of that reality.

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN EUROPE;
Clinton Promises Help for Belarus Before Changing Focus to Mideast

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Switching his focus from Russia to the Middle East, President Clinton flew from Moscow to Geneva today for meetings on Sunday with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria aimed at getting the stalled Mideast peace talks started again.
On his way to Geneva, Mr. Clinton stopped in Belarus, where he pledged at least $50 million in additional aid, including $25 million to help the Government carry out its pledge to surrender all 81 of the old Soviet SS-25 nuclear missiles left on its soil. 
 During his six-hour stopover in Minsk, Mr. Clinton also became embroiled in a local dispute over which victims of oppression to honor first.
On his arrival in Geneva, Mr. Clinton was met by President Otto Stich and Foreign Minister Flavio Cotti. He is to meet with President Assad for three hours on Sunday before flying home to Washington at the end of his eight-day visit .
 
On Diplomatic Tiptoe
 Administration officials expressed hope that the prospect of better relations with Washington might prompt Mr. Assad to seek a comprehensive peace with Israel. The Syrians, who have faced economic hardships since the collapse of the Soviet Union, hope to build a new relationship with the United States.
But the officials said President Clinton is not ready to remove Syria from his Administration's list of terrorist states, a designation that carries heavy sanctions, as Mr. Assad has demanded.
Mr. Assad will be seeking to restore Syria's position as a key player in any Middle East peace negotiations. His position has been eclipsed by the separate Israeli accord with the Palestine Liberation Organization, which was signed in Washington on Sept. 13.
En route to Geneva, the White House faced a diplomatic squabble over Mr. Clinton's plans to visit a memorial for the victims of Stalinist oppression in Belarus before laying a wreath at a monument to those killed by the Nazis.
The original White House itinerary for Belarus called for Mr. Clinton to go straight from Air Force One to a stark memorial in Kuropaty forest, just outside Minsk, that was raised to victims of Stalinist repression.
But in deference to the leaders of Belarus, most of them former Communists, the White House agreed to postpone Mr. Clinton's stop at the Kuropaty memorial and first lay a wreath at the black obelisk in Victory Square in Minsk that honors victims of World War II, as Prime Minister Vyacheslav F. Kebich had insisted.
The last-minute change was viewed with dismay by Belarus's political opposition. The switch also exposed White House uneasiness about possibly offending the Soviet-style Government, which Mr. Clinton was prodding to hold elections this spring.
 
No Signs of Modernization
 Despite Mr. Clinton's support, there is no indication that Belarus will accept Washington's advice to go forward with economic reform. The nation's leading reformer, Stanislav S. Shushkevich, chairman of the Supreme Soviet, holds less power than Mr. Kebish, the old-line Prime Minister.
The importance of Kuropaty to domestic politics lies in the fact that it is the country's only known mass grave for those executed by Stalin's secret police between 1937 and 1941, giving it symbolic importance for the anti-Communist opposition, whose leader, Zyanon Paznyak, was the archaeologist who discovered it.
As many as 200,000 bodies of Poles, Jews and other victims of Stalin are believed to be buried at the site, and a senior Western diplomat in Belarus bluntly described it as "unfortunate" that the White House had backed away from its original plan.
"What is needed here is for the West to remind everyone about the Communists' past," the diplomat said.
The Administration had initially added Belarus to Mr. Clinton's itinerary partly as a gesture of thanks for its decision to relinquish its nuclear weapons, but more importantly as an object lesson for Ukraine, which until Mr. Clinton's visit had refused to do so.
 
An Unnecessary Symbol
 But Ukraine's about-face last week, under which it will surrender its 176 nuclear missiles and 1,500 warheads over the next seven years, stripped the Belarus stop of its symbolism, leaving Mr. Clinton confronted more starkly with a system that has seen few changes from the old Soviet style.
In Minsk this afternoon, senior White House officials sought to minimize the significance of the decision to reschedule the visit to Kuropaty, an ice-covered clearing with a crude wooden cross crowned with barbed wire.
In a speech this afternoon at the Academy of Sciences in Minsk, Mr. Clinton tried to keep the focus on the arms agreement, telling the audience that Belarus deserved the "thanks and credit of citizens all over the world" for being the first former Soviet republic to plan a nuclear-free future.
But he made a clear reference to the Government's refusal to assure March elections, saying he would "hope and pray" that they would go forward. He also called upon Belarus to "press ahead" with economic reforms.
 
Separate Meetings
 Mr. Clinton was greeted at the Minsk airport by Mr. Shushkevich, a former nuclear physicist turned centrist democrat whose position makes him the leader of Parliament, and whom American officals regard as the country's best hope of reform.
The President also held what the officials described as cooler talks with Mr. Kebich, who rose through Communist Party ranks and who has headed the Government since 1990. Mr. Clinton met separately with the opposition leaders, among them Mr. Paznyak, who told reporters later that they had urged Mr. Clinton to cut off aid to Belarus altogether on the ground that it would support only the Government and not reform.
But there was also evidence of the resentment felt by some Belarusians at Mr. Clinton's visit: a group of Communists marched around a statue of Feliks Dzerzhinsky, the founder of the K.G.B., and waved banners that included one reading, "Yankee Go Home."

HEADLINE: Broader Acceptance Sought for King Holiday

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Jan. 15

 BODY:
The Rev Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s birthday will be officially observed for the ninth time on Monday, but the holiday is still struggling for broad acceptance: widely observed by governments, mostly ignored by businesses and in danger of being viewed as a black holiday rather than a national one.
Admirers of Dr. King are rethinking the national observance and trying to change the public perception of it from civil rights to broader themes of nonviolence and public service and prevent it from being marginalized as a second-tier holiday. 
 "We have two challenges," said Alan Minton, chief of staff for the Martin Luther King Jr. Federal Holiday Commission, created in 1984 to establish and promote the holiday. "One is to make sure it's an American holiday, not just an African-American holiday, and two is to perform some sort of community service work. Like Mrs. King says, the holiday is not where it should be, not where it can be and certainly not where we want it to be, but participation is increasing, and we think we're on the verge of becoming something substantive and meaningful."
Born in often rancorous debate, wedded to still painful issues of politics and race, the King holiday, marking his birth on Jan. 15, 1929, has a unique place in the nation's official holidays. But its problems in achieving broad acceptance may have as much to do with the difficulty of establishing a tradition and convincing employers to give their workers a day off as with enduring controversy.
This year the holiday, which is observed on the third Monday of January, will be celebrated by all 50 states, the Federal Government and many local governments and school districts. Observances range from a sunrise prayer service in Miami to a tribal dance by American Indians in Great Falls, Mont., from gun-buyback programs in Florida and other states to a multicultural breakfast in Phoenix honoring both Dr. King and Cesar Chavez, the leader of the United Farm Workers' Union, who died last year. In New York, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo made the day a working day for the State Assembly to consider gun control measures. He said curbing the use of arms was the most powerful tribute that could be paid to Dr. King.
But winning over the nation's employers and weaving the holiday into the fabric of American life has proved difficult. According to the Bureau of National Affairs, a Washington-based research and publishing concern, employees at 22 percent of the businesses surveyed will get the day as a paid holiday this year. A 1990 study of the Fortune 500 companies, found that 18 percent gave the day off. For many, it is an optional, floating holiday that can be observed or taken at another time. Employers in the South, which has the highest percentage of blacks in its population, were the most likely to give a holiday.
On the other hand, about 8 in 10 governmental agencies and banks, and 2 in 3 school and colleges will close.
 
Progress Is Measured
 Mr. Minton said the figures showed substantial progress, and he said he believed that trend was accelerating. For example, a study done for the King holiday commission found that the number of those participating in the holiday increased to 31 percent last year from 23 percent in 1991.
But the figures do not approach the status of the most-observed holidays, Christmas, New Year's, Thanksgiving, Independence Day, Labor Day and Memorial Day, which are days off for 99 percent of the nation's businesses. A 1985 study by the Bureau of National Affairs found that 45 percent of employers gave days off for President's Day, 40 percent observed Good Friday, which is not a national holiday, and 20 percent gave Veterans Day off.
Businesses, large and small, say their reluctance to give employees the day off reflects economics, not politics.
"It comes at the wrong time of year for preparing taxes," said Brent Stewart, who employs eight people in his accounting firm in Scottsdale, Ariz. "But if it didn't, I would consider it."
The Boeing Company, which employs 86,000 people in the Seattle area, has never celebrated the King Holiday, or any other holiday between New Year's and Memorial Day.
 
Resistance to Change
 "This goes back at least 25 years," said Paul Bender, a Boeing spokesman. "We shut down around Christmas and don't get a break until Memorial Day."
Along with a lack of observance, the holiday also suffers from a lack of definition. Organizers want the holiday to have broad, ecumenical appeal, but even some blacks feel its focus is supposed to be on black issues. In Arizona, where feelings are still raw over the long battle for statewide designation for the holiday, there is general support for the multicultural tint to the observance. But some blacks have objected to honoring both Dr. King and Mr. Chavez.
"It's stupid and shows no respect to the black community," said Carolyn Lowery, who is politically active in the black community.
To some blacks, the lack of general observance is an indication that the racial issues Dr. King addressed are still troubling the country.
"It's a slap in the face to the African-American community," said Willie B. Kennedy, a member of the Board of Supervisors in San Francisco.
Indeed, for white supremacist groups, the holiday has become an occasion to show their distain for Dr. King. The Ku Klux Klan has scheduled demonstrations in eight cities from Ohio through Texas.
Backers of the holiday are aware of the problems and trying to deal with them before the holiday becomes too narrowly defined.
Dr. King's widow, Coretta Scott King, at the start of 10 days of observances of the holiday at the King Center for Nonviolent Social Change in Atlanta, said the violence buffeting American life made the holiday particularly relevant. She called on people here and abroad to stop the violence and dedicate the day to community service as a way to continue Dr. King's work.
Dr. King's youngest daughter, the Rev. Bernice King, in an interview, said focusing on race served only to limit and distort Dr. King's life and work.
"The whole controversy about it being a black holiday is unfortunate," she said. "I like to think he was a nonviolent prophet for this country, kind of like Gandhi in his country."
A group of scholars, civil rights leaders and public officials, calling itself the American Committee to Invigorate the King Holiday, was formed last year to increase observance of the holiday and promote meaningful community service projects.
"The King Holiday has incredible importance in a country where violence is the major subject of the land and of the time," said Peter Kovler, a writer and investor who formed the committee to invigorate the holiday. "Who else pops up into your head on the subject of violence in this country? I've searched. King is the only one."

HEADLINE: Ulster Church Leaders Seek End of Job Bias

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS 

 BODY:
In an unusual joint statement, leaders of both Roman Catholic and Protestant churches in Northern Ireland have called for vigorous efforts to combat discrimination in the work place and attract foreign investment.
The declaration, issued in Belfast on Friday, challenges a widespread view in the Protestant population and among some overseas investors that job discrimination is a Catholic issue or one linked only to Irish nationalist politics. The statement was signed by Roman Catholic, Presbyterian, Methodist and Anglican church officials. 
 Cahal Cardinal Daly of Armagh and the Rev. John Dunlop, former moderator of the Presbyterian Church in Northern Ireland, expressed hope that the joint nature of the statement would add to the momentum for finding a solution to end the violence dividing Protestants who want Northern Ireland to remain a British province and Catholics opposed to British rule.
Catholic discontent is aggravated by the high unemployment rate among Catholic men in Northern Ireland, generally more than twice the jobless rate of Protestants. More than 28.4 percent of the province's Catholic men were out of work in 1991, compared with 12.7 percent of Protestant men, according to Government census figures for 1991, the latest year for which a breakdown was available. The difference is somewhat narrower for women.
Procedures to limit discrimination against Catholics and resolve the disparities were written into a 1989 Fair Employment Act, which is now under review. But with even Protestant unemployment exceeding 12 percent, the measures have fostered tensions similar to those surrounding affirmative action programs in the United States.
"There are people in the Protestant churches who think of fair employment as wrapped up in the nationalist ideology, or as discriminating against Protestants," Mr. Dunlop said. "This lifts it out of that context."
The church leaders agreed that high unemployment was found "disproportionately in the Catholic community." They argued that the public needs to be educated about discrimination and the need to remove it. While opposing "reverse discrimination or quotas," the church leaders backed the use of "goals and timetables" and other measures that they see as strengthening the 1989 anti-discrimination law.
The statement, Drafted with the endorsement of Catholic, Presbyterian, Methodist and Episcopal officials in the United States, is aimed at people on both sides of the Atlantic. It was endorsed on Friday by the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Ancient Order of Hibernians, an Irish-American fraternal group.

HEADLINE: NEW ONTARIO LAW BOLSTERS STRIKERS

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Jan. 15

 BODY:
The scrap wood burning in a rusty oil drum warmed the hands of Anna Sarra during a break from the picket line. The temperature was below zero, and there was a chill wind as she huddled around the crackling fire with other members of Local 175 of the United Food and Commercial Workers Union at a shopping mall in northwest Toronto.
The 38-year-old cashier, who had been earning an hourly wage equivalent to $12.40 in American currency, is one of 6,500 Miracle Food Mart workers who walked out last Nov. 18 after management in Montvale, N.J., said it wanted to close stores, lay off hundreds of workers and slash wages. 
 With a 6-year-old daughter at home and an income equivalent to $67.50 a week in American money in strike pay, Ms. Sarra has little to smile about.
But she brightened up when the talk turned to a new law banning the use of replacement workers in a strike, one of the most far-reaching and hotly debated labor reforms in Canada. American unions, supported by President Clinton, are pushing for a similar law in the United States.
"It's helped us," Ms. Sarra said. "They can't run the stores without us, and I guess if they ended up hiring scabs in here, we wouldn't have liked that very much, and there would have been some violence."
Jim Hobbs, 49, a former meat cutter who makes the equivalent of $13.57 an hour in United States currency and one of the strike coordinators, explained that the only person who can legally work in any of the stores is the manager. "And you can't run a supermarket with one person," he said
 
All the Stores Closed
 Days after the walkout, the first major strike since the law took effect, the Ontario Labor Relations Board ordered the company to stop using replacements. All 63 stores in the chain, run by the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, were forced to close.
The law is a product of Ontario's socialist-oriented New Democratic government. In the public relations war before passage in November 1992, Premier Bob Rae was depicted on billboards and in television ads as Marx and Lenin. Labor showed employers as skinflints of the same class that kept children in factories a century ago.
The Ontario government says the law has reduced bitterness and brought a spirit of cooperation to the workplace. Strikes are indeed fewer; yet that could reflect Canada's 11 percent joblessness as well as the law.
The Labor Ministry recorded 76 stoppages through November resulting in 243,970 lost person days, compared with 119 strikes in the same 1992 period and 556,010 lost person days. But contracts were less lucrative, chiefly reflecting the weak economy.
The sweeping legislation also eased restrictions on union organizing, for example, allowing organizers and pickets to operate inside shopping centers and industrial parks and banning some anti-union petitions. One result: a rise in applications for union certification. .
One of the largest supermarket operators in Canada and the United States, A.&P. acquired Miracle Mart three years ago. It also operates several other chains in Ontario, including Dominion Stores, Super Fresh, Food Emporium and Sav-A-Center.
Courts have allowed the union to shift pickets from the closed Miracle Mart stores to other units of the A.&P. group that are not on strike, thus increasing pressure on management.
 
Substantial Adverse Impact
 A. & P. -- half of which is owned by one of the largest supermarket chains in Europe, the Tengelmann Group of Muhlheim-an-Ruhr, Germany -- has already reported a substantial adverse impact. Its net income in the fiscal quarter ended Dec. 4, which included the first two weeks of the strike, was only $379,000 in United States currency. The company said the cost of the shutdowns was $2.3 million in United States currency.
Retail analysts said that A.&P. has been under pressure to cut costs because of nonunion competitors like the new "price clubs" in the Ontario market from the United States. These barn-like structures offer unusually attractive prices on a wide range of staples.
Michael Rourke, vice president for corporate affairs at A.&P.'s New Jersey headquarters, said the company "is taking the position that we're really not commenting on the strike." .
Mr. Hobbs, the strike coordinator, said the workers overwhelmingly rejected the company's last offer, which called for a cut of about 700 jobs and a wage reduction equivalent to $1.75 an hour in American dollars for full- and part-time employees. Management, he said, also demanded the withdrawal of seniority rights.
Many economists say a year may not be enough time to make a judgment about the law, but for the people around the oil drum fires, it is a welcomed ally. "We're being pushed around right now," said Ms. Sarra, "but we're also making history defining the law by doing all this."

HEADLINE: FIGURE SKATING;
Images of Bodyguard Textured by Shadows

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 15

 BODY:
As Portland television stations repeatedly played the images of Nancy Kerrigan, crumpled and crying after she was attacked at the national figure skating championships last week, Shawn Eric Eckardt began to realize the gravity of his role in the crime. Seized by feelings of anguish and a need to tell his story, he sought out a minister friend and revealed what he and others had done.
With a past that includes an arrest for soliciting a prostitute, extensive interest in espionage and brief service as the bodyguard for Kerrigan's rival, Tonya Harding, Eckardt hardly seems the type to be swayed by sentiment or emotion. 
 Yet that scenario, according to his lawyer, began a sequence of events that has provided Federal and state investigators an outline of a conspiracy to injure Kerrigan and give Harding a clearer path to an Olympic gold medal next month in Lillehammer, Norway.
 
Who Else Is on Arrest List?
 Just how wide the conspiracy stretches is the central issue in a case that has captured worldwide attention for its criminal intrigue, played out against the spectacle of the Winter Olympics, its most popular sport and the commercial opportunities that await an Olympic figure skating champion.
By Friday, Eckardt and two other men had been arrested and charged with conspiracy to commit assault, and lawyers involved in the case predicted that more arrests were likely soon -- a strong suggestion that Jeff Gillooly, who is Harding's former husband, or Harding herself, could be implicated.
Both have denied any involvement in the case, and last week each retained a different lawyer from the same firm, Garvey, Schubert & Barer, which is primarily known for handling civil cases.
 
 
Investigators Are Noncommittal
 Robert C. Weaver, a former United States Assistant Attorney who is representing Harding, said in an interview that he does not believe she is currently the subject of the investigation. Weaver said that investigators had not yet interviewed Harding although they were "circumspect" in response to his questions about their suspicions.
"They didn't say either way," said Weaver, who was recommended to Harding by her coach's husband, who is also a lawyer. "They simply said they have a number of questions they need answers to. But I don't have the feeling they are focusing on her."
Christopher P. Koback, who is representing Gillooly, did not respond to a message left for him.
Edward J. Jones, a Portland criminal defense lawyer who is not involved in the case, said that in general, anyone with prior knowledge of a conspiracy would only be vulnerable to charges if prosecutors can prove any subsequent act contributed to the crime.
 
'A Man With a Heart'
 Whatever happens next will depend in large part on what Eckardt has told the authorities. But already, Eckardt, a 26-year-old lifelong friend of Gillooly, has played a major role in helping investigators examine the extent of the conspiracy and who did what in the attack.
"Contrary to the way he has been portrayed this last week, my client is a man with a heart, a soul and a conscience," Eckardt's lawyer, M. Mark McKnight, said in an interview. "If he had not sought the counsel of a spiritual confidant, the authorities would still be running around in the dark."
Nearly all those directly involved in the case, including lawyers in the district attorney's office, Federal investigators and Eckardt, have declined to comment on any aspect of the conspiracy. That silence has created a void that has been generously filled by a wealth of conflicting reports of who told what to which authorities.
 
Confession to a Friend
 However, it seems clear by now that the investigation received a considerable boost once Eckardt told his version of events to Eugene C. Saunders, a 24-year-old minister of the Celebration New Song Church and a classmate of Eckardt's at Pioneer Pacific College, a small trade school outside of Portland where they were studying to become paralegals.
McKnight, who taught the two of them in a legal ethics class at the school, said that once Saunders had heard the story, he related it to another instructor, a Portland private detective named Gary Crowe.
In an interview, Crowe recalled his meeting with Saunders and quoted the minister as telling him: "You're not going to believe this. But you know that Kerrigan deal? Shawn Eckardt arranged it. He played me a tape."
Crowe said Saunders told him he had heard an audio tape of a conversation in which Eckardt, Gillooly and another man planned the attack. Crowe said that he did not hear the tape, but after his conversation with Saunders, they both went to the F.B.I.
 
An Earlier Proposal
 The minister was a likely sanctuary for Eckardt, Crowe said, because "Eugene would help anybody. Everybody trusted him." Crowe described Saunders as being "totally distraught" after Eckardt came to him.
Saunders has declined to speak to reporters. Whether the authorities have the tape, whether it still exists or whether it ever existed are among the many questions lawyers in the case have declined to answer.
In any event, other evidence suggests that Eckardt was intent on arranging an assault on Kerrigan. Russell Rietz, a 38-year-old student at Pioneer Pacific, said that Eckardt had approached him several weeks ago with an offer.
"He said, 'I got a job for somebody,' " Rietz said. "He asked me if I would kill somebody for $65,000? I said no. He said, 'Would you break someone's leg for $65,000?' I said no."
Rietz said he "sort of laughed off" the conversation. But he added, "Right after the Kerrigan thing, he said, 'Did you hear the news? We got her.' "
In an interview today on a Portland television station, KATU, another fellow student, 20-year-old Sarah Bergman, said Eckardt had told her of a plot to get Kerrigan.
 
A Resume Filled With Intrigue
 Eckardt's three-page resume describes a man more experienced than James Bond. For example, working as a "contract operations specialist" for a Swiss firm from 1984 to 1988, when he was between the ages of 17 and 21, he said he "successfully tracked and located targeted terrorist cells throughout the Middle East, Central America, and Europe; coordinated and conducted a successful hostage retrieval operations (sic); performed advanced surveys for close protection details in Europe, the United States and Southeast Asia."
Despite all that activity, McKnight said that his 300-pound client was "not smart enough" to have masterminded the conspiracy plot against Kerrigan.
On Thursday night, Eckardt became the first of three men arrested in the case, as he was brought into the Multnomah County Sheriff's office in handcuffs. It was at least the second time in six years he was charged with a criminal activity. In 1988, he was arrested in Oregon City, a small town 13 miles south of Portland, for soliciting a prostitute. He was fined and given a one-year probation.
 
Portland Awash in Speculation
 Within the hour of his latest arrest, he was followed into the sheriff's office by Derrick B. Smith, a 29-year-old unemployed resident of Phoenix who authorities believe drove the getaway car in Detroit.
Both men were arraigned in county court on Friday, hours after the F.B.I. said its agents in Phoenix had arrested the man they say committed the assault on Kerrigan, Shane M. Stant, a 22-year-old nephew of Smith.
Later in the day, Eckardt posted bail, the required 10 percent of $20,000; Smith posted the same amount today.
Within the last few days, all kinds of rumors and speculation have flooded this scenic city of one million, astride the Willamette River in the northwest corner of the state. Principally, they concern what role, if any, Harding might have had in the attack.
 
Harding Described as 'Drained'
 Weaver, who said he only met Harding on Friday, described her as being "absolutely drained" by events of the last two weeks, to the extent she has been unable to sleep or practice -- a major concern for her with the Olympics beginning soon.
He also said that from his brief involvement in the case, "it makes no sense to me" that she would have been part of a conspiracy. "She never would be able to live with herself if she didn't win straight up," he said.
Events initiated by Eckardt's disclosures have also touched a 49-year-old unemployed native of Jackson Heights, Queens, named Joe Haran, now a Portland resident and the editor of "The Tonya Harding Fan Club Newsletter."
Haran said today that he had checked himself into the Veterans Medical Center in Portland this week, complaining of extreme depression and despondency.
"It all became too much for me to bear," he said.

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
After 13 Seasons, Who Could Be Taylor's Next Target?

BYLINE: By MIKE FREEMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 15

 BODY:
Lawrence Taylor, one of the best defensive players ever, did what everyone expected him to do: he retired today after 13 years of pro football.
In an eloquent but unemotional announcement in a cramped room below Candlestick Park, Taylor, who is a shoe-in for the Hall of Fame, announced his retirement after the Giants' humiliating 44-3 loss to San Francisco. His reason was simple: he said he just couldn't do it anymore. 
 When asked what he thought his legacy would be, he said in typical Taylor fashion that he would leave it to the people who follow the game.
"That's not for me to decide," he said. "People will remember me for what they remember me. The players, the people who study the game, they know what I brought to it."
Taylor knew months ago that he was going to retire, but didn't want to announce it because he felt it would cause a distraction to the team. He spoke to Coach Dan Reeves about retiring several times this season, and Reeves told him to make sure it was a not a decision based on emotion, but one based on whether he thought he could still play after this season. Before the season, he signed a two-year contract worth $2.25 million a season. Since the contract wasn't guaranteed he will not receive next year's salary.
Taylor isn't the emotional type, and he was upset with a reporter who asked him to describe his feelings. But his words were passionate, even if his demeanor was not.
"I'm going to miss just being around the guys," said Taylor. "I've been playing with the Giants for 13 years. It seems like I've been in the locker room thousands and thousands and thousands of times. It's been my world for a lot of years."
Many consider Taylor to be the best linebacker in the history of the game. He is the reason many young players today wear his No. 56. In his prime, he did things no other player could do, and some think the offensive left tackle position became so important because of Taylor's blinding hits on the quarterback's blind side.
"I think it's time for me to retire," he said. "I've done everything I can do. I've been to Super Bowls. I've done things that other people haven't been able to do."
But this season, coming off an Achilles' tendon injury, Taylor just didn't have it. And he knew it. He had six sacks and 79 tackles -- not bad, but Taylor is used to being great. There were many games when he was simply a nonfactor on the field.
"Over the years I've been able to find some way to counteract what the other team is doing, but today I couldn't," Taylor said. "It just wasn't there."
Where Taylor did constantly excel was in the locker room providing leadership. A tirade by him at halftime last Sunday helped propel the Giants past Minnesota in the wild-card game. He may not remember everyone's names sometimes -- he often referred to some of the young players by their numbers -- but everyone was touched just by the fact that such a great figure in the history of sports was around them.
"His personality is what made him great," said Phil Simms. "He was the greatest linebacker to ever play the game. I'll miss him."
Reeves said: "I'm happy for him and I know he'll be as successful outside of football as he was on the field."
Taylor, who said he will take the next couple of weeks to decide what he's going to do in place of football, likely won't be unemployed for long. Certainly he will pay more attention to his business, All-Pro Sports, and there is always the possibility he could go to televison as an analyst. But what does he plan on doing in the immediate future?
"Hook up with Michael Jordan and play some golf."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;
Threat of a Bloc Veto Hangs Over Meetings

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS 

 BODY:
In what could develop into one of the most momentous of their many meetings or deteriorate into another dud, major league club owners will gather in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., this week amid threats that some of them will hold the election of a commissioner hostage to revenue sharing.
The meetings have been preceded by a series of intriguing developments in the past week. 
 The low-revenue clubs, numbering from seven to nine, say they will consider blocking the election of a commissioner if the owners do not adopt a plan to share a significantly greater share of their local revenue.
Eight high-revenue clubs have made a commitment not to break ranks to support a revenue-sharing plan without seriously debating it among themselves. That means the other 20 clubs cannot expect to easily get the 21st vote they need to approve a plan proposed at the last owners' meeting Jan. 6.
And the commissioner search committee, according to a well-placed lawyer, is prepared to recommend Arnold Weber, retiring president of Northwestern University, to fill the office that has been vacant for nearly a year and a half.
 
Won't Be Overlooked
 The owners will resume their revenue-sharing debate Tuesday. During a meeting tomorrow of the executive council, the major leagues' ruling body, William Bartholomay of the Atlanta Braves, chairman of the search committee, is expected to recommend that Weber be the next commissioner.
Matters that are presented to the executive council often become buried, like bills in Congressional committees, but the acting commissioner, Bud Selig, said he "absolutely" has the matter of the commissioner on the agenda for Wednesday's session.
Some club people, not all of whom can vote, have questioned the wisdom of naming Weber, a 64-year-old academician and economist. He has advised presidents, but the critics say that he has too cozy a relationship with two Chicago powers, Stanton Cook, chairman of the Cubs, and Jerry Reinsdorf, chairman of the White Sox.
Cook and Reinsdorf are members of the Northwestern board of trustees, Cook since 1987, Reinsdorf since last June, and Weber serves on the board of the Tribune Company, owner of the Cubs.
Weber, who will retire from Northwestern Aug. 31, was the last name to surface as a serious candidate for commissioner, but that's only because he also was the committee's best-kept secret.
 
The Small Block
 But the election of Weber, or anyone else, could be blocked by the small-revenue clubs, a group that includes Montreal, Pittsburgh, San Diego, Milwaukee, Minnesota, Seattle and Cincinnati. Those clubs desperately want a new revenue-sharing plan and are apparently prepared to take a militant stand to try to force it. Election of a commissioner requires 21 of the 28 votes.
Richard Ravitch, the clubs' chief labor executive, who has been in the forefront of the effort to forge a new revenue-sharing plan, said he has not heard of any threatened action linking revenue sharing and the commissioner. Selig, whose Brewers epitomize a low-revenue operation, said he hasn't "heard anything about that" either.
But high-ranking officials of two low-revenue clubs acknowledged that the possibility exists.
"I'm going to keep that to myself," said Claude Brochu, managing partner and president of the Expos, when asked about the threat to block election of Fay Vincent's successor. "I'm not going to comment on that. But that has been discussed."
Dick Freeman, president of the Padres, also declined to make concrete comment, but his words were revealing.
"I'm not going to get into that," he said. "Any comment I would make on that would be counterproductive. It's not in the best interests of the Padres or major league baseball to give any comment." Asked where the threat stood, Freeman said, "I can't say."
Their tacit confirmation of a report that originated with a man close to several owners made it curious that Selig would not be aware of the threat. Selig constantly communicates with other owners, and they credit the de facto commissioner with knowing everything that happens.
 
Of Overbearing Importance
 What would the low-revenue owners gain by blocking the election of a commissioner?
One official from a club not aligned with that group, who has heard the rumor of what those clubs might do, offered one possible explanation. "I think their point is to say this is of such importance to us that we don't want to go on to business as usual before this is clarified," he said. "We don't want it to get lost."
Jerry McMorris, chairman and president of the high-revenue Rockies of Colorado, said he hasn't heard specifics of the strategy, but he said, "I've heard words thrown around like anarchy."
At the other extreme, the eight members in solid standing of the high-revenue bloc are intent on preventing passage of a plan that would take too much of their money. The speculation coming out of the last meeting, in Rosemont, Ill., was that the proponents of the latest Ravitch plan would try to pick off St. Louis for the decisive 21st vote, perhaps altering the plan just enough to lure the Cardinals.
But the Cardinals have joined the other seven clubs in pledging their loyalty to the high-revenue bloc.
"The eight are very firm," McMorris said.
 
The Big Boys' Plan
 An official of another club, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said, "There's a commitment among the group to stay together on the plan they developed and not support any other plan unless the group collectively decides otherwise."
The high-revenue plan received only 11 votes in Rosemont (the Big Eight plus Florida, Texas and Detroit), but its proponents believe closer study of it could produce additional supporters. The plan, presented last late in the day, marked the first time a proposal by the high-revenue clubs was discussed and voted on. With 11 days' extra time to consider it, some of the other clubs might see it as an alternative to the Ravitch variations, three of which failed to gain the necessary 21 votes.
Particularly inviting, the proponents believe, should be the formula they say could annually produce $10 million each for some of the lowest-revenue clubs. The big eight will push the plan Tuesday. The unknown element of the meetings, though, is which group will push the hardest.
 
Not Necessarily Pals
 Before Weber's name surfaced in the commissioner search, Harvey Schiller was viewed by some as the leading contender for the job. Schiller was perceived to be George Steinbrenner's candidate because Schiller is executive director of the United States Olympic Committee and the Yankees' owner is a committee vice president. These were two good buddies, it was widely thought.
But, said one owner who knows both men: "I don't think the two are best of pals. It's quite erroneous to make a correlation between two people who serve on the same body. In this instance, it's quite the contrary."
 
Reality Check, Please
 Upon his election into the Hall of Fame, Steve Carlton said, "I think I can still pitch." Why? He couldn't pitch in his last four seasons. He staggered to a 16-37 record as he became a vagabond, desperately trying to extend, but instead tarnishing, a brilliant career, one of the best ever.
 
Foul by Jordan
 Michael Jordan was too great a basketball player for baseball players to resent him, but he insults them all, major leaguers and minor leaguers, by his arrogance of thinking he can walk into the Chicago White Sox spring camp and -- poof! -- become one of them.
Hitting against a pitching machine or batting practice pitchers in three-hour, five-day-a-week workouts after having played no baseball in a dozen years or more will not convert the world's best athlete into a major league baseball player.
Bo Jackson and Deion Sanders, remarkable for their professional versatility, played baseball in college and the minors. Jackson, before his devastating hip injury, never did become a major league player with no serious flaws. Sanders needed four professional seasons, spent mostly in the minors, before becoming a legitimate major leaguer.
In parts of two major league seasons before 1992, Sanders batted .158 and .191. With all the winter and spring hitting he could get, if Jordan somehow played in the majors next season, he would be a personal success if he could average one hit every 10 times at bat. He would be virtually guaranteed to strike out more frequently than Jackson's one every 2.85 at-bats.
Jordan is acting like a spoiled little rich kid who thinks he should have whatever he wants. Jerry Reinsdorf, the man who runs the White Sox and the Bulls, should spank little Mikey and send him to bed without supper.

GRAPHIC: Photo: In spite of having floundered in his last four seasons, Steve Carlton says he thinks he can still pitch. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: How Family Planning Came to Bangladesh;
India's Dowry Problem

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Bangalore Journal: For Many Brides in India, a Dowry Buys Death" (news article, Dec. 30): My research on dowries in India has attempted to demonstrate that its major cause is the demographic phenomenon of too many brides looking for far fewer bridegrooms. This should be understood in the context of a marriage market, where women have to get married by a very young age or face severe social and economic consequences, and where 99 percent of men and women get married by their early 20's, with less than 2 percent getting divorced. 
 When mortality rates declined with health initiatives in the early 1930's, population grew. As in all populations with increasing growth rates, this resulted in a disproportion of younger people. As bridegrooms tend to be many years older than brides, this caused an excess of brides, and the resultant increased competition for scarce bridegrooms caused their price -- dowries -- to rise.
This relationship between excess brides and rising dowries is confirmed in ethnographic investigations conducted by me and other researchers, where respondents typically say they are compelled to pay high dowries because of the high degree of competition for scarce bridegrooms. This, even though the average dowry is more than five times a family's annual income.
My research seems also to confirm a statistical association between small dowry payments and wife beating. A woman who is married with a dowry that is perceived as inadequate by her husband's family is more likely to be beaten by him than a woman who pays a larger dowry. However, the extent of the husband's alcohol consumption also seems to make him more likely to be physically abusive. Women do not have the option of leaving an abusive husband, because of a lack of opportunities to earn an income and the social unacceptability of divorce. These conditions exacerbate matters.
Had there been no strict social sanctions against women staying unmarried, dowries may not have risen. The proportion of women choosing to stay single would have gone up instead. Thus the most effective and lasting solution to this problem is the provision of options to women outside marriage. This would involve widespread investments in their education and training, along with employment opportunities outside traditional local labor markets, which are inextricably tied to the male-dominated social structure.
 
VIJAYENDRA RAO
Ann Arbor, Mich., Jan. 5, 1994
The writer is adjunct assistant professor of economics, University of Michigan Population Studies Center.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;
Awaiting Repairs at the Fish Market

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
After a fire on Oct. 31 displaced several wholesalers at the Fulton Fish Market, city officials promised swift repairs to get them back in business for the holiday season. Eleven weeks later, repairs have yet to begin.
The fire gutted 109 South Street and forced the evacuation of two adjoining buildings. The brick buildings, all landmarks in the South Street Seaport Historic District, are boarded up and cordoned off by police barricades. The residual scent of smoke competes with the market's fishy aroma. And the fish dealers who worked in the three buildings are still in temporary quarters across the street; city officials did not know the exact number of companies affected by the fire. 
 In November, the Community Board 1 chairwoman, Anne Compoccia, contacted officials of the Economic Development Corporation and other agencies of the city, which owns the building where the fire started. They said the work would start right after Thanksgiving. Ever since, she said, she has been prodding them with calls and letters.
"The bureaucracy is destroying these little businesses and hurting the 30 or so families that make a living from this," she said.
Officials admit their plans went awry. "We're very disappointed with the turnaround time as well," said Pamela McKoin, a senior vice president at the economic agency. "We went to the board and represented that these things would be done faster. It was an unintentional misrepresentation, because we misunderstood the process with the insurance company." Once the insurance claim is settled, she said, contractors could start within a few weeks and finish in a couple of months. She declined to estimate the cost of work, which would entail restoring No. 109 and safeguarding the adjoining buildings from collapse.
Meanwhile, the businesses say they are having a hard time because customers can't find them at their old location. "Space in the market is at an absolute premium, and basically if you're out of operation for a couple of weeks, as they were, you're out of business," said Gerald J. McMahon, a lawyer for the Fulton Fish Market and for Carmine Sarnelli, owner of one of the buildings.
The wholesalers are willing to put up their own money to stabilize the buildings so that their fish stands can resume business on the sidewalk, Ms. Compoccia said. So far the city has not accepted that offer. "We put men on the moon," she said, "but we can't shore up three little buildings." B.L.
