HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING/FRESH MEADOWS;
Portrait of Decline at a City Parking Garage

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

 BODY:
The city-owned parking garage in downtown Flushing is crumbling after years of neglect and is in the worst condition of any of the city's 16 garages, a City Council investigation has determined.
The findings offer a striking and detailed portrait of the 1,100-spot garage's decline: crumbling beams and girders; leaking drainage pipes clogged with weeds and shrubs, and flaking and eroding ceilings. 
 City Council investigators say the lack of regular maintenance over the years has driven up the cost of repairs to nearly $3 million from $136,000 in 1985, figures that the Department of Transportation was unable to confirm.
Councilwoman Julia Harrison, who requested the investigation, called the upkeep of the garage "the kind of work that is not sexy and doesn't get a lot of attention." But, she added, parking is "critical to the survival of the retail district in the area. How can people shop if there's nowhere to park?"
Officials at the Department of Transportation say the garage is structurally sound. But they note that until 1991 they could not undertake renovations because the city's Economic Development Corporation had a plan to replace the garage, a plan that has fallen through. Now, the Transportation Department plans to rebuild it, starting in March, for $2.7 million.
The garage is still open, but residents, civic leaders and others have long expressed uneasiness and frustration over its deteriorating condition. Many say it has become a blemish in a neighborhood that is thriving with new shops and stores.
And increasing congestion and streets clogged with double- and triple-parked cars underline how ill-equipped the area is to handle the accompanying rise in demand for parking spots.
Councilwoman Harrison opposes an overhaul of the garage, calling it a "primitive" structure that should be demolished. She endorses a plan proposed by community leaders to use the space as public square with an underground parking garage.
Lisa Daglian, a spokeswoman for the Department of Transportation, said of the garage, "It's not pretty, but it's safe." RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Building the Szechuan Empire

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES

 BODY:
CHICKEN teriyaki pizza? Relax, some people are already eating it, but out in one of the suburban satellites of the Empire Szechuan Gourmet restaurant, not in the founding emporium itself, where Misa Chang rules as ever with an entrepreneurial sixth sense of when the Upper West Side will be ready for whatever chopstick challenge should come next.
"It take time, so maybe next menu," Ms. Chang explains, her eyes darting carefully across a small tabletop feast in the Empire Szechuan flagship restaurant at Broadway and 97th Street. The tiny, hyperkinetic businesswoman scrutinizes the evening's gleaming array of dishes with the same managerial eye she applies to the nine Manhattan restaurants of the Empire Szechuan chain that she oversees in her long-running, ever-evolving partnership with Jimmy Shau. 
 The two started out 17 winters ago with six tables, $25,000 in loans from family and friends, and Ms. Chang's hunch that West Side palates were ready for the new, more eclectic cuisine of her native Taiwan, China's fabled crossroads island bastion, where her father and grandfather were master chefs.
What followed has been one of the grandest small-business successes of modern Manhattan commerce: a highly popular chain of restaurants whose menus, though more than ubiquitous, are never predictable. There is, for example, a new sushi bar and sushi chef tucked into a corner of the enlarged 97th Street restaurant. Lately, among other endless innovating, Ms. Chang has revived some of her grandfather's Taiwan noodle dishes, not to lose a step on the noodle mania lately sweeping the city's Asian restaurants, and she selected a special Taiwan supplier for the vegetarian basics of the chain's new health food menu of ersatz "meat" dishes.
Ms. Chang's Empire once totaled 13 eating places, but it has been pruned and consolidated to 9, including the new one at Broadway and 170th Street. This is a site that offers the sort of low-rent, high-risk adventuresomeness that was Ms. Chang's founding trademark in December 1976, when, as the young wife of a Ph.D. candidate at Columbia University, she desperately home-delivered takeout food herself to see the business through its early rocky months.
"Our tiger," says Mr. Shau, saluting his partner at the dinner table in the 97th Street restaurant. The compliment causes a bit of a metaphysical debate. True, Misa Chang has tenaciously etched the Empire's success through the city's long recession years, but not so much with a tiger's claws as with a gamecock's talons, according to her husband, Joseph Woo, who lovingly claws the air above his wife's busy little head.
Mr. Woo is one of the clan's executive chefs just back in from the suburbs to report that the experiment with chicken teriyaki pizza and other Oriental adaptations of the Italian staple is being wolfed down happily out in the new Massapequa Park Empire Szechuan. This is one of four Long Island satellites opened in the chain's evolution, which characteristically is more defined by informal Chinese family traditions than by Western notions of franchise, stockholding and other contracted arrangements.
The clan, with the canny Ms. Chang at its heart, shares restaurant capital and savvy for new ventures on the basis of blood kinship and deep friendship. The matriarch is always importing the latest master chefs to update the flagship restaurant offerings and to spread them from the primal woks of 97th Street through the rest of the Empire.
"Ideas like 'franchise' do not work in explaining our business," notes Mr. Shau of the Empire's 200 employees and dozens of interrelated chefs and managers. "We say we are family and leave it at that," he says, politely declining to specify Empire's current balance sheet, profits dispersal and capital success, but at least directing a digging reporter's chopsticks over toward the spicy lobster.
City dwellers pose a complicated question in wondering why Ms. Chang and Mr. Shau have skipped the other four boroughs in fostering so many Manhattan eateries and then leaping eastward to Long Island. The answer, Ms. Chang says, lies first in her commitment to her Manhattan roots and to her compulsion to visit personally and boss the Empire restaurants, much as she still compulsively goes off to the Bronx wholesale markets at midnight to choose produce personally for the Empire menus.
Then again, the answer lies in the fact that Homer Lee, a business consultant and much- trusted principal now in the Empire, is based on Long Island and presents a personal tie to the restaurants of that market. Customers constantly propose new neighborhoods, but Misa Chang prefers a mix of care and providence over pure marketing strategems. The new 170th Street restaurant was right in her mind for a whole complex of reasons, not only in following her early, low-rent customers northward in their economic migration but also in establishing an Empire outpost for her 18-year-old daughter, Julie, to run.
"Danger area?" Misa Chang asks of the uptown neighborhood. "Nah, she in charge now," she declares, happy with the mother-daughter parallel in recalling that 97th Street was forbidding, too, when she first opened the doors and, after two hours, sold an 80-cent takeout order of egg drop soup.
"I so scared, I locked the doors," she recalled of those struggling days in which success was gradually delivered by such early customers as Marty Reisman, a Ping-Pong champion of classic West Side sensibilities, and students at Columbia University. They discovered that the Empire Szechuan not only offered low-priced new dishes, but also delivered them free. More important was Misa Chang's desperate stratagem of papering the neighborhood with her menu, an innovation in those days that haunts the West Side now. "I'm first at that," the business woman confesses unapologetically.
Jimmy Shau smiles in nostalgia amid the booming success of the restaurant, which recently subsumed a Blimpie's and Mexican restaurant in enlarging down Broadway from its busy southeast corner stronghold. In making this move, Mr. Shau and Ms. Chang strategically accepted the loss of their older sidewalk cafe, which was closed after the local community board revoked the cafe license in the West Side's sour "menu wars."
Some residents are furious that Empire Szechuan menus, along with many others now, are constantly delivered uninvited to building foyers. Ms. Chang says her restaurant will cease the advertising practice when her many competitiors do too. Meantime, she accepts the nightly overflow crowds as a popular vote of confidence in the Empire's food and continuing business acumen.
"I made a lot of friends here," says Misa Chang. "I stay. Get stronger."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;
Stretch of Piers Awaits Its Turn To Be Cinderella

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
The four city-owned piers along the East River at Manhattan's southern tip have long been overshadowed by their waterfront neighbors: the South Street Seaport Historic District and Fulton Fish Market. Over the years the piers have had a number of uses, including as a parking lot and as tennis courts run by the New York Health and Racquet Club beneath enormous plastic "bubbles."
Now city officials and local leaders are seeking to open up the waterfront to the public, provide recreation and attract more maritime businesses. The city's Economic Development Corporation is spending $10 million to restore the deteriorated pilings at Piers 13 and 14 and plans a parallel renovation of Piers 9 and 11. (There is no Pier 10 or 12.) The agency is also seeking $6 million in Federal aid for a pedestrian esplanade connecting Battery Park to the South Street Seaport. 
 Community Board 1 is considering a more far-reaching proposal that also calls for parks, playgrounds, a marina, restaurants, a boat showroom, fishing and sailing boats, and tackle rental shops. The piers now have ferries to Brooklyn and New Jersey, a hospital ship, the dinner cruise ship Mystique, and Delta Air Line's water shuttle to La Guardia.
How soon improvements appear will depend on government aid, the economy, the demand to do business at the piers and policy decisions by the Giuliani administration. A draft of the board's proposal urges paying for the projects with revenue from the commercial uses.
The piers, remnants of New York's first port, languished for decades, cut off by the elevated Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, as developers dreamed of building a towering complex that would be the East Side equivalent of Battery Park City and the World Financial Center. With the current economic climate and heightened environmental restrictions on riverside development, many experts say it is unlikely that the plan will ever be realized.
A resolution going before the community board on Tuesday proposes an end to skyscraper zoning there, and the Economic Development Corporation agency also supports down-zoning. "We're trying to fulfill the piers' potential for much greater public use," said Paul Goldstein, the board manager.
The major sticking point is the board committee's plan to keep 65 percent of the pier space open to the public, in contrast to the agency's proposal of 40 percent. But Ann L. Buttenwieser, a vice president of the economic agency, said the board committee's proposal is "very much in tune with what we envision." BRUCE LAMBERT

HEADLINE: How the East Was Won

BYLINE: By Orlando Figes; Orlando Figes, the author of "Peasant Russia, Civil War," is writing a history of the Russian Revolution.

 BODY:

THE CONQUEST OF A CONTINENT
Siberia and the Russians.
By W. Bruce Lincoln.
Illustrated. 500 pp. New York: Random House. $30. 
 THE Russian conquest of Siberia, rather like the American conquest of the West, was a formative moment in the making of a nation. Just as the spirit of America was in part defined by its pioneers in the West, so that of Russia was defined by its conquest of the East. Many of the basic features of the Russian state reached their perfection (or imperfection) in Siberia. Nowhere else were its rulers so lawless, its customs so barbaric or its prisons and industries so vast and destructive. This was not so much a place as a state of mind.
In "The Conquest of a Continent," W. Bruce Lincoln tells the story of Siberia's subjugation through several hundred years, beginning at the end of the 16th century, very well. There is much to enjoy in his colorful narrative. But he does not tell us much, despite the book's subtitle, about the impact of that conquest on the history of Russia as a whole, and this will no doubt leave many feeling shortchanged. Nor does he say much about its impact on the indigenous Siberians -- the Buryats, Yakuts, Kirghiz, Oroks, Chukchi and dozens of other hunting, fishing and nomadic peoples -- despite a growing literature on this subject. This is like a history of the American West without the American Indians.
Mr. Lincoln, a professor of Russian history at Northern Illinois University, begins his book with the early geographic exploration of Siberia, which is two million square miles bigger than the United States. It is a wonderful story, perfectly suited to Mr. Lincoln's narrative style. As early as 1648 the celebrated explorer Semen Dezhnev sailed around its far northeastern tip, thus effectively proving that Asia was separate from North America, though at the time he had no idea of the importance of his discovery. Nearly a century later, Vitus Bering, a Dane in the service of the czars, sailed through what is now called the Bering Strait and into the Gulf of Alaska. The 50th state was originally colonized by the Russians as a new base for the hunting of sea otters, whose precious pelts had become scarce in Siberia. In 1867, when the animals had been virtually wiped out, it was sold to the United States for $7 million.
Commercially, the story of Siberia was a simple one of plunder. Cossacks, trappers and merchants exported furs to the West or traded them with the Chinese in exchange for cotton, silk and tea. Gold, coal and iron later became the main resources to be scooped out of the Siberian landscape. This lazy reliance on the export of raw materials has always been at the root of Russia's underdevelopment; even today such trade accounts for more than half of its gross domestic product. This is easier to understand when one stops to think of all the resources -- as Mr. Lincoln points out, a sixth of the world's gold and silver, a fifth of its platinum, a third of its iron and a quarter of its timber -- that Russia has in its backyard colony of Siberia. But the monopolistic nature of the Russian state, which cannibalized the country for its own needs, was also crucial in the underdevelopment of Siberia. There was neither a landowning gentry nor an independent class of entrepreneurs to turn Siberia into another America. It was only at the end of the 19th century, when a prosperous new tier of peasant dairy farmers arose on its western plains, that Siberia might have followed a different path. But the 1917 revolution prevented that, and most of them were later suppressed, branded by the Communists as kulaks, farmers too well-to-do to be tolerated.
Convicts, of course, were the main product and the very symbol of Siberia; when one thinks of its Arctic wastelands one automatically thinks of them. Mr. Lincoln gives an excellent survey of penal policy in Siberia from the 19th century to the gulags. Compared with the latter, the czarist penal system was extremely tame (Lenin was left to make his own way into exile in 1897 and was even allowed to take his hunting guns and half his library with him). But as Mr. Lincoln stresses, both systems largely served to provide free labor for the state economy. Convicts felled the timber, dug the mines and later built the railways, canals and dams that made Siberia the jewel in the Communist crown.
Perhaps Mr. Lincoln might have made more of the links between Soviet penal policy and economic planning in Siberia. The gigantic nature of the various building projects there -- from Stalin's construction of Magnitogorsk, the largest iron and steel plant in the world, to Brezhnev's giant power stations -- were all made possible by an endless supply of convict labor. On request from the economic ministries, the K.G.B. would simply arrest more "enemies of the people" and ship them off to the East.
It is tempting to conclude that the gigantic nature of these projects was also partly inspired by the sheer expanse of the Siberian landscape. The transformation of nature was central to the Marxist plan, and Siberia had an awful lot of nature to transform. But the dream of harnessing nature to the needs of man soon turned into the nightmare of destruction. Today the air of Siberia is polluted with chemicals, its Arctic coasts contaminated by radioactive waste, and Lake Baikal, which once held a fifth of the earth's fresh water, is not so fresh anymore. It is this concern that has largely fueled the recent movement for Siberian independence from Russia. Always resourceful on their own, the Siberians are fed up with serving the interests of their distant masters in Moscow. Don't be surprised if they one day break away.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Barracks at one of Siberia's worst prisons around the turn of the century, where inmates slept on wooden benches. (THE LIBRARY OF CONGRESS/FROM "THE CONQUEST OF A CONTINENT")

HEADLINE: JAZZ VIEW;
Lincoln Center and Its Critics Swing Away

BYLINE: By Tom Piazza; Tom Piazza is the author of "Blues Up and Down: Jazz, Race and American Culture in Our Time," a collection of essays to be published next year.

 BODY:
JAZZ CRITICS HAVE ALWAYS BEEN an argumentative bunch, but the current critical uproar over the jazz program at Lincoln Center is something new. As the program has moved into its third season, reviewers, writing in The New York Post, The Daily News, the Nation and a number of other journals have attacked, with increasing frequency and stridency, Lincoln Center's attempt to establish a sort of canon for jazz -- a body of work by musicians as different as Louis Armstrong and Thelonious Monk that might define certain stylistic tendencies in the music.
The controversy reached a fever pitch in November when The Village Voice published a full-page broadside by the reviewer Kevin Whitehead that questioned the program's motives and philosophy in extremely combative terms. The program's artistic director, Wynton Marsalis, was so infuriated by the Whitehead piece, which came on the heels of another full-page critique only a month earlier by The Voice's regular jazz reviewer, Gary Giddins, that he wrote a 2,500-word response challenging Mr. Whitehead's premises and conclusions. The Voice declined to publish Mr. Marsalis's letter. 
 Because of the immense financial and logistical resources available for jazz at the nation's preeminent performing arts institution, Jazz at Lincoln Center has assumed a central importance in the debate over the definition and direction of America's most important native art form. Since most of the critics involved are white and most of the program's directorship is black, that debate has become an alternately illuminating and dismaying lesson in cultural politics.
Lincoln Center's jazz programming under Mr. Marsalis has been underway since 1987, first as the weeklong "Classical Jazz" series in August, then, since 1991, as the year-long Jazz at Lincoln Center. The latter has encompassed concerts, film programs, lectures, young people's concerts presided over by Mr. Marsalis and national tours by the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra.
Although almost all of Jazz at Lincoln Center's individual concerts have received extremely good reviews, some critics have called its governing vision "elitist," "divisive," "exclusionary," even "neo-conservative." Their main complaint has been the supposed absence of "new" music in the program's lineup, which leans heavily but not exclusively toward what Lincoln Center terms "classical" jazz. This appellation is applied to music that covers a wide stylistic and chronological range but addresses a number of specific esthetic preoccupations. These include swing at slow, medium and fast tempos, the blues, the romantic ballad and Afro-Hispanic rhythms, as found in the work of such disparate artists as Duke Ellington and Ornette Coleman.
The program's critics argue that Jazz at Lincoln Center should make room for a music with a more diffuse set of esthetic concerns, encompassing the work of such musicians as the reed virtuoso Anthony Braxton (who insists that his music is not jazz) and others who base their approaches in funk and world music. But running underneath the charges, like an especially tricky set of chord changes, are a number of questions surrounding the roles that African-American art has played in this society.
For years, most critics have shrugged their shoulders when asked to define jazz. As recently as last month, Mr. Whitehead himself asserted that the only possible definition was "I know it when I hear it." It is an odd statement for a critic to make -- imagine an art critic not being able to say what he means by, say, the Baroque -- but it is a typical one, and it betokens not so much a resistance to a particular definition as a resistance to any effort at definition whatsoever. Jazz is often the one place where people with otherwise good intellectual equipment insist that intelligible critical standards not be applied.
To understand why, one needs to face an uncomfortable truth about the relation of certain jazz critics to the music they write about. For these critics, jazz, like other parts of black culture, serves as a sort of Garden of Eden, a bit like Kipling's "Mandalay" -- some place east of Third Avenue where the best is like the worst and a critic can be absolved from the burden of history and intellectual responsibility.
Over and over, these critics assert the primacy in jazz of the "new," the "outrageous" and the "irrational." Their spiritual father, James Lincoln Collier, summed it up when he claimed that "jazz is emotion more than design," as if the two concepts were somehow less than compatible. This attitude is an extension of the Romantic myth of the Noble Savage, a role that blacks have long been saddled with in society, often by those who profess to be their greatest friends.
Such critics tend to be in constant search of "the new," a concept that fits an image of jazz as an iconoclastic music on the outside of the culture at large. Yet for the musicians themselves, from the time of King Oliver to the time of John Coltrane, the music has represented not an escape from responsibility and community but a sophisticated model of the way in which the individual and the community might work hand in hand. Jazz uses specific, definable musical techniques to achieve its democratic balance between the musical ideas of the improvising soloist and the ensemble against which, and with which, he plays. Music that does not use these techniques may be excellent music, but it is not, by Lincoln Center's criteria at least, jazz.
If there is a main problem in American art today, it is not that we need the new to unshackle us from a suffocating and outmoded tradition. The new is constantly pumped out, by the ton and 24 hours a day, into the esthetic rivers, reservoirs and gullies of our culture, and nobody needs to go looking for it. With all the economic force of corporate profit and advertising behind it, pop culture, with its Billy the Kid ethos, has in fact become the new establishment. In a truly Orwellian irony, the new is the status quo.
In times like these, the new, as these critics mean it, is not what saves an art. What saves an art is an attempt to rediscover its wellsprings or to redefine its roots. This process is not a "conservative" activity but a literally radical one. Within the realm of the arts, enduring forms constitute a kind of collective unconscious, without the use of which the artist is powerless. Glenn Gould once wrote that "all art is really variation upon some other art," and that statement applies not just to European "high art" but to any art.
Jazz at Lincoln Center is an attempt to address this notion. If the program has anything resembling a tragic flaw, it is that its directorship has been tactless and defensive, or worse, with some segments of the jazz press. Perhaps the defensiveness is understandable, given episodes like one that occurred last summer, in which the reviewer Chip Deffaa, writing in The Post, offered a list of critics -- all of whom happened to be white -- who might be called upon to oversee the decisions of the program's directorship. Send that man a mint julep.
No program of this sort is perfect, and no administrator is without blind spots or prejudices. Jazz at Lincoln Center is important enough to argue over at length, but paranoia and ad hominem attacks do the music no good. More midrash, please, and less diaper rash. Lincoln Center has a huge promise to fulfill, and anybody who loves jazz can only wish it well.

HEADLINE: The Man From Treasure Island

BYLINE: By Brock Baker; Brock Baker, a freelance writer and critic, has just finished a novel about New York family life in the 1960's.

 BODY:

DREAMS OF EXILE
Robert Louis Stevenson:
A Biography.
By Ian Bell.
296 pp. New York:
Henry Holt & Company. $25. 
 Robert Louis Stevenson was a successful author for only the last six or seven years of his short life (he died in 1894, at the age of 43). Yet in that short span the author of "Treasure Island," "Kidnapped," "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" and "A Child's Garden of Verses" had become for a significant segment of the general public an icon of contemporary rebelliousness: a defier of religious and moral conventions in the guise of an esthete and a consumptive, who wrote as he lived and lived as he wrote. Stevenson's death on a South Sea island and his burial on the local mountaintop, where he was mourned by many of the local inhabitants, was a fittingly romantic ending to so adventuresome a life.
Inevitably there was a reaction, and then a reaction to the reaction, so that from shortly after his death right up to the present, every aspect of Stevenson's life has been the subject of much bitter wrangling. Given the accumulated dross from this bad-tempered controversy, one of the most important services performed by "Dreams of Exile," a short and fast-paced biography by Ian Bell, a former literary editor of The Scotsman, is to give a plausibly sympathetic account of Stevenson's wife of 13 years, for it is on her and on certain members of her family, all of whom outlived the writer by many years, that most of the ill feeling has been concentrated.
Stevenson was born in Edinburgh in 1850, the only son of a prosperous engineer and his often ailing wife, in the middle of the century during which the technological, economic and military might of Britain reached its greatest height. Yet the childhood of this scion of a scientific family was spent largely under the care of a country woman, whose amalgam of punitive hellfire Presbyterianism, fierce Scottish patriotism and local superstitions worked deeply on the child. He was made more susceptible by the days and weeks he was forced to spend at home with Cummy, as she was called, because of recurring bouts of ill health that continued to dog him throughout the rest of his life.
His early and middle 20's were spent in what passed for bohemian Edinburgh, in London and in France. While staying in the village of Barbizon he met Frances (Fanny) Vandegrift Osbourne, an American woman 10 years older than he, who with two small children was consciously seeking an artistic alternative to life with a philandering husband. After a complicated courtship that began slowly, he followed her back to America in August 1879 and married her in California on May 19, 1880.
Stevenson was being supported by his father at the time of their marriage, and it was not until he and Fanny had been back on the other side of the Atlantic for several years that he wrote the works that would make him famous. "Treasure Island" was written first, in 1881, with friendly suggestions from his father and the desire to amuse his stepson, Lloyd, playing key parts in its conception. However, it was the sensational and macabre novel "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" (1886) that made Stevenson known to an adult readership in the hundreds of thousands. Its popularity in the United States led to generous book advances and newspaper commissions that at long last established his financial independence.
In the next seven years, before he died of a brain hemorrhage at his new home on an island in the South Seas, he wrote and published prolifically: most notably "Kidnapped" and its sequel, "David Balfour" (or "Catriona"), both written in a modified Scottish dialect and set in the Scotland of the previous century; a collection of South Sea tales full of sympathy for the contemporaneous exploitation of the islands' residents by outsiders; and an unfinished novel, also set in pre-Industrial Age Scotland, called "The Weir of Hermiston," the father of its title character based on a famous hanging judge of Stevenson's grandfather's day.
Mr. Bell declares himself no scholar: "I am a journalist, and do not pretend to be anything else." He has certainly taken a no-frills approach to Stevenson's life, eschewing all references to other biographies as well as footnotes to many of his quotations and other allusions. Making up for what some readers may feel are such serious drawbacks are his jargon-free, commonsensical and usually persuasive analyses of the book's key figures.
He describes Stevenson at 25, shortly after he met Fanny: "He was, in many important ways, still a boy. Illness had shredded his education and almost killed him, but it had also prolonged his adolescence, excusing him from the pressures of maturity. His life at this period was a series of vacations and jaunts interspersed with sickness and a little light essay writing."
Here is Fanny at the same period: "Fanny was one of those for whom the life of the artist, its affectations, conceits and freedoms, was as important as art itself. She could not help herself. The romance of bohemia -- however either word is defined -- appealed to her."
And here is the key to the marriage: "But Louis, for all his vigor, his insistence on freedom and his temper, responded in a deep and basic way to older women. It is the key to his sexuality, if there is one."
Yet the marriage worked, and Mr. Bell makes it seem, by and large, a good one for both of them. At least until the last two years of Stevenson's life, when she developed mental and physical problems, Fanny was able to be both tender nurse and protective wife, enabling him to be "heroic" (in his struggles against his illnesses) and productive. He in return gave her years of thoroughly bohemian poverty, then fame.
That Stevenson ended up living in the South Seas and surrounded by admiring local inhabitants will seem less romantic to most readers than it apparently does to Mr. Bell. On the other hand there was an endearing courageousness and idealism about Stevenson that may fairly be called romantic, and a few incidents both in Samoa and back in England illustrate that side of him. However, not surprisingly, its most effective expression was in his books. Unfortunately, Mr. Bell takes most of his examples of Stevenson's writings from occasional work: prefaces and dedications, the fairly lame travel writing of the pre "Treasure Island" period or the too-fluent autobiographical essays of Stevenson's later years. To bring Stevenson alive at the height of his "charm and artistic rigor" requires better examples of his art than these.
For instance, in "David Balfour," the central character is responding to the arguments of a high Scottish official that he should put politics first and the welfare of his friends second, for what we would call national security reasons:
" 'You deal with me very frankly, and I thank you for it,' said I. 'I will try on my side to be no less honest. I believe your policy to be sound. I believe these deep duties may lie upon your lordship; I believe you may have laid them on your conscience when you took the oaths of the high office which you hold. But for me, who am just a plain man -- or scarce a man yet -- the plain duties must suffice. I can think but of two things, of a poor soul in the immediate and unjust danger of a shameful death, and of the cries and tears of his wife that still tingle in my head. I cannot see beyond, my lord. It's the way that I am made. If the country has to fall, it has to fall. And I pray God, if this be willful blindness, that He may enlighten me before too late.' "
Many, including Mr. Bell, have argued that had Stevenson lived longer he would have achieved significantly greater stature as a novelist, and the strength of the novel fragment he left behind makes a case for this claim. More important, what he did write is often underestimated, because of its association with tales for the young. "Kidnapped" and "David Balfour" (although not, in my view, "Treasure Island" or "The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde") can be appreciated by the late-20th-century adult reader. This is the case not because our literature lacks able practitioners of narrative, a key reason given by Mr. Bell for Stevenson's continuing popularity, but because a spirit of selfless bravery, of a delight in physical activity, of high-heart edness amid the perils of life, is so rarely found.

HEADLINE: Behind Mexican Rising Lies a Wider Despair

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As you note in "The Other Mexico" (editorial, Jan. 4), the peasant, or campesino uprising in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas does not "herald any wider national insurrection." But neither is it simply, as you phrase it, a protest of "an older Mexico beneath the free-market, modernizing society" of President Salinas de Gortari and his supporters, the rich and well off who dictate economic and political policy. 
 That "other Mexico" includes not merely campesinos from Chiapas to Sonora but most of the urban poor, who survive on meager wages, when they have jobs, and endure unbelievable hardships, even in Mexico City, not infrequently just blocks away from opulent mansions.
Nor is there much evidence to believe that Mr. Salinas's "textbook reforms" will end the terrible inequities in income distribution and wealth in Mexico. To the contrary, the policies you applaud, which have their roots in the 19th century of Porfirio Diaz, who also won the acclaim of powerful Americans, have enshrined social and political distortions in Mexico, the cause of the despair in Chiapas.
The gap between poor and rich is wider today than ever before and getting worse. A decade or so ago, the middle class made up more than 30 percent of the Mexican Republic; today, because of depression and austerity measures adopted, it is no more than one-fifth.
To imply that the error of the Salinas administration lies in its attempt to impose the "Mexican revolution" from above displays ignorance, not only of Mexican history but also of the Constitution of 1917, a charter that challenged the liberal doctrines of David Ricardo and Adam Smith, now so much in vogue. And if, as you maintain, it is in the northern border states that neoliberalism has got the go-ahead, then God help Mexico.
From Tijuana to Matamoros, where more than 2,000 mostly American-owned maquiladoras employ largely young women 14 to 24 years old, paying them 60 cents to $1.20 an hour, more and more of them and their families live in cardboard and plywood shacks lacking electricity and toilets, denied health care and schools for their children.
The uprising in Chiapas may be local, but the underlying feeling of hopelessness, it is well to keep in mind, is widespread in the Mexican Republic.
RAMON EDUARDO RUIZ
Santa Fe, Calif., Jan. 5, 1994

HEADLINE: CLINTON IN EUROPE;
ASSAD HOLDS OUT PROSPECT OF NORMAL TIES WITH ISRAEL AFTER TALKS WITH CLINTON

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Jan. 16

 BODY:
After more than five hours of talks here with President Clinton, President Hafez al-Assad of Syria today held out the prospect of normal relations with Israel soon and said his country was committed to achieving peace in the Middle East this year.
The statement by Mr. Assad was the most explicit sign yet of Syrian willingness to rejoin peace talks with Israel in earnest. Mr. Clinton said immediately that he hoped the statement "would provoke a positive response in Israel." 
 After two years in which the talks between Israel and Syria have stagnated -- their representatives have not met at all for four months -- American officials said the negotiations could resume in Washington this week.
 
What Happens Next Is Unclear
 But beyond the generally warm aura around their news conference, Mr. Assad and Mr. Clinton offered few details about who would do what and when as a next step toward peace. Though their talks included discussions of Israel's control of the Golan Heights, Syria's support of terrorism, water rights and other issues, the Presidents declined to answer specific questions.
American officials had said they did not expect any breakthroughs, and none were announced. But Mr. Assad, standing beside Mr. Clinton, said flatly after the meeting: "We are ready to sign peace now. In honor we fought, in honor we negotiate, and in honor we shall make peace." [Excerpts from their news conference, page A6.]
 
What Is Meant by Normal?
 The meeting between the two men was their first, and the first between American and Syrian leaders since 1990. Its main purpose was to enlist Syria as a full partner in the peace talks, and United States officials said Mr. Assad's statement had given them hope that this goal has been reached.
Mr. Assad did not spell out what he meant by normal relations with Israel. But his mention of that prospect represented a step toward a commitment that Israeli officials have been waiting to hear before considering a withdrawal from the Golan Heights.
The Israeli Government withheld formal reaction until two United States officials, Dennis Ross of the State Department and Martin Indyk of the National Security Council, go to Jerusalem to provide details about what Mr. Clinton and Mr. Assad said in private. The problem with the public remarks, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres said, was that "the tone was too positive to be disappointing, but it was too general to be satisfactory." [Page A6.]
In the words that a senior Clinton Administration official described as "breaking the silence," Mr. Assad spoke repeatedly of his aspirations for peace, but both he and Mr. Clinton were vague on the timing.
"If the leaders of Israel have sufficient courage to respond to this kind of peace, a new era of security and stability with normal peaceful relations shall dawn," President Assad said.
Asked later in the news conference, "Have you decided to sign peace now?" he replied, "Yes, we are ready to sign peace now." But such a peace, he warned, must be one "that secures Arab rights, ends the Israeli occupation and enables our peoples in the region to live in peace, security and dignity."
Until today, the Syrian leader insisted that Israel declare its willingness not only to withdraw from the Golan Heights but also to restore Syrian sovereignty there in return for peace. But he now appears to have moved closer to meeting the longstanding Israeli insistence that Syria acknowledge a willingness for normal relations before Israel agrees to pull back.
 
Clinton's Interpretation
 Indeed, although Mr. Assad did not say so himself, President Clinton said he believed that the Syrian leader had committed himself to seeking a settlement that would provide for open borders, free trade and diplomatic relations, a formula that Israeli leaders have been waiting to hear.
But Mr. Clinton also cautioned, "We did not have any discussions today about the details of any phase of the Middle East peace process, because the other parties are not here present, and it would not have been an appropriate thing to do."
"I believe that President Assad has made a clear, forthright and very important statement on normal, peaceful relations," Mr. Clinton said. "Now, in order to achieve those relations, a peace agreement has to be negotiated in good faith and carried out.
"But this is an important statement -- the first time that there has been a clear expression that there will be a possibility of that sort of relationship."
By meeting with Mr. Assad, whose country remains on a State Department list of terrorist states but who has been eager for close relations with Washington, Mr. Clinton hoped to entice Syria at least to assume a more active role in the peace talks, particularly because the separate accord concluded in September between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization had run into problems.
Flanked by four aides each, the two Presidents met in the Salon des Nations in the International Hotel. The session was scheduled to last two and a half hours, but it ran for almost four and a half, and was followed by a one-on-one meeting between the two leaders that lasted almost an hour.
White House officials said that even those sessions were short by Mr. Assad's standards, and they attached no great significance to the fact that the talks had been prolonged. "It just seemed to develop a rhythm of its own," one official said.
Mr. Clinton got a laugh at the news conference when he was asked about the personal chemistry between the two men and responded: "I had heard a lot about President Assad's legendary stamina in these meetings. He deserves every bit of it."
 
Lockerbie Bombing Mentioned
 Apart from the Middle East peace talks, Mr. Clinton said he had also raised the issue of Syrian support for terrorism. He made it clear that this issue had been among those on which they differed, but said the two countries would establish a formal mechanism, coordinated by Secretary of State Warren Christopher and Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa, to assess the situation in the hope of resolving their differences.
Mr. Clinton also discussed with Mr. Assad the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1987, an attack that killed all 259 people on the plane and 11 on the ground. The relatives of some survivors believe that Syria was responsible, but Administration officials said Mr. Clinton had made it clear that the United States still believed that the two Libyans charged in the case had carried out the attack, and asked Mr. Assad only to provide information in response to new allegations of Syrian complicity.
Another important issue was the presence of Syrian and Israeli troops in Lebanon. At the news conference, Mr. Clinton said: "President Assad agreed that there should be a successful conclusion to the peace process that left Lebanon free and independent as a nation. So there was no difference between us on the objective."
The meeting appeared at least to have laid a strong foundation for progress on Middle Eastern peace when the talks in Washington resume later this month.
In that respect it resembled other gains won by Mr. Clinton in his trip abroad, in which he and other world leaders mapped out proposals to extend eventual NATO membership to Eastern European nations, won an agreement by Ukraine to surrender its nuclear weapons and developed a closer partnership for economic reform in Russia.
 
Details Remain to Be Defined
 But in each case, a wealth of details remain to be defined.
Mr. Clinton headed home to Washington tonight after a trip that began on Jan. 8 and took him to six countries and meetings with two dozen foreign leaders. In Geneva, as in the five other capitals that Mr. Clinton visited, the mood was generally upbeat.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Assad sat across from one another at a long table, where each was flanked by his foreign minister and interpreters. Mr. Assad chatted jovially with the American delegates for the few moments that reporters were allowed in the room.
The two men obliged a group of photographers with a handshake, but Mr. Clinton wore a serious expression as the talks began and through most of the news conference, presumably not wanting to appear too friendly toward a man whom Washington has accused of human rights abuses and terrorism.

HEADLINE: Tinder in Mexico -- A special report.;
In Remote Mexican Village, Roots of Rebellion Are Bared

BYLINE: By TIM GOLDEN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: RIZO DE ORO, Mexico, Jan. 15

 BODY:
There are no guns in this small farming community that pioneers cut from the rain forest some 30 years ago; none, at least, that an outsider is allowed to see.
But signs of the insurrection that has shaken Mexico since the year began are everywhere: in the empty shacks of families who fled their rebel neighbors in terror; in the uniform pants and lace-up boots that have replaced threadbare trousers and ratty sandals; in the swagger of younger men back from their first battles and the prideful things that their fathers say.
 
'Whole World Is Listening'
 "The peasants have awakened and realized that they had to do something in order for them to listen to us," said Carlos Aguilar, 58, who helped to found the community beside a cool mountain stream in the southern state of Chiapas. "Now the whole world is listening." 
 It seems as obvious as it is unspoken that the village rebels were organized and at least partly financed by leaders with a broader political agenda. The central concerns of the men who remain here have to do with their families and their crops and their lack of means to maintain either. The state capital is farther than some of them have traveled; the Government is almost an abstraction.
But even the unwillingness of people in Rizo de Oro to admit being part of the Zapatista National Liberation Army does not keep them from baring the heart of its war on the Government. Here, as in other villages and towns just north of Mexico's border with Guatemala, the ancient struggle of Indian peasants for land and fair treatment has come crashing into the very symbols of hope that President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has worked to create.
The sweeping changes in land-tenure laws by the Government, its free trade agreement with the United States and Canada and even the shortcomings of its huge anti-poverty program, add up to betrayal and nothing more to the people whose wooden shacks dot this lush valley. At a time when economic and political change come to seem almost a constant in some other parts of Mexico, such change still strikes the people who remain here as impossible.
If their poverty seems distant from the lives of many Mexicans in the northern and central regions, where down payments have already been made on Mr. Salinas's promises of greater prosperity, the Zapatistas here also bear a strong resemblance to the striving, self-reliant people in other parts of the country who have drawn hope from the President's programs.
The story of Rizo de Oro is told one way by the families who stayed and another way by those who abandoned their homes on Jan. 6, saying they felt threatened by neighbors who had joined the insurgents. Government officials and others familiar with the area have done little to clarify the accounts.
Still, it is a revealing fragment of the story behind the first Latin American rebel movement to emerge in the post-cold-war era, a force that burst from obscurity in the first moments of the new year to seriously threaten what Mr. Salinas's supporters call his "revolution."
"Unlike the guerrillas in Guatemala, they are not seeking out bases of support among the campesinos, but coming up from them," said Andres Aubry, a French-born anthropologist who has lived and worked in Chiapas for the last two decades, contrasting the leftist rebels who have fought the Guatemalan Government for 32 years with the insurgents who take their name from Emiliano Zapata, the peasant leader of Mexico's 1910 revolution. "In that, they are like Zapata himself."
 
The Rebellion
Guerrillas Strike, Then Fall Back
 In the early hours of their rebellion, the Zapatistas seized the state's second-largest city, San Cristobal de las Casas and three sizable towns: Ocosingo, Altamirano and Las Margaritas.
Since retreating from those places and three more towns through which they passed, the insurgents have for the most part faded back into the remote villages and encampments from which they came. The fighting, in which at least 100 people and perhaps many more have been killed, has died down sharply since the Government declared a unilateral cease-fire on Wednesday.
The rebel leaders, who remain mostly unidentified, did not immediately respond to Mr. Salinas's offer of peace talks and a pardon for repentant peasant rebels.
[The President expanded his offer in a nationally televised speech, saying he would call a special session of Congress to pass a blanket amnesty for all those who committed violent actions in Chiapas before 11 A.M. on Jan. 16. He said subsequent violence would not be covered.]
Neither the rebels nor their commanders appear to be holding as adamantly as before to the idea that violence is the only solution to the problems of Mexico's impoverished Indians.
In a communique dated Jan. 6, the Indigenous Revolutionary Clandestine Committee of the Zapatista General Command described its central objective as "making known to the Mexican people and the rest of the world the miserable conditions in which millions of Mexicans, especially we indigenous people, live and die."
Yet as thousands have fled Zapatista strongholds in the Lacandon rain forest and the highlands to its north and west, and as the rebels have begun to seize privately owned ranches in the area, it has become clear that bringing about a real peace will be far more complex than simply pacifying the region.
The insurgents' complaints of deep social inequities and a lack of democracy suggests they will press for political changes and new forms of economic aid. But the bitter divisions the war has already wrought suggest even broad reforms along those lines might prove insufficient.
"They might be my father, they might be my brother, but what they are doing is wrong," said Alfredo Aguilar, a slight, bedraggled man of 33 who was evacuating his family on Monday from Cruz del Rosario, another hamlet that was taken over by its resident Zapatistas.
 
High Hopes
Building a Home In the Rain Forest
 No one can agree on the date Rizo de Oro was founded, and no one seems to recall why the 33 farmers who came to the valley three decades ago decided to name it ripple or curl of gold. What is not in dispute is the hope with which they began carving a home from the dense forest.
"We thought it was a very pretty place here, that it would serve for us," said Caralampio Aguilar, whose family name is a common one in the area. "We did not realize that the land was so dry."
Many of the men were mixed-blood descendants of Tojolabal Mayan Indians who had worked together on a big farm in what was a common form of indentured servitude.
The Government, with little notion of the fragility of rain forest soils, encouraged what it called "the opening of the agricultural frontier." Thousands of peasants moved onto public property, and in trying to solve land problems in more populated regions of the country, officials pushed the problems toward the impoverished southern border where they would turn more violent.
Within a few years, the men said, their land began to lose its fertility. Of the 50 acres that each farmer was allotted as a member of the new ejido, the state-owned communal farm created under laws that emerged from Zapata's rebellion, few can still coax crops from even half that soil. A plot that produced 20 or 30 sacks of coffee years ago might now yield fewer than 5, many farmers in the area said.
The law permitted landholders to hand down their properties to their children, but not to sell them. Faced with dividing their plots among six or eight children, farmers from Rizo de Oro and nearby San Carlos del Rio asked the Government to expand their ejidos. After years of pleading and paperwork, the request was denied.
"We have struggled and petitioned to make our ejido better," said Hector Alvarez, 19, as he looked out at the trim hedges of hibiscus and bougainvillaea that set one weathered shack off from another. "But they do not hear us."
 
Hopes Dashed
Deepening Mistrust Of Official Efforts
 The economic crisis that exploded in 1982 when Mexico defaulted on its foreign debt payments forced the Government to halt big oil exploration and hydroelectric projects that had been a major source of jobs in Chiapas.
The same year, tens of thousands of refugees began to flood into the area from Guatemala as the army there razed villages and killed thousands of peasants in its war against leftist guerrillas. More than 250 refugees settled in Rizo de Oro, almost doubling its population and bringing low-paid competition for day-labor jobs on larger farms.
The next two governors of Chiapas, Absalon Castellanos, a retired army general, and Patrocinio Gonzalez Garrido, earned reputations for brutality with Mexican and international human rights groups for the way they handled land seizures and protests by Indian and peasant groups.
The peasants did not forget them. General Castellanos was kidnapped from his ranch near Las Margaritas on the first day of the Zapatista rebellion and has not been heard from since; Mr. Gonzalez Garrido, whom Mr. Salinas had brought to Mexico City as his interior minister, was ousted Monday.
In conversations with about two dozen Zapatistas and an equal number of refugees from Rizo de Oro, none spoke of more than run-of-the-mill mistreatment by the authorities. But by the time that Mr. Salinas's anti-poverty initiative, the National Solidarity Program, began to pour aid into Chiapas in 1991, the men who would become rebels had begun to see the few Government projects almost as scars on their land.
"The children are growing up and the land is going down and there is no remedy, no cure," said Caralampio Aguilar, 60, the village's reputed rebel leader and the brother of Carlos Aguilar. The eldest of six brothers, Caralampio said he has struggled for years with his wife and family to make a life here. "We see all that work of many years. She is dead, and I am old and we are still as badly off as ever."
With contributions from seven neighboring communities, six miles of dirt road were built from Poza Rica, a town connected by several more hours of washboard dirt road to the two-lane rural highway that leads to Comitan de Dominguez, the closest city. But the effort -- like that required for a few modest school rooms, a water tank and shrinking agricultural loans -- left deep reserves of bitterness because of what the men described as the stinginess, bureaucratic obstacles and political motivation behind the Government's help.
Two years ago, some of the men in town stopped voting. According to those who fled, some began to form what they described as a local chapter of a group called the Regional Organization of Independent Peoples, or Orpi by its Spanish acronym. They criticized the North American Free Trade Agreement and Mr. Salinas's plan to give peasants permanent title to their ejido plots, the refugees said, and opposed the Government's aid.
"They said they were gifts, like sweet bullets, so that we would be calm and not organize ourselves," one refugee, Ramiro Mendez, said.
 
Seeds of Violence
Shadowy Origins Of Rebel Movement
 According to Jose Roberto Alvarez, 25, and other refugees, it was Caralampio Aguilar who brought the seed of the Zapatista army from another ejido, El Hermosillo, where he had supposedly gone to take Communion.
They said that neither the Roman Catholic deacon there nor the Marist priest who sometimes visited Rizo de Oro would give Communion to villagers who supported the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party. But the refugees said they had only suspicions, not proof, that the two men were involved with the Zapatistas. Some of the men also said they suspected that Guatemalan refugees might have helped the rebels, a charge that officials of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees strongly denied.
Although their stories could not be confirmed, separate groups of refugees in the city of Comitan and the village of Venustiano Carranza gave similar accounts of the Zapatistas' emergence, and their stories coincided broadly with those of refugees from three other villages in the area.
Government officials now say the Zapatista army grew most directly from a tiny and now-defunct guerrilla force called the Armed Forces of National Liberation and a larger, regional political group called the Emiliano Zapata Independent National Peasant Alliance, or Anciez, which went underground last spring. But peasants from three other villages besides Rizo de Oro said the Zapatistas in their villages also organized first in different legal peasant groups that may not have been tied directly to the rebel movement.
Jorge Morales, the son of a landowner, said that long before most people in Rizo de Oro knew anything about a Zapatista army, Caralampio Aguilar "began to invite people into his home, in a nice way, and he began to put things into them."
On the instructions of Mr. Aguilar, the future Zapatistas built a wooden "safe house" beside the house in which his family lived and a radio was installed inside. Strangers whose names the refugees never learned came to the house, and meetings and dances were held there frequently.
Some of the men sold their cows to buy .22-caliber rifles. Mr. Mendez said the youngest Aguilar brother, Cresencio, got drunk and told of three-day military training sessions at camps in the mountains.
 
Call to Arms
Guerrillas Summon Peasants to Battle
 Several of the people who fled the Zapatistas said they complained of the rebels' preparations last year to Romeo Suarez Culebro, Mayor of Las Margaritas, the municipality that encompasses Rizo de Oro. Two refugees from other villages said they had done the same, but the Mayor, a representative of Mr. Salinas's party who was at a New Year's Eve party at the Lion's Club when rebels seized his town, angrily denied this.
Nearly shouting, he said, "The peasants never complained about this!"
In an account that people from other villages seemed almost to repeat, the refugees said about 14 younger men from Zapatista families left Rizo de Oro on the night of Dec. 30. Their fathers all but moved into the safe house. The men returned on the night of Jan. 4, saying they had participated in the taking of Las Margaritas.
"They went to the safe house and told about what they had done," Jose Roberto Alvarez said. "Then at about 2 in the morning, the dance began."
On the morning of Jan. 6, Caralampio Aguilar blew a hollowed cow's horn to call the men of the village to a meeting in the collapsing, tin-roofed structure that serves as the ejido hall. Four men with guns stood behind him.
"They said they were ordered to report publicly on the war they had provoked and to invite us to join," Mr. Mendez recalled as two dozen other refugees huddled around him in a makeshift shelter in Venustiano Carranza. Then another man spoke, Jose Roberto Alvarez said: "He said the war had begun and we all had to participate because it was for the good of the people."
 
Aftermath
Some Families Flee In Fear of Violence
 After a short meeting at the edge of the road, 34 of the men decided instead to take their families and leave. The families of 21 Zapatistas stayed. Although the refugees said their lives had not been threatened directly, they felt as though they had. Rolando Mendez, a shy, 20-year-old man, went for his wife, Carmen, at the home of her father, one of the Aguilar brothers.
"When I said I was not going to stay with them," Mr. Mendez said, almost whispering, "they said they were going to keep her."
Many of the men who left Rizo de Oro appeared to view their Government with resentment like that of the rebels, and to see their future with similar despair. The difference, said Ramiro Mendez, was that they did not see guns as a solution.
"Because I have only 50 acres and five children, it does not mean that I want to die."
On Saturday, a sentry in an olive-drab uniform stood at the end of the road as visitors to the village arrived; all of the elder men in the town were said to be out working in the fields, one young man said.
The same explanation was given when three reporters and a photographer first came to the valley on Tuesday. But after repeated requests, six hours of waiting and what appeared to be long meetings in the safe house, a dozen men marched out in single file, Caralampio Aguilar at their lead.
Asked about the refugees, he said vaguely that they had fled out of fear; he did not directly associate either the fear or the men who stayed in the town with the insurgency. But asked if he and the others had been sought out by the rebels, he said, "It was we who went to look for them."
As the sun set, the pretense began to fade a bit more. As he addressed a question about how the rebellion might end and what might happen to the village, Carlos Aguilar seemed close to tears.
"At least they have heard us," he said.

HEADLINE: Internet Users Get Access To S.E.C. Filings Fee-Free

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
In a two-year experiment that begins today, documents filed electronically to the Securities and Exchange Commission from public companies will be available to users of Internet, a global network of computer networks.
Documents obtainable on the service include annual reports, 10-K filings, proxy statements and other information valued by traders and investors. These documents are already available electronically through commercial data suppliers, including Mead Data Central Inc. of Dayton, Ohio, but the new Internet service is the first to make them available without additional charges. 
 The new service is the most ambitious experiment so far by the Clinton Administration to make much Government information widely available to the public at minimum cost. Although access to Internet itself can be costly, millions of people can tap into it through commercial, Government and educational computer networks. Once a computer user is connected to Internet, a giant global network that links millions of large and small computers so they can share information, there is typically no extra fee for document transfers.
 
Financed by Taxes
 "We have a policy that Government information ought to be made available at only the marginal cost to provide the information," said Tom Kalil, who coordinates science and technology policy at the White House's National Economic Council. "We view this type of information dissemination as one of the ways we can address the info 'haves and have-nots' issue. Since taxpayers have already paid for it, the idea of making it available was appealing."
The cost of providing the S.E.C. data to Internet users is being underwritten by a National Science Foundation grant to the New York University Business School. In turn, the contract for operation of the computer data bases is with a not-for-profit company, the Internet Multicasting Service of Washington.
 
Coordination With S.E.C.
 Carl Malamud, the principal of Internet Multicasting, said the S.E.C. is charging $78,000 a year to supply his company with data tapes of each day's filings. The fee, he said, basically covers the cost of the tapes and messenger fees. Mr. Malamud said the S.E.C. has projected that as many as 50 gigabytes of data -- 50 billion characters of information -- will be supplied each year. An average S.E.C. document contains about 3,000 characters, he said.
Mr. Malamud said that although they offered the same raw data, his Government-subsidized service is not in conflict with commercial information services like Mead Data. In return for its higher fees, Mead Data provides search software that makes it easier to find a particular document, and it guarantees its customers access to the data within minutes of the time the document is filed.
"Our data is 24 hours later than theirs, and we are not massaging the data to the extent that Mead is," Mr. Malamud said, although a goal of the experiment is to fashion easier search and retrieval mechanisms for the raw S.E.C. data.
Also, only 50 Internet users can gain access to the S.E.C. data base at one time, he said, cautioning that "if you were betting your business on getting a document right away, you shouldn't bet on us."
Computer users with access to Internet can get more information by sending an electronic-mail message to "mail[at]town.hall.org" requesting help. Those without Internet access can telephone (202) 628-2044.

HEADLINE: Father Returns To Claim Estate Of Child He Left

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WARWICK, R.I., Jan. 16

 BODY:
A 38-year-old man who left his wife and daughter more than a decade ago and owes tens of thousands of dollars in child support is asking a court for half the estate of his daughter, who died last summer at the age of 15.
The father, James E. Brindamour, is seeking half of the $350,000 an insurance company paid after his daughter, Colleen, was killed when a pickup in which she was a passenger skidded off a road and crashed into a tree. 
 The money came from a settlement in a lawsuit brought by Mr. Brindamour's estranged wife, Rose Brindamour, against the driver of the truck and its owner.
 
'It's Immoral'
 But Mrs. Brindamour, a nurse's aide, says her husband does not deserve to share in the settlement. "I don't want him to have a dime of her money," she said in an interview today at her home here. "He's trying to get half and then use part of the proceeds to pay me off. It's immoral."
Mrs. Brindamour says her husband owes her $69,000 in child support payments. Mr. Brindamour's lawyer calculates that his client owes $15,000 to $20,000.
On Friday, about 20 of Colleen's high school classmates picketed the Kent County Courthouse as lawyers for the Brindamours met with Judge Francis Darigan of Superior Court, who set a hearing for Jan. 28.
Under Rhode Island law, if a child's death results from a wrongful action, the parents can file claims based on the extent to which the child's death affects them. Under that standard, Mrs. Brindamour said, her absent husband is not entitled to any money.
But Mr. Bridamour says that despite his lack of contact with his daughter and his admitted failure to pay child support, as her biological father he is entitled to half her estate.
"I wanted to see my daughter over the years, but Rose prevented me from doing so," Mr. Brindamour, a machine-tool operator, said, an assertion Mrs. Brindamour denied.
Howard I. Lipsey, a Rhode Island judge who is chairman of the Family Court Committee of the Family Law Section of the American Bar Association, said Mr. Brindamour "has a prima facie right to get the money," but that Mrs. Brindamour is raising new legal questions. He added that whatever the outcome of the case, Mr. Brindamour would be required to pay all the child support he owed.
The battle over the estate began a month after Colleen's death, when Mrs. Brindamour sued the driver of the pickup and his mother, who owned the truck.
A few weeks later, on the advice of her lawyer, she filed for divorce. She had not filed for divorce earlier, she said, because "I just forgot about it" and there was not enough money to hire a lawyer.
Since shortly after her husband left her, Mrs. Brindamour has lived with a man named Gary Gallagher. Colleen's friends said she had referred to Mr. Gallagher as "my father."
Several months before Colleen's death, a judge told Mr. Brindamour he would be put in prison if he did not pay $8,000 of what he owed. Mr. Brindamour, who was unemployed at the time, fled the state. In late November, he returned to Rhode Island, surrendered and spent a week in jail. He was released after paying $1,000 to his wife.
Since Dec. 20, Mr. Brindamour has been paying the $75-a-week support he was ordered to begin paying in 1983.
 
'He's Not a Monster'
 Mr. Brindamour's lawyer, Dennis Baluch, said his client had a history of alcohol problems, but added, "He's not a monster by any stretch of the imagination."
He said his client asserted that until three years ago he had paid his child support in cash and that he owed no more than $20,000.
Mrs. Brindamour said she had received about $650 in 10 years.
According to court records, Colleen was 4 when her parents married, and the marriage lasted only about eight months. In July 1983, Mrs. Brindamour was granted a restraining order against her husband, who she said had kicked her and threatened to kill her.
In 1989, Mr. Brindamour pleaded no contest to sexually molesting an 11-year-old relative in Rhode Island and was given an eight-year suspended sentence.
Mrs. Brindamour said she planned to use the settlement to finish nursing school and have an operation to reverse the tubal ligation she had undergone a few months before her daughter's death.
"I would like to try to have a baby and try to start over," she said. She said she also wanted to use $8,000 to buy a stone marker for Colleen's grave, which is now marked by a wooden cross.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
'Reinventing' New York, From a Strategist's View

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts 

 BODY:
ATTEMPTS at "reinventing Rudy" into a gentler politician may have been overtaken by the crush of events that have already tested his administration during its first two weeks in office. But David Osborne, the national guru of "reinventing government," says that the Mayor can still revive his campaign agenda of fulfilling and enforcing the social contract.
"Do you have a choice?" said Mr. Osborne, co-author with Ted Gaebler of "Reinventing Government" (Addison-Wesley, 1992), which was written for public managers but which was seized as a largely nonideological bible by aspiring politicians. 
 "You've got a $2 billion deficit after how many years of struggling to patch together budgets in a recession?" he said of the budget gap projected for the next fiscal year. "Everyone I talk to in New York City says they're thinking about moving away, that the quality of life is going rapidly downhill. So, can the city afford not to do it?"
Mr. Osborne acknowledges, though, that his prescriptions for delivering basic city services more efficiently will be harder to do in New York.
"It's harder to do in New York than in a smaller place and in a place where politics is more rational and where corruption is less of a problem and you tend to need more red tape or think you do," he said the other day from one of those smaller places, his home in Essex, Mass., population 3,000. "And in New York, the unions tend to be more powerful."
Mr. Osborne conferred twice with Mr. Giuliani, at his request, before the election. Since November, responding to a request from recruiters for the new Mayor, he submitted the names of about two dozen heroes of the reinventing government crusade as possible appointees. None, he said, has been given major jobs so far (although the Mayor, his Parks Commissioner, Henry Stern, and Public Advocate Mark Green, weigh in publicly with proposed reforms).
The relative inexperience in city government of Mr. Giuliani's appointees remains the administration's greatest vulnerability. But while the Mayor has a lot to learn, he and his deputies also may be emboldened by their naivete. As Felix G. Rohatyn said when he resigned as chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation after nearly two decades of nudging the bureaucracy, the job demanded a naif who still harbors illusions about what can be accomplished.
The challenges are daunting. Rikers Island has a higher number of admissions than the City University system (86,000 detentions at the city jail last year compared with 28,000 freshmen entering all of the university's colleges). The disparity between the higher infant mortality rates among blacks and the lower rates among whites is widening.
In 1991, the most recent year for which comparable figures are available, New York City spent $193 for every $1,000 in personal income earned by city residents -- 45 percent more than the $133 average for all local governments. (More than half the $193 is spent on operating budgets for education, social services, housing and health).
Because the city collected only about $100 per $1,000 in personal income from Federal and state aid, bond issues and various fees -- a marginally higher figure than the national average -- the difference was derived from taxes. A City Planning Department analysis found that city taxes took $96 for every $1,000 of personal income, more than twice the national average.
"In New York, there are pockets of experimentation here and there, but not across the board," said Mr. Osborne, who heads the nonprofit, Washington-based Alliance for Redesigning Government. "New York does quite a lot of performance measurement, but it's not used to drive decisions. Most of the principles in our book have been used in one place or another in New York City government and have worked, but no one has tried to revamp the city's management."
Among the success stories he cites are Operation Scorecard, which measures street cleanliness, and the Sanitation Department's vehicle repair program.
Mr. Osborne disagrees with the notion of radically "disinventing" government -- divesting itself of responsibility for certain services.
"Government's most fundamental role is to steer society, to make sure that problems get solved," he said, adding, though, that the business community and neighborhood organizations often can deliver services and solve problems more efficiently.
What he proposes is "entrepreneurial government," which he defines as a systematic strategy to imaginatively improve efficiency and effectiveness. Competition with private companies. More aggressive management. Accountability. Incentives. Decentralization. Community empowerment. Regionalism.
New York may be unique, but not ungovernable, Mr. Osborne said, and its size is not the biggest obstacle.
"The single most important variable in determining whether a community can reinvent its government is: Is it a necessity, is there a crisis? When I listen to New Yorkers talk about life in their city, there's a crisis. The second big condition you need to make major change is leadership, and just the fact that New Yorkers elected a Republican Mayor says they want big changes."
Would he single out one goal? "I would tell Mayor Giuliani not to think that way, that's what all the politicians say," Mr. Osborne said. "I would say, stop and develop a strategy that has things building on each other and puts the right people in charge of the right pieces. Otherwise, politicians produce a lot of motion by the time they're running for re-election, but it hasn't added up to a lot."
