HEADLINE: Man at The Side of (Not Behind) Whitman

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 14

 BODY:
John R. Whitman is not shy. It turns out his Greta Garbo performance during his wife's gubernatorial campaign was part of a political strategy and not at all reflective of a retiring personality.
Sitting with his wife in her transition office, sipping Diet Pepsi and laughing freely at his own jokes, Mr. Whitman talked without prodding about Christine Todd Whitman, her campaign, the next four years and his much-discussed role in it all. In those long, weary months on the trail, Mr. Whitman, 49 years old, steadfastly avoided the spotlight, professing his desire not to become a public figure. He did so, he says, because he wanted to avoid becoming an issue. But now the campaign is over. 
 "I have to now sort of admit that I exist," he said.
"I've been trying to deny it for 20 years," joked his wife.
Mr. Whitman, who is a financial consultant, is his wife's closest adviser and the core of a close-knit family that surrounds the Governor-elect. There are her children, Kate, 16 years old, and Taylor, 14, both attending boarding school in Massachusetts. There is her brother, Webster B. (Danny) Todd, a Montana rancher and former New Jersey Assemblyman who ran the day-to-day operations of the Whitman campaign until he was moved aside in favor of a political consultant, Edward J. Rollins Jr. Mr. Todd was the visible family member, a rugged, colorful character who wore ascots and cowboy boots, dished out homey quotes and snarled at reporters.
 
Subject of Questions and Rumors
 But it was the elusive Mr. Whitman who was the subject of the most questions, and was the focus of rumors that he was the real engine behind his wife's campaign.
"The reports of my influence were greatly exaggerated," Mr. Whitman said last week during a 40-minute conversation as peppered with the plural "we" as with the singular "I."
Christine Todd Whitman, who takes office Tuesday as the first female governor of New Jersey, is the product of a politically prominent New Jersey family. Her father, the late Webster B. Todd, was a builder whose projects included Rockefeller Center and Radio City Music Hall as well as a powerful figure in the state and national Republican parties. Her mother, the late Eleanor Schley Todd, was head of the New Jersey Federation of Republican Women.
Mr. Whitman's family was also immersed in politics. His father was a circuit court judge in New York. His grandfather, Charles S. Whitman Sr., was Governor of New York from 1914 to 1916.
Mr. Whitman, a Vietnam veteran who was twice awarded the Bronze Star for valor in combat, said he knew of his wife's ambitions when he married her. "Our marriage vows could have said in sickness and in health and in politics, given Christie's family tradition and mine," he said.
They appear to be a close couple. They finish each other's sentences. She frowns slightly when he says something potentially embarrassing and firmly reminds him that she can speak for herself whenever he starts to define her role in promoting New Jersey.
Mr. Whitman has the unrestrained manner of the truly confident. His criticism of the Florio administration, which he described as deadly to New Jersey's economy, allows no softening for the defeated. He cracks jokes and laughs wholeheartedly at them. One example: "I said to her if she divorces me, I get half of New Jersey. She said, 'I'll gerrymander it.' "
During a photo shoot, Mr. Whitman playfully wraps his wife in a suggestive embrace. She swats at his hands and tells him, laughingly, to stop.
Mr. Whitman formerly worked in the venture capital unit at Citicorp and was chairman and chief executive officer of Prudential-Bache Interfunding, a group that financed leveraged buyouts. In 1992 he started his own investment consulting business, Broken Bridge Inc., in which he advises companies on how to obtain financing. He declined to name any of his clients.
 
Investments Pay Off
 The Whitmans are wealthy and got wealthier through Mr. Whitman's financial dealings on Wall Street in the late 1980's and early 1990's, according to their financial records. In 1990 the couple reported income of more than $4 million. A large chunk of that came from the sale of stock.
In 1992, the Whitmans reported more than $3.5 million in income. Mr. Whitman made nearly $268,000 from a profit-sharing program at Citicorp Capital Investors Limited and $1.5 million from his own business. The couple also made $1.8 million from the sale of government bonds and stocks.
It was, in part, this knack for financial dealings that Mr. Whitman worried would be somehow used against his wife by the Florio campaign.
"They could have brought up the fact that I've obviously done very well," he said. "I've worked on Wall Street -- a whole bunch of things people can say were unpopular. I could be an example of the excesses of the 80's."
 
Matters of Speculation
 The Florio campaign strategy, as interpreted by Mr. Whitman, was to take the focus off Mr. Florio and his $2.8 billion tax increase. The Whitmans said they wanted to keep voters focused on Mr. Florio, and the choice offered by Mrs. Whitman.
"Nobody was going to vote for me," Mr. Whitman said, making it clear that the campaign wanted to insure that no one voted against him.
"We wanted to be sure it was clear that it was Jim Florio and Christie Whitman. It wasn't Christie and her alter ego and Svengali, John."
But Mr. Whitman's stealth performance did not keep observers from both parties from speculating about his influence over the campaign. Mrs. Whitman's impressive, though unsuccessful, 1990 race against United States Senator Bill Bradley was run almost exclusively by the Whitmans with help from Mr. Todd. Mr. Whitman acted as the finance manager in that campaign.
Given Mr. Whitman's financial background, pundits speculated that Mrs. Whitman's surprising proposal to slash the state income tax 30 percent over three years held more of the husband's fingerprints than the wife's, especially since Mrs. Whitman had earlier dismissed talk of a tax cut as a "cynical" election-year ploy.
 
Taking No Role
 Both Whitmans said sexism and egotism fed the rumors of his exaggerated role in the campaign.
"A lot of that came from the inside people," Mrs. Whitman said, referring to fellow Republicans. "I think it grated on some of them that a woman was saying, 'No, we're not going to do that.' They said it has to be the men behind her who don't know what they're doing, because this is such a good idea of mine."
Mr. Whitman said he will have no role -- official or otherwise -- during Mrs. Whitman's governorship. If Mrs. Whitman asks for his opinion on an issue, he said, he will give it. Otherwise, he said, he will stay out of state affairs.
"I will carry on my business, which is an investment business and consulting business, with a very careful eye to not doing business with anyone who has something to do with state government," he said.
Mr. Whitman runs his business from Pontefract, the couple's 237-acre farm in Somerset County. Mrs. Whitman has said she plans to use Drumthwacket, the governor's mansion, during the week but said the family will remain at home for the foreseeable future.
 
Sharing Opinions
 Mr. Whitman knows his business is likely to come under close scrutiny as he begins life in the biggest public fishbowl in New Jersey. During the campaign, the couple was reluctant to release their tax returns, but relented under pressure from the Florio campaign. Releasing tax returns is not required under state law.
Mrs. Whitman said voters can be assured that she is running the show. While she often asks her husband for his advice, she does not always take it, she said. "We don't have an embargo about talking about things facing us," she said. "But to say his opinion is always the one that wins -- that doesn't happen."
Sal Russo, a Washington political consultant who worked on Mrs. Whitman's Republican primary campaign, said voters have yet to realize how thoughtful and tough-minded Mrs. Whitman really is.
"She pretty much calls her own shots," he said. "John's not going to play a Hillary Clinton."
 
Not a Consensus Builder
 Mr. Whitman said that his role will develop over time and that he is eager to do what he can to promote New Jersey and support its institutions.
During the campaign, the Whitmans made an effort to shield their children from the daily slings and arrows of politics, even taking a week off during the summer to go biking in Idaho, a decision that drew criticism from fellow Republicans who felt Mrs. Whitman should have been concentrating on the election. During the campaign, Kate Whitman recorded a radio commercial praising her mother, but the two teen-agers were rarely seen on the campaign trail.
Mr. Whitman said having the children attend school in Massachusetts maintains a semblance or normalcy for them. "They can behave like everybody else does," he said.
Asked if he himself had ever considered seeking political office, he said no. "I am not the kind of person who is electable," he said.
Why not?
"I really believe if you run something, you run it and you're responsible for it," he said. "You decide what you're going to do and you do it. I don't need to go and talk to 27 or 46 or whatever the Legislature numbers are to ask them to come along."
Besides, he added, "I've never been really good at convincing other people to come happily along."
Mrs. Whitman agreed that consensus-building was not her husband's strong suit.
"You have a lot of strong suits, but not that one," she said warmly.
"I like making money," he said, and laughed.

LENGTH: 1545 words

HEADLINE: United Asset: Little-Known Financial Giant

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
As Norton Reamer, president of United Asset Management, puts it, "$100 billion may sound big, but it's really not a lot of money."
And from Mr. Reamer's perspective, his statement does make some sense. As the founder of a one-of-a-kind holding company, Mr. Reamer has been busily acquiring independent money management firms -- 39 of them, at last count, with $100 billion in assets at his fingertips. 
 But that is a pittance, by some calculations. Money management, a highly fragmented and entrepreneurial business, measures itself in the trillions. There are now some $7 trillion in mutual and pension funds invested on behalf of others. And Mr. Reamer's stable of assets, while large, represents less than a 2 percent market share.
 So, with the enthusiasm of a carnival barker, Mr. Reamer, a pillar of the money management community here, says that $100 billion is not enough. As money gushes into investment and retirement plans of all types, Mr. Reamer wants his cut. He is offering hard cash -- and an immediate windfall -- to these small and highly profitable firms. Why, he boasts, he is out shopping and there are some 300 firms on his list.
"There are only two kinds of money management companies out there now," Mr. Reamer said in an interview at his spacious office overlooking Boston harbor. "Those part of United Asset now, and those that will be a part of United Asset later."
United Asset Management, close to Merrill Lynch & Company and J. P. Morgan & Company in asset size, is a little-known financial giant. Its home office in the cramped financial district has only 33 employees. But that is because the Boston concern is only a holding company for a global operation.
More than a decade ago, Mr. Reamer, then president of Putnam Investments, came upon the notion of starting a money management conglomerate, not unlike, he said, advertising and accounting giants built by acquisition. He would take an equity stake in independent mom-and-pop money management firms -- which are paid to invest for pension and mutual funds. This arrangement allowed executives of these small firms to "cash out" their illiquid holdings in return for giving, typically, about half their annual revenues to United Asset.
As a further inducement, Mr. Reamer promised to keep his hands off these entrepreneurial ventures -- the firms set their own salaries and operate as before. The words "United Asset" are never on their doors or literature.
"When I first floated the idea of United Asset, everyone thought it was pretty kooky," Mr. Reamer said. "But, there is no one quite like United Asset Management. I knew that money managers love managing money and will do that as long as we don't make it unpleasant for them."
This kooky idea has some pretty compelling economics. The money management business is expected to have double-digit growth well into the future, fueled by an aging population and the growth of pension and mutual fund assets. With little invested in the way of plant and equipment and other fixed costs, most money management firms are able to generate large sums of money from the brain power of a small number of people.
 
 
Robust Growth
 By hitching to this profitable and growing business, United Asset, since going public in 1987, has enjoyed 30 percent annual growth in profits, 27 percent annual growth in revenues and a 50 percent annual rise in dividend payouts. In 1992, the company earned $35 million on revenues of $295 million.
But normal accounting measures fail to capture what sets United Asset apart.
The company's strength is its cash flow and, under controversial accounting approaches recently upheld by the Supreme Court and included in President Clinton's tax package, United Asset can completely write off the cost of its acquisitions. This means United Asset gets to reduce from taxes the amount it spends to buy money management firms.
As a result of this tax break, it has an enormously powerful cash flow -- what Mr. Reamer calls the "green hose" -- that must be spent on something. United Asset's cash flow exceeds its net income: in 1993, its cash flow reached $100 million. This money has only three uses: dividends, acquisitions or paying down the company's modest debt.
 
 
'Free Cash Flow'
 "Their cash flow is powerful and huge," said Jeff Adams, a vice president at Denver Investment Advisers, which owns $50 million in United Asset shares. "And, it is free cash flow since they have no capital demands. That, plus the good demographics of money management, means they will grow 10 percent a year without doing anything."
To many, buying shares in United Asset is like buying an option on the stock market. And some say United Asset may face rough times in a bear market. James Rogers, a New York investor, is one of them. "United Asset is a put-together company and most eventually will fall apart," Mr. Rogers said. He also dismisses the tax write-offs as "water" on the balance sheet, which, if removed, gives United Asset a negative net worth. "Everyone knows this is a house of cards that will fall apart, especially in the next bear market," he said.
This view is shared by many short-sellers -- investors who bet stocks will fall. Short interest in United Asset recently reached a new high of about 1.1 million, or 4 percent, of all the company's shares.
But United Asset and most analysts dismiss this view. They point out that the company grows in two ways: as the dollar value of the assets managed increases and as United Asset makes more acquisitions. The greater the assets under management, the greater the revenues sent to the holding company.
 
 
Domestic Equities
 To begin with, domestic equities represent only 54 percent of all the company's assets and its recent acquisition of global money management and real estate firms are part of a strategy to diversify from such equities. In addition, the corporate pension plans that represent the bulk of United Asset's assets are typically structured so that if the securities in those plans drop in value because of falling markets, the corporations that sponsor the pension plans must make up any shortages.
"The shorts don't understand the fundamentals of this business," John Adams, an analyst at Adams, Harkness in Boston, said. "If assets go down, corporate pension sponsors must pony up more."
United Asset is further protected by the revenue-sharing arrangements with its acquired companies. United Asset takes a portion of the acquired company's revenues -- typically 40 to 50 percent. The rest is kept by the acquired firm to cover costs, most typically salaries. If the markets and business fall, the acquired firms must cut expenses out of their own revenues. "United Asset can never lose money," said John McNamara, a United Asset executive vice president.
More critical to United Asset's future, however, is the issue of succession at its acquired firms. Once the money management firm's top management is bought out, the question arises of how to motivate the junior ranks.
 
 
'Right Financial Incentives'
 After all, the older managers will retire and a younger generation will take over -- but in a company without the same chance to reap a lucrative one-time windfall. And money management is a people business; keeping talented people happy and well paid matters. Mr. Reamer, who took home nearly $900,000 in 1992, claims he is the 41st highest-paid person at United Asset.
"The long-term question at United Asset is whether they have bought a perpetuating or a depleting asset," Michael Blumstein, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, said. "United Asset gives a generation of money managers the opportunity to take the money out of their firm and yet still run the show. But the question is whether the younger people are given the right financial incentives."
That issue is well understood. "The beauty of our arrangement with United Asset is that it allows the key owners of our firm to run our firm, yet reap financial security," said George B. Kauffman, a principal in Sirach Capital Management Inc., one of the acquired firms. "But as senior people we've got to be willing to share the rewards with those junior to us."
 
 
New Starting Mutual Funds
 For his part, Mr. Reamer said he was trying to help. Despite United Asset's avowed hands-off policy, the holding company has decided to start a new set of mutual funds, called the Regis Funds, to help its firms tap into the rapidly expanding 401(k) retirement market. Mr. Reamer hopes this will give the acquired firms another product line to generate future revenues -- and salaries.
Under the Regis plan, a pool of institutional funds will be plucked out of the various acquired firms to form the Regis family. The Regis Funds can be marketed by all 39 firms, which are otherwise ill-equipped to compete in this market with Fidelity and Vanguard.
Given the fact that the acquiring companies, so far, profess to be satisfied and that none have been ill-fated acquisitions, many have raised the question of why no one else has copied the United Asset model, especially because there are so many money management firms that may want to cash out.
To this, Mr. Reamer has a simple answer: "Damned if I know."

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Debate on Health Care May Depend on 'Crisis'

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 16

 BODY:
When different people say, "There isn't a crisis in health care," they mean different things. But none are particularly helpful to the Clinton Administration's hopes for enacting sweeping health care legislation.
When Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York, said it on Jan. 9, he meant that he would rather deal with welfare legislation first, although he has often acknowledged that the health care system is a mess and needs fundamental change. 
 Even so, after that appearance on the NBC News program "Meet the Press," in which Mr. Moynihan also denounced Western inaction in Bosnia and urged President Clinton to accept an independent counsel and make his Whitewater papers public, it was the Senator's health care line that troubled the White House the most.
That was because Mr. Moynihan had echoed a phrase that more and more Republicans are using. They are still not sure what they want, but those who are certain that they don't want anything like Mr. Clinton's plan have found a unifying way to argue that his proposal goes too far.
When Bill Kristol, a Republican strategist who heads something called the Project for the Republican Future, made the "no crisis" argument in December, he was basically offering tactical advice, saying Republicans had to calm the country or something sweeping might be enacted.
Not that he was all that calm himself in the December memorandum in which he first gave visibility to the dismissive approach; he called Mr. Clinton's style "a brazen campaign of fear-mongering" and a "campaign of fright."
It was up to Republicans, Mr. Kristol said, to "remind the nation, point by point, that it currently enjoys the finest, most comprehensive and most generous system of medical care in world history."
But lest they sound like Pollyanna and perpetuate the Republican image of not caring about domestic problems, he urged Republicans to acknowledge that the problems were "serious"; they just did not constitute a crisis.
To some Senate Republicans, those differentiations are just plain silly and basically reinforce the assumptions that have made the public trust the Democrats but not the Republicans on health care.
Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island, for example, insists that Mr. Kristol is plain wrong. Mr. Chafee, chief sponsor of the most comprehensive of the Republican health care bills, says that when serious students consider rising health costs for business and government and the 15 percent of the public who lack insurance, then the word "crisis" is appropriate.
As to suggestions that some tinkering here and there -- a favorite Washington response when the complexities of a problem first attract attention -- will be enough, Mr. Chafee replies, "What seem to be simple solutions simply won't work."
But there is concern among supporters of both the Clinton plan and the Chafee proposal that the argument that there is no crisis will prove a siren song, especially as the economy improves and fears of unemployment and the consequent loss of health insurance decline.
They fear that the slogan will weaken the allegiance of some Republicans who were reluctant supporters of Mr. Chafee. They think that right now the public supports the idea of making sure that all Americans have health insurance. But they worry that as the "no crisis" argument is made more and more there will be less pressure on supporters of other plans to shift to explicit support of universal health care coverage.
Perhaps the biggest puzzlement of all is what Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader from Kansas, means when he says "there isn't a crisis," as he did on Jan. 2 after previously scoffing at Mr. Kristol, a former aide to Vice President Dan Quayle, as a nobody who had never run for public office.
Mr. Dole's view matters because everybody expects him to play a central role in the back-room legislating the Senate will need if it is to pass a bill. So the Senator's comment could be read with concern by Mr. Clinton's allies, seen as a hint that he was retreating from his own commitment to universal health care.
More likely, Mr. Dole was trying to convey that there might not be a need for all of the controls in the Clinton plan, but that there were enough individuals and businesses in serious trouble to create a need for deep reform, and a reform that would promise universal health care coverage.

HEADLINE: Leading Russian Reformer Quits, Questioning the Cabinet's Policies

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 16

 BODY:
A day after President Clinton left Moscow, carrying assurances of continued Russian market reforms, their architect, Yegor T. Gaidar, announced today that he was quitting the Government because he did not think that it would pursue a sensible economic policy.
"I cannot serve in the Government and at the same time be in opposition to it," Mr. Gaidar said, citing recent decisions made without Cabinet approval that he said contradicted his efforts to stabilize the economy and bring the budget deficit under control. 
 His resignation, in a letter to President Boris N. Yeltsin, is a considerable embarrassment for Mr. Clinton, who cited Mr. Yeltsin's "strong assurances of his intention to continue the reform process" as one of the most important achievements of their three-day summit meeting.
 
Yeltsin's Pledge to Clinton
 Mr. Yeltsin, in his joint news conference with Mr. Clinton on Friday, said, "As regards reforms, we will be resolute and radical." But by then, according to Mr. Gaidar, Mr. Yeltsin knew of his impending resignation after a long private talk on Thursday.
[Heading back to the United States from Geneva, Mr. Clinton said that Mr. Yeltsin had told him several days ago that Mr. Gaidar was going to resign. "We are not going to reverse our reform course," Mr. Clinton quoted Mr. Yeltsin as saying. "But we do want to cushion the impact of it."
[Secretary of State Warren Christopher seemed to play down Mr. Gaidar's resignation. "I'm not sure it's a bad thing that there are one or two changes," he said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press."]
Yet if the Finance Minister, Boris G. Fyodorov, who is said to be considering resigning, joins Mr. Gaidar in leaving the Government, that would shake already dwindling Western confidence in Moscow's commitment to financial stability and structural change.
Mr. Gaidar said he had no assurances that he would be able to control financial and economic policy, even if he kept his posts as one of four FirstDeputy Prime Ministers and as Economics Minister. He refused, he suggested today, to serve as window dressing for a sharp turn in Government policy toward higher spending and inflation that would inevitably continue to be described by Russian officials as "reform."
"I cannot answer for reforms without being able to prevent unwise actions of the Government, without possessing the necessary levers to persistently pursue the economic policy I am convinced is correct," Mr. Gaidar wrote Mr. Yeltsin.
He objected specifically to a projected monetary union of Russia with Belarus and plans for a new $500 million parliamentary center.
Mr. Yeltsin and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin are expected to meet Monday to discuss the resignation, and may try to persuade Mr. Gaidar to change his mind. Mr. Gaidar would insist on assurances of control over economic policy that are unlikely to be forthcoming, however, after Mr. Gaidar's Russia's Choice party came in second to the party of the caustic nationalist, Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky, in the Dec. 12 parliamentary election.
Mr. Fyodorov, whose efforts to control expenditure more strictly have been widely applauded in the West, has said he would resign if reformers lose control of economic policy and Viktor S. Gerashchenko, the director of the Russian Central Bank and an opponent of reform, keeps his job.
An official of Russia's Choice told Interfax news agency that Mr. Fyodorov also planned to resign, because "he cannot bear the responsibility for a policy that will inevitably spur inflation."
 
Pressure on Yeltsin Seen
 But it may also be that Mr. Gaidar and Mr. Fyodorov are trying to force Mr. Yeltsin to dismiss Mr. Gerashchenko, who has regularly received support from Mr. Chernomyrdin, and to give fewer important posts to enemies of reform when the Government is shuffled, perhaps as early as Tuesday.
"Gaidar has to carry the can for the poor performance of Russia's Choice," a senior Western diplomat said. "And it would be hard for Gaidar and Chernomyrdin to work together in Government." Mr. Chernomyrdin took the election results as a clear sign to slow and soften economic reform.
But if Mr. Gerashchenko stays and Mr. Fyodorov goes, the diplomat said, "that would be in policy terms a pretty unwelcome signal, and makes it a lot harder to let any of this I.M.F. money loose."
Much of Western aid to Russia is funneled through organizations like the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. The Fund's loans are loosely contingent on some form of prudent Russian economic performance, a position the Clinton Administration has intermittently applauded and criticized.
At the moment, with Mr. Clinton talking of social protections and his Treasury Secretary, Lloyd Bentsen, talking of fiscal rigor, the Russian reformers themselves are disheartened and confused. Washington seems to be using the possibility of further loans from the Fund and World Bank as an incentive to keep Russian reformers, already a minority, in power. If Mr. Yeltsin is willing to play that game, another senior Western diplomat suggested, Mr. Gaidar seems sick of it.
 
Deferred Spending to Come Due
 But with inflation due to surge in April, given a huge amount of deferred spending in November and December, an abandonment of Mr. Fyodorov's efforts to restrain inflationary deficits would put the Fund and World Bank in an even more awkward position.
"Is this the worst of the news, or just the start of the bad news?" the diplomat wondered.
One of Mr. Gaidar's allies, Social Security Minister Ella Pamfilova -- the only woman in the Cabinet -- said she would also resign, while Mr. Gaidar said Mr. Fyodorov's decision would come in a few days, suggesting a coordinated, last-ditch effort to force a change in Government direction. "We hope that the Government's policy will not be drastically altered after all," Mr. Gaidar told Interfax.
Mr. Fyodorov said the Government was at a "turning point, where everyone is being promised money and there are offers of stronger social support policies." But "no one says who will pay or how," Mr. Fyodorov continued. "When these great projects arise from who knows where, of course one's enthusiasm for work in the Government is low." He said his decision about resignation would depend on the shape of the future government.
 
Gaidar's Changing Fortunes
 The fortunes of Mr. Gaidar, a balding, round-faced man of 37 with a courtly manner, have been a measure of the wildly uneven pattern of Russian economic changes. He has been a Yeltsin favorite and was chosen to initiate the great experiment of turning Russia into a free-market, private economy in January 1992, after the collapse of the Soviet Union.
Forced out of office in December 1992 by conservatives in Parliament, Mr. Gaidar was asked to return to office by Mr. Yeltsin last September, to reassure the West about the future of reform just days before the President disbanded Parliament. Again, after the December elections and sharp criticism of Mr. Gaidar by Mr. Chernomyrdin, Mr. Yeltsin, at a news conference Dec. 22, answered a question about the future of economic reform by intoning: "Gaidar stays. Which means that the policy he pursues stays -- naturally, together with the Government and the President."
But the poor election performance of Russia's Choice, and the failure of Mr. Gaidar to persuade other reformers like Grigory A. Yavlinsky to unite with him against Mr. Zhirinovsky, have weakened Mr. Gaidar enormously. Even though he was out of office for nearly all of 1993, he was still seen by many voters as the embodiment of economic reform, even though it was Mr. Chernomyrdin who was Prime Minister. Mr. Gaidar himself criticized the slow and incoherent pattern of reform, which made social pain sharper and more prolonged.
In an interview today, Mr. Yavlinsky was dismissive. Mr. Gaidar "was decoration -- he fulfilled his role Oct. 3 and 4," when Mr. Yeltsin shelled the old Parliament, Mr. Yavlinsky said. "He couldn't change the situation; he wasn't an active member of the Government; he wasn't included." But Mr. Yavlinsky denied reports he has been approached about a Government portfolio.
In his resignation letter, Mr. Gaidar cited two cases to explain his growing frustration over economic decisions made about which he was either uniformed or strongly opposed.
First, he objected to the monetary union with Belarus, an agreement announced Jan. 4 with no discussion in the Cabinet. If the weak Belarusian currency is exchanged for the Russian ruble at one to one, it could cost the Russian economy $1.4 billion, Mr. Gaidar estimates. "We are not rich enough to sacrifice the welfare of Russian citizens to political considerations," he said. His objections were ignored.
In objecting to the new parliamentary center, he wrote that "this destructive decision was taken without my knowledge and despite my resolute objections." It, too, was never discussed in any Government meeting.
Mr. Gaidar said he would continue to support Mr. Yeltsin "and your policy of reforms." But he said his party would not blindly back the Government in the new Parliament.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Newspapers Race for Outlets In Electronic Marketplace

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GLABERSON 

 BODY:
The rapid development of electronic information technologies has placed the American newspaper industry at a crossroads.
New methods of delivering information to desktops and living rooms are threatening the economic foundation of the $45 billion newspaper industry, historically one of the most lucrative and influential of American businesses. Newspaper companies are racing toward electronic media of all kinds in an attempt to pre-empt the competition. 
 Last week alone, three ventures were announced. The Los Angeles Times said it was starting an electronic shopping service with Pacific Telesis, and The Philadelphia Inquirer, owned by Knight-Ridder Inc., said it was going into the television news business with its own local evening newscast. The Washington Post and the Oracle Corporation also agreed to an alliance to develop an electronic publishing service, which they are expected to detail today. [Page D7.]
Increasingly, newspaper executives and industry analysts recognize that computer, telephone and cable hookups have opened paths for new vendors to compete cheaply in the sale of news and other information.
"With the digital age (apparently) fast approaching, the newspaper industry has been racking its communal brains figuring out how not to be left behind," Tod A. Jacobs, a newspaper securities analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, wrote in a recently published study of the industry's future.
Some on-line computer services now carry news updates and financial information, like stock market reports, that do not originate at newspapers. Perhaps most threatening to the newspaper industry, electronic buying and advertising services are already competing for advertiser dollars that traditionally went to big daily newspapers.
Without the need for costly presses and newsprint, or fleets of delivery trucks, it is now economically feasible for the new vendors to sell everything from world and national news reports to neighborhood listings and restaurant reviews, Mr. Jacobs and others said. On-line services have already opened a new market for wire services and various suppliers of niche information. And entrepreneurs are working feverishly to find new ways of collecting information to sell.
 
A Franchise Challenged
 Some in the newspaper industry are convinced that paper-and-ink dailies will never die. But the likelihood that they will be challenged as primary providers of daily information has captured the industry's attention.
James Longson, the vice president for technology at the Tribune Company, owner of The Chicago Tribune and other newspapers, gave this tongue-in-cheek explanation when asked why newspaper executives are rushing into electronic ventures: "Because everybody else is," he said. "Everybody can't be wrong, can they?"
More seriously, Mr. Longson said, "There will be some segment of the audience that will prefer to receive their information electronically; if we don't meet that need, someone else will."
Some newspaper executives argue that if they move quickly, newspapers can establish themselves in new media as suppliers of "brand name" information that they sell at premium prices, the way Procter & Gamble sells soap.
Toward that end, newspapers are starting on-line editions, data base marketing businesses and telephone information services. They are struggling to harness newspapers' strengths as the owners of vast stores of information.
 
'Evolution' of News Providers
 When he announced the television venture last week, P. Anthony Ridder, the president of Knight-Ridder, one of the country's largest newspaper companies, said the move represented a step in his company's "evolution from print to a full-service information provider."
Many executives at large newspapers are expressing similar sentiments as they try to avoid becoming "road kill" on the information highway, to borrow a warning phrase coined by Jeff Greenfield, a political and media analyst for ABC News.
The newspaper industry still has vast wealth and enormous power, and many analysts say that it has years, perhaps even decades, to fight to retain its place as a primary source of current information.
But there is an emerging consensus that newspapers face a challenge that may be as fundamental as previous threats from television, radio and other competitors for Americans' attention.
 
Costs No Longer Prohibitive
 Electronic delivery of information could negate the newspaper industry's biggest financial protection, Mr. Jacobs said. For decades, the enormous cost of newspaper printing plants and delivery systems served as a barrier to many potential rivals.
The stock market has been enthusiastic about non-newspaper companies that are aiming for multimedia riches, according to the newspaper securities analysts at J. P. Morgan Securities Inc. But some analysts contend that the new information suppliers cannot yet compete meaningfully with newspapers.
"It will take many years and much capital for such companies to usurp the traditional newspaper information franchises," the Morgan analysts said in a recent report.
Newspaper executives do not like to hear talk about usurping their franchises, no matter how far off. But entrepreneurs are already carving away parts of the newspaper industry's revenues.
 
Computer Classifieds
 An example is classified advertising. A fledgling industry is already offering various types of ads by telephone or computer, providing users with quick access to information. Some services let a potential buyer of a used car, for instance, specify the desired make, model and year without having to pore over thousands of listings. Newspaper companies are involved in some of the new ventures.
Industry analysts and newspaper executives differ on the extent of the new competition and on how quickly the industry must move against it. But in the last year, most big newspaper companies and many small ones have sharply accelerated their own electronic ventures.
Whether the financial commitments are large or small, it is clear that newspapers are struggling to protect what they consider special relationships with their communities. Competing information vendors, they say, will have difficulty matching ties that developed over generations.
Still, significant hurdles face the industry as it tries to reshape its business. Here are a few of the challenges facing newspaper executives in their race against the digital clock:
Is the newspaper a forgotten friend?
To take advantage of reader loyalty in the electronic age, newspapers must have reader loyalty in the first place. Veronis, Suhler & Associates, a firm that provides investment banking services to media companies, recently calculated that the hours Americans spend with their newspapers is dropping. By 1997, it said, the average American will devote about 165 hours a year to reading a newspaper, down almost 11 percent from 185 hours in 1984.
The slippage is occurring while time spent on activities like watching videos is increasing sharply. If readers are jilting newspapers, is there any reason to believe the romance will be rekindled electronically?
Will consumers pay more for newspaper information?
Even at 50 cents a day, some analysts say, Americans essentially view newspaper news as costing nothing. And that is exactly what they want to pay for it -- even electronically. With many newspaper executives concluding that traditional advertising revenues may never return to the lucrative levels reached before the stock market crash of 1987, an unanswered question of many new newspaper businesses is how to make the ventures pay.
Is the electronic glass half full or half empty?
A strength that newspapers are said to bring to electronic ventures is credibility as carriers of advertising. But old advertising patterns have been eroding for some time. Direct-mail companies and a host of broadcast and print rivals have been grabbing newspaper advertising dollars. In retailing, Wal-Mart Stores Inc. rewrote some industry rules in the 1980's partly by slashing the amounts spent on newspaper advertising.
Newspapers compensated somewhat for retail advertising losses by increasing the percentage of their revenues derived from classified advertisements. But even classified ads fell sharply after the market crash of 1987. And now, Morgan's analysts say new electronic information ventures by cable and telephone companies "could be a long-term threat" to traditional classifieds.
On the other hand, the Morgan analysts conclude that newspapers participating in these ventures see electronic classifieds as "a new product opportunity."
Where should newspapers place their electronic bets?
Though newspapers may seem nearly prehistoric next to electronic gizmos, a sometimes overlooked fact is that newspapers, the biggest segment of the communications business, rake in large amounts of cash. Even during the tough times of the last few years, the nespwpaper industry's average profit margins have remained respectable -- 12 to 14 percent, according to Veronis, Suhler -- and consistently higher than those in the communications industry as a whole.
Moreover, with most newspaper markets beginning to show signs of economic recovery, those profit margins are expected to climb. Newspaper publishers "are poised for positive earnings surprises in 1994," Michael A. Kupinski, a securities analyst at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis, said.
That means that some of the country's leading newspaper companies will have fat rolls of cash to invest. Mr. Kupinski recently predicted that with costs down and advertising starting to rebound, profit margins at major newspaper companies were likely to head toward pre-recession levels of 21 percent or more.
Mr. Jacobs of Bernstein & Company recently calculated that over the next four years the Gannett Company, the largest newspaper company in the country, was likely to have about $1 billion in cash available for investment, while the Tribune Company was likely to have $700 million and Knight-Ridder about $600 million.
In effect, the old dinosaurs have enough money to reinvent themselves before there is any real danger of extinction. The issue is whether they will make the right choices about investing in the new forms of electronic information delivery. As Mr. Jacobs put it: "The billion-dollar question, of course, is: What'll they do with all that dough?"

HEADLINE: Beijing Will Take Steps On Rights, Bush Is Told

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 16

 BODY:
Former President George Bush, on a private visit here, told President Jiang Zemin this weekend that the Clinton Administration needed real progress on human rights from the Communist leadership here or it might be forced to cancel China's favorable trade privileges in the American market.
At the same time, the Chinese leader reportedly told Mr. Bush that China was planning to take a number of unspecified steps to improve its human rights record in coming months. 
 Mr. Bush's conversation with the Chinese leader was described by his former national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, in an interview. Mr. Scowcroft is traveling with Mr. Bush.
 
Similar Pledge to Gephardt
 The Chinese President's remarks to Mr. Bush and Mr. Scowcroft echoed a similar Chinese pledge given this weekend to the House majority leader, Richard A. Gephardt, who arrived in Beijing carrying a strong message from Mr. Clinton that further progress on human rights was needed or United States relations with China were headed for a serious confrontation this year.
"We gave them a factual analysis of the situation in Washington," Mr. Scowcroft said, "and without saying whether we agreed or disagreed, we told them that since these conditions had been laid down" requiring "overall, significant progress" in China's human rights record, Mr. Clinton would have to see real progress or he would be forced to cancel China's low-tariff trading privileges.
"For one way or the other," Mr. Scowcroft said, "the President is in a box, and he cannot get out of it with mirrors," but rather must have tangible improvements in human rights.
The political assessment Mr. Bush offered the Chinese leadership was helpful to Mr. Clinton in that it reinforced the notion that China must take seriously Washington's determination that there be significant progress this year on the plight of the thousands of political prisoners languishing in Chinese jails.
 
A Clinton Campaign Theme
 Such progress eluded Mr. Bush while in office, and he came under fire from Mr. Clinton during the 1992 Presidential campaign for "coddling" China's "dictators." But at the same time, Mr. Bush's and Mr. Scowcroft's assessment suggests that China policy under the Clinton Administration is long on political exuberance and confrontation, and short on practical substance.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Scowcroft are known to believe that a more low-key approach that avoids ultimatums or setting deadlines is a more effective way of dealing with China.
The Chinese President reportedly told Mr. Bush that "within our legal limits, there are some things we can do" that would be responsive to Washington's concerns. Mr. Jiang's positive remarks to Mr. Bush and to the Congressional delegation traveling with Mr. Gephardt represent a marked departure from the usual refusal by Chinese leaders to engage American officials in discussions of human rights.
On the NBC News program "Meet the Press," Secretary of State Warren Christopher, speaking from Geneva, reiterated that China must heed warnings to improve its human rights record, and that progress in other areas could not replace that.
"I would say, from our standpoint, the progress they've made on their economy, while laudable, does not excuse the failure to make progress on the human rights record," he said.
Mr. Christopher added: "A number of people have said, 'Look, they're doing so well on the economy, you ought to forget about the human rights record. That's not my position. It's not the President's position.'
During his stay in Beijing, Mr. Bush met not only with Mr. Jiang, who is the designated successor to China's paramount leader, Deng Xiaoping, but also with officials including Prime Minister Li Peng.

HEADLINE: 9,000 Offer To Go Feed Wild Birds In Taste Test

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER 

 BODY:
Cornell University has recruited 9,000 amateur researchers in a mass experiment to determine the food preferences of wild birds in cold weather.
In tens of thousands of outdoor tests that will end in April, bird-watchers in the United States and Canada are putting a smorgasbord of seeds before birds and recording their choices. 
 The answers, which will not be known until several months after the tests end, are important economically because bird feeding is a billion-dollar business in America, according to the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service. It reported that in 1991, the last year it made a survey, $2 billion worth of bird seed was sold nationwide.
Bird-watching and bird feeding are also important and growing hobbies for a large number of Americans. The Fish and Wildlife Service estimated that 40.9 million people feed wild birds annually.
 
Watching It Grow
 "Bird feeding is growing more and more popular," said Sue Wells, executive director of the Wild Bird Feeding Institute, a trade organization of companies involved in growing and supplying bird feed. The institute, based in Northville, Ill., has 150 members.
But questions remain among suppliers and bird feeders about which seeds ground-feeding birds like chickadees, finches, jays and sparrows prefer. They, unlike the meat-eating hawks and eagles, are mostly vegetarian, feeding on seeds either on the ground or in feeders near the ground.
The Cornell Laboratory of Ornithology, based at the university in Ithaca, N.Y., set out to find answers to two specific questions: What kinds of seeds do ground-feeding birds like best, and do seed preferences vary from region to region throughout the United States and Canada?
It recruited the 9,000 unpaid volunteers in every state and province. They are paying their own expenses, including $7 for a test kit and seed purchases at a cost of about $5.85 each for separate five-pound bags of three different kinds of seed -- black-oil sunflower, red milo and white millet.
 
A Double Purpose
 "We are involving amateurs, the back-yard bird-watchers, because we are trying to involve more people in a scientific experiment and for them to learn something about the scientific method," said Margaret A. Barker, the test coordinator.
The tests consist of setting out a half cup of each seed on one of three brown cardboards, about three feet apart, and recording the number of feeding visits by different species to each in a five-minute period. Observers were asked to repeat the test several times a day, once a week for up to 26 weeks.
The new experiment is one of several Cornell bird research projects paid for by a $759,000 grant from the National Science Foundation. Ms. Barker said that figures were not yet available about the cost of the seed preference experiment alone.
Based on evidence from bird feeders and earlier scientific tests, many ornithologists have concluded that black-oil sunflower seeds, if available, are the preferred food of almost all birds.
 
An Earlier Test
 That, too, was the conclusion drawn in basic research into bird-feeding habits by Dr. Aelred Geis for the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service in the early 1980's. Dr. Geis, now retired and living in Clarksville, Md., is a consultant for Bird Centers of America, a chain of stores supplying materials for bird-watchers and feeders.
In his report, Dr. Geis not only concluded that birds preferred black-oil sunflower seeds, but that many mixtures and seeds, such as millet, wheat and cracked corn, were relatively unattractive.
However, bird-seed mixtures are best sellers in commercial outlets, according to Evan Mann, product manager for one large supplier of commercial bird food, Sanford Seed in Binghamton, N.Y.
"We are strong believers in mixtures," he said. "If you are trying to attract a wide variety of birds, you do better when you offer a variety of seeds."
In a series of preliminary experiments last year, the Cornell researchers used three different seeds to tempt the birds -- black-oil sunflower, white millet and red milo. Their preliminary conclusions, which will be tested in the current mass experiment using the same seeds, were the following:
*Black-oil sunflower was the consistent choice of American goldfinches, black-capped chickadees, blue jays, house finches, pine siskins, tufted titmouses and northern cardinals.
*Red milo was chosen by Inca doves, Gambel's quail and mourning doves.
*White millet was selected most often by American tree sparrows, brown-headed cowbirds, red-winged blackbirds and curve-billed thrashers.
Not surprising to any bird feeder, the preliminary tests came up with a major problem: squirrels. The best advice from the experiment managers to the new researchers was to chase the intruders away during the test period.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Will Versus Paper

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Now we know why Vice President Gore was suddenly detoured to Budapest last month, ostensibly to attend a funeral. He met secretly with Leonid Kravchuk, the Ukrainian President, to set up the most important function for Bill Clinton's debut on the European scene: to act as catalyst in moving Ukraine's nuclear missiles back to Russia to be dismantled.
American tax dollars cannot be better invested than in such disarmament. Although the "re-aiming" of missiles away from cities was meaningless flackery, the tripartite agreement signed by Yeltsin, Kravchuk and Clinton was a triumph of good sense and skillful American diplomacy. The ballyhoo of summitry shored up the Ukrainian leader in persuading parliamentarians -- who could still queer the deal -- to trust Russia. 
 The worrisome part of the agreement is the hint that some private "security guarantee" was given Ukraine, perhaps by Mr. Clinton. If hostilities break out between these two glowering neighbors, the American President cannot then surprise us with anything like "Oh, I forgot to tell you -- if Moscow nukes Kiev, I promised massive retaliation."
Should Mr. Clinton ever again face press and public in a prime-time East Room press conference, he must be prepared to say what commitments, if any, he has made to close this worthy deal.
In the cause of reducing global nuclear risk, prospective intelligence aid to Ukrainian defense may well be defensible. But the days of Rooseveltian secret agreements are gone; for our word to be our bond, we require Wilsonian "open covenants."
The question is not "How'd Clinton do?" The disarmament brokerage, aided by the promise and deadline of a summit, made the trip worthwhile. Although Yeltsin's promise to continue economic reform rang hollow when he fired his leading reformer after waving goodbye to the Americans, world aid is properly tied to ending the inflation Moscow causes by foolishly subsidizing Communist-era plants.
The question is rather: "What can we do to deal with the debilitation of NATO?" Mr. Clinton thinks of Bosnia as a sad sideshow, but it has become the West's main event. On the eve of his departure for Europe, he admitted to pundits that the lifting of the arms embargo -- the dirty U.N. deed that prevents Bosnians from defending themselves -- was a dead issue.
It's dead only because he refuses to revive it. If Bosnian Muslim soldiers could acquire a balance of firepower, invaders would have reason to negotiate a sustainable peace. If the U.S. proposed an end to the embargo in the Security Council, who would veto it -- John Major? Boris Yeltsin?
But Clinton has abandoned the "lift" end of "lift-and-strike." Why? Because the new key man among his national security advisers -- John Shalikashvili, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs -- is afflicted with the defeatist mind set of Europeans who want the Bosnians to give up like good victims.
That reduced the American President's role to a feeble exhortation about not threatening to strike Serbian gunners by air "if you don't mean it." He has adopted the role of spectator, commenting sagely on the inaction of others, when what NATO urgently needs is a forceful push from its most powerful member.
All the talk about extending Western protection eastward is so much hot air when the West refuses to act collectively to stop the plundering of a small state by its neighbors.
NATO is not a scrap of paper, nor a club where members defend their exclusivity; it is the concerted will of democratic nations to resist tyranny's aggression. That remarkable will is what worked against the Soviet threat. Presidents Bush and Clinton did not realize that the collective will to resist an invasion is bleeding to death in the Balkans.
As Ethiopia was the test of the League of Nations, Bosnia is the test not just of the U.N., but of NATO. If we do not blast besiegers; if we do not arm and train defenders -- then what assurance does Ukraine have that its borders are safe? What's the use of paper partnership to the Czechs, Balts, Poles and Hungarians, who have been betrayed before?
The way to keep a U.S. military presence in Europe is for NATO nations to manifest their will to enforce the peace. Where there is no will, there is no way.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Behind Mexican Rising Lies a Wider Despair;
Liberation and Payoffs

 BODY:
To the Editor:
For the peasant uprising in Chiapas, Mexico, the Mexican Government blames "liberal Catholic priests in the area" and accuses "Catholic priests of the theology of liberation." 
 Helder Camara, retired bishop of Recife, Brazil, was treated in the same manner by Government officials and landowners for his heroic support of impoverished peasants in the northeast area of his nation.
Dom Helder relates, "When I give bread to the poor, people say, 'Ah, Dom Helder, you are a saint.' When I ask, 'Why don't the people have bread?' they respond, 'but Dom Helder, you are a communist.' "
Mexican officials blame liberation theology to distract attention from a call for insurrection that comes with implementation of the North American Free Trade Agreement between the United States and Mexico.
The Nation (June 14, 1993) and the Environmental Research Foundation (Oct. 28, 1993) present documentation on how Mexican Government officials and business leaders spent more than $25 million persuading our Congress to adopt the trade pact, far exceeding some previous attempts to buy the defenders of democracy:
* "Koreagate" in the late 1970's disclosed how a South Korean rice broker distributed $850,000 in cash and gifts to 31 members of Congress from 1967 to 1977.
* In 1987 a Japanese company illegally exported high-tech equipment to the Soviet Union. Japanese corporations then spent $9 million to prevent retaliation by Congress.
* In 1990 Hill & Knowlton, the public relations organization, was paid $10 million by the Kuwaiti Government to persuade the American people of the need for military intervention in the Persian Gulf.
Indian peasants in Central and Latin America have been deprived of rights for centuries. The killing of indigenous peoples by the ruling classes has gone on too long. Joining for a violent insurrection is indeed a sorry outcome for those who cannot influence the legislative process as they are driven from their land.
Would that the governments of the United States and Mexico were liberated from the buying of political favors.
 
(Rev.) VIC HUMMERT
San Antonio, Jan. 10, 1994

HEADLINE: Behind Mexican Rising Lies a Wider Despair;
Trade Pact's Fallout

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Readers should not be misled by "The Other Mexico," your apparently sympathetic Jan. 4 editorial on the Indian uprising in Chiapas, Mexico. Native people across North America have been opposed to the North American Free Trade Agreement all along because they understand that it can only intensify pressures against the already burdened indigenous communities of this continent. 
 You state, "What economists hail as rational use of resources looks" -- to many Indians in Chiapas -- "like yet another assault on the traditional way of life they prize." It looks that way because it is.
The problem is not limited to a small fringe group in Chiapas, but is widespread. In an article last July 12 you reported that the trade agreement was expected to destroy the corn economy that sustains Mexico's indigenous peoples -- some 29 percent of the population. Similar effects can be expected in Canada, where efforts are being made to pass the First Nations Chartered Lands Act, which will make it easier for corporations to get at natural resources on Indian lands.
Yet you avidly supported the passage of the trade agreement, apparently with the attitude that if you want to make an omelette, you have to break a few eggs. Now you express sympathy and fine words. They say the crocodile has a good cry before devouring his victims. Your crocodile tears don't deserve any greater credence.
 
JEFFREY WOLLOCK
New York, Jan. 6, 1994
 
The writer is research director of the Solidarity Foundation, the information and research service of the Native American Council of New York.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

International
China and the United States reached an 11th-hour textile agreement, averting a major trade clash over the $7.3 billion in Chinese textiles sold in the American market each year. The Clinton Administration had vowed to reduce Chinese textile imports by more than $1 billion unless a new pact ended overshipments and cheating by Chinese companies. [Page D1.] 
After months of fruitless negotiations with the Japanese Government, the Administration has begun to talk directly to Japanese companies, urging them to buy more foreign products. [D1.]
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen told President Suharto of Indonesia that while the United States believed his Government was making progress on workers rights, it should do more if it wanted to retain its trade privileges with Washington. [D6.]
Saudi Arabia is nearing agreement with five big U.S. military contractors to stretch out $10 billion in payments. [A8.]
 
The Economy
The most significant long-term economic impact of the Los Angeles earthquake was expected to stem from disruptions in travel and commuting. Analysts said Southern California could enjoy modest economic gains as the region rebuilds. [A21.]
The United States, in agreeing last week to buy billions of dollars worth of uranium that had been the explosive material of Russian and Ukrainian nuclear warheads, is trying to regain market share in a business it once monopolized. [D7.]
 
Companies
Viacom is expected to raise its bid for Paramount as early as this morning to match the total value of QVC's current offer. [D1.]
Greyhound Lines, the only nationwide bus company that links the smallest American towns and the largest cities, is acting more like an airline. And the company's goal is to shape a bus system that airlines will seek to emulate. [D1.]

Some Coffee Connection clients come miles out of their way, a tribute to the discriminating coffee taste of the chain's owner. [D2.]

Shares of Metallgesellschaft surged after a deal was devised to save the German metals giant from bankruptcy. [D4.]
The Energy Department has joined a Texas utility in a trial to produce enough wind-generated electricity by 1995 to supply 3,000 homes in the middle of the nation's richest oilfields. [D4.]
 
Markets
The Dow recouped early losses to close at its second straight high amid expectations that the Los Angeles earthquake would help to stimulate California's economy. It rose 3.09, to 3,870.29. [D8.]
Treasury bond prices slipped in light trading overseas. [D18.]

HEADLINE: Malcolm Forbes Jr., Heir at Whitman's Side, Escapes His Father's Shadow

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
Malcolm S. Forbes Jr. still remembers when he and Christine Todd Whitman, who becomes Governor of New Jersey today, first joined hands in support of their favorite Republican candidate.
"The Nixons came to New Jersey in 1952 for the vice-presidential campaign," Mr. Forbes recalled recently at the lower Manhattan headquarters of Forbes magazine, flagship of the publishing empire he has run since his famously flamboyant father, Malcolm Forbes, died in 1990. The younger Forbes, who is known as Steve, was 5 years old and Christie Whitman was not much older. 
 "We were delegated, each of us, to hand Mrs. Nixon dolls for her two daughters," he said.
After their early debut, "Christie went one path, and I went another," added Mr. Forbes, now 46, glancing around at the photos of Forbes estates all over the world and models of its yacht and private DC-9 jet.
 
Far Hills Country Day
 Well, not exactly. Indeed, their paths have crossed frequently ever since. Growing up wealthy in Somerset County, they attended Far Hills Country Day School together. They both own large estates in the horse and farm country near where they grew up. Later, one of Steve's five daughters went to Far Hills with Mrs. Whitman's son. So, when they met last June at the school's graduation, it was natural that Mr. Forbes agreed to help lead an economic advisory group for her campaign.
Out of that came Mrs. Whitman's provocative and risky pledge to cut state income-tax rates by 30 percent. And with it, Mr. Forbes emerged more clearly from the long shadow cast by his late father to assume prominence in the conservative nexus where money, ideas and political ambitions furiously mix.
For Steve Forbes, Mrs. Whitman's victory was proof that the tax-cutting ideology he has championed outlives the end of Ronald Reagan's Presidency and the 1980's. He hopes that a protest against high taxes and expansive government in New Jersey, Massachusetts and Michigan presages a national revival of the 'supply-side' (tax-cutting), term-limit, school-choice populism of the right.
It is the list expounded by such Washington Republican luminaries as Jack F. Kemp, the former Congressman from Buffalo, Newt Gingrich, the deputy Republican leader in the House, and William Bennett, who served as Mr. Reagan's Education Secretary. All three have expressed interest in running for President.
 
The Forbes $400
 Steve Forbes is well placed to help them toward that goal. He commands a fortune that New Jersey Monthly estimated at $400 million, plus a privately owned magazine with his own two-page column reaching well over a million affluent business readers every other week. He recently became chairman of Empower America, a Washington advocacy group that serves as a somewhat shaky umbrella organization for Messrs. Kemp, Gingrich, Bennett and others in the anti-tax, pro-market camp.
"It's no easy task getting them all to work together," Mr. Forbes said. "But look, I feel very strongly about some of these issues and will do everything I can to help propagate them. And while all the consultants are mesmerized by process, I believe we are entering a time where ideas are going to be the chief motivator of political movements."
"Steve transcends the squabbling," said Mr. Kemp, who was Secretary of Housing and Urban Development under George Bush. "Art Laffer, Larry Kudlow, Jude Wanniski -- Steve gets along with all of them. He has a way of disagreeing without being disagreeable."
"I've known Steve for 20 years," said Jude Wanniski, a former Wall Street Journal editorial writer and an early popularizer of 'supply-side' ideas. "There is no one in journalism who has been more consistently enthusiastic about the supply-side growth model than Steve."
 
Shaped Whitman Tax Plan
 Mr. Forbes showed his political acumen last fall. Against the opposition of Edward J. Rollins Jr. and other political advisers, Mr. Forbes and Lawrence A. Kudlow, a Wall Street economist, persuaded Mrs. Whitman to support their tax-cut plan. They promoted it at a series of meetings at the Whitman home last September. The tax pledge was roundly criticized by editorial pages and still faces formidable obstacles, but it proved crucial to her victory.
Mr. Forbes expects to continue as an informal adviser to Governor Whitman, but he understands the limits of his influence. "I don't see a kitchen cabinet or anything like that," he said. For State Treasurer, he and Mr. Wanniski recommended James H. Wallwork, a former State Senator who lost the Republican gubernatorial nomination to Mrs. Whitman. Instead, she went outside New Jersey to select Brian W. Clymer, a Bush Administration official.
"Christie will listen and talk to everybody but she leans on no one when she makes up her mind," Mr. Forbes said. "Because of her nice manners she is underestimated, but I think she has shown she is a lot more determined and tougher than people gave her credit for."
 
In Whitman's Transition
 Mr. Forbes gave the legal maximum to Mrs. Whitman's campaign: $1,800 each for primary and general elections. Other family members contributed as well. Since her victory, he has met with Mrs. Whitman three times and taken an active part in her transition effort as a member of the budget review committee.
Mr. Forbes, like others close to Mrs. Whitman, expects her to push her tax-cut plan vigorously through the Legislature. And he is convinced that lower taxes and a curb on government spending are just what New Jersey needs.
Forbes's weekly newspapers in New Jersey "have not been big money makers," he said. "That's another reflection of the New Jersey economy. So it's more than intellectual interest that I have in Christie Whitman's success. I want New Jersey to do well for selfish reasons, too."
As he becomes a popular speaker in conservative circles and perhaps a future kingmaker, Steve Forbes makes one thing perfectly clear: He is not his father.
"It would be silly to try to imitate my father," he said. "Learn his approach to life, yes. But take up hang gliding in some kind of competition to prove who's more daring? No."
 
Father Was Flamboyant
 Malcolm Forbes, while somewhat shy and reserved in early adulthood, delighted in an extravagant life in the limelight. He collected, among many things, Faberge eggs and modern art. In his late 40's he threw himself into cross-country ballooning and motorcycling. In his 60's, he led a jet-setting life, frequently as a companion of Elizabeth Taylor.
By contrast, Steve collects books and autographs. On the private jet returning from Malcolm's notorious $2-million 70th birthday party in Morocco, one guest remembers Christopher (Kip) Forbes, one of Steve's brothers, glad-handing such celebrities as Henry and Nancy Kissinger. Steve primly sat reading sales reports from Forbes's ad people.
Many people in publishing thought Forbes would wither without Malcolm to drum up advertising and attention. There were fears that Forbes Inc., like so many other family enterprises, might plunge into internecine warfare in the next generation.
But the company, a privately held concern that does not disclose its revenue or profit, has thrived since Steve Forbes took the helm in 1990. In 1992, during a publishing slump, Forbes magazine became the industry leader in ad pages. Its circulation, at 767,789, has continued to climb.
 
Expands Empire's Reach
 Together with his three younger brothers, Kip, Robert and Timothy, who each run parts of the business, Mr. Forbes has expanded the empire's reach. He killed off a flashy life-style magazine, egg, begun only months before with great fanfare by his father. But Forbes then started two new magazine supplements: FYI, on leisure pursuits for its well-to-do business audience, and ASAP, a bimonthly on technology. ASAP was immediately profitable and both are doing well, Mr. Forbes says.
The company also expanded its weekly newspaper chain in New Jersey and began custom textbook publishing. It recently took over an unprofitable annual journalism review from Mr. Wanniski and renamed it Forbes Mediacritic, with plans to make it a quarterly critique.
"My first priority is to run a business, not to worry about the fortunes of the Republican Party," he said.
Yet Mr. Forbes also says that his greatest pleasure derives from his favorite causes. "Writing my pages is a sheer delight," he said. "That is the most enjoyable part of this position."
 
Column Focuses on Politics
 Malcolm Forbes's comments in the magazine ranged far and wide. Steve Forbes, though, uses his soapbox to focus almost exclusively on politics.
"Steve really is a true believer," said Allen Sloan, a former Forbes editor now a columnist at Newsday. "His father just believed in what was convenient. Malcolm was much less of an ideologue."
For all his business instincts, some journalists say Mr. Forbes lacks the cutting talents of tax foes like Robert Bartley, editorial page editor at The Wall Street Journal.
"He's been an excellent steward of the company and the family, but the column is not particularly original," said a former Forbes editor, who agreed to talk only if he was not identified. "There's a lot of standard Clinton bashing in there."
Some outsiders contend that both Malcolm and Steve on occasion cross the line between business and journalism, exploiting their position to unduly influence stories in the magazine. They cite, as one example, Forbes's turnabout from being an early critic of Michael R. Milken, the Drexel Burnham junk-bond king who went to prison for securities violations, into an unabashed cheerleader for Mr. Milken. One of Mr. Milken's biggest boosters is Mr. Wanniski, a close friend of Steve's.
 
Milken Not Darth Vader
 Mr. Forbes says the critics are wrong. "We like to cut against the conventional wisdom," he said. "When Milken was a new phenomenon, we took a critical look at him. But when everybody said he was Darth Vader, our attitude was that he made possible MCI and a lot of other things that wouldn't have happened without his financial genius."
Mr. Forbes insisted that James W. Michaels, the longtime editor of Forbes, has essentially carte blanche. "I leave Jim Michaels alone," he said. "Under my father, Jim probably had 98 percent autonomy. Still does today; some say 99 plus."
Outside of work, Mr. Forbes's life revolves around his family. He lives in Bedminster with his wife, the former Sabina Beekman, a minister's daughter. They have five daughters, in age from 6 to 20. Steve calls his three brothers "my closest friends," adding: "I guess we got all our sibling rivalry out beating each other up as youngsters." A sister, Moira, is married to a doctor in the Philadelphia area.
Despite the Forbes tradition of primogeniture, Steve insists that he can easily envision one of his daughters' taking over the family enterprise some day. "I take a very liberated view of these things," he said. "I mean, 'Why not?' especially in this day and age."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Christie will listen and talk to everybody but she leans on no one when she makes up her mind," said Malcolm S Forbes Jr., who expects to continue to serve as an informal adviser to Christine Todd Whitman after she becomes Governor of New Jersey today. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Yonkers Looks to Hudson Riverfront for Its Future

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: YONKERS, Jan. 17

 BODY:
On a day when craggy ice floes clogged the Hudson River and the majesty of the Palisades was curtained by heavy fog, two public works employees sat in their truck, sipping coffee and watching the river. They were the only humans in sight along the city's rundown hodge-podge of a waterfront.
But by early in the next century, city officials hope, the downtown portion of Yonkers's 4.5-mile Hudson River shoreline will be transformed into a lively strand bustling with sightseeing ships, canoes, a public marina, shops and apartment buildings. 
 The new plan, devised by Ehrenkrantz & Eckstut Architects, the firm that designed Battery Park City and Baltimore's Inner Harbor East, and Travers Associates, a consulting company, is reminiscent of the renewal of Baltimore's waterfront. More than $18 million in public money has been committed to the project.
The transformation will take 7 to 15 years, city officials say, but the first steps are under way. This month, the city signed an agreement to provide space in the new waterfront for Ferry Sloops, a Hudson River environmental and educational organization that teaches sailing and ecology.
 
From the Water Inward
 The agreement is important to Ferry Sloops because after several years of uncertainty over a permanent home for its 42-foot sloop, Sojourner Truth, and five other vessels, the group will finally have a home. But the agreement is also emblematic of what environmentalists say makes the Yonkers plan special.
"The major concept, what gives it real hope at this point, is the idea of starting at the water and moving inward," said Jerry Goldman, vice president of Ferry Sloops.
Rather than pick a site and choose a developer, the city decided to create attractive public spaces, come up with a zoning plan, and then wait for private investment. And unlike other municipal development plans along the Hudson, the Yonkers proposal actually widens the river. A new marina and deep water wharf for ferries and pleasure craft will add two extra acres of water.
Access to the waterfront would be improved for both pedestrians and motorists, with the creation of new city streets west of the railroad tracks used by Metro-North and Amtrak.
 
Riverfront Identity
 In addition, the plan calls for preserving the historical character of downtown Yonkers. To that end, the city has reached agreement with every property owner along lower Main Street, which runs west toward the Hudson, to refurbish the facades of the buildings, many of which date from the last century. The city has applied for a $225,000 grant from the State Urban Development Corporation for the renovations, and officials hope the application will be approved next month so that work can begin in the spring. The state money is to be matched by the building's owners.
Mayor Terence M. Zaleski said the plan aimed to give Yonkers back its identity as a riverfront city.
"We believe that the downtown waterfront area can really bring people from throughout the region to enjoy what's really there," Mr. Zaleski said in an interview at City Hall, where soaring windows provide a panoramic view of downtown Yonkers and the Hudson River. "A hundred years ago, it was very dynamic, very active. The city had a waterfront identity. That's why in the 21st century, we're almost going back to what worked in the 19th century, what worked originally."
The Army Corps of Engineers has promised half a million dollars in design work along the waterfront, and the city is in the process of hiring a contractor to rehabilitate the turn-of-the-century pier, which stands with its huge Yonkers sign at the base of Main Street. That project will cost about $1 million, Mr. Zaleski said.
 
Plans for Ferry Service
 Ferry service to midtown Manhattan from Yonkers is expected to begin next year once negotiations with the Port Imperial Ferry Corporation, the same company that runs trans-Hudson service between New Jersey and Manhattan, are complete.
Remarkably, in a city known for its pitched political battles, there seems to be little disagreement over the plan. Democrats and Republicans back the plan, environmentalists have embraced it and Mr. Zaleski said there was interest from developers as well, including a large shopping-center developer from out of state.
But as John D. Spencer, the Republican majority leader of the City Council and a critic of the Democratic Mayor, put it: "We've been talking about it for decades. We have a library full of plans, and the Mayor has just unveiled another one. No one is opposed to any of these plans, they're like Mom and apple pie and the American flag. The true test is implementation."
Mr. Zaleski said that because the refurbishment was planned in three stages, the city would avoid an all-or-nothing investment approach that he said had led to failure in the past. He said that Westchester County, the state, and the Federal Government have already promised aid.
"There's been talk that this is just another plan," he said. "But I'm committed to action. Do you know that there are children who live within blocks of the river who don't know that the Hudson River is the city's western boundary? I think the waterfront could become the basis for the strength of this city again, like it was 100 or 200 years ago."

Zaleski. (Photographs by William E. Sauro/The New York Times)
