HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Bond Prices Slip Overseas

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices slipped slightly yesterday in very light trading overseas. But the market for Treasury securities and other Government securities was closed in the United States in observance of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
The Treasury postponed its weekly auction of three-month and six-month bills until today. Still, there was light trading in corporate bonds. 
 In London, the Treasury's 30-year bond fell 3/32 of a percentage point, to 999/32 , as the yield edged up to 6.30 percent from 6.29 percent.
 
 
Housing Report
 The bond market is awaiting this week's Government report on housing starts for further signs of whether the economy is strengthening. Strong economic growth could encourage the Federal Reserve to push up interest rates to head off any new inflation.
In addition, many traders are concerned about the recent rise in commodity prices, which could point to a re-emergence of inflation.
The municipal bond market was also closed yesterday, so it was unclear what immediate impact, if any, the Los Angeles earthquake would have on the debt of cities and counties in Southern California.
But municipal bond analysts did not believe the earthquake would affect bond ratings.
The analysts said their assessments were based on damage reports they had seen on television. In recent years, California cities and counties have withstood severe earthquakes without having their credit ratings lowered.
 
 
'Not Overly Concerned'
 "We're not overly concerned based on past history," said Tom Kenney, director of municipal research for Franklin Resources Inc. in Mountain View, Calif. Franklin's mutual funds own more than $14 billion in California bonds.
The City of Los Angeles has about $6.8 billion in municipal debt, including general obligation bonds, lease obligations and revenue issues. The general obligation debt is rated Aa1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Chris Irwin, a director in Standard & Poor's San Francisco office, said that "over the following weeks" the rating company would assess earthquake damage done to specific projects that were financed by bonds.
Officials at Moody's were not available for comment on their plans.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Closes Mixed And Gold Rises Worldwide

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar settled mixed in light, uneventful trading yesterday.
Gold prices rose worldwide. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery gained $2.10 to settle at $392.20 an ounce. 
 Trading was subdued in the United States. The Treasury bond market and most banks, which are major players in worldwide currency trading, were closed in observance of the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.
"There really was not much going on," said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group. "The dollar was just consolidating, not going anywhere in very quiet holiday trading."
The only news to move the market was the resignation of Yegor T. Gaidar, First Deputy Prime Minister of Russia and a key supporter of economic reform. His action leaves the ranks of reformers severely depleted.
The news took its greatest toll on the German mark, which was pushed lower, since Germany is perceived to be the European nation that stands to benefit most from economic expansion in the former Soviet Union.
Elsewhere, favorable economic data in Britain helped bolster the pound. The Government reported a modest rise in producer prices while both industrial production and manufacturing output were up slightly more than expected, Donney said.
"That helped the pound, especially against the mark," he said.
The dollar, for the most part, remained out of the spotlight. Trading was expected to return to normal levels today, when banks reopen and their currency traders are back at their desks.
In late New York trading, the dollar rose to 111.05 Japanese yen, from 110.98 on Friday. It also rose to 1.7535 German marks from 1.7495.
The British pound rose to $1.4935 in New York from $1.4934. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's rates, included: 1.4770 Swiss francs, down from 1.4781; 5.9540 French francs, up from 5.9415; 1,706.00 Italian lire, up from 1,704.00, and 1.3178 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3248.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Is it now the time for some bottom fishing in the oil patch?

BYLINE: By Agis Salpukas 

 BODY:
WITH crude oil prices in the doldrums and likely to stay there, now may not seem like the time to buy oil company stocks. But oil analysts say there are some special opportunities, especially among the domestic oil companies, including ARCO, Phillips Petroleum, Pennzoil and Amarada Hess. Some, however, acknowledge that the best time to buy may be six months from now, when oil prices start moving.
Simon Trimble, an oil analyst at Lehman Brothers, says that because of pessimism over the future price of oil, the domestic oil stocks have taken a rougher beating in the market than have the large international companies, which generally can better weather regional economic downturns because they get their oil and market their products globally. 
 But the situation has created some bargains.
"The clear advantage that the domestics have is that the United States is coming out of the recession very rapidly, whereas the internationals are faced with ongoing recessions in Europe and Japan," he explains.
Another plus is that the recent cold and storms in the East have firmed up demand for natural gas and heating oil. That will particularly benefit the domestic producers, which market most of their products in the United States.
In fact, as winter weather swept over much of the country yesterday, crude oil prices staged a small recovery. Heating oil and natural gas prices also rose.
Another benefit: oil companies generally have strong yields from dividends.
But some analysts warn that oil prices are in a holding pattern -- and oil stocks, therefore, remain in the same condition.
"The market was certain that OPEC would step in early to drive oil prices higher by cutting production at an emergency meeting in the latter part of January," Mr. Trimble says. "What's happened is that the market has begun to realize that the chance of calling such an emergency meeting is falling fast."
As a result, oil prices are expected to continue to stand at about $14 to $16 a barrel most of the year. For the first six months of 1993, the price averaged about $19 a barrel.
"It's premature to be buying these stocks," says William Randol, an oil analyst with Salomon Brothers. "There is still more carnage that lies ahead."
Mr. Randol says that although demand for gasoline was up more than expected last year, 2.3 percent from 1992, that has less to do with the economic recovery than with the more narrow reason that consumers are buying larger, less-fuel-efficient vehicles -- like small trucks. Such consumer tastes often fluctuate year to year.
Nevertheless, Jim Clark, an oil analyst at First Boston, says there are some attractive buys.
"The way to make money is to buy stocks that are relatively inexpensive in the group," he says.
One of his favorites is Amoco, which has a dividend yield of 4 percent, has low debt and is one of the least expensive stocks given its potential strong position. The stock closed at $53.875 yesterday, up 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
In addition, Mr. Clark adds, the company has a strong position in natural gas in North America. Natural gas prices have a better chance of holding up in North America than those of crude oil because demand for gas has been high and prices have been rising.
Small additions to capacity in refineries could also help Amoco, which could become the largest refiner east of the Rocky Mountains in the next few years, strengthening its ability to market its products in the East and Midwest.
"Even in a weak crude oil environment," he adds, "there will be stocks that will outperform the rest."

HEADLINE: In German Theater, A Daring Director Takes Center Stage

BYLINE: By JOHN ROCKWELL, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: HAMBURG, Germany, Jan. 16

 BODY:
There are probably more full-year repertory theaters, more actors, more performances, more new plays and more theatergoers in the German-speaking countries than in the rest of the world combined. Most of this enormous activity remains unknown to American audiences, given the language barrier. Very occasionally, a German company will make it across the ocean, as the Thalia Theater of Hamburg did last fall with "The Black Rider" at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. But there is more to theater in Germany, and even in Hamburg, than the Thalia. Right now, the hot item in the German-speaking theater world is the Thalia's main Hamburg rival, the Deutsches Schauspielhaus, or German Theater.
The Schauspielhaus is in the news because of the arrival this season of Frank Baumbauer as its new intendant, or director. Mr. Baumbauer, 48, comes from Munich and got started there and in Dusseldorf as a stage director. From 1983 to 1986 he was intendant at the Bavarian State Theater in Munich and, after a year's stopover in Stuttgart, served from 1988 to 1993 as director of the Basel Theater in Switzerland, where he was in charge of the entire theatrical operation, including opera and dance. 
 His arrival here, and the flurry of premieres he presented throughout the fall, has been big news in Germany, with articles in the national magazines and newspapers as well as in most of the major local papers. Mr. Baumbauer was seriously wooed by at least two other German cities before deciding on Hamburg, and he won concessions that bucked the prevailing budget-cutting trend.
What he got, he said in an interview on Saturday, was a restoration of the city's subsidy to the level it had enjoyed in the late 1980's, adjusted for inflation. That means $22 million for an overall budget of $24 million, the difference made up mostly by the box office. In addition, Mr. Baumbauer won a budgetary increase that enabled him to hire seven more technicians and spend $5 million for backstage improvements.
"People have lost faith in these big state theaters," Mr. Baumbauer said. "What I am trying to bring here is the belief that one can run a theater of this size efficiently and effectively."
The Deutsches Schauspielhaus, with some 1,300 seats (the number varies with the adjustable configuration) the largest theater for spoken drama in the country, had fallen on evil days. A series of star directors had tried to administer the company but had been unable to stay within budget (especially after it began to be whittled away in the late 80's) or to maintain excellence throughout the repertory, even in plays they themselves did not direct.
By all accounts what distinguished Mr. Baumbauer's Basel tenure was his ability to create an ensemble spirit that in turn attracted some of the brightest lights among Germany's roving playwrights and directors. And as a full-time administrator, he was able to devote his full attention to the business of running the company.
"Honestly, it depends on the personality," he said diplomatically. "Strong personalities like Claus Peymann in Vienna, Jurgen Flimm at the Thalia or Dieter Dorn in Munich can build good teams around them and afford to spend eight weeks in rehearsal. I need the whole day just to be intendant. Also, I enjoy it."
 
Defections and Additions
 Theoretically, Hamburg has a company of 40 actors, but by the time Mr. Baumbauer arrived, that had eroded to fewer than 25. He kept 10 of those, brought eight actors from Basel (along with five artistic and technical people) and hired 22 actors from around the German-speaking world who wished to work with him.
The result has been a troupe that "has already proven itself spectacular competition for the Thalia," said the monthly Prinz, Hamburg's leading cultural-listings magazine. For his opening months, Mr. Baumbauer introduced new works by leading German playwrights, developed a provocative series of small-space and late-night experimental pieces, offered the first German production of the first part of Tony Kushner's "Angels in America," and brought in Leander Haussmann, the new young star among German stage directors, for Shakespeare's "Troilus und Cressida."
Although attendance, at 87 percent, has been strong (76 percent at this theater would be an overflow audience at the smaller Thalia), Mr. Baumbauer concedes that some of the interest may be simple curiosity. Critical response to the most prominent new productions has been mixed. "Angels in America" attracted considerable attention, and Mr. Baumbauer's idea of entrusting it to Werner Schroeter, who has the most flamboyantly operatic, overtly gay sensibility among German stage directors, seemed a good one.
In practice, Mr. Schroeter offered a curiously muted, ponderous staging, lacking in nearly all respects the spunk and spirit that distinguishes the New York version. He had some interesting notions, above all the use of Zazie de Paris, a transsexual, as the Angel, surrounded by a nimbus of recorded operatic music. But even here, Mr. Schroeter slighted the apocalyptic aspects of Mr. Kushner's vision.
 
Bright Past
 The Deutsches Schauspielhaus was built in 1900, but its brightest moments came in the late 50's and early 60's when the intendant was Gustaf Grundgens. Germany's most famous actor, he made Goethe's Mephistopheles his signature role, flourished during the Nazi era and become the subject of Klaus Mann's novel and Istvan Szabo's film, "Mephisto." Mr. Grundgen's 1957 production of "Faust," seen at the City Center in New York, was so famous that the Schauspielhaus had never dared to present another.
Mr. Baumbauer solved that problem, at least partly, by bringing Christoph Marthaler from Zurich to direct his "Roots of Goethe's Faust Parts 1 and 2." In a production of under three hours, Mr. Marthaler compacted key scenes from both parts of Goethe's tragedy, adding snippets of 19th-century German music, bits of other texts and allusions to Christopher Marlowe and Thomas Mann. The action was set in a Frankensteinian laboratory, playing off ideas of art and science and deconstructing the text among a corps of interchangeable actors, including four as Gretchen.
The result was both thought-provoking and annoying. Mr. Mart haler's works in general seem as much exercises in style as statements of content. That style owes a little to Robert Wilson, more to Samuel Beckett and most to Pina Bausch. The effect is witty in an oppressed sort of way, and terribly Teutonic. The Deutsches Schauspielhaus still needs a new "Faust."
Mr. Haussmann, a 34-year-old East German director, has burst onto the German theater scene in the last couple of years. His "Troilus" took that problematic play and emphasized its comic elements to the point where the tragedy seemed almost gratuitous. As such, it was dismissed in much of the German press. But what Mr. Haussmann did, he did brilliantly, and certainly Mr. Baumbauer's new ensemble, given the full scope of this play and of the theater's vast stage, had a chance to shine. Particularly compelling was the sly, erotically knowing Cressida of Anne Bennent, who left Mr. Peymann's Burgtheater in Vienna, arguably the most prestigious theater in the German-speaking world, to work with Mr. Baumbauer in Hamburg.
 
One-Man 'Magic Flute'
 In one three-day period, there was also a trenchant student matinee of Edward Bond's "Saved' in a smaller ancillary space; a late-night version of Mozart's "Zauberflote" in the big theater in which everything, all the sung and spoken parts as well as bits of the orchestral score, was performed a cappella by one tenor, Christoph Homberger, in a production conceived and staged by Herbert Wernicke, and several readings that directly conflicted with plays in the big theater.
All of this activity is part of Mr. Baumbauer's plan to emphasize the company's image, build its audience and shore up its reputation before new budgetary whittling, already being discussed, can take effect. And although he may be disappointed at the less-than-ecstatic response his seemingly surefire offerings have elicited, he professes himself satisfied that Mr. Marthaler's "Faust" and his more experimental efforts have been appreciated.
"I think that's good," he said. "The idea is to give people something they can't get on TV. I want for the time being to present everything within this theater, and not elsewhere in the city. If we can get a profile in one or two years, then we can go out. What we are trying to do is give the Schauspielhaus visibility again."

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
Police Trying to Learn if Harding's Funds Were Used for Attack

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 17

 BODY:
In pursuing evidence of a conspiracy, Federal and state authorities say they are trying to determine whether any of Tonya Harding's money was used in the assault on her American skating rival, Nancy Kerrigan.
Harding, who resumed training for the Olympics around 1 A.M. today, has strongly denied any involvement in the crime. American Olympic officials have said they would drop her from the team if she is charged in the attack. Kerrigan also skated in public for the first time, in Stoneham, Mass., since the incident. 
 Investigators say they have been investigating where Shawn Eric Eckardt, Harding's former bodyguard, got the $6,500 he has told authorities he paid a man to commit the assault. They said they will try to determine through bank records or other means whether the money was paid and, if it was, whether it originated with Harding, who has earned several hundred thousand dollars in recent years.
They also say that Harding's former husband, Jeff Gillooly, who is unemployed, could be implicated if records show that he controlled the money.
Norman W. Frink, a deputy district attorney, declined to elaborate on any aspect of the case, other than to say investigators are actively pursing all possible leads. He also said that the authorities had tentatively arranged a time to interview the skater.
They have not, however, succeeded in arranging an interview with Gillooly, from whom Harding has been divorced since last August even though they now live together and call each other husband and wife.
Harding, Gillooly and Eckardt have declined to discuss the case, and their lawyers did not immediately return telephone calls for comment.
Eckardt, a 300-pound self-described expert in espionage and security matters, was one of three men arrested last week and charged with involvement in a conspiracy to harm Kerrigan, who was bashed in the right knee 11 days ago in Detroit. Another of those arrested, Shane M. Stant, is the man the authorities say committed the attack. The other man, Derrick B. Smith, is suspected of driving Stant away from the Joe Louis Arena after the assault.
Investigators have said that Eckardt claimed to have paid Stant $6,500. But they are not certain where Eckardt, a 26-year-old who lives with his parents in Portland and runs a bodyguard service from their house, might have got that amount of money. As a bodyguard for Harding, his only known client, he was paid about $3,000 for protecting Harding when she returned to Portland from Detroit.
 
$200,000 in Earnings Since 1991
 Investigators say they are focusing on the money Harding has earned since she burst into skating prominence five years ago. While lucrative commercial endorsements have eluded her, she has made around $200,000 since 1991, including about $150,000 from ice skating tours managed by Tom Collins, a Minneapolis-based promoter.
Collins said in an interview today he paid Harding about that amount for her participation in shows in 1991 and 1992 and that he gave her an additional $10,000 as a gift for training expenses last fall, when he said she called and said she needed some money. Collins said that some skaters incur as much as $50,000 a year in expenses.
In the last three years, Harding has also received $12,500 from the United States Olympic Committee through a trust fund and additional sums from private donors, including $20,000 last year from George Steinbrenner, the owner of the Yankees and an Olympic committee vice president. Jerry Lace, executive director of the United States Figure Skating Association, said in an interview that his organization had also given money to Harding although he was not certain of the amount.
Steinbrenner, attending an owners' meeting in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., refused to discuss the Harding case when asked by reporters, saying, "I'm here on baseball."
In general, money has been available to athletes from trust funds upon request for training and other expenses. Athletes are required to submit receipts for any money spent. But recently, the figure skating association eliminated trust funds for skaters who didn't want them, allowing those athletes to receive the funds directly provided they inform the association about the source of the money. Kristin Matta, a spokeswoman for the association, said Harding signed a release, indicating she would no longer use a trust fund.
Harding also received money from a local fan club. The Tonya Harding Fan Club Newsletter, a periodic publication, actively solicits donations for the skater. Elaine Stamm, president of the fan club, said that the club had raised about $10,000 for the skater since last February.

HEADLINE: Computer Vision of Global Warming: Hardest on Have-Nots

BYLINE: By DAVID E. PITT 

 BODY:
USING a combination of computer models, an international team of scientists investigating the effects of global warming on agriculture has summoned up a detailed vision of the future that will cheer farmers and commodity traders in the northern latitudes, but not people in developing countries.
Experts say the three-year study is apparently the first in what is likely to be a torrent of interdisciplinary, computer-assisted projections of the myriad biophysical and socioeconomic consequences of climate change. 
 The study predicts that rising temperatures resulting from greenhouse gas emissions will cause only a "slight to moderate" decline in world grain production, causing prices to rise, but leaving most industrial nations more or less unharmed -- and actually increasing crop production in some.
But people in already impoverished tropical and subtropical countries are likely to face more starvation and malnutrition than ever before, despite the best efforts of farmers to counter the effects of rising temperatures on their harvests, according to the study's principal authors, Dr. Cynthia Rosenzweig of Columbia University and the Goddard Institute for Space Studies, and Prof. Martin L. Parry, director of the Environmental Change Unit at Oxford University in England.
 
Efforts to Assess Risks
 The study was published a month before the more than 150 governments that have signed the 1992 United Nations treaty to combat global warming are to gather for talks in Geneva.
Until recently, much of the advanced research on climate change focused on whether significant global warming was likely to occur at all. This debate is far from settled, but many scientists are convinced that without drastic measures to reduce the burning of fossil fuels, average temperatures are likely to rise 3 to 8 degrees Fahrenheit by the year 2100. Efforts are turning more and more to making precise assessments of the likely risks if this turns out to the case.
Earlier computer models of climate change predicted similarly disparate effects on crop yields, with some northerly regions benefiting while developing countries suffered. But until the Rosenzweig-Parry study, other scientists say, no assessment had incorporated so many variables into a series of precise, comprehensive predictions.
"They've done a terrific job in gradually learning about the agricultural system and how it might change, then building models that will simulate those changes," said Dr. Michael Oppenheimer, a senior scientist at the Environmental Defense Fund, an advocacy group. "Any one scenario that they ran might not tell you much, but they've run a lot of them, and the sort of underlying themes which emerge within the broad range of uncertainty tell you something about what the future may actually look like."
The Environmental Protection Agency, which largely financed the project with technical help from the United States Agency for International Development, is also sponsoring studies on the effects of global warming on natural ecosystems, human health, river basins and the rise of sea levels.
The Rosenzweig-Parry findings, published in the current issue of the British journal Nature, involved 60 economists, agronomists and atmospheric scientists from 25 countries who helped prepare "general circulation" models of the atmosphere; global food-trade patterns and crop growth in 18 countries, 12 of them in the developing world.
The study used crop-yield data supplied by agronomists from Argentina, Australia, Bangladesh, Brazil, Canada, China, Egypt, France, India, Japan, Mexico, Pakistan, the Philippines, Thailand, Russia, the United States, Uruguay and Zimbabwe. The crop figures were then examined under three different models of climate change. The researchers then juxtaposed the data with world food-trade projections to obtain a picture of how many people would be put at risk of hunger.
 
A Surprising Finding
 The study found that although the amount of warming was expected to be highest in the northern latitudes, harming some growing areas and expanding others, the effect on crops was likely to be more uniformly severe in the southern latitudes. This is because the basic subsistence crops the study looked at, including wheat, maize, rice and soybeans, would not fare as well under the stress caused by increased heat and higher evaporation rates.
"This is the most surprising part of our study," Dr. Rosenzweig said. "It shows that even with lower amounts of warming, the vulnerability of the low-latitude places, where developing countries tend to be located, is very much present. The high temperatures will push the crops very near the edge."
According to the study, crop yields will be stunted by higher temperatures and damaged by increased difficulty in retaining water. And, because increased heat accelerates the growth cycle, the crops that will be produced will have less time to accumulate carbohydrates and are thus less nutritious.
The study says the problem will be compounded by sharp increases in world cereal prices resulting from the climate-induced declines in harvests.
"These increases in price affect the number of people at risk of hunger," the study said, noting that because of global warming, an additional 60 million to 350 million people, most of them in the developing world, could face critical food shortages by the year 2060.
The study also found that although the presence of heightened levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere would increase crop productivity in the northern latitudes by enhancing photosynthesis rates, its beneficial effects would probably be limited in the southern latitudes by the damaging effects of heat.
Experts differ over whether the study is based on unrealistically rosy or overly negative assumptions, especially about whether farmers can compensate with new planting techniques or capital-intensive measures like irrigation and new fertilizers.
"I think some of their scenarios are fairly optimistic about the ability of farmers to adapt, particularly in terms of the likely availability of capital and technology," said Alden Meyer, director of the climate change program of the Union of Concerned Scientists, an environmental research and advocacy group.
But John Reilly of the Economic Research Service, a private study center in Washington, writing in the same issue of Nature, suggests that the study underestimates the determination of farmers in developing countries to overcome obstacles "if it pays them to do so."
He also asserts that the study's "focus on crops that are staples of temperate agriculture may have led to an overestimate of the negative impacts in tropical countries."
Dr. Rosenzweig acknowledged that "further research clearly needs to be done on other crops that are very important in these areas, things like cassava and millet."
"The real strength of our study was that it was interdisciplinary," Dr. Rosenzweig said. "There's a move to make very integrated models now, and have one model do everything. I like our approach, in which we let the state-of-the-art models in each discipline handle each of the three aspects, and then we work together as scientists to see where the linkages are."

 BODY:
The Damage . . . A16
 LOCATIONS AND LOSSES -- An earthquake that measured 6.6 on the Richter scale struck at 4:31 A.M. yesterday about 20 miles northwest of downtown Los Angeles. It was felt from San Diego, 125 miles to the south, to Las Vegas, Nev., 275 miles to the northeast. Water and natural gas lines were ruptured, sending torrents rushing water through streets and fireballs billowing into the predawn sky. Dozens of homes and other buildings collapsed.

 THE EARTHQUAKE -- The quake that rattled Southern California awake was by far the most destructive in recent years because it struck ina heavily populated area. Buildings and highways collapsed, power and water were cut off, hundreds of people were hurt and more than a score dies. (Continued From Page A1.)

HEADLINE: A Warning Exit in Moscow

 BODY:
On its face, Yegor Gaidar's departure from the Russian Government is a blow to Boris Yeltsin and an embarrassment to President Clinton. Only last Friday in Moscow, Mr. Clinton praised President Yeltsin for his commitment to economic reform, though he was apparently then aware that Mr. Gaidar, one of Russia's ablest reformers, was about to quit as First Deputy Prime Minister. Citing profligate decisions taken without Cabinet consultation, Mr. Gaidar gave a blunt farewell: "I cannot be at one and the same time in the Government and in opposition to it."
A dramatic exit, certainly. But not yet a last bow for Mr. Gaidar, who has quit, or threatened to quit, on previous occasions. Resignations are a way of forcing decisions, and one of the biggest facing Mr. Yeltsin is whether to continue on a ruinous inflationary course. The specific moves protested by Mr. Gaidar illustrate the point: the earmarking of $500 million for a lavish new parliamentary building and, far more troubling, a proposed monetary union between Russia and insolvent Belarus. 
 The draft agreement with Belarus, adopted by the Yeltsin Government without discussion, provides that already weak rubles would be exchanged one for one with a still weaker local currency, worsening Russia's own monetary hemorrhage. It is the kind of decision that has made Viktor Gerashchenko, chairman of the Russian central bank, a symbol of incompetence. He has printed money chiefly to keep unproductive factories afloat. So appalling has been his stewardship that Boris Fyodorov, the Finance Minister as well as a Deputy Prime Minister, threatens to resign rather than serve with Mr. Gerashchenko.
To view these disputes as arguments over the pace of reform wholly misses the point. Runaway inflation sabotages any economic system, and the poorest are the biggest losers. Voters cannot eat worthless rubles. Unfairly if understandably, Mr. Gaidar's reformist party was punished in recent elections by frustrated Russians who turned to ultra-nationalists.
Fiscal restraint is a precondition for any functioning economy, with or without reforms -- a point underscored by Mr. Clinton and his economic team in their overtime talks last week. How Russia moves against hyperinflation is first and foremost the job of the Russians themselves.
While not taking sides in Moscow's internal quarrels, Washington needs to keep pressing for an end to fiscal folly. Seen in this context, Mr. Gaidar's exit is a warning that, if unheeded, could presage a calamity.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: EDITORIAL

HEADLINE: Observer;
The Won't-Do Guy

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
I have been studying the Washington news this past week while you, I'll bet, have been in deep immersion with ice skaters and the families Bobbitt and Menendez.
Am I being condescending? Absolutely not. The kneecapping of Nancy Kerrigan and the Bobbitt and Menendez bloodlettings speak painfully of our time and place. 
 There is real significance in stuff like this, and you can be sure the Washington news people would not only find it, they'd make your hair stand on end by explaining it, if they weren't so busy saving the nation from its bumbling Presidents.
What, after all, could be more American than blowing the old folks away with shotguns while they're eating ice cream in front of the TV set? That's right: not just apple pie, but also telling the jury you did it in self-defense.
What could be more American than the butcher knife in the bedroom and the club to the knees in the ice rink? Right again: not just apple pie, but also the automatic pistol, reveling in the opportunity to say "penis" out loud, and paying millions of dollars to athletes willing to praise breakfast cereal.
Still, while studying the Washington news may be dusty, musty work for the unlusty, somebody has to keep track of the Union's ever-declining state. Thus I can report as follows:
President Clinton still won't do.
That's the consensus of the press and television newsfolk whose duty is to grade our Presidents. Some do it in newspaper columns, some do it in news stories and some do it in weekend television's noisy grading sessions.
These can be seen on national networks between Friday night and the start of the Sunday football games but, except by masochists, they are pretty much ignored outside Washington. Besides grading the President, the experts of press and television point out what he is doing wrong, how he could do it right, what he ought to be doing but isn't, how he should do it and how he can stop making a terrible mess of everything.
This, it usually turns out, requires him simply to take the advice of the reporter or columnist who has successfully shouted down all his colleagues and hijacked the camera.
Washington columnists with inferior lung power tend to shun these raucous TV grading sessions and issue marks more sedately in print's discreet black-and-white.
Has any President been more thoroughly graded during his first year than Bill Clinton? Surely not. This week, marking the end of his first full year, naturally brought end-of-year report cards.
Studying them, I am saddened but not surprised to learn that, in the judgment of these Washington news people wise in governance, President Clinton simply won't do.
The reason I am not surprised is that when they graded him last week they also said he wouldn't do. What's more, in their year-end report cards issued to fill the news doldrum between Christmas Eve and Twelfth Night, we all remember what they said, don't we? "Won't do."
If you've ever had a child who shouldn't have taken Particle Physics 101 in the first place you know it's no fun having these grades on your President sent home from journalistic equivalents of Professors Oppenheimer, Fermi and Teller.
They began when he'd been less than a month in the White House: "Won't do." Then came the depressing "First Hundred Days" report: "Still won't do."
A successful speech or two and a couple of occasions when Republicans voted his way because his way was the Republican way -- these brought a little relief. "Slight improvement this week." Always followed by the same old report after the news experts' latest assembly: "Just won't do."
Having studied the wisdom of these graders, I know what the President must do to succeed, and list just a few of these things here: Get tougher with North Korea, come clean pronto about Whitewater, either adopt a dynamic new foreign policy or cut out foreign policy altogether, show contempt for labor and civil rights leaders, find out what Republicans want done and do it, do something absolutely brilliant about Bosnia, talk less, and tell his wife to stay out of the office and mind her own business.
Personally, I say he'll have to stop saying "grow the economy." You grow tomatoes, not economies. Presidents who don't know the difference just won't do, and I'd like to say so if you'd just point the camera my way.

TYPE: OP-ED

HEADLINE: Entire Region Must Share in Economic Growth

 BODY:

To the Editor:
We were pleased that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City and Governor-elect Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey met Jan. 6 to begin ending New York-New Jersey economic border warfare. 
 Their pledge to work together and meet regularly is a second step in the right direction that began with the Mayor's initiative to form a regional alliance with the county executives of Nassau, Westchester, Suffolk and Rockland counties last November.
But New York City and New Jersey should expand their neighborly embrace to include Connecticut and other nearby New York counties. The regional challenges of a stronger economy, better transportation and a healthier environment do not end at the Fairfield or Orange County lines.
Most important, it is time to set out an agenda to move from rhetoric to action. Here are some suggestions:
* Promote the region's strongest industry clusters, such as biomedical technology, professional and information services, financial services, so that we can all share in growth.
* Invest in our extensive but fragmented rail systems, linking them into a true regional network.
* Develop a regional capital budget to maximize the impact of all of our infrastructure investments.
* Create links between urban community groups and suburban employers to find inner-city residents jobs.
We need such initiatives to restore the three-state area's economy and quality of life.
 
H. CLAUDE SHOSTAL
President, Regional Plan Association
New York, Jan. 7, 1994

HEADLINE: Woodward & Lothrop Files For Bankruptcy Protection

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Woodward & Lothrop Holdings Inc., the parent company for two venerable retailers in the Washington and Philadelphia areas, said yesterday that it had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code and had reshuffled top management.
Joining in the filing, which was entered in United States Bankruptcy Court in New York, are John Wanamaker Inc., the Philadelphia-based retailer that is a Woodward & Lothrop subsidiary, and Woodward & Lothrop Inc., the retailer that has catered to Washington customers for more than a century. 
 The company said that Arnold H. Aronson, the former head of Saks Fifth Avenue who made a bid to acquire Woodward & Lothrop Holdings in the late 1980's, had resigned as its chairman and chief executive.
Robert B. Mang, who since 1991 has served as president and chief operating officer, was named to succeed Mr. Aronson.
Rumors that the company would declare bankruptcy have been heard in retailing circles for weeks.
Woodward & Lothrop, with 16 stores in the Washington-Baltimore area, and Wanamaker, with 15 stores in Philadelphia and southern New Jersey, are regarded as strong franchises. Still, the parent company has been hampered by debt obligations incurred in the mid-1980's when the company was purchased by A. Alfred Taubman, the Bloomfield Hills, Mich., real estate developer.
In 1984, Mr. Taubman paid $226 million, much of it borrowed money, for Woodward & Lothrop. Two years later, he paid $183 million for John Wanamaker in another highly leveraged transaction.
"Our highly leveraged balance sheet has generated increasingly burdensome levels of debt and interest expense which, over the past several years, have made it extremely difficult to operate our business competitively," Robert J. Mulligan, Woodward & Lothrop Holdings' vice chairman, said in a statement announcing the bankruptcy filing.
A statement from Mr. Taubman said he "wholeheartedly" supported management's efforts to "see that a strong, competitive Woodward & Lothrop emerges from the reorganization as soon as possible."
Mr. Taubman, who unsuccessfully tried to sell the company in 1988, has been propping it up with infusions of cash over the years.
Analysts said rumors circulated in the fall that Mr. Taubman had told Woodward & Lothrop management that his patience and financial support had run out. He remains the company's largest creditor.
Servicing a huge, high-interest debt was made more difficult by the recession that hit the Middle Atlantic States in the late 1980's. Moreover, analysts said that the company had fallen prey to image problems, as well as increased competition.
 
Strategy Called Confusing

 
 "Their merchandising hasn't been bad," Peter Schaeffer, a partner at Johnson Redbook Service, a retailing and apparel research firm, said. "But over the last few years they tried to move from being a moderately priced chain to being more upscale. Then they tried to move back downscale. Those moves have confused and angered customers and caused them to stay away."
The privately held retailer has liabilities of roughly $600 million and assets of slightly more than $600 million, Mr. Schaeffer said.
Frederick H. Taylor, director of corporate bond research at Salomon Brothers, said the bankruptcy filing was "a combination of too much debt and underperformance."
According to Mr. Taylor's estimates, Woodward & Lothrop had sales of about $850 million and earnings before interest, taxes and depreciation of about $36 million. "They ought to be making roughly twice that amount," he said.
 In its announcement, Woodward & Lothrop said it had received commitments for approximately $300 million of debtor-in-possession financing from the CIT Group.
Mr. Mang said the financing package was "more than adequate" to support continuing operations. He added that the bankruptcy filing would have no effect on "customers or employees" of the stores.
Mr. Schaeffer said he was a bit skeptical that the reorganization could be brought off that cleanly. But he added that the company had an even chance of emerging from bankruptcy without being forced to sell either of its chief assets.
 
An Analyst's Predictions

 
 Walter Loeb, who heads his own retailing consulting firm, said, "I frankly think Woodies has some underperforming assets that have to be closed, and that it will be a leaner company when it emerges" from bankruptcy protection.
If Woodward & Lothrop is forced to sell either of its main businesses, analysts identified Federated Department Stores as a potential buyer for the Woodward & Lothrop chain. They said the May Department Stores Company, which owns the Hecht's department stores in Washington, might be interested in John Wanamaker.
Mr. Mang said speculation about sales of either business was just that. "There are no plans at present to sell this business," he said. "Our total efforts are being directed at further strengthening the company financially and restructuring its balance sheet."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 19, 1994, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
A picture caption in Business Day yesterday with an article about the bankruptcy filing of Woodward & Lothrop Holdings Inc. misidentified the subject in some copies. He was A. Alfred Taubman, the real estate developer who controls Woodward & Lothrop, and not Arnold H. Aronson, who resigned as the company's chairman and chief executive.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY'S NEW GOVERNOR;
Inaugural Surprise: Whitman Wants Tax Cut Now

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman, New Jersey's 50th governor and its first female chief executive, today called for an immediate and early start on her campaign pledge to cut state income taxes by nearly a third.
Governor Whitman, who was sworn in today before an enthusiastic assemblage at the Trenton War Memorial, proposed that the first installment of tax cuts for individuals and businesses be retroactive to Jan. 1, rather than wait until July 1 and the new fiscal year. The cuts must be approved by a Legislature controlled by her fellow Republicans. 
 "I will not hedge, I will not backtrack," Governor Whitman declared. "I will keep my promises to you, my friends, to the best of my ability, so help me God." [Page B4.]
Although her accelerated tax cut will not change anyone's tax bill, compared with her original campaign promise, her proposal drew gasps and applause.
Governor Whitman, who had been criticized during her campaign for failing to offer specific proposals, used her inaugural address to deliver a brisk catalogue of policy initiatives. Most governors have taken the occasion to paint a broad vision of their administrations, but she turned the address into an early State of the State speech, outlining the problems faced by New Jersey and providing a plan of action, much of it intended to create a more hospitable climate for business.
"We will be competitive," she said. "No more losing our employers to job raids by low-tax states. New Jersey is open for business." Mrs. Whitman mentioned Pennsylvania as one of the neighboring states that competes with New Jersey for jobs. But she pointedly avoided mention of New York City, the source of many transplanted firms for New Jersey, but with whose Mayor and fellow Republican, Rudolph W. Giuliani, Mrs. Whitman has pledged an end to economic border wars.
New Jerseyans have lost faith in the promises of their government, the new Governor said. The schools are unsafe, she continued, state government is often incompetent, taxes are too high, and jobs are draining away to low-tax states.
Besides promising to cut income taxes retroactively, Mrs. Whitman pledged to eliminate state income taxes for residents earning less than $7,500, saving them about $150 a year, and proposed to cut the business tax rate by three-eighths of one percent, to 9 percent, saving state businesses about $40 million a year. Both measures would be retroactive to Jan. 1.
Governor Whitman also proposed to inoculate Education Commissioners against political interference by giving the commissioner, who now serves at the will of the Governor, a fixed five-year term.
 
Mandatory Life Sentences
 She also applauded and approved a pilot program to give parents in Jersey City greater say in which public school to send their children to, and she said the program would be expanded if deemed successful.
Like Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York in his State of the State address earlier this month, Governor Whitman asked for mandatory life sentences upon a criminal's third conviction for violent crime.
And with a flourish, Mrs. Whitman called her chief counsel, Peter Verniero, to the podium as she signed her first Executive Order, creating an Economic Master Plan Commission to improve the business climate.
Governor Whitman has often said she would see her program enacted without either cutting services or forcing municipalities to make up for lost state aid by raising local taxes. Today, she repeated that commitment, pledging "the same or better services for less."
Her new plan to enact a 5 percent tax cut retroactive to Jan. 1 will not increase the tax savings she had already proposed for New Jerseyans for 1994 or the cost to the State Treasury of making good on her pledge to cut state income taxes by 30 percent over three years. By extending the tax cut for the full year, she answers a major complaint about starting the tax cuts in July, which was that it is difficult for the Department of Taxation to change tax rates in the middle of the tax year.
The retroactive tax cut at 5 percent has the same effect over the entire year of the 10 percent cut she had initially proposed to take effect July 1. That cut would have applied only during the last six months of 1994.
For a married couple filing jointly with total taxable income of $50,000, the Whitman tax plan would mean a saving of $345 annually.
Nevertheless her plan to make the tax cut retroactive stirred a buzz and her jab at the Clinton Administration, whose midyear tax increase last year applied to the whole calendar year, drew laughter and applause.
"Let's not keep economic growth waiting another minute," Governor Whitman declared. "If President Clinton and his Congress can reach backward into time and raise your taxes retroactively, your Governor and your Legislature can cut them retroactively."
 
Right Date, Wrong Year
 Legislative Republicans responded favorably to the new proposals.
"I knew it would be Jan. 1," Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco, who presided at the inauguration, quipped after her speech. "I just didn't get the year straight." Mr. DiFrancesco had publicly suggested that a tax cut wait until 1995. But he and other Republicans made it clear they expected her to come up with ways of paying for her tax cuts and mandatory sentencing proposals.
"Sure, we'll pass it; a tax cut's easy to pass," Senator DiFrancesco said later. "The big part here is, she's committed her Cabinet people to come up with cuts. So the pressure's really not on us; the pressure's on them to come up with the money."
Robert E. Littell, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, also said he would embrace a tax cut as long as the offsetting budget reductions make sense.
"The tax cut is doable," he said in an interview, "but in order to find the votes for it in our committee, we have to know where the spending cuts are." Mrs. Whitman has promised to deliver budget details on March 15.
Democrats repeated their long-held skepticism about the feasibility of cutting a budget already afflicted with a built-in deficit by an additional $500 million a year for three years, as the 30 percent cut implies.
Accordingly, the Democrats appeared to draw battle lines along the Governor's promise that the tax cuts would not translate into higher local property taxes for schools and town government.
"We have no interest in a tax cut proposal that smacks of dubious smoke-and-mirrors fiscal tactics," said Joseph V. Doria Jr., the Assembly minority leader. "We have no intentions of being party to a tax cut that gives money with one hand, while taking money away with the other."
Other groups likely to be heard from as Mrs. Whitman's plan unfolds include a host of local government officials and public employee unions whose members enjoy pay scales and work schedules that are generous by state government standards.
Mrs. Whitman became Governor on a radiant winter's day, taking over a state whose economy is beginning to show distinct signs of improvement, yet whose electorate remains broadly beset with economic anxieties ranging from the depressed values of their houses to faltering job prospects of their growing children.
Mrs. Whitman appeared to speak to this restive mood when she promised to shake up the way state government is operated, and she sounded a theme that was often heard from President Ronald Reagan:
"Our principal problems are not the product of great global economic shifts or other vast, unseen forces," she said. "They are the creation of government."

HEADLINE: Henry Balgooyen, Trade Expert, 81; Advised Presidents

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Henry Warren Balgooyen, an economist and Presidential counselor who devoted many years to the fostering of inter-American cooperation and free trade, died on Saturday at his home in Katonah, N.Y. He was 81.
The cause was pneumonia, his family said. 
 Mr. Balgooyen's mastery of international commerce took him to many conferences in the Americas as a delegate or adviser, starting in the 1940's. An expert on Latin American affairs, he counseled Presidents Dwight D. Eisenhower, John F. Kennedy and Lyndon B. Johnson.
Over the years, Mr. Balgooyen headed or held high office in the Pan American Society, the Americas Foundation, the Ecuadorian-American Association, the Argentine-American Association and the Bolivarian Society.
Other organizations in which he held office included the Institute of International Education, the American Enterprise Institute and the Council for Latin America.
A native of Hadley, Mich., Mr. Balgooyen graduated from the University of Michigan and received an M.B.A. degree there in 1929. He started his business career in the foreign department of Chase National Bank and eventually became president and chief executive of American and Foreign Power Company in New York.
In the late 1960's, the company merged with Ebasco Industries, from which he retired in 1968 as senior vice president.
Mr. Balgooyen is survived by his wife of 63 years, Violet Linden Balgooyen; two sons, Warren P., of Norridgewock, Me., and Bruce W., of Chico, Calif.; a daughter, Marjorie B. Drysdale of Randolph, Vt.; 10 grandchildren, and one great-grandchild.
Another daughter, Carol B. Wilkinson, died in 1988 after a long illness, and Mr. and Mrs. Balgooyen also raised her four children, Stephanie, Eric, Mark and Joseph.

HEADLINE: THE EARTHQUAKE: Coping;
Aftershocks in Paradise: Hearts Are Trembling Too

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Jan. 18

 BODY:
A few days ago, Diana and Morrie Eisenman were Rollerblading along the beach here in perfect sunshine, smug about living the California dream while their East Coast friends shivered and shoveled.
Today was another beautiful day in paradise in this beach-front city, where the urban thoroughfares meet the shining sea, so Mr. and Mrs. Eisenman again put on shorts, T-shirts and sunglasses and pedaled along the promenade. 
 But on this outing, accompanied by a friend, they noticed the heaps of bricks on the sidewalk, the telltale police tape and the pinch of dread in their hearts more than the rustling palm trees, the flawless sky or the balmy temperatures.
This uneasiness about the place they call home was not a new feeling for the Eisenmans or their friend, Terry Martin -- not after two years rudely punctuated by riots, fires, floods and grim economic news.
 
A New Urgency
 But they experienced it today with a new urgency, as the region rattled with the aftershocks of a deadly earthquake, and Angelenos asked themselves if the dangers of living in Southern California had finally outstripped the dream.
"Do other places have this multiplicity of disasters?" asked Mr. Martin, a real-estate broker.
"Especially lately," interjected Mrs. Eisenman, who manages a boutique too damaged to open today.
"It makes you feel jinxed," said her husband, a film producer who has lived here for 20 years. "It drains your mental resources. After a while you feel numb. I think a lot of people are going to move because they can't take the helpless feeling. It makes you think you should take your chances elsewhere."
Mrs. Eisenman, a transplanted Texan, suggested just that on Monday night, when she was ragged from sleep deprivation and edgy from long hours of watching televised images of destruction and death. Instead, she snapped off the round-the-clock news, popped in a National Lampoon videocassette and waited to see if she would feel different in the morning.
And "maybe because it was a beautiful day," Mrs. Eisenman said, she did. But her husband awoke contemplating an easier life elsewhere. "Some days you just feel it's not worth it here," he said. "But it comes and goes and usually we don't feel that way simultaneously."
 
'An Incredible Setback'
 Mr. Martin, who experienced the bust years in New York City in the mid-1970's and the boom there a decade later, said he was hoping, until the predawn temblor on Monday, that this beleaguered city was about to turn around.
"It felt very much like New York City at its emotional ebb," Mr. Martin said, "and I thought we were poised for a renaissance. After this rubble clears, that still might happen. But this is an incredible setback."
The Northridge earthquake, which killed at least 38 people and which early accounts said caused $7 billion in damage, came atop two years of other deadly, expensive disasters here, both natural and caused by humans.
Fires, floods and storms in Southern California in 1993 led to 26 deaths and $1.3 billion in damages. And the 1992 riots touched off by the acquittal of four police officers in the beating of a black motorist caused more than 50 deaths and $1 billion in property losses.
 
A Sense of Apocalyptic Times
 Add to those disasters the scores of lives lost and the billions of dollars of damage from the earthquake in the San Francisco area and the Oakland Hills firestorm, all within the last five years, and Californians cannot be blamed for feeling they are living in apocalyptic times.
Some of those strolling the pier and the sandy beach here today insisted that there had to be an end to this surfeit of suffering, that surely calm would soon be restored to the nation's most populous state, which is reeling from recession.
"The worst of it has to be over," said Stephen Hutton, who works in the computer industry. "It can't keep on like this."
Mr. Hutton said he had no plans of leaving and managed the stress by alternating between his home here and a weekend refuge in the desert. "It's very exhausting," Mr. Hutton said, "and many times I've wanted to leave. But it's such an exciting place to live."
"You mean terrifying," countered Terry Kelley, a childhood friend from Dallas who had been contemplating a move to California until this week, when he was thrown from his bed in the pitch black, heard the incessant clatter of helicopters and the wail of sirens and felt his knees turn to jelly. "There's a big difference between excitement and terror."
Everyone on the promenade today had a different idea about which of the recent plagues here was the most upsetting. Mr. Hutton picked last fall's wind-driven fires, which he watched scorch the Malibu hills from a promontory at the juncture of Wilshire Boulevard and Ocean Avenue. "It just kept coming and coming and coming," he said. "Closer and closer."
 
Coming Unglued
 Mr. Kelley voted for the earthquake. "You can drive away from a fire," he said. "You can run from a riot. But an earthquake that slams you out of bed at 4 o'clock in the morning. . . . I still can't trust my legs. My heart won't stop beating. I don't believe it's over. With all this shifting of pressure, one day it's going to come unglued. And that will be worse than hell in terms of carnage."
But Richelle Mickle, heading for a game of Frisbee on the beach with her fiance, Griffin Wright, said the riots and her fear of crime were what would chase her from the Los Angeles area, if only she could find a job someplace else.
"We're focused on a family one day," she said, "and bringing up children here, with so many guns, is frightening."
Mr. Terry, for his part, argued that earthquakes, fires and riots all touched the same dark place in his soul. "Financially, intellectually, emotionally, I'm able to cope with most of the things that come into my life," he said. "But fires, riots and earthquakes crack that illusion of control. It doesn't put me in a panic mode, but it does make me acknowledge my interconnectedness to the whole environment."
Mr. Terry was asked if the latest calamity here might prove for him to be the proverbial straw that breaks the camel's back. "I don't know if this is the straw or the straw will come next month," he said. "Because who knows what's going to happen then."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

NEW YORK CITY
 
HOSPITALS UNIT PROPOSES CUTBACKS

A BUDGET WITH AN EYE ON NOVEMBER
In an ideal election-year budget, a chief executive spreads largess far and wide, and the closer the money gets to the swing voters the better. New York's economy has not recovered sufficiently to afford Governor Cuomo that luxury. So Mr. Cuomo did the next best thing. He proposed a budget that allowed him to declare that the state, under his stewardship, had turned the fiscal corner. News Analysis. B6.
 
BUDGET IS ASSAILED OVER MEDICAID
As cities and towns across the state digested what was in Governor Cuomo's proposed budget, New York City and surrounding counties complained about what was left out, a state takeover of local Medicaid costs that could save them millions of dollars. B6.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY'S NEW GOVERNOR: Reporter's Notebook;
Little Warning Given of Tax Cut in Whitman Speech

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
In a town where political secrets have never had much of a shelf life, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman managed to protect a major one on her tax-cutting plans.
So there was more than a little stir today, over both the theater and the substance of the statement, when Mrs. Whitman used her inaugural address to ask the Republican-controlled Legislature to enact a 5 percent income tax cut for every family in New Jersey retroactive to Jan. 1. 
 Mrs. Whitman said later that her chief counsel, Peter Verniero, had spoken with senior staff members of the Republican legislative majority on Monday night and advised them of the tax announcement.
Still, the word did not reach many movers and shakers in Trenton until today.
"It wasn't a surprise to me," deadpanned Senator Robert E. Littell, chairman of the Senate Budget Committee. "I knew about it 15 minutes ahead of time."
 
Piecing Together a Speech
 Governor Whitman delivered one of the few scripted speeches of her political career today -- a collaboration that involved her own work, supplemented by contributions from various members of her staff and borrowings from some more practiced Republican orators.
There was a bit of Abraham Lincoln:
"We in government must have a patient confidence in the ultimate justice of the people."
A lump of Reaganism:
"Our principal problems are not the product of great global economic shifts or other vast, unseen forces. They are the creation of government."
And there was the politically de rigueur recognition of someone in the audience who stands as an exemplar of the point that the new Governor was trying the drive home. In Mrs. Whitman's case, it was Claudia Grier, an 8-year-old second grader from Neptune, who she met last week when the class visited her at the State House and delivered a bundle of letters.
Mrs. Whitman interrupted her speech today to introduce the schoolgirl and incorporated parts of the girl's letter in her inaugural message.
"We should all learn to share and be nice to each other," Mrs. Whitman said, quoting the letter. "I know that you have a demanding job ahead of you and I will be there to help you."
 
All in the Family
 The Bible that Mrs. Whitman used to take her oath of office was used nearly 80 years ago in the inauguration of a New York governor.
The American Bible Society Bible was purchased in New York City in 1852 by Seymour Whitman, the great-grandfather of Mrs. Whitman's husband, John R. Whitman.
In 1915, Charles S. Whitman, the grandfather of John Whitman, used the same Bible at his inaugural. Mr. Whitman was Governor of New York from 1915 to 1918.
 
Rubbing Partisan Shoulders
 Politics makes for strange bedfellows, and as it turns out, even stranger seating arrangements.
United States Senator Frank R. Lautenberg and State Assembly Speaker Garabed (Chuck) Haytaian, likely rivals in what promises to be one of the most expensive Senate races in history, found themselves sitting shoulder-to-shoulder today at the swearing-in of Mrs. Whitman.
Mr. Lautenberg, a two-term Democrat, and Mr. Haytaian, a Republican who as Speaker holds the third-highest elected office in the state, shook hands and appeared to exchange small talk.
Mr. Haytaian has said that he will formally announce on Jan. 25 as a candidate for the Republican nomination to face Mr. Lautenberg, whose seat is among those targeted by the national Republican Party in its bid to take control of the Senate this fall.
Party leaders on both sides have predicted that as much as $15 million could be spent in the New Jersey race, which they say could be one of the hardest-fought campaigns in the nation.
But the political fireworks today were limited to the 19-gun salute, a traditional honor for a governor, which was fired by the New Jersey National Guard at the conclusion of Mrs. Whitman's oath of office. The thundering startled residents in some sections of Trenton and set off dozens of car alarms.
 
Of Fame and Fans
 Waiting outside the Governor's office with former Gov. Thomas H. Kean and soon-to-be-former Gov. Jim Florio to leave for Mrs. Whitman's inauguration, former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne offered an insight into the fleeting fame that comes with political leadership.
Mr. Byrne recalled an episode during his first term as Governor when he was stricken by a violent viral infection that required that he be carried by stretcher from his office to a waiting ambulance.
Mr. Byrne said that as he was being carried from the State House, many of his aides were worried that he might have suffered a heart attack. But from somewhere in the crowd of onlookers who gathered came the cry:
"Hey, who's using your Giants' tickets this weekend?"

HEADLINE: Chung Il Kwon, Korean General And Premier, 76

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. LYONS

 BODY:
Chung Il Kwon, the chief of staff of the South Korean Army who became a national hero at the age of 32 while commanding forces at the start of the Korean War in 1950, died on Monday at a hospital in Hawaii. He was 76.
The cause was cancer, his family said. 
 He left the army in 1957 as a four-star general and served for 20 years in high positions in the South Korean Government. He was the Prime Minister in 1964, during a period of sustained economic growth.
 
Led South Koreans at Inchon
 During periods of the fiercest fighting with North Korean and Chinese forces, General Chung served as a tactical commander of his country's forces, winning the respect of American military leaders. As a major general, he led South Korean units during the landing of United Nations forces at Inchon. Shortly after that, the North Koreans were forced out of most of South Korea.
He received his early military training in Japan and served as a captain in the Japanese Imperial Army during World War II. After the war he served in the Chinese Nationalist Army, and then joined the nucleus of what became the South Korean Army.
In 1960 he became Ambassador to the United States and later served as Foreign Minister and Speaker of the South Korean Parliament. During the 1960's Mr. Chung studied international relations at Harvard University and political science at Oxford University.
Mr. Chung was a political ally and confidant of Gen. Park Chung Hee when General Park seized power in South Korea in a coup in 1961. Mr. Chung later became Prime Minister in the Park Government, and he served in the Government in one capacity or another until he was dismissed by President Chun Doo Hwan in 1980.
Mr. Chung is survived by his wife, Park Hye Soo, and four children.

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK STATE BUDGET;
Cuomo Calls For Tax Cuts For Business

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 18

 BODY:
In an election year in which the economy looms large as a campaign issue, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed today what he described as a pro-business budget that would cut an array of business taxes, provide modest increases for education and anti-crime efforts and establish new restrictions on health-care services for the poor.
The budget is Mr. Cuomo's least painful in five years, calling for only 160 layoffs in the state's 151,000-member work force, no major service reductions and small increases for programs that faced severe cuts in recent years, including the arts and libraries. Under the proposal, the $33.4 billion general fund budget for the fiscal year starting on April 1 would grow by 3.8 percent, the first time in six years that it would grow faster than the rate of inflation. 
 The budget, which requires the approval of the Legislature, in many ways continues the Governor's recent tight fiscal policies, and Mr. Cuomo said he hoped that those "prudent" measures would help improve the state's bond rating, which is the second lowest among the 50 states, after Louisiana.
 
On Cusp of Recovery
 The most significant initiatives in the budget proposal are tax cuts, not service improvements. Describing the state economy as on the cusp of vigorous recovery but in need of a boost, Mr. Cuomo called for reducing or phasing out more than a dozen taxes and fees on businesses, worth $210 million in 1994-95 and an increasing amount in subsequent years. The budget also includes an income tax credit for families that earn less than $25,300 a year, which would cost the state $50 million in revenue in the 1994-95 fiscal year.
The tax cuts would be balanced largely by higher-than-expected revenues from personal income and other taxes, he said.
But the tax cuts would also be financed partly by reductions in some programs, including restrictions on health-care services for the poor. Mr. Cuomo, who is seeking his fourth term this year, defended his efforts to improve the business climate even if it involved squeezing some social services.
"The only source of our wealth is going to be private-sector business because we cannot count on Washington to bail us out as they did in the old days," he said at a news conference. "It's not a question of saying I like rich people more than that sick woman there."
But in the Legislature, both Democrats and Republicans can be expected to push for additional spending on local programs, particularly since all are up for re-election.
Though the budget message sounded themes long championed by the Republicans, leaders of the Republican-controlled State Senate accused Mr. Cuomo of promoting "runaway" social spending while not making deep enough tax cuts. And they attacked Mr. Cuomo's revenue projections as too conservative, saying more money should be allocated to school aid, a measure that would hold down local taxes.
The State Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, an Oyster Bay Republican, said, "The Governor's budget proposal is an election-year document that is long on rhetoric but short on ideas and results."
 
Support in From Assembly
 The Democrats who control the State Assembly expressed broad support for Mr. Cuomo's proposal, especially the earned-income tax credit. But they indicated concerns that the budget does not do enough for the working-class and poor.
"As we start to enjoy an economic recovery, we will work to make sure that all New Yorkers share in our economic revitalization," Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat, said in a statement.
The budget proposal is based on forecasts for somewhat stronger economic growth, with total state income rising by 4.7 percent. While Mr. Cuomo said higher profits are expected in most sectors of the economy, they are expected to be tempered by continued layoffs at large corporations, particularly the International Business Machines Corporation, and plans to close the Air Force base in Plattsburgh and cut back the base in Rome, N.Y.
 
Closing the Gap
 In developing the budget, Mr. Cuomo also had to close a gap of more than $3 billion between projected revenues and projected spending. To do that, he proposed saving the state $800 million by deferring, as he and the legislators have done several times in the past, scheduled reductions in the personal income tax and not allowing $275 million in hospital taxes to be phased out. He also used a $299 million surplus in the current budget to help close the gap.
There are in fact three different ways to add up the state budget; depending on which one is used as a base, there are three ways to measure how the Governor is proposing to increase state spending. The most commonly used yardstick is the $33.4 billion general fund budget, which is financed largely through state revenues; that is the one that will grow nearly 3.8 percent. The second is the state funds budget, which includes capital spending and programs financed by fees earmarked for specific purposes; that budget would increase by 5.5 percent to $42.6 billion. The third is what is known as the all-funds budget, which includes Federal money and which would increase by 6.1 percent to $62.6 billion.
Though the state is reaping more revenues on most of its taxes this year, Mr. Cuomo proposed some new sources of income. Those include a new lottery game, Keno, that he said would generate $74 million in 1994-95, a $15 fee for new pistol permits and a $10 fee for three-year gun-license renewals. He also called for allowing the state to collect $50 million a year for uncollected bottle deposits.
Mr. Cuomo had proposed the Keno game last year, but it was killed by the Legislature. "There are concerns that raising revenue that way is regressive," said Michael Moran, a spokesman for Assembly Speaker Saul Weprin, a Queens Democrat. "People who can least afford it are often the ones who play the game."
Mr. Cuomo proposed several measures intended to improve the state's credit ratings. Those include paying off this year a $120 million Medicaid payment that is due next year, increasing to $311 million a special fund to pay for litigation against the state, and ending a 36-year tradition of borrowing in the spring to pay off last year's bills. The budget also includes fewer "one shots," which are one-time sources of revenue that will not be around next year. Those drop to $78 million, compared with $103 million in the current budget.
"It really does show a commitment to achieving long-term stability," said State Comptroller H. Carl McCall. But Mr. McCall chided Mr. Cuomo for not repaying local governments this year for $222 million in pension fund contributions that the state used to close past budget gaps. Mr. Cuomo called for repaying the money over several years.
The budget calls for curbing Medicaid costs by $185 million to keep growth of Medicaid spending to 8 percent. It would do that by reducing payments to hospitals by about $45 million and cutting payments to nursing homes by $50 million, primarily by allowing them to keep only 75 percent of their profits. It would also cut $54 million in client services by eliminating coverage for non-emergency transportation costs and restricting inpatient psychiatric services.
Mr. Cuomo called for increasing aid to local primary and secondary schools by 2 percent to $198 million, bringing total state school aid to $9.3 billion. New York City would receive $88 million of that total. His budget would also increase aid to state universities by $77 million and to the City University of New York by $37 million. He said no tuition increases would be needed in either system.
 
'Excelsior Schools'
 Mr. Cuomo proposed using $15.5 million for the planning and preliminary construction of what he calls "excelsior schools": residential high schools that would accept exceptional science and mathematics students. The schools, to be situated on state university campuses, would be modeled after New York City's Stuyvesant High School and Bronx High School of Science, Mr. Cuomo said.
In a year when Mr. Cuomo and the Senate have proposed tougher penalties for violent offenders, the Governor did not call for any new prison construction. But he did propose spending $17 million to convert the closed Gowanda Psychiatric Center into a 750-bed prison.


GRAPHIC: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed these major cuts in taxes and fees.
 
BUSINESS TAXES: Would reduce the corporate surcharge on corporations, banks, insurance companies and utilities from 15 percent to 12.5 percent halfway through the 1994 tax year and to 10 percent midway through the 1996 tax year. Cost in the 1994-95 fiscal year: $70 million.
 
EARNED INCOME TAX CREDIT: Would create a credit on the state personal income tax for working New Yorkers with incomes below $25,300. The credit would be equal to 5 percent of the Federal earned income tax credit in the 1994 tax year and would rise to 10 percent in the 1995 tax year. 1994-95 cost: $0.
 
REAL PROPERTY GAINS TAX: Would exempt construction projects or substantial renovations that are started before the end of 1995. 1994-95 cost: $0.
 
Would make various changes to reduce the amount of gain subject to the tax. 1994-95 cost: $28 million.
 
HOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX: Would reduce the 5 percent tax on hotel rooms that rent for $100 or more to 2.5 percent on Dec. 1, 1994, and would eliminate it on Dec. 1, 1995. 1994-95 cost: $8 million.
 
PETROLEUM TAXES: Would eliminate the tax of 10 cents per quart on lubricating oil on Sept. 1, 1994. 1994-95 cost: $8 million.
 
ESTATE TAX: Would allow a special credit for estates when a closely held business represents more than 35 percent of an estate. 1994-95 cost: $2 million.
 
SALES TAX: Would create a process that would permit businesses to retain 1.5 percent of the state sales tax they collect from consumers on goods and services, up to $400 a year. 1994-95 cost: $12 million.
 
MISCELLANEOUS FEES: Would eliminate various fees, including those charged for companies thay pay wages by check, for inspections of coin-operated laundries, for Environmental Conservation applications, for vapor recovery systems at gas stations, and for incorporation filings. 1994-95 cost: $4 million.
 
Would impose a $15 fee for a new pistol permit and a $10 fee for each three-year renewal. 1994-95 revenue: $4.8 million.
 
Would increase fees for professional licenses and registration by about 31 percent: 1994-95 revenue: $10.4 million.
 
"THE BUDGET: Balancing the Books"
Charts: "THE BUDGET: Putting Money Back in Some Pockets"
 Highlights of the budget plan for the 1994 fiscal year released yesterday by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
 
TAXES: Calls for reducing state taxes and fees by $210 million in 1994-95, including reducing the surcharge on state business taxes, phasing out the state hotel tax, eliminating a tax of 10 cents per quart of motor oil and providing an income-tax credit for families making less than $25,300 a year.
 
EDUCATION: Would increase state aid to local schools by $198 million, to $9.3 billion. Calls for no tuition increases for the state university system or the City University of New York.
 
HEALTH:j Woudl increase spending for AIDS programs by $8.7 million, to $83 million. Woudl curb the growth in Medicaid spending by reducing coverage for inpatient psychiatric services, eliminating nonemergency transportation programs and restricting certain payments to nursing homes and hospitals; total Medicaid spending would be $5.7 billion, $185 million less than it would be without the change.
 
DEBT REFORM: For the first time since 1958, would eliminate borrowing in the first quarter of the fiscal year to pay for the previous year's costs, a policy that has contributed to the state's low bond rating.
