HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Unable to Maintain Strong New York Opening

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar declined across the board yesterday in largely technical trading on world currency markets.
Gold prices were mostly higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery settled at $393.60 an ounce, up $1.40 from Monday. The Republic National Bank said spot gold gained $1.30 an ounce, to a late bid price of $392.80. 
 The dollar opened domestic trading on a relatively strong note as trading resumed after Monday's holiday honoring the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Many traders were expecting the dollar to move even higher.
 
 
'Ran Out of Steam'
 But the upward move "just kind of ran out of steam," said Frank Pusateri, a vice president with the Bank of Boston. He said there was a dearth of news for traders to focus on, and trading remained largely technical.
Dealers were divided over whether Germany's Bundesbank would lower interest rates at its regular policy-making meeting scheduled for tomorrow.
Tom Yi, a vice president at ABM-Amro Bank N.V. in Chicago, said he was "fairly confident" the Bundesbank would keep rates at their current levels. That would help strengthen the mark, since higher interest rates in Germany tend to enhance the yield of mark-denominated securities.
 
 
Dollar Slips Against Mark
 In late New York trading, the dollar slipped to 1.7465 marks, from 1.7525 marks on Monday. It also fell to 110.79 Japanese yen, from 111.05 yen.
Meanwhile, the British pound rose to $1.4960 in New York, from $1.4935.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's rates, included: 1.4605 Swiss francs, down from 1.4770; 5.9325 French francs, down from 5.9540; 1,699 Italian lire, down from 1,706, and $1.3138 (Canadian), down from $1.3178 (Canadian).

HEADLINE: Bentsen Seeks Freer Asian Markets

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen today laid out the Clinton Administration's strategy for gaining access to foreign markets for American financial service companies, which say they are being shut out of some of the world's biggest emerging economies.
Asian stock markets, outside of Japan, have grown in value since 1988 from $180 billion, to $1 trillion, but many countries in this region still put severe constraints on American investment banks, brokerage firms, commercial banks and insurance companies that want to sell their services in these markets. 
 Asian and other developing governments say they are afraid of being dominated by American financial institutions, or having too many banks competing for limited capital, and have restricted their ability to operate or expand with branch offices.
 
Bringing Down Barriers
 One of the reasons for Mr. Bentsen's trip to Indonesia, Thailand and China, which he visits on Wednesday, is to brief governments in the region about how the United States intends to bring down the barriers to its financial services. The recently concluded General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade negotiations in Geneva failed to reach a consensus on this point, after endless wrangling between the United States and the big emerging economies of Asia and Latin America.
In a speech to the Thai Bankers Association, which Treasury officials hope will be heard around the region, Mr. Bentsen presented the American approach. Basically, he said, Washington will insist that from now until six months after the GATT agreement takes effect -- July 1995 -- countries that limit access to American financial services will have to enter into good-faith negotiations with the United States for a phased end to those barriers.
If they do not, the United States will likely retaliate by limiting the access of foreign financial service companies to the American market.
Mr. Bentsen stressed to his Asian audience the increasingly important role of financial services in the American economy. "Two-thirds of our output is in services," Mr. Bentsen told the Thai bankers. "Service exports are a major counterbalance to our imports of manufactured products. In 1992, we had a services surplus of $61 billion and a merchandise trade deficit of $96 billion."
Those who followed the GATT talks, Mr. Bentsen added, "know what a high priority the United States placed on the area of financial services." He said: "We were left with an unfinished agenda. And frankly, I'm disappointed we did not see more countries willing to liberalize."
Before his speech, Mr. Bentsen met with some of the leading American investment bankers in Asia, representing Morgan Stanley, Goldman, Sachs & Company, Citibank and J. P. Morgan, to hear their concerns about being restricted in lucrative markets like South Korea and Taiwan -- both of which are important conduits for capital into China.
John S. Wadsworth Jr., managing director of Morgan Stanley's Asian operations, who organized today's meeting with the Treasury Secretary, said Shanghai's newly organized stock market was expected to have a value of $2 trillion by the end of the century. That is not a marketplace that American investment bankers can tolerate being restricted from, but for now none are allowed to have seats.
Mr. Bentsen said there was still time to negotiate financial service agreements between the United States and its major trading partners before the GATT agreement goes into effect.
Three principles, he said, will guide the United States in these negotiations.
First, he said, "we will look for agreements that offer reasonable market access" and the same treatment for American firms as those of the host nation.
Second, Mr. Bentsen said, the United States will not take a heavy-handed approach to these negotiations. In particular, he said, it will not take any step during discussions that harms the existing operations of foreign firms already in the American markets and "we won't unreasonably refuse access to nations that aren't already in the U.S. market," he said.
Third, he said, Washington will seek an agreement that treats all nations alike. It will not tolerate a situation in which other countries retain the right to discriminate against American firms while their firms are permitted to expand into the American market.
In an attempt to reassure the Asians that the United States will not demand equal access to their own financial service institutions overnight, Mr. Bentsen said: "We understand that many nations consider their financial system to be an integral part of their development strategy, and that it must remain largely in domestic hands. We understand that there can be legitimate concerns about overbanking in small economies. We accept that greater access by foreign firms should not unduly disrupt domestic markets."

HEADLINE: Fed Official Will Resign

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Wayne D. Angell has submitted his resignation as a governor of the Federal Reserve Board, effective on Feb. 9, a spokesman for the Fed said today.
Mr. Angell's term expires on Jan. 31, but unless he resigned he would remain in office until the installation of his successor, not yet nominated by President Clinton. 
 Mr. Angell, one of the central bank's staunchest anti-inflation voices, had notified the Fed that he would not participate in the meeting on Feb. 3 and 4 of the Federal Open Market Committee, the main arm for setting monetary policy.
The departure of Mr. Angell, a professor and banker from Kansas, gives President Clinton his first chance to put his stamp on the institution. Senior Administration officials have recommended that George L. Perry of the Brookings Institution be named to the board, but there has not been a nomination announcement.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Reduced Real Estate Losses Bolster Big New York Banks

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Three of the largest New York banks said yesterday that losses from bad loans fell sharply in the last three months of 1993 as they renegotiated troubled real estate loans and sold properties they had repossessed.
The reduced losses, along with continued strong trading results, led Citicorp and the Chemical Banking and Chase Manhattan corporations to report sharply increased profits for the fourth quarter. All three said profits for 1993 were at record levels. 
 As a result, the three banks, which were in dire straits just two years ago, are now well on the way to restoring their profitability and financial strength.
"We have been lucky," Thomas E. Jones, the principal financial officer of Citicorp, said at a meeting with analysts yesterday. "I don't think anyone would have predicted 12 months ago the degree of liquidity in the real estate market that we have seen."
Also yesterday, two big regional banks that never got in much trouble, Nationsbank and Banc One, reported stronger earnings.
Citicorp and Chase cut their bad loans by about $1 billion each in the fourth quarter. Chemical reduced its bad loans by $607 million.
The banks said stable real estate prices enabled them to sell more quickly properties they had repossessed. And low interest rates allowed owners of troubled projects to borrow money to pay off their existing bank loans.
The decline at Chase was most impressive because of a particular emphasis on selling troubled real estate assets and loans to developed countries. The bank has $1.96 billion in bad loans, down by 34 percent for the quarter and down by 62 percent for the year.
Chase sold about $1 billion of its loans that it had made to developing countries. It also moved $1.4 billion, most of the remaining exposure, to its trading account to be sold as market conditions permit, virtually eliminating problem third-world debt from its balance sheet.
Citicorp and Chemical were not so aggressive, but both recorded gains of more than $100 million on the sale of bonds issued as part of restructurings of loans to less developed countries.
 
Citicorp
 Citicorp, as expected, earned $575 million for the quarter, up from $280 million a year earlier. For the year, the nation's largest bank earned $2.2 billion in 1993, up from $722 million in 1992.
Problem real estate loans and repossessed properties fell by $634 million in the quarter, to $4.1 billion.
Citicorp, which has had the lowest capital ratios of any big bank, increased its Tier 1 capital, the main measure of financial strength, to 6.5 percent of assets, up from 4.9 percent a year earlier.
The bank posted a return on equity of 19.9 percent for the quarter and 17.7 percent for the year. A return on equity of 18 percent is considered highly profitable for a bank.
 
Chemical Banking
 Chemical's fourth-quarter profit was $347 million, up 14 percent from a year earlier. The quarterly earning of $1.23 a share was higher than analysts' expectations of $1.15 a share.
Bad loans and repossessed real estate fell by 15 percent, to $3.5 billion in the quarter.
The bank's Tier 1 capital was 8 percent, up from 7.3 percent a year earlier.
Chemical's profitability, as measured by the return on equity, was 13.4 percent for the quarter, a below-average result because of higher taxes. For the year, the return was 16.7 percent.
 
Chase Manhattan
 Profits at Chase were $313 million for the fourth quarter, up 85 percent from $169 million a year earlier.
The bank reported earnings of $1.53 a share, higher than analysts' expectations of $1.06 a share. For the year, Chase reported profits of $966 million, up 51 percent from the previous year.
The bank posted a return on equity of 17.9 percent for the quarter and 14.6 percent for the year.
The bank said it had reduced its portfolio of real estate held for sale by $500 million in the quarter. Chase has $475 million in problem real estate loans, compared with $2.01 billion a year ago.
Its Tier 1 capital increased to 8.4 percent, from 6.8 percent a year earlier.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY'S NEW GOVERNOR: On Her Own Course;
Whitman's Inaugural Speech Outlines Plans With a Sense of Independence

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 18

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman took the oath of office today and wasted no time in demonstrating that she intends to set her own agenda, whether or not it coincides with that of the Trenton establishment.
In an inaugural speech that reiterated the themes of her campaign and tried to dispel doubts about her pledge to cut taxes, Mrs. Whitman said she not only intended to fulfill her promise, but would also to make the tax-cut plan retroactive to Jan. 1, instead of waiting until July. 
 Mrs. Whitman made her call for immediate cuts in the $15.7 billion budget just as the Legislature was beginning to struggle with a budget that has a projected shortfall of $1.2 billion and a week after the Senate president, Donald T. DiFrancesco, suggested that the tax cut be delayed until next January.
In effect Mrs. Whitman issued a call to action to a Republican Legislature accustomed to setting its own agenda in its two years of jousting with a Democratic governor.
"What it really does is outflank DiFrancesco and the moderate Republicans who thought that cut should be delayed," said David Rebovich, a professor of political science at Rider College in Lawrenceville.
"It clearly establishes the fact that Whitman sees herself as the leader of the State of New Jersey and the Republican Party," Professor Rebovich said. "And it attempts to quickly get Jersey residents in the mindset of her administration, which is to cut taxes and cut spending.
Voters have virtually always shown that they liked Mrs. Whitman. They liked the way that she listened to them. They liked that she was not Jim Florio. They liked her proposal to cut the income tax by 30 percent over three years.
But next to the granite-faced Mr. Florio, Mrs. Whitman often appeared defensive, ill-prepared and lightweight in her campaign, which had frequent blunders and missteps. She narrowly beat an unpopular incumbent and left many voters wondering whether the blueblooded woman with a royal Republican background but little governing experience could manage a state as difficult as New Jersey. And the key to her victory -- the tax-cut proposal -- only reinforced the skepticism of those who viewed her as lacking in experience.
But in an unusually eventful transition and again in her inaugural address, Mrs. Whitman has demonstrated that she is steady under pressure, particularly during the Ed Rollins fiasco. And in her rejection of a deal worked out by Mr. Florio and the New Jersey Sports and Exhibition Authority that would have moved the Philadelphia 76ers basketball team to Camden, Mrs. Whitman has signaled that she will countenance nothing that might interfere with her goal to slash spending while cutting taxes.
In saying tax cuts would stimulate the sagging economy and that the quicker and larger the cuts the better, Mrs. Whitman has echoed Reaganism. At one point during her speech she said the principal problems of New Jersey stemmed not from the economy, but from government. She attacked excessive regulation and scoffed at the notion that the state needed two agencies to regulate its cemeteries.
"Many have lost faith in the ability of government to deliver services efficiently, to lend a helping hand when it is needed and to get out of the way when it is not," Mrs. Whitman said.
In opposing the politically popular 76ers deal, Mrs. Whitman seemed to establish a litmus test to judge the many proposals that will come before her. Will they require more taxes?
If the answer is yes or even possibly, Mrs. Whitman has indicated, she will not back down from powerful interests like the sports authority.
Despite her inaugural speech and its promises for quick action on taxes, Mrs. Whitman is not likely to break speed records in her first few weeks in office. In his first six months as Governor Mr. Florio pushed through the Legislature a $2.8 billion tax increase, a ban on semiautomatic weapons and a new school financing formula, and he paid the political price three years later. But Mrs. Whitman has shown herself to be more deliberative.
 
Next Ruling on Education
 In her campaign she set up commissions to study issues like economics and crime and waited for their reports before staking out positions. She sharply criticized Mr. Florio for pushing through his revamped education financing before the State Supreme Court had ruled on the issue, and said she would not venture into that thicket until the court rules again in the spring.
In the transition Mrs. Whitman appointed 14 teams to conduct fact-finding on every state department, board and authority and held a series of town meetings and call-in radio and television programs to hear taxpayers' suggestions on trimming the state budget.
 
Surprised by Fluency
 In contrast to perceptions of her as a novice on many policy issues, Mrs. Whitman was able to use her appearances during the transition to display her knowledge about a wide range of subjects. "She has shown a fluency on the issues that surprised me," Professor Rebovich said. "If this came out during the campaign she would have won by 15 points."
Mrs. Whitman's supporters say New Jerseyans can expect to see more of the creative problem-solving Mrs. Whitman now that she is in office. "So much of the campaign was waged on a lot of silly issues against her that the fact that she's a thoughtful person who has a lot of ideas never really came out," said Sal Russo, a political consultant in Washington who worked on Mrs. Whitman's primary campaign. "She can make the tough decisions."

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK STATE BUDGET: An Eye on November;
Budgets Have a Variety of Audiences: Voters of All Stripes and Bankers Too

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 18

 BODY:
In an ideal election-year budget, a chief executive spreads largess far and wide, and the closer the money gets to the swing voters the better.
New York's economy has not recovered sufficiently to afford Gov. Mario M. Cuomo that luxury. So today Mr. Cuomo did the next best thing. He proposed a budget that allowed him to declare that the state, under his stewardship, had turned the fiscal corner after four nightmarish years. 
 He also found enough cash to make at least symbolic commitments to the vital elements in his re-election platform: a warmer climate for business, a welfare system that emphasizes work, and a tougher approach to crime. But he deferred much of the cost of politically popular proposals, like cutting business taxes, until after the November election, when the economy presumably will be stronger.
 
What Isn't There
 What may be most significant about Mr. Cuomo's 1994-95 budget is what it does not include: the tax increases, fiscal gimmicks, layoffs, college tuition increases, and deep cuts in social services and aid to education that he relied on to close huge budget gaps in the last four years.
For the first time in six years, Mr. Cuomo recommended increasing spending at a rate higher than the rate of inflation -- 3.8 percent, compared with an estimated inflation rate of 3 percent. While Mr. Cuomo proposed real cuts in Medicaid programs -- $185 million evenly distributed among hospitals, nursing homes and patients -- the reductions pale when compared with the billion-dollar cuts he has proposed in previous years.
Yet, the budget also reflects Mr. Cuomo's dual feelings that the state's revenues are not yet strong enough to splurge, and that moderation is needed to impress Wall Street bond raters.
The business tax cuts he recommended are modest, and many would have little fiscal impact on the 1994-95 budget. Of the $700 million in revenue that the state eventually would lose from the tax cuts, only $200 million would be lost in the coming year.
 
Small Increases
 Mr. Cuomo would increase spending for economic development programs that retrain workers and provide incentives for companies to locate and expand in New York. But the increases are in the tens of millions, not the hundreds.
His proposal to reorient the welfare system would cost the state little, and his new crime-fighting initiatives would absorb only a few million in a $33.4 billion general fund budget.
For example, the Governor has boasted in recent weeks about Operation Firebreak, which he said would deploy 100 state troopers to combat violent crime in upstate communities. But he disclosed today that only 50 of the officers would be newly hired. The others would be reassigned from New York City.
Mr. Cuomo would increase aid to education by $198 million. That is a vast difference from the cuts in school aid he has proposed in the past. But it still is only a 2 percent increase over the current year.
In one clear sign that campaigning has begun, Mr. Cuomo said he would insure that no school district suffers a cut in state aid. That is a change from budget proposals of recent years that have called for deep cuts in aid to suburban schools to pay for increases in urban and rural districts. The suburban districts are home to moderate and conservative voters that Mr. Cuomo must woo if he is to win a fourth four-year term.
 
The Battle Lines
 The Republicans who will oppose Mr. Cuomo this year in both the Legislature and the campaign are not likely to disagree with his direction. But they already have drawn battle lines over the depth of his commitment. The tax cuts, they argue, are too small and too slow to have any effect. The increase in school aid, they say, should be larger.
"The Governor's new budget proposal, much like the newfound fiscal conservatism expressed in his State of the State message earlier this month, offers great promise," the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, said. "But as usual, he fails to deliver."
Senator George E. Pataki, a Republican from Peekskill who plans to run for governor, said Mr. Cuomo's tax cuts are too small to make a difference, particularly given that the Governor and Legislature have rescinded larger scheduled tax cuts in each of the last four years.
"At best it's a token effort and any person who's looking to make an investment in this state knows that it's token," he said.
Mr. Marino and Mr. Pataki called for deeper cuts in social services, without specifying what they would be. Perhaps more significantly, Mr. Marino questioned whether the Governor's revenue estimates were too conservative. That suggests that the Senate may simply declare that more money is available and then seek to spend it on tax cuts and education. After all, state legislators face re-election this year too.
If Mr. Cuomo's projections are too conservative, it may be because he does not view the voters as the only audience for his budget. He is also seeking to please the decision makers at Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's, the Wall Street bond rating agencies that dropped the state's credit rating so low that it is the second lowest among states. Few events would make for better election-year symbolism for Mr. Cuomo than a mid-year increase in the bond rating.
"This budget is a great budget to go to the raters with," Mr. Cuomo said today, citing the budget's conservative revenue estimates, its dedication of $82 million from this year's surplus to a reserve fund, and its relatively small number of non-recurring revenue measures.
At least one bond rating executive, Richard J. Marino, the director of Standard & Poor's, said he was encouraged by just those factors. "It potentially could have a positive impact on the ratings," he said.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY'S NEW GOVERNOR;
Excerpts From Whitman's Address on Leadership, Taxes and Schools

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's inauguration speech, as transcribed by The New York Times.
Today's inauguration marks not a victory of partisanship, but a test of our democracy, of our ability to govern ourselves. As a people we face a crisis of confidence. Many have lost faith in the ability of government to deliver services efficiently, to lend a helping hand when needed and to get out of the way when it is not. 
 We worry about the ability of our economy to generate jobs and restore prosperity. We question the ability of our schools to deliver the quality education our children deserve at a price their parents can afford. We question the ability of our criminal-justice system to prevent crime and to deliver justice and safety.
Americans have lost faith in institutions that are the foundations of our democracy. They question those they have elected to serve them. Wherever I go, whether I'm at a shopping mall, attending a Devils or a Nets game, taking questions on a call-in show I hear the same implicit question. After the oaths, after the speeches and the parties and festivities, will you remember your promises and will you keep them?
As the first statement of my governorship to every voter in New Jersey, let me answer that question. I have just taken the oath of this office you have entrusted to me. To me this oath means one thing. I will not hedge. I will not backtrack. I will keep my promises to you, my friends, to the best of my ability, so help me God.
But I can't do it alone. I need your help, your wisdom and your support. If government is to be for the people, it must be of and by the people. For democracy to work, as Abraham Lincoln said in his first inaugural speech, we in government must have a patient confidence in the ultimate justice of the people. Government must trust and listen to the people, or it is not a democracy. That is why I've spent the last four years listening to you. And it is why I will keep listening for as long as I am your Governor. 
I believe in the people of this state. I believe in open government. I believe that the best decisions are based on consensus and like you, I believe deeply in the fundamental need for change. To those who question whether I'm serious about bucking the special interests who hold so much quiet power in this city, let me be clear. I did not run for Governor to conduct business as usual. It is going to be different around here.
The only way government can win back your trust is to earn it.Our principal problems are not the product of great economic shifts or other vast unforeseen forces. They are the creation of government, of government that puts special interests ahead of the people's interests, of government that refuses to change. You know it, I know it, and this time together we're going to fix it.
 
Leader on National Scene
 New Jersey should lead the nation. In a world driven by ideas and technology, we boast some of the world's leading telecommunications, pharmaceutical, chemical and other high-tech firms. We have first-class universities, great ports and a prime location between America's financial and political seats of power. We have great natural resources, from the Highlands to the Shore.
New Jersey should be the engine of economic growth that leads this nation into the 21st century. It should be a powerful engine of prosperity that gives our children the same opportunity that our parents worked so hard to give us, the chance for a better life.
Together we will unshackle that economic engine from the restraining chains of high taxes. Four months ago I said I would put 1.4 billion of your tax dollars back in your pocket by cutting taxes over the next three years, with the first cut coming in July. The skeptics groaned, but here we are.
 
Retroactive Tax Cut
 And, I say, why wait until the next fiscal year starts in July? Between now and then families have car payments and credit-card bills that will come due. Senior citizens on fixed incomes will be struggling to make ends meet. And businesses have payrolls to make. Their plans to create new jobs are sitting on shelves waiting for a stronger economy.
Let's not keep economic growth waiting another minute. If President Clinton and his Congress can reach backward into time and raise your taxes retroactively, your Governor and your Legislature can cut them retroactively.
That is why I will be asking my partners in the Legislature, Senate President Donald DiFrancesco and Assembly Speaker Chuck Haytaian, to enact a 5 percent income tax cut for every family in New Jersey effective Jan. 1, 1994, 18 days ago.
Secondly, I am asking the Legislature to eliminate all taxes on those earning less than $7,500, again retroactively to Jan. 1. Those who are struggling the hardest need a tax cut the most. Third, I'm asking the Legislature to cut the corporate business tax to 9 percent, again effective Jan. 1 of this year.
We will be competitive. No more losing our employers to job raids by low-tax states. New Jersey is open for business.
Crafting a budget that covers not only the cost of these tax cuts, but also makes up more than $1 billion in previous one-shot revenues will not be easy. We must do so without cutting the state's services on which so many of us depend. We must do so without driving up the property tax. The shell game of raising one tax to cut another is over.
My budget task force and the 350 citizens who served on my transition teams have been poring over every department's budget. My Cabinet officials take office with a mandate to find ways to provide the same or better services for less.
 
Ideas for Savings
 Hundreds of citizens have been writing in with their ideas on how we can save 5 cents on every tax dollar that we spend. Let me tell you, once we put our minds to it, it's amazing all the ways you can find to save money.
Take just three areas. A vast amount of uncollected bad drivers' surcharges are owed to the state. Yet no attempt has been made to collect them. We're owed unclaimed Federal Medicaid funds for health-care services provided to poor children by their schools. And even an inmate from Rahway state prison wrote in to the Our Tax Dollar program to point out that more than $160 million in fines owed by criminals have never been collected.
Together these three areas alone offer the potential for closing the budget gap by several hundred millions of dollars. What's more, almost $200 million has been left unspent in each of the last two budgets because programs were overfunded. I am directing my Cabinet to try to save at least that much from current-year accounts. Budget cuts are just part of the equation.
To cut taxes in each of the next three fiscal years will require sustained economic growth. Economic growth doesn't just happen. We have to plan for it, encourage it and court it. That is why I have directed my Secretary of State to serve as an advocate for business. And it's why the first executive order of my administration, which I will sign in front of you today, creates the New Jersey Economic Master Plan Commission. This commission will develop the long-term strategy we need to make New Jersey the economic powerhouse it deserves to be.
Done.
 
The Campaign for Jobs
 Make no mistake about it, we are in a battle for jobs with Pennsylvania, the Carolinas and the Sun Belt every single day. One of the main reasons we've been losing that battle is state government. We must cut through the needless overregulation that drives businesses out of New Jersey and discourages new firms from locating here.
We can protect the environment without taking years to process a permit. Our businesses deserve better, and you deserve better. It isn't just a question of money being wasted. It's a question of duplication, inept planning and inadequate services.
We have 68 Department of Labor field offices. Yet in some counties we require unemployed workers to sign up for unemployment benefits in one office and then drive 10 miles to another office to find out what jobs are available.
Look at how the state regulates cemeteries. If you are buried only with members of your own religion your corpse is regulated by the Attorney General's office. But if you're buried in a nonsectarian cemetery, the Department of Banking has jurisdiction over your remains. That's right, banking. Do we really need two different state agencies to regulate the dead?
 
$15 Billion Corporation
 From cradle to grave our state government needs reform. We must reinvent government the way American corporations have been reinventing themselves to survive in the 1990's. You elected me as a chief executive officer of a $15 billion service corporation with 60,000 employees. And that's what we're going to provide -- service -- efficient, cost-effective service. After all, we work for you.
And of all the tasks we are entrusted to perform as your government, nothing is more sacred than our responsibility to educate your children. The school system we have today was developed in the 19th century to prepare the children of farmers and new immigrants for an industrial revolution that wanted bodies for repetitive factory work. The world has changed. And our education system must change with it. Employers today require a highly educated work force that knows how to think and how to be creative.
The state that can provide the best educated workers is the state that will be the powerhouse of the 21st century. The states that fail will fall behind. We must make New Jersey No. 1. We, parents, teachers, students, administrators, government leaders and business executives must work together to reinvent education. We must make it our top priority to teach our children, all our children, to read in kindergarten and first grade and second grade, when they're enthusiastic about learning. That way we will not have to spend tens of millions of dollars in junior high school, high school and college trying to rectify the failures of the past.
 
Competition for Schools
 We are going to inject competition and encourage innovation by developing alternatives like magnet schools and charter schools within our public school systems to give parents a choice of where to send their children.
Schools should compete for the chance to teach our children. They are our greatest treasure. If we are going to teach democracy in our schools, we should practice democracy in our school systems.
In Jersey City five long years of state control have not fixed schools that continue to do far too little. We should give Mayor Brett Schundler the green light to test school vouchers and invite the top school experts in the nation to measure the results.
We will get politics out of the Department of Education by giving the Education Commissioner an independent five-year term. We will push authority down to the local level, because I trust parents who love their children to get involved in school boards and P.T.A.'s. The state can give you better schools, but you must be responsible for raising your children.
We will develop a strong core curriculum that teaches every student the basics of reading, writing, arithmetic and respect for our nation's heritage. We will make our schools safe and we will demand discipline in our classrooms. The last thing children should learn about in school is violence and fear.
 
Victims of Crime
 Personal safety is a sacred right in America. Our children, our parents, all of us deserve to live in peace. Yet far too many of us are imprisoned by fear of crime. Some say we should turn our heads, give up and just accept a violent crime-ridden society. Some say crime is too tough a problem to solve. My answer to them: we're tougher.
We know that a small percentage of hardened criminals commit most of the violent crime. It's time to make every criminal know that he or she will serve 70 percent of the court sentence. For three-time violent offenders, those who make a career out of crime, it should be three strikes and you're in, for life.
We also need to set up boot camps and other alternatives to teach young people who are toying with the criminal life that they want to go straight instead. Everybody deserves a second chance, but not a third.
Criminals are not the victims of society. Society is the victim of criminals.
The way to make our streets safe again is to make sure criminals know they will pay surely and perhaps permanently for their crimes, and we will.
 
Unity of Vision
 Our blueprint to make New Jersey first is an agenda of economic growth, good schools and safe streets, an agenda of hope, optimism and determination, of government that is for the people because it is of and by the people. The hope, the vision, the strength of our people, is our guarantee of success.
And what remarkable people make up this state. In the factories of Paterson and the research laboratories of Princeton, in the ethnic neighborhoods of Perth Amboy and the senior-citizen villages of Lakewood, in the towns of the Shores and the Pinelands and in the cities like Camden and Newark, all across our state, I have come to know so many of New Jersey's people. We are one family, one community, one state.
There is a phrase in Spanish that means all that, Somos un solo pueblo. When one of us is out of work, homeless, cannot read, is a victim of violent crime, we all suffer. And when we help one another succeed, we all succeed.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Former Gov. Jim Florio and his wife, Lucinda, listening to Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's inaugural speech. Governor Whitman called for an immediate tax cut. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
In many college dorms, brand pitches replace Che, rock bands and James Dean as poster subjects.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
WOULD you buy advertising posters and plaster a room with them? Of course not, you say.
If you're a college student, though, the alternative to pinning up glossy images from Madison Avenue might be staring at cinder block painted as cheerily as a battleship. 
 Now have your tastes in decorating changed?
That's the idea behind a company, Posters Preferred Inc., started by two former employees of Procter & Gamble who are themselves not long out of college. The company's Beyond the Wall catalogue, based in Westport, Conn., offers students an opportunity to order oversized ad posters. More than 500,000 copies are being circulated this month on 80 campuses nationwide; plans call for 2.5 million catalogues to be distributed at about 400 campuses in August.
The initial issue, running 24 pages, sells posters from marketers including Coca-Cola, Levi Strauss, Nabisco Foods, Pepsi-Cola, P.& G. and Volkswagen. The first poster ordered costs $10, the second $8.50, and each additional one $7, plus shipping.
"The idea came to me in college, when I was playing basketball in the gym," said Brian Gordon, 24, co-founder of Posters Preferred, who graduated from the University of Pennsylvania before working at P.& G. as a brand assistant on Head & Shoulders shampoo.
"There was a great banner in the rafters for ESPN, and I had to have it." After acting on his larcenous impulses, he said, "as I was running through campus, hoping not to get arrested, I thought, 'Why can't you buy these?' "
Dennis Roche, 28, the other co-founder, who graduated from Georgetown University before working on Bain de Soleil and the Pantene Pro-V hair care line at P.& G., said: "The ad is a billboard. And it lives with a student who's a point-of-entry consumer, so to speak."
The pair's efforts exemplify the unconventional approaches being made to aim sales pitches at the nation's 13.7 million college students, particularly those whom Roper College Track, a research service of Roper Starch Worldwide of New York, calls the core of the college market, the 5.1 million full-time undergraduates at four-year schools.
Students tantalize marketers because they are still forming their brand loyalties. And Roper College Track estimates the core group's total annual personal buying power at $25 billion. But students' life styles place them out of range of most advertising in traditional media.
"This is opportunistically a way to build awareness among a fairly difficult-to-reach audience," said Fran Myers, senior director of integrated marketing at the Nabisco Biscuit Company unit of Nabisco Foods of East Hanover, N.J. The company is offering a poster, 31 inches by 40 inches, titled "Indulgence," displaying a glass of milk surrounded by stacks of Oreo cookies.
Susan McDermott, a spokeswoman for the Coca-Cola Company in Atlanta, said, "This was a new and creative avenue by which we could reach an important demographic group." Coca-Cola has the back cover of Beyond the Wall, offering a 31-inch-by-40-inch version of a print advertisement for Coca-Cola Classic featuring an Always Cool polar bear from a popular commercial.
Mr. Gordon and Mr. Roche met at P.& G., refined the ad poster concept during walks home from the company's headquarters in Cincinnati and left last year for the entrepreneurial life. They are using lessons learned at P.& G. to operate Posters Preferred, which they began with a couple of hundred thousand dollars in personal savings and investment capital.
"This is the P.& G. coming out," Mr. Gordon said, smiling, as he recalled focus group interviews during which he and Mr. Roche asked students why they buy posters. (The most common answer: "To express something about myself.")
P.& G. decided to offer a Bain de Soleil swimsuit poster in Beyond the Wall, Kimberly Stewart, a spokeswoman, said, not because Mr. Roche worked on the brand, but because "we're interested in further developing the college-age market."
Posters Preferred is charging marketers $9,847 for each page in Beyond the Wall. In return, they get 5 percent of the poster sales and the names and addresses of the student customers, which they can add to data bases.
Cynthia Rhea Woods, vice president and management supervisor at TBWA Advertising Inc. in New York, said, "We're very intrigued because posters are a whole different kind of interaction between brand and consumer." TBWA is the agency for Evian water, which is offering a poster, 44 inches by 28 1/2 inches, called "Our Factory," showing the snow-capped French Alps.
TBWA is familiar with ads doubling as wall art because of the many consumers who collect the print ads it creates for Absolut vodka. And in the 1970's, marketers like Anheuser-Busch and Warner-Lambert distributed small free ad posters with college newspapers.
If memory serves, one for Listerine mouthwash showed a bottle perched on a narrow ledge at Notre Dame in Paris alongside a grotesque statue.
The caption? "Gargoyle with Listerine."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Post Modest Price Gain

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities posted modest gains yesterday amid expectations that the Federal Reserve Bank is not about to raise short-term interest rates. The gains reversed some losses from late last week, but came in the same choppy trading pattern.
By late in the day, the 30-year Government bond was being offered at a price of 9927/32 to yield 6.26 percent, down from 6.29 percent on Friday. Prices and yields move in opposite directions. 
 With no major economic news, analysts said that market participants were inclined to remain on the sidelines. The recent spate of upbeat economic news had left traders edgy and reluctant to take major positions, they said. Besides, traders said, there is a tendency in the market to lower prices of Government securities ahead of Treasury auctions.
 
Terms of Auction
 The Treasury is expected to announce today the terms of its coming two- and five-year note auctions, set respectively for Jan. 25 and 26.
Analysts at MMS International said the market traded lower early in the session, led by some heavy selling from a Japanese account and some dealers in the five-year sector, ahead of today's auction announcement.
With two-year and five-year notes to be auctioned next week and the Fed's quarterly refunding coming next month, the supply of Treasury securities is creating some uneasiness in the market, especially given the uncertainty over the first quarter's economic outlook, one dealer said.
Analysts said that securities with shorter maturities benefited from an abundance of cash in the market, as the proceeds from $21 billion in maturing seven-year notes and cash-management bills this week flow into the bill sector.
 
A Place to Park
 Investors generally seek out Treasury bills as a safe place to park money until the outlook on the economy and market is more concrete. This reinvestment appeal was evident in the weekly Treasury bill auction, which drew strong demand.
The economic numbers the market has come to rely on for direction may not yet provide clear-cut answers. Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities Inc., said that he did not trust economic numbers released in January or other winter months "especially those influenced by bad weather and earthquakes."
"They possess an unpredictable nature, and seasonal factors can't account for the random movement of winter month numbers." Mr. Fine said.
Mr. Fine said trade balance figures scheduled to be issued today should show the merchandise trade deficit at around $11 billion. "You'd need a number significantly far and away from the consensus to impact the market," he said.
The Johnson Redbook survey of retail sales' most recent figures showed that sales among selected leading retailers in the first two weeks of January rose 3.5 percent from the first two weeks of December.
 
Sees a Decline
 Mr. Fine said he expected to see a decline next week. "There's no doubt that bad weather in the Northeast and the California quake will affect retail sales numbers," he said.
As far as tomorrow's figures for December housing starts, "housing is on the upturn," Mr. Fine said. "I'm saying the number will be up a little," he added. "If it's down it's an aberration, but if it's up, it's a trend."
Dealers said many in the market were sure the Fed would in time raise short-term interest rates, but not before it had definitive evidence of growth.
Business inventories in October and December were up on strong auto numbers, since Detroit usually restocks inventories of automobile and trucks before retooling in the third quarter for the new models. But auto sales have fallen off, traders said, and if the current sales pace is not increased significantly, those sales, which have been a leading engine for the gross domestic product, will not be much of a factor in the second quarter.
 
Weekly Bill Auction
 The Treasury drew strong investor demand yesterday at its weekly bill auction of new three- and six-month securities. Traders said the auction of $25.2 billion in bills produced an average rate of 2.99 percent for a three-month bill and 3.15 percent for a six-month bill. Both were down from the previous auction, when the average rates were 3.02 percent and 3.18 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Japan Airlines Will Cut 5,000 Jobs in Revamping

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 18

 BODY:
In the days of Japan's economic boom, the nation's corporate warriors would fly off to their latest conquest in the lavish first-class or business-class sections of Japan Airlines.
But in tight economic times, Japan's humbled businessmen are flying coach. Or even worse, as far as Japan Airlines is concerned, they are flying on United. 
 Weighed down by the nation's lingering recession, the strong yen and aggressive competition, Japan Airlines said today that it would trim 5,000 people, or about 23 percent of its work force, over the next four years as part of an extensive reorganization aimed at cutting costs.
 
Hiring Foreigners
 The company, which has had heavy losses, said it would make the cuts through attrition, early retirements, transfers to subsidiaries and reduction of hiring. Only 80 pilots will be hired in the next fiscal year -- no flight attendants, ground crew members or office workers. And many of the flight attendants to be hired will be foreigners who can be paid less than Japanese workers.
J.A.L. also said it would cut its planned investment on new aircraft and ground operations in the four-year period almost in half, to 440 billion yen, or about $4 billion. As part of that cutback, the company will defer delivery of six Boeing 747 jumbo jets, a spokesman said.
While the airline previously instituted wage freezes, hiring freezes, voluntary retirement programs and other cost-cutting steps, the plan announced today was the most aggressive yet, reflecting the recognition by J.A.L. that its way of doing business was ill suited for the competition in today's airline industry.
The carrier, which was Government controlled until 1987, was known for pampering customers and employees. It uses 19 flight attendants on a jumbo jet flight between Tokyo and New York, while some competitors might use as few as 13, said Geoffrey Tudor, a J.A.L. spokesman. Pilots were taken to and from Narita Airport in Tokyo in limousines.
But with Japan's economy in a slump, sales of lucrative first-class and business-class seats are down significantly. American carriers, sharpened by deregulation in the United States, have become tough competitors, offering low prices and incentives like frequent-flier plans, which Japan Airlines and other Asian carriers were slow to match. A new airport that will open later this year in Osaka will allow foreign carriers to increase their service to Japan, putting even more pressure on J.A.L.
 
Continuing Poor Results
 Japan Airlines expects a net loss of 26 billion yen, or about $234 million, in the fiscal year ending in March, after a net loss the year before of 43.8 billion yen, or about $395 million. Revenues in this fiscal year are expected to fall for the fourth consecutive year, to 970 billion yen, or about $8.7 billion.
Susumu Yamaji, chairman of Japan Airlines, said J.A.L. and other carriers worldwide were losing money because of overcapacity in the industry. "That overcapacity is mostly provided by American carriers," he said late last year.
He has frequently complained that the 1952 aviation treaty between the United States and Japan is outdated and unfair because it gives more flights to American carriers even though most passengers between the two nations are Japanese.
To seek relief from the international market, Japan Airlines is trying to gain more business in Japan's protected and high-priced domestic market. But right now, that market is hurt by the recession as well, so Japan Airlines sometimes flies nearly empty jumbo jets on 90-minute hops.
Robert Rowland, an analyst with Barclays de Zoete Wedd Securities in Tokyo, said the steps announced today should allow the airline to earn a small profit in the next fiscal year instead of the loss he had projected.
"It changes my forecast quite dramatically," he said. "It will give them a fighting chance next year."
The airline previously said it expected that in four years as many as 30 percent of the cabin attendants on international flights would be foreigners. A Thai attendant, for instance, who lives in her home country, can be paid only a fourth as much as a Japanese attendant.
 
More Work for Charter Unit
 Today, J.A.L. said it planned to make more use of Japan Air Charter, a low-cost unit it set up in 1992 that has only Thai attendants and mainly uses American contract pilots.
While the unit now makes mainly charter flights, it would increasingly take over scheduled J.A.L. flights, mainly to tourist destinations like Hawaii. After the four-year revamping period, Japan Air Charter is expected to account for 20 percent of Japan Airlines' overseas flights, said Mr. Tudor, the spokesman.
As for the limos to the airport, those were eliminated in a previous cost-cutting move. "We succeeded in getting pilots to take taxis," Mr. Tudor said. Of course, in Tokyo, even a taxi ride to Narita airport can cost more than $100.

HEADLINE: How One New York Coffee Bar Came to Be

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
ON the southwest corner of 91st Street and Broadway stands Joe Bar, a modest glass and brick testament to the dreams of a New York couple and a college friend.
This is the story of Joe Bar, which began its commercial life on Nov. 20. It is also the story of three neophytes who seized upon the American dream of owning a business, refusing to be deterred by the naysayers, who warned of recession, high rents and other formidable risks. 

 
THE BEGINNING: JANUARY 1991
 David and Amelia Silver. A happily married couple, both 31, both on fast tracks toward successful careers in finance and marketing in New York. On a trip to San Francisco, the Silvers stopped in for coffee at Pete's, a trendy coffee bar. Mr. Silver, a copywriter at Ogilvy & Mather, the advertising agency, turned to his wife, a manager at the Bankers Trust Company, and said, "Wouldn't a coffee bar like this be great in New York?"
Mrs. Silver was intrigued by the West Coast coffee bars, casual places for people to meet, hang out and drink great coffee. Soon they were dreaming of opening their own coffee bar.
Back in New York, sleep didn't come easy. The Silvers were jolted awake by the voices of other coffee-bar owners who cautioned them to think twice. Would New Yorkers, who like their coffee in a New York minute, at no more than 50 cents a cup, be willing to pay $2 or $3 for special brews? Was the New York market ready for coffee bars?
Nonetheless, the Silvers saw opportunity on every corner. "New York is a very sophisticated city, and the product made a lot of sense," Mrs. Silver said. "We felt we could do well because of the density, amount of buildings and pedestrian traffic."
 
 
THE EDUCATION OF THE SILVERS
 Mr. and Mrs. Silver spent the better part of 1992 reading about coffee and attending business seminars. They enrolled in "How to Open a Coffee Bar" at the Learning Annex, a three-hour course taught by Paul Bernstein and Alan Phillips, the owners of Cooper's Coffee, two Upper West Side coffee bars. Mrs. Silver also attended a seminar sponsored by the Specialty Coffee Association of America.
"We figured if we were really serious, we'd better study up on the coffee business," Mr. Silver recalled. Although Mrs. Silver had done some catering in high school, the food business -- and all it entailed -- was no lifelong dream. It was new to them. But "by the time we started the actual process," Mr. Silver said, "we pretty much knew what our strategy was going to be, knew the kind of numbers we wanted to hit and whether that was achievable."
Basing their figures on the industry average, the couple knew it would take about $200,000 to open a coffee bar in Manhattan. Rather than seeking financing from investors, a process that would have delayed the opening, they decided to go it alone, using their own savings and some money borrowed from relatives. Before taking the next step, another essential piece was necessary: finding someone to manage the bar.
He and his wife couldn't afford to give up their day jobs, Mr. Silver said. "We had to find someone with a solid background in business, someone we could trust, to go in with us on this," he added.
Alison Prioleau, 31, a friend of Mr. Silver's from their college days at Wesleyan University, was the first person to come to mind. When Mr. Silver telephoned, she was working on an M.B.A. at New York University, planning to teach or start her own business.
"Coffee's a great, interesting product, but it's gotten a dated image," Ms. Prioleau remembers Mr. Silver telling her. Within a few minutes, her old college buddy had convinced her that New York needed a coffee bar -- with her as its manager.
 
 
THE LOCATION
 With Ms. Prioleau joining them as the manager and as an investor, the Silvers were ready to scout locations. The early part of 1993 was devoted "to finding the right spot," Mr. Silver said.
Initially, they looked in the Wall Street area.
"In scouting locations there, we noticed that everything starts early, around 6:30 A.M., and by 10 A.M., it's dead," Mrs. Silver said. "Plus, most of the business down there is five days a week. The weekends are dead. We knew we weren't going to be able to make a go of this in a 'three hour a day, five days a week' business, so we decided to look in midtown."
They estimated that they would need 300 to 400 customers a day to survive, the sort of traffic not easy to come by in most locations.
The rents in midtown were in the $10,000-a-month range, more than they wanted to pay, although the rent in the location they finally chose was no lower.
They found several storefronts on the Upper East Side, some priced at half of what was being asked in midtown. But they thought volume of the pedestrian traffic was too low.
"We would stand on a corner at a certain time of day and just watch the traffic go by a location and try to gauge what it was," Mrs. Silver said. "We weren't comfortable with the numbers."
It was June when Mrs. Silver spotted a "For Lease" sign in a shop on the west side of Broadway at the corner of 91st Street.
"For us, Broadway was the perfect location," Mr. Silver said. "It's open seven days a week, versus five. Also, it was a corner store, located on the west side of the street, which meant more of a premium. The sun rises in the east, so in the morning you get a lot of sunlight. And for some reason, people naturally walk on the west side of Broadway." Especially in the morning, when they are heading downtown to work -- and when they would want coffee.
In mid-September, the three principals signed a 10-year lease for the 600-square-foot space. The target date for opening was Nov. 16.
 
 
THE COFFEE AND RENOVATIONS
 To meet that goal, construction would have to begin by the first of October. The principals hired an expediter to help them navigate the city's byzantine licensing process.
Considerable time was spent at coffee roasters trying to find a special blend that would best suit discerning New Yorkers.
"We'd go to different roasters for tastings," Ms. Prioleau said. The roasters would pour hot water over freshly ground beans, allowing the coffee to brew until a crust formed at the top. Then the tasters would put their noses next to the cup, and with a spoon, break the crust. That released the aromas and allowed a close evaluation of the coffee. After that, they tasted the liquid. Within six weeks, the three neophytes were talking the language: a blend was not simply "good" but "rich, robust, not lacking acidity points." They chose a special blend of Costa Rican, Tanzanian and Sumatran beans.
The first major problem the principals encountered was an architect whose visions were far grander, and much more expensive, than theirs. They finally parted company and found another architect, the husband of one of Mr. Silver's colleagues at Ogilvy & Mather.
"We wanted a post-industrial look, and he came up with a lot of options," Mrs. Silver said.
Ms. Prioleau added: "We didn't want it to be too feminine or too cold and masculine. What we ended up with was a space that is mid-tech and homey without being clubby."
Some 120 applicants responded to a "help wanted" advertisement in The Village Voice. Ms. Prioleau chose 12 employees, whom she described as students and " 'struggling artist' types." The renovations were completed by Nov. 16, the planned opening date.
 
 
JOE BAR
 Seats 22. Open weekdays from 7 A.M. to 9 P.M., Saturdays from 8 A.M. to 10 P.M., and Sundays from 8 A.M. to 5 P.M. Menu includes caffe latte, espresso, cappuccino, house blend, cafe au lait and a special coffee of the week.
Mr. Silver came up with the name from "a cup of joe," 1940's slang for "a cup of coffee."
"The older types get it right away," Mr. Silver said. "Some of the younger clientele get it, but most come in here looking for Joe."
Despite its sleek tile and chrome decor, the bar has a warm, cozy ambiance, with its steel Rancilio espresso machine, a Fetco coffee brewer and Bunn warmers, track lighting, gray steel bar stools and tinted windows.
In plexiglass cases are an assortment of baked goods, everything from scones, muffins and bagels to chocolate cake, a selection culled from the suggestions of people in the business who knew the names of suppliers. Two weeks ago, light sandwiches with fillings like cheese and grilled vegetables were added to the menu. Hearty soups may be next. T-shirts, aprons and mugs with the Joe Bar logo -- a black and white sketch of a mug with droopy eyes, protruding nose and three strands of steam serving as hair -- are also on sale.
On the first day of business -- on Nov. 20, four days after the target date -- there were lines waiting outside the door.
"We learned our first lesson," Mr. Silver said. "Never open on a Saturday. It was a nice, sunny day, and we weren't prepared for the flow of customers."
Since its opening, the bar has drawn 300 to 400 customers a day.
 
 
EPILOGUE
 "We're doing better than we thought," Mrs. Silver said. "We thought we'd run much more of a loss in the beginning, and we haven't." In fact, the partners have had several tentative inquiries about selling their fledgling business.
Her husband added, "We're not out of the woods yet, but we've made money." He wouldn't say exactly how much.
Mr. and Mrs. Silver both work in Joe Bar on weekends. "People come in here just to wish us good luck," she said. "I think most everyone has thought of being an entrepreneur. It's kind of an American dream. But a lot of people don't have the courage to do it."
When the partners first made their plans, coffee bars were rare in New York. Now, they seem to be popping up on every block, more than a dozen in Manhattan in the last two years, by some estimates. Ted Lingle, the executive director of the Specialty Coffee Association, said that nationally, the number of coffeehouses and stand-up bars is projected to grow to 10,000 in 1999, up from 200 in 1989.
So far, Joe Bar's closest competitor is Cooper's Coffee at Broadway and 75th Street. But the partners believe that if they serve good coffee, they will flourish, no matter how many coffee bars open.
The Silvers and Ms. Prioleau see Joe Bar as only the beginning. Someday, they say dreamily, they'd like to see Joe Bars across America.

Drawing. "What Dreams Cost"
 Opening a coffee bar requires capital to lease space, renovate, buy equipment and inventory, and hire help. To start Joe Bar, the partners spent about $200,000. (pg. C1)

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Owners Adopt Revenue Plan, But It's Tied To Salary Cap

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 18

 BODY:
A Missouri Compromise propelled major league club owners to unanimous agreement tonight on a revenue-sharing plan that Bud Selig, the game's acting commissioner, called historic, unique and meaningful. But only labor negotiations with the players' union will determine if the plan ever goes into effect.
"This does not take effect until and unless there is a salary cap-type of basic agreement," cautioned Richard Ravitch, the clubs' chief labor executive, who worked for more than a year to produce an agreement under which clubs will share a greater portion of their local revenue. 
 The beginning of the end of Ravitch's quest came at midafternoon today when Stuart Meyer, the president and chief executive officer of the St. Louis Cardinals, presented a plan that was a compromise between the revenue-sharing plans favored by the high-revenue clubs and the low-revenue clubs.
"It's got some of the good points of both sides," said John Harrington of the Boston Red Sox, a spokesman for the group of eight high-revenue clubs that had blocked an agreement. "It's a consensus plan and that's what he's labeled it."
After an extensive series of caucuses at which Meyer's plan was altered back and forth, the owners approved the resulting plan, 28-0, at 9:25 P.M. to cheers and loud applause that resounded beyond their meeting room at Marriott's Harbor Beach Resort.
The agreement will allow the owners to proceed with two other critical matters: the election of a commissioner and the beginning of negotiations with the Players Association for a new collective bargaining agreement.
A group of low-revenue clubs had threatened to block the election of a commissioner if a new revenue-sharing plan were not adopted, and negotiations with the union had been put on hold a year ago pending the outcome of Ravitch's effort with the owners.
That effort could turn out to be futile. The players long have opposed a salary cap, and the past year hasn't produced a change in their stance. When Donald Fehr, the head of the union, was informed tonight of the owners' action, he was not overwhelmed.
"There's nothing like pre-determining the end of negotiations before you start," Fehr said by telephone from his home in Rye Brook, N.Y., alluding to the owners' insistence on a salary cap. "If the real hard part of the negotiations is supposed to be with players, I wonder how much time the owners have allocated to that. I would suggest many moons."
Selig and Ravitch refused to disclose details of the new plan, saying Ravitch had to inform Fehr first before they would make anything public. Basically, though, the plan will call for the wealthier clubs, like the Yankees and the Mets, to put a percentage of their local revenue into a pool that will be distributed to the poorer clubs, like the Milwaukee Brewers and the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Based on last year's revenue, Ravitch said, speaking in approximate terms and without offering figures, one-third of the clubs would have paid a significant amount of money, one-third would have received money and one-third would have been in the middle, neither paying nor receiving.
The collection and distribution of revenue, Ravitch further explained, will depend on "revenues, expenses and economic events, which we can't predict. So you could have 10 payers, 10 receivers and 8 who neutral out. But that number could change one way or another depending on economic circumstances. Clubs that meet certain economic standards pay, those that meet others receive. Some clubs, for example, will get new stadiums that transfer them from payees to payers."
There had been speculation in recent weeks that if the high-revenue clubs ever agreed to a plan, it would be so watered down that the low-revenue clubs would not get any significant funds. Discussing that possibility last week, Jerry Bell, president of the Minnesota Twins, a low-revenue club, said there would be a point beyond which it would be meaningless for clubs in the Twins' classification to approve it.
Asked tonight about the plan that was adopted, Bell said, "You can assume we do not see this as meaningless."
George Steinbrenner of the Yankees, who had been one of the staunchest opponents of a new plan, declined to comment as the owners walked swiftly to a dinner that had been delayed for three hours while they continued to hammer out a plan agreeable to everyone. Passage required 21 votes.
Ravitch was asked what was in this plan for clubs that will have to pay out money.
"They will derive an economic benefit from it," he said, tired but elated at the development. "There will be a higher degree of competitive balance. If you're a big-market club, you care about how many people come to your stadium. If a club 35 games behind comes in, you don't draw as well. They also will benefit from a new economic arrangement with the players."
Fehr and the players have said it doesn't matter to them how the owners distribute the money among themselves, that it would have no impact on them. But Ravitch said, "If there was not this agreement, we could not make such a proposal to the union because we wouldn't be in a position to fund that obligation to the union."

HEADLINE: OLYMPICS;
CBS Wins the Rights to '98 Winter Games

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR

 BODY:
One month after losing the TV rights to pro football to the Fox Network, CBS will announce tomorrow its victory over Fox in securing the rights to the 1998 Winter Olympics in Nagano, Japan, for an estimated $375 million.
Winning the Nagano rights provides a crucial jolt of adrenaline and good news to CBS Sports by providing a major event to look forward to so quickly after its failed football negotiations. And last year, CBS lost a last-ditch bid to renew its deal with major league baseball and was greatly outbid by NBC for the rights to the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta. 
 The $375 million is the most ever paid for the rights to the Winter Olympics, eclipsing the $309 million ABC paid in 1988 for Calgary Games. CBS paid $295 million for next month's Winter Olympics in Lillehammer, Norway.
"We surveyed the lay of the land and decided to do business with CBS," said Richard Pound, the International Olympic Committee's chief television negotiator. CBS is closely identified with the Winter Olympics; it broadcast the 1992 Games in Albertville, France, and its telecasts of the 16 days in Lillehammer will begin on Feb. 12.
 
Essentially Only One Bid
 But CBS was essentially the sole bidder. NBC and ABC had dropped out, deeming the expected price tag too steep. And Fox was told by the I.O.C. to cut its teeth on National Football Conference games before bidding on the Olympics. Fox, which knocked CBS out of pro football coverage after 38 years, won the N.F.C. rights beginning next season and lasting through 1997.
Upon winning the rights to the N.F.C. on Dec. 17, Fox executives voiced considerable interest in bidding for the Nagano rights.
"We met with Rupert Murdoch in December," Pound said, referring to Fox's owner. "They were enthusiastic, but between Fox and the I.O.C., we concluded the best thing for them to do was to concentrate on the N.F.L. You don't go from A to Z in a single day."
Betsy Hoffman, a Fox spokeswoman, had no comment on Pound's remarks.
The next Olympic rights negotiation will be in approximately two years for the 2000 Summer Games in Sydney, Australia, Murdoch's homeland.
Pound said that once Fox was eliminated from the mix, the I.O.C. and CBS negotiated to reach the $375 million sum.
CBS executives were unavailable to explain why, without competition, it bid so much for the Nagano rights or whether it chose to overpay to make a statement about its long-term viability in sports broadcasting.
Without football, CBS's primary properties are college basketball; golf, highlighted by the Masters; auto racing, including the Daytona 500, and the United States Open tennis championships.

 
 
'It's a Good Deal'
 "Considering the agenda CBS needs for its sports division," said Jon Mandel, senior vice president of Grey Advertising, "it's a good deal, but we'll have to see what the sports economy will be in four years."
CBS said it broke even on its Albertville telecasts; Mandel said the network would "come close to profiting on Lillehammer."
According to Pound, the I.O.C. and CBS had similar ideas about what the Nagano rights were worth.
"The number we reached was within both our ranges," he said. "I have no desire to make a killing and get out of town with an unfair price."
Asked whether the price reflected CBS's urgent desire to make a post-football statement, he said: "There may have been some of that, but all I can say is that the price we agreed on was one we thought to be reasonable."

 
 
N.F.L.'s Gain Is Nagano's, Too
 Dennis Swanson, the president of ABC Sports, said: "Nagano benefits from its particular place in the negotiating phase, coming right after the N.F.L."
Bob Silberberg, executive vice president of Backer Spielvogel Bates, the advertising agency, said: "I'm amazed the price went that high, but CBS wouldn't do it it if weren't supported financially."
CBS could reduce its financial exposure by linking up with a partner. For the 1992 and 1994 Winter Olympics, TNT has paid a combined $50 million to CBS for the cable rights.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy

HEADLINE: THE EARTHQUAKE: The Work Force;
2 Days After Quake, a Taste of Traffic to Come

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Los Angeles went back to work today, and the city's businesses concentrated on cleaning and coping. Their employees, reporting to the job in large numbers for the first time since the Monday morning earthquake, created some of the worst traffic tie-ups in recent memory.
Offices and plants close to the quake's epicenter in the San Fernando Valley sustained the worst damage, and many businesses there remained closed because they were uninhabitable or because collapsed freeways prevented employees from coming in. 
 But those people who did go to work got a taste of what life would be like for months to come.
Traffic snarled to a standstill along alternative routes to major highways, like the Santa Monica Freeway, that were damaged in the quake. Drives to work that normally took 30 minutes stretched to three hours or more.
Cars and trucks were backed up 10 miles on the northern border of the city, where the collapse of highway ramp closed both Interstate 5 and Highway 14 and forced all north-south traffic to the only alternative route, a much smaller road called Sierra Highway.
Traffic slowed even more in some areas as President Clinton and an entourage toured the San Fernando Valley. Gazing at a collapsed section of the Simi Valley Freeway, Mr. Clinton said, "There's a difference in seeing this, actually standing here and looking at it." [Page A18.]
On several major thoroughfares, like Wilshire, Pico and Santa Monica Boulevards and Sierra Highway, motorists sat bumper to bumper, swearing, honking, reading or listening to music.
When they were finally able to arrive at their place of work, they often spent the day cleaning it up, as at the badly damaged Anheuser-Busch Brewery in the Van Nuys section. Other employees arrived to discover that their businesses were still closed, and still others, who lacked water at home, took advantage of nearby health clubs to bathe.
 
Not Even Good Phone Service
 As usual, Mark C. Matlock, 32, a promotion assistant for the EMI Records Group, drove to his office on Sunset Boulevard from his home in the Rosamond section of Lancaster, 80 miles to the northeast. But what usually took 90 minutes took three hours because he had to use side streets to avoid the closed freeways.
"It was bumper to bumper all the way," Mr. Matlock said, "but the worst part of it was that the car phone didn't work because all the circuits were busy."
Asked if he was looking forward to making the trip twice a day for the next year while repairs were being made, he said, "You have no choice but to barrel in and do it." Still, he left for home early, at 2:30 P.M., hoping to beat the evening rush.
And things could get worst. David Royer, principal engineer in charge of traffic operations for the city's transportation department, said many San Fernando Valley residents did not even try to go to work today because their homes were still without electricity and water.
"We really didn't see the brunt of traffic problems today," Mr. Royer said, "but just wait a few days when everyone absolutely has to be back at work."
 
'Such a Mess'
 Congestion was made worse today, he said, because city engineers were unable to adjust the timing on traffic lights until power was restored and had to use cardboard signs for instructions on detours until the city could prepare the standard metal ones.
Many employees found their offices and businesses in disarray, with file cabinets and desks overturned and ceiling tiles littering the floor, andsome offices were flooded because the quake had activated emergency sprinkler systems. So employees at large and small businesses alike found themselves cleaning up, just like what they had been doing at home over the last 48 hours.
"It was such a mess in here, I thought someone had looted the place," said Cathy Bromley, a sales clerk at the Sky Fashion store in Santa Monica, about 10 miles west of downtown. "It took us three hours to clean up and put things back in order."
The Lockheed Corporation, a weapons contractor in Calabasas, about 10 miles north of the quake's epicenter, said that most of its 5,000 employees in Los Angeles County showed up for work today after being allowed to take Monday and Tuesday off. Keith Mordoff, a Lockheed spokesman, said it would take many days to clean up the sodden debris in the company's offices.
Twenty-seven of First Interstate Bank's 116 branches in the metropolitan area remained closed today because of broken windows, power outages and structural cracks. Employees of those branches had been reassigned, said Ken Preston, a bank spokesman.
In all, First Interstate sustained more than $1 million in structural damages, Mr. Preston estimated, but he said that most of the closed branches, if not all, should be open by the end of the week.
After closing for two days to repair minor damages, some businesses like the Century City Spectrum Club, a health club near Beverly Hills, reopened to discover that they were serving a new function. Members "were coming in to take showers before going to work because they had no water at home," said Dennis Burns, the Spectrum Club's manager.
Commuters from the Santa Clarita and Antelope Valleys, who were cut off from downtown by the closing of I-5, had the hardest time getting to work. Many formed carpools, took extensive detours or used public transportation like buses and trains.
Pete Harrigan, a Lockheed manager who lives in the Santa Clarita Valley, said he drove to work with several co-workers who live nearby. He said that they spent a lot of time on the phone on Tuesday trying to figure out the best route but that the drive still took about 90 minutes, twice as long as usual.
Many other Santa Clarita Valley residents shifted to the metropolitan area's fledgling light-rail commuter line, Metrolink. The line, which runs four morning trains on the 35-mile route to downtown, increased the number of cars per train to eight from three.
Local economists said it was still too early for credible estimates of how much the quake would cost businesses, but they said it represented yet another disincentive for companies to do business in Southern California along with environmental regulations and high labor costs.
In the short term, the economists said, the quake may jump-start the region's sluggish economy because of an increase in construction work.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The snarl of morning traffic on the Sierra Highway near Sylmar was even tighter yesterday as commuters bypassed State Route 14. (Associated Press)
