HEADLINE: FIGURE SKATING;
Ex-Husband of Harding Arrested in Skating Attack

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 19

 BODY:
Federal authorities today arrested Jeff Gillooly, the former husband of Tonya Harding, and said they had grounds to believe he has implicated her in planning the Jan. 6 assault on her figure-skating rival, Nancy Kerrigan.
Mr. Gillooly, a 26-year-old unemployed former warehouse worker, was the fourth person to be arrested in the case but not necessarily the last. Norman W. Frink, a deputy district attorney, said that the investigation was continuing and more arrests were possible. 
 Before the authorities announced the arrest, Miss Harding, who is already in danger of losing her place on the Olympic team because of the spreading investigation, said that she had separated from Mr. Gillooly. Although they were divorced five months ago after more than three years of marriage, they had reconciled and were living together during the time the authorities say the attack was being planned.
 
First Account Given
 In a statement from her lawyer today after Mr. Gillooly surrendered, Miss Harding "categorically denied" any involvement in a conspiracy, echoing statements she has made throughout the investigation. Mr. Gillooly has also maintained his innocence.
An 11-page affidavit that accompanied the arrest warrant presents the first account by officials of how they say the attack was planned and executed. In it, officials say that one of the three men previously charged in the case, Shawn E. Eckardt, told Federal agents that Mr. Gillooly had implicated his former wife. Mr. Eckardt worked briefly as a bodyguard for Miss Harding.
According to Mr. Eckardt's account in the affidavit, "in furtherance of the scheme to injure Miss Kerrigan," Mr. Gillooly said that Miss Harding had twice telephoned a skating rink on Cape Cod, where the attack was initially intended, to learn when Miss Kerrigan was practicing. Telephone company records show four calls from the Gillooly-Harding residence to the Tony Kent Arena in South Dennis, Mass., where Miss Kerrigan practiced, the affidavit said.
 
Calls Reported to Rink
 A woman who identified herself as a manager at the rink but would not give her name said that some employees had received telephone calls from a woman asking when Miss Kerrigan would practice during the time in question, but, she said, "We have no idea who they came from."
Mr. Gillooly added, according to the Eckardt account, that Miss Harding was so concerned about the calls that she said that if she were ever asked about them, she would say she was trying to get Miss Kerrigan to sign a poster.
That was the only part of the affidavit concerning any link between Miss Harding, who met with investigators for more than 10 hours on Tuesday, and the plan for the attack, which was eventually carried out at the national championships in Detroit.
The affidavit reflects evidence collected by the Federal Bureau of Investigation from the confessions of Mr. Eckardt and two other men, a statement by Mr. Eckardt's mother, bank records, money transfers, telephone logs and hotel records. It includes no information or allegations from Miss Harding, whose interview on Tuesday concluded around 11:30 P.M.
"The warrant was signed before," Mr. Frink said.
Looking somber, Mr. Gillooly surrendered to the F.B.I. at 11:25 this morning. He was arraigned this afternoon in a state district court on a charge of criminal conspiracy to commit assault, a felony offense. By the time of his surrender, he had not been interviewed by investigators. Afterward, he was interviewed briefly "but was not forthcoming," said one investigator.
Asked if Mr. Gillooly was the "mastermind" of the group, Mr. Frink said, "If they were smart, we would not have caught them."
Shane M. Stant, who the authorities say has confessed to committing the assault on Miss Kerrigan and was arrested last week in Phoenix, was also arraigned here today on the same charge as Mr. Gillooly. Mr. Eckardt and the other man charged in the case, Derrick B. Smith, were arraigned last week.
Mr. Gillooly was released on $2,000 bail after his arraignment. Mr. Stant, who could not immediately raise the money, was being held until a hearing could determine whether the court would allow him to live with a relative under a form of house arrest.
The affidavit is the first document made public that outlines the Multnomah County case against those charged in the assault, which left Miss Kerrigan unable to perform in the national championships. Miss Harding went on to win the event and earn a place on the United States Olympic team.
The affidavit presented this version of the plan and the assault:
The plan to injure Miss Kerrigan was set in motion at a late December meeting at the home of Mr. Eckardt's parents in Portland attended by the four men eventually charged. Mr. Eckardt's parents, Agnes and Ron Eckardt, were at home and were aware of the meeting but did not participate, a contention Mrs. Eckardt confirmed in her interview with a Federal agent.
At the meeting, the four men discussed attacking Miss Kerrigan's right knee. "This was decided in Oregon," the document said, "because as it was explained to Stant, by Gillooly, this was Kerrigan's landing leg, and that by injuring it, she would be unable to compete."
It was agreed at the meeting that Mr. Stant and Mr. Smith would carry out the assault for $6,500, at Miss Kerrigan's training rink on Cape Cod. But after five days in the area, spending time in two hotels, Mr. Stant was unable to find an opportunity to attack. With the national championships approaching, he left Massachusetts by bus and arrived in the Detroit area on Jan. 4, checking into a Romulus, Mich., hotel.
Money first changed hands on Dec. 27, when Mr. Gillooly gave Mr. Eckardt $2,000 in cash, and Mr. Eckardt gave the money to Mr. Smith. Mr Eckardt wired another $750 to Mr. Smith in Phoenix on Jan. 4, after which Mr. Smith flew to Detroit to meet Mr. Stant in Romulus. On Jan. 6, Mr. Gillooly gave Mr. Eckardt another $1,300, which Mr. Eckardt wired to Mr. Smith.
Once together in Detroit, Mr. Stant and Mr. Smith "did a reconnaissance mission" at Cobo Hall, where figure- skating competitors were practicing and found a suitable place for the attack.
As planned, Mr. Stant hit Miss Kerrigan on her right knee with a collapsible police baton, then ran for a Plexiglas door, which he found locked. "Stant had to break through the door using his head as a ram," the report said.
Then, running from the arena to "an awaiting rental car, which was driven by Smith," they left the area and flew back to Phoenix.
On Jan. 10, Mr. Eckardt performed his only security work for Miss Harding, meeting her plane at the airport in Portland upon her return from a triumphant competition in Detroit. He escorted her and Mr. Gillooly through a crowd of adoring fans at the Portland airport.
But later that night, the affidavit said, Mr. Eckardt and Mr. Gillooly "spent several hours together making up an alibi."
"They were concerned," it continued, "that they had left both a paper trail, in terms of wiring money and telephone calls, and had to come up with an alibi" for the presence of Mr. Stant and Mr. Smith in Detroit. They decided they would say that Mr. Eckardt and Mr. Smith, the recipient of each money transfer, were in the process of creating a security company for ice skaters. "This would also explain all the telephone calls between them," the report said.
The report, which was compiled by James McNelly, a deputy for the Multnomah County Sheriff's Office, includes wire transfer records that corroborated accounts given to investigators by Mr. Eckardt, Mr. Smith and Mr. Stant.
The report also discusses telephone logs that show calls were made from the Gillooly-Harding residence to the Massachusetts rink and a call to the same number from a hotel room in Yarmouth, Mass., that records indicate Mr. Stant had rented, and from Mr. Stant's hotel room in Romulus to the Gillooly-Harding residence.
The only apparent contradictions in the affadivit are recollections of when the initial meeting took place to plan the attack. Mr. Smith told investigators it occurred on Dec. 26. Mr. Eckardt said it was on Dec. 27. Mr. Stant remembered it as Dec. 29.
While none of the lawyers representing the defendants have spoken in any detail publicly, Ronald H. Hoevet, who is representing Mr. Gillooly, has said that he would attack the credibility of Mr. Eckardt, who is a self-described expert in counter-terrorism and espionage.
Mr. Hoevet, who appeared with his client before Judge Donald H. Londer at the arraignment, declined to speak to reporters and did not return a telephone message left for him.
Nor did Robert C. Weaver Jr., the lawyer representing Miss Harding. He had accompanied her throughout the questioning on Tuesday and spoke briefly afterward, apologizing for insisting that Miss Harding would have nothing to say for the time being.

HEADLINE: Poll Finds Increasing Confidence In Economy, and in the President

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

 BODY:
For the first time since the onset of the recession in mid-1990, the number of Americans expressing confidence in the economy has caught up to those with negative views about it, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. The shift has helped restore President Clinton's public approval rating to the higher level he enjoyed when he first took office.
After one year of Mr. Clinton's Presidency, 54 percent of the public approve of the way he is handling his job, a striking rebound from last summer, when Americans were more critical of him than they had been of any new President since World War II. 
 Now Mr. Clinton's popularity compares favorably to his post-Watergate predecessors on their first anniversaries in office. Ronald Reagan had a 49 percent approval rating at this stage, while Jimmy Carter had 51 percent. George Bush was at 76 percent, but that was due in part to the public's rallying behind him after the American invasion of Panama, and the collapse of Communism.
 
Seen as Untested in Crisis
 The nationwide telephone poll was taken Saturday through Monday and was no doubt influenced by the fact that it coincided with the final days of Mr. Clinton's European trip. The President's higher marks overall are owed partly to the approval by 50 percent of the way he is handling foreign policy, up from 38 percent in November.
While 66 percent of the respondents approved of Mr. Clinton's posture toward Russia, it is clear that many Americans do not believe that he has been tested on foreign matters. Only 39 percent expressed confidence in his ability to deal wisely with a difficult international crisis, while 54 percent said they were uneasy about his approach.
More Americans are concerned about the economy at home than about international affairs, and 42 percent approve of the way Mr. Clinton is handling the economy, reflecting a slow but steady climb from 38 percent in November and 34 percent in September.
After years in which most people were downbeat about the economy, the poll found that 50 percent viewed the economy as either very good or fairly good, while 49 percent said it was either very bad or fairly bad. The one-point difference is not significant; the poll, of 1,146 adults, had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
There were several other signs of the public's more positive economic mood: Fifty percent said now was a good time for most people to buy a new car, up from 37 percent just before Mr. Clinton took office. Seventy-six percent said for most people it was a good time to buy a house, up from 61 percent. There has been a marked decline in the number of Americans who say they believe someone in their family will be out of work and looking for a job in the next year; those fears have receded to 21 percent, from 40 percent a year ago.
 
Economy 'Getting Better'
 And in a particularly optimistic indicator, 31 percent said the economy was "getting better," sharply up from 19 percent in November and 14 percent in September.
While any President benefits from an improved economy or the perception of one, that may be especially true for Mr. Clinton since the central theme of his campaign was a promise to fix the economy. More than anything else, many analysts attributed President Bush's defeat in 1992 to a sour economy. If the more optimistic trend continues, it could be a significant boost not only for Mr. Clinton but also for the Democratic members of Congress who are struggling to keep their seats this year; usually the party in power suffers losses in off-year elections.
Although Mr. Clinton has climbed back eight percentage points in overall approval since November -- and is virtually even with the 55 percent approval rating he registered in March, his highest level since taking office -- he is by no means a widely popular President. He has not made great inroads beyond the 46 percent of Americans who voted for him, and those who supported Ross Perot are evenly split in their opinion of Mr. Clinton.
Frank Evanouskas, a respondent from North Brunswick, N.J., who voted for Mr. Perot, said that he averted personal economic peril himself and that Mr. Clinton deserved credit for trying. "I'm one of the people who got laid off last year and found another job in two weeks," Mr. Evanouskas, 47, a computer operator, said in a follow-up interview. "You can't blame Clinton for everything -- it's one year into his Administration. He seems to be trying to get the job done."
The questions raised about Mr. Clinton's involvement in real estate investments in the 1980's, when he was Governor of Arkansas, have not had much effect on people's views of his performance. Bowing to Congressional pressure, President Clinton last week asked Attorney General Janet Reno to appoint a special counsel to investigate accusations that money may have been improperly diverted to the Whitewater Development Company by the Clintons' partner, James B. McDougal, from an Arkansas savings and loan association he owned. The Clintons have denied doing anything wrong.
Yet the matter has the potential to harm his image. Six of 10 Americans said that in answers to recent questions about his financial dealings, Mr. Clinton was mostly telling the truth but also hiding something. Another 14 percent said he was mostly lying. Of those who saw hiding or lying, most said the matter was something the public needed to know about.
By contrast, in earlier polls dealing with the President's private life, most people who saw hiding or lying said they were matters the public did not need to know about.
The Whitewater accusations have not affected Mr. Clinton's image, with 26 percent saying Mr. Clinton has less honesty and integrity than most other President they know about. The matter may be less favorable for Hillary Rodham Clinton, who was also involved in the Whitewater deal; 39 percent of registered voters say they held a favorable opinion of her, which is down from 47 percent in November. In a sign of the uncertainty, most of the shift was to the "don't know" category rather than the "unfavorable" category.
 
High Marks on Health Care
 A majority of Americans gave Mr. Clinton high marks for his handling of health care and the economy, and gave him lower marks on issues like reducing the deficit, improving the environment, creating jobs, reducing crime and overhauling the welfare system. Forty-three percent said Mr. Clinton had made progress in getting health insurance for all Americans; 31 percent said he had made progress in significantly improving the economy.
Fifty-eight percent said Mr. Clinton cared about the needs and problems of people like them. Many Americans also had high expectations for the economy and health care for the rest of Mr. Clinton's term. Sixty-seven percent said that by the end of Mr. Clinton's four-year term, they expected the economy to be good, while 66 percent said they expected more Americans to be covered by health insurance.
Far fewer, 40 percent, said they expected the welfare system to be significantly changed in the next three years, while only 29 percent said they expected crime to be reduced. And few had faith in the Clinton campaign promise that he would cut taxes on the middle class: only 15 percent said they expected taxes on the middle class to have been reduced in the next three years.
Vice President Al Gore, who has had a higher profile in recent months, was viewed favorably by 42 percent, with 15 percent holding an unfavorable view of him. But nearly half of the public was undecided or said they did not know enough about the Vice President to respond.
Though Mr. Clinton campaigned as a "new Democrat," more Americans still view him as liberal than moderate, 44 percent to 32 percent.
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Saturday through Monday with 1,146 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen to assure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the potential sampling error is larger. For example, for blacks it is plus or minus nine percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey may introduce other sources of error. For instance, variations in question wording or the order of questions can lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: Whitman and Cuomo Seek to Cut Different Taxes for Same Reasons

BYLINE: By TOM REDBURN 

 BODY:
In trying to make their states better places to do business, Mario M. Cuomo, the long-time Governor of New York, and Christine Todd Whitman, the new Governor of New Jersey, may be talking the same talk but they're not walking the same walk.
While the rhetoric from both governors is remarkably similar, New York and New Jersey are emerging as tests of two strikingly different approaches to stimulating economic growth. With the Northeast just beginning to shake off a long and painful recession, Governor Whitman is placing her bets on sharp cuts in personal income taxes. By contrast, Governor Cuomo is pursuing his plan to ease business taxes directly.
 
'An Important Factor'
 "There is growing evidence that higher state and local taxes are an important factor in discouraging business," said James R. Hines, a professor of public policy at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government. But the jury is still out, Mr. Hines added, on "whether personal or business taxes have a more powerful effect." 
 Many other factors besides state tax burdens, of course, will affect the future prosperity of the regional economy. Yet governors have to deal with things they can influence. And New York and New Jersey, like Connecticut and Massachusetts before them, are relying on new efforts to cut taxes and ease regulations in hopes of shedding their images as hostile to business and stemming the loss of companies and jobs to other parts of the country.
"It is a much more competitive environment," said Steven Gold, director of the Center for the Study of States in Albany. "New York and New Jersey have suffered among the most severe job losses in the nation. What you are seeing is that both states now recognize they need to make themselves appear much more friendly to business."
In appealing to business, Mr. Cuomo and Mrs. Whitman are striking many of the same chords.
"We will be competitive. No more losing our employers to job raids by low-tax states," Governor Whitman said in her inauguration speech on Tuesday. "New Jersey is open for business."
Governor Cuomo has used the same theme. "Here's the message. New York State believes in business," he said recently in his State of the State speech. "We need you; we want you."
The contrast between Governor Cuomo's proposals and Governor Whitman's plan reflects more than political differences between Democrats and Republicans. It also reflects fundamentally different premises about what it takes to generate more jobs and higher incomes.
Advocates of income tax cuts tend to believe that risk-taking by individual entrepreneurs and innovations by new businesses are the underlying sources of economic growth. Mrs. Whitman is counting on a pocketbook appeal to individuals who might be tempted to start a business. To retain existing New Jersey companies, she is also aiming at upper-income executives who may be tempted by their own tax picture when they decide where to locate their firms' operations.
"The personal income tax is the most destructive tax around," said Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., president of Forbes magazine and an informal adviser to Governor Whitman. "Just take a look at Pennsylvania, where the business tax is worse than New Jersey's and probably as bad as New York's. But companies are moving there anyway and Pennsylvania is doing better than we are. Why? Because its top income tax rate is 2.8 percent."
Michael Boskin, chief economic adviser to President George Bush, said cutting personal taxes not only "provides more income to New Jersey residents, it also makes it easier to attract employees by easing the burden of compensation."
By contrast, many other analysts see the economy as being driven more by the profit-and-loss calculations of thousands upon thousands of different companies. They consider income tax cuts a scattershot solution to the problem of lagging economic growth and contend that state governments will receive the greatest payoff by offering tax incentives to home-grown businesses.
"The impact of personal tax cuts is too dilute," said Charles Bartsch, an economic development expert at the Northeast-Midwest Institute, a Washington-based research organization sponsored by Congressional representatives from the regions. "You give people a few hundred dollars in tax savings and all they may do is buy a new VCR -- which comes from overseas anyway."
Peter Eisinger, director of the LaFollette Institute of Public Affairs at the University of Wisconsin in Madison, argues that cutting taxes is a very blunt instrument. "You also have to worry about the impact on public services that business values highly," he said. "It is much more sensible to send a good signal by getting rid of those taxes and regulations that are a hassle for business, without cutting very deeply into your revenue base."
Mr. Cuomo is offering a number of relatively small tax cuts for businesses together with a more generous tax credit for the working poor, which represents a more cautious approach. Mrs. Whitman is taking the larger gamble that she can reduce income taxes by 30 percent without seriously impairing state and local services.
"Whitman is much more ambitious than Cuomo in the scale of her tax-cutting," said Mr. Gold of the state study center.
In general terms, the burden of state taxation in New York and New Jersey is roughly similar. Taking all state tax collections into account, a recent study by the Washington-based Tax Foundation found that the average household in New York pays $4,750 a year compared with $4,638 in New Jersey.
But that comparison omits local income and property taxes. It also masks wide variations in the distribution of state taxes. New York, for example, collects nearly 50 percent of state revenues from the individual income tax, while New Jersey relies on individual income taxes for just 32.7 percent of state tax collections.
Some analysts warn that both New York and New Jersey, in focusing so much recent attention on competing with other states through lower taxes, may be falling into a trap.
"You can build a strategy around being a cheaper place to do business -- like Arizona, Alabama and South Carolina -- or you can design an approach to be a more productive place to do business," said Paul Brace, a professor at Florida State University and author of a recent book on the subject, "State Government and Economic Performance" (Johns Hopkins University Press, 1993). "With places like Malaysia and Mexico as your competitors, though, going the cheaper route may prove to be a dead end."

HEADLINE: North Korea Buying Old Russian Subs

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Thursday, Jan. 20

 BODY:
North Korea has quietly begun purchasing 40 aging attack submarines from Russia's Pacific Fleet through a small Japanese trading company, according to Japanese, South Korean and American officials tracking the movements of the subs through the North Pacific.
Military and intelligence experts have offered conflicting explanations for why North Korea would want leftover hulks of the Russian Navy. Some experts raised the possibility that North Korea could try to restore the submarines to bolster its fleet, or cannibalize them for spare parts; Russian officials insist that the vessels are being sold to the Communist Government of President Kim Il Sung solely for use as scrap metal. 
 Skeptical about the Russians' explanation, the Clinton Administration has pressed the Russian Embassy in Washington for more details.
 
Leaks in Sanctions
 The deal suggests the difficulties the Clinton Administration would face in enforcing the economic sanctions it has threatened against North Korea because of its nuclear program, when private companies are busily trading with North Korea's huge military force. Japanese officials said today that they had no legal means to block the transaction.
In an interview on Wednesday, the president of the Japanese company acting as the intermediary in the deal, Toen Trading Company, said the submarines were being towed intact from Russian naval bases in Vladivostok to the nearby North Korean port of Najin, a major naval base on the Sea of Japan.
"The reality is that we are uncertain what is happening to the submarines after they reach North Korea," a senior Japanese intelligence official said Wednesday. "Perhaps it is an unusual way to obtain scrap metal."
Most of the submarines being shipped to North Korea are 20- to 30-year-old diesel models of questionable seaworthiness. Most are part of the class known by the NATO code-name Foxtrot, which can fire up to 21 torpedoes or be used to lay mines.
 
Useful for Spare Parts
 In recent years, the Foxtrot class subs have been steadily withdrawn from front-line service in the Russian fleet. But even if they could not be restored to service, they could be used as sources for spare parts to keep other submarines operating.
Norman Polmar, an expert on naval issues in Virginia, estimates that, because of mechanical problems, only half the current North Korean submarine fleet can be operated, and says that the North Koreans are probably buying the Russian vessels to obtain spare parts.
He said the parts from the old subs could be most useful on the handful of old Russian-made subs in the North Korea arsenal. It is less clear that the parts could be used on the old Chinese-made subs that make up the bulk of the North Korean fleet, he said.
 
North Korean Submarine Force
 The North Koreans currently own 24 submarines, mostly smaller Chinese-made models. They have also built 48 "midget submarines" designed to slip undetected into South Korean ports in the event of renewed hostilities in the Korean Peninsula.
The number of submarines involved in the transaction -- four times the number first reported from Russia a week ago -- has clearly taken Japanese and South Korean officials aback.
"Obviously, we are paying a lot of attention to this," a senior South Korean official said Wednesday night. But until South Korea receives a fuller explanation from Russia, which only resumed diplomatic relations with Seoul two years ago, "we won't be unduly alarmed," he said.
In a dispatch from Moscow, Reuters said the Russian Navy press center acknowledged that a deal had been signed with a Japanese company in November to sell 12 decommissioned Russian submarines that had been built between 1961 and 1968.
"These former vessels at the present time, after being disarmed, have been brought to a state that precludes their restoration for military purposes," the navy said in a statement.
 
U.S. Monitoring Deal
 One senior United States Navy official said that American intelligence was closely monitoring the transaction and that it had no basis to dispute the Russian Government's explanation that the subs are being sold for scrap.
The Navy official said the Russians had told the United States that the subs would be "demilitarized," that is, stripped of their weapons systems, before being delivered.
But the trading company executive who handled the sale, Ariyoshi Shibata, a Japanese citizen of Korean descent, said: "Everything is left as it is. Nothing is removed."
He said his North Korean partners, whom he declined to identify, had no intention of adding the subs to the North Korean fleet, however, and were already cutting them up for scrap.
At times, it seems as if North Korea runs on leftover goods from Russia and China. Many of its commercial aircraft are former Aeroflot planes, and most of its trucks and ships are retired models of its former ally.
The revelation comes as North Korea is engaged in a tense, painfully slow dialogue with the United States and the International Atomic Energy Agency over inspection of its nuclear program.
 
A Commercial Connection
 Russia has been described as consistently helpful to the United States in its dealings with the isolated North Korean Government. But the transaction, which may be valued at upwards of $8 million, suggests that there is still a close commercial connection between the Russian and North Korean militaries, one that many in Asia believe is not regulated by Moscow.
"We think these guys in the Russian Pacific Fleet are free-lancing," an American official tracking the submarine sales said today.
The deal marks the second time in recent months that Russian deals with the North Korean military have come to light. Last August a civilian Russian company flew truck chassis for mobile Scud missile launchers from North Korea to Damascus, Syria, despite quiet protests from the Clinton Administration. There were reports last year that Russian military engineers had been hired by North Korea to improve its ballistic missile program but that they were stopped in Moscow just before their plane left for Pyongyang.
 
Role of Japanese Company
 It is unclear why a Japanese trading company played the intermediary role in the deal, but some Japanese officials suggested today that for political reasons, Russia did not want to be seen dealing directly with the North. Another official suggested that the Japanese were brought in to guarantee that the Russians would be paid even if North Korea, which has defaulted on many of its international debts, failed to come up with the money.
Mr. Shibata, speaking in Japanese, said that like many Korean-Japanese, he travels to North Korea about 10 times a year on business. For two years, he said, he has been buying old locomotives in Russia that could be cut up in North Korea for scrap metal. "Recently it has been more difficult to obtain those," he said, "so we are shifting to submarines and warships."
He said the first submarine was shipped to North Korea last October and that nine more have gone since.
He said that on one recent trip he saw at least one submarine being dismantled at Najin. "The equipment was run down," he said. "I'm not even sure the screw could turn."

HEADLINE: THE EARTHQUAKE: The President;
Clinton Visits Quake Area And Feels the Earth Rumble

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19

 BODY:
President Clinton rode out a strong aftershock here today and pronounced the damage from Monday's earthquake "amazing." He promised "unusual and unprecedented" steps to help the region recover after Gov. Pete Wilson told him the disaster might be one of the most expensive in American history.
Gazing at a collapsed section of the Simi Valley Freeway, a few miles from the epicenter of the earthquake, the President said, "There's a difference in seeing this, actually standing here and looking at it." 
 As he toured neighborhoods in the San Fernando Valley, where the earthquake was centered, the ground shook under his feet from an aftershock that registered 5.5 on the Richter scale of ground motion.
On his ninth visit to this politically crucial state since his election as President, Mr. Clinton brought millions of dollars in immediate assistance and promised more long-term aid. The Small Business Administration will release about $240 million in low-interest loans, he said, and the Department of Transportation will make $45 million available to support immediate repairs and removal of debris.
In addition, Richard Krimm, the associate director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, said his department might spend as much as $500 million on earthquake recovery.
In a letter to the President that was made public today, Governor Wilson said a computer model estimated that the earthquake had caused $15 billion to $30 billion in damages. Hurricane Andrew, which destroyed a swath of South Florida and Louisiana in 1992, caused $30 billion in damage; the earthquake that struck the San Francisco area in 1989 caused about $7 billion in damage.
Most state and local agencies were still assessing the destruction caused by Monday's earthquake, and few estimates were available on actual costs. Damage continued to mount as hundreds of aftershocks shook Los Angeles.
Throughout the city today, residents removed clothing and furniture from damaged apartments and homes before building inspectors condemned their homes.
The earthquake on Monday was measured at 6.6 on the Richter scale. Damage and loss of life, which the authorities have so far placed at 46, were far less than they might have been because it struck at 4:31 A.M. on a holiday, when few people were on the roads or at work.
Although there are still few dollar assessments, officials described widespread destruction to roads and highways, aqueducts and water purification plants, homes, schools and office buildings, as well as potential economic losses in damaged businesses, tourism and the costs of a grotesquely prolonged commute.
Although many of the area's residents continued to stay home from work and school today, the commute to Los Angeles already began to take on tragicomic proportions as trips that usually take 45 minutes stretched toward three hours.
In his letter to the President, Governor Wilson noted that the earthquake was the latest in a series of calamities that had pummeled a region that continues to suffer a severe recession.
"On the heels of this economic disaster have now come three major disasters in the course of the last 20 months in the Los Angeles area alone," he wrote. "Following the civil unrest of 1992, the winter storms of 1993 and the most recent firestorms of a few months ago, it is clear that neither this area nor the state can be asked to bear the burden of recovery alone."
He asked the Federal Government to cover 100 percent of recovery costs, as it did after Hurricane Andrew and Hurricane Iniki, which caused $7.7 in damage on the Hawaiian island of Kauai in 1992.
The President said Congress would need to waive a requirement for matching financing by local governments but that "I think you have a very strong case for a waiver."
Wearing an open-necked blue shirt with the sleeves rolled up in the relentlessly balmy weather, Mr. Clinton gaped at the sight of a collapsed overpass on the Simi Valley Freeway in the San Fernando Valley.
Large, noisy wrecking machines chewed at the broken concrete and iron bars around him, carting away the rubble in the first stages of an urgent highway-repair program that officials said they hoped to complete before the end of the year at a cost of about $100 million.
The President's motorcade took him past miles of small buildings that had suffered seemingly undramatic damage that rendered many of them uninhabitable, and past residents who now camp outside their homes because of the damage or because of their fear of aftershocks.
Officials here continued to add up the effects of the earthquake, and the death toll rose to 46. Most of those added to the list were victims of heart attacks. Hospitals reported that more than 4,200 people had been injured.
The Red Cross said about 4,000 buildings were heavily damaged or destroyed, and city officials estimated that 15,000 people had lost their homes, including 4,700 who continued to stay in 24 government shelters.
Utilities had mostly been restored two days after the earthquake, but 52,000 people still had no electrical power, 40,000 homes and businesses had no water and about 35,000 customers were without natural gas.
 
Hundreds of Damaged Schools
 At least 200 public schools in Los Angeles were damaged, including 100 that were found to be unsafe for students, said Shel Erlich, a spokesman for the district. He said initial estimates of damage to the school system ranged from $500 million to $700 million. The closings affected about 600,000 elementary and high school students, he said.
With damage still being assessed, the Los Angeles area was coming to the realization that it would be living with the effects of the earthquake for months and even years to come.

HEADLINE: THE EARTHQUAKE: The Victims;
The Unthinkable Occurs: Homelessness

BYLINE: By CHARISSE JONES, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Elizabeth Thomas has watched the homeless walk the streets of this city, carrying everything they own in a plastic bag. Never did she think she would be among them.
But before dawn on Monday the ground shook beneath the building she called home. Cracks filled the walls of her apartment in Tarzana, five miles south of the Northridge area of the San Fernando Valley, where the quake was centered. Her building slid off its foundation. And she knew that she and her four children could no longer stay there. 
 So today Ms. Thomas sat at a Red Cross shelter in Canoga Park, about five miles northeast of Tarzana, holding a plastic bag filled with everything she has left, and contemplated the tricks that life plays. How in a matter of minutes the unthinkable -- being homeless -- had happened. And how she does not know what to do, or where to turn, to make it better.
 
'I Need a Place to Live'
 "I live paycheck to paycheck," said Ms. Thomas, an insurance underwriter. "We don't have money in the bank. We are homeless. And I need a place to live."
It has been more than two days since the quake, which measured 6.6 on the Richter scale of ground motion, jolted Los Angeles, and this city is struggling to cope with the devastation. The cleanup has begun, and the President has come to survey the damage and talk to quake refugees. But still, thousands of people have no safe place they can call home.
The American Red Cross estimates that 4,700 people spent Tuesday night in the organization's shelters. City and state officials believe, however, that there may be many more who are in need of housing but do not know where to go, or are too frightened to sleep indoors.
Workers plan to distribute 100,000 fliers in parks and gathering places throughout the Los Angeles area to tell people of available shelters, said Barbara Wilks, a spokeswoman for the Red Cross.
In the meantime, hundreds of people continue to light charcoal fires and sleep in parks, saying they prefer the night sky to a roof that might collapse the next time the earth moves. Others have gone to the shelters, most of them situated in school gymnasiums, churches and recreation centers in the San Fernando Valley.
 
Relying on Strangers
 The newly homeless often have just the clothes on their backs. These are people used to taking care of themselves. Now, they say, they are forced to rely on the kindness of strangers. For many, that is difficult to do.
"I've never asked the Government for a penny," said Juanita E. Casco, who with her family spent the first two nights after the quake sleeping in her building's parking lot. "We've always worked very hard. But I'm hoping now that they can help us."
Until that happens, the Cascos and many others wait. They sleep on cots in crowded gymnasiums, dial phones that often go unanswered, and pray that they will be able to return to work soon. They share showers and sleeping space with people they do not know and eat meals when they are served, not when they want them. And they wait anxiously for word that never seems to come on how they can rebuild and get their lives back to normal.
"Nobody is helping us," said Maria Dominguez, who has been staying with her husband and two children at the Canoga Park shelter. "How are we going to support ourselves? How are we going to get food, pay the rent?"
Mrs. Dominguez said she must strike an emotional balance, reassuring her 7-year-old son that everything will be all right, when she herself is not so sure.
 
'The Earth Might Eat Me'
 "When he goes to the bathroom he says, 'Mommy, stay here, because the earth might eat me,' " Mrs. Dominguez said. "I tell him nothing is going to happen to us. I tell him good things so he can feel a little bit secure. But I feel like the world is going to end."
Her husband, Moses, a factory worker, has spent the two days trying to find out how to get financial assistance for his family. "I called the fire department," he said. "I called 911. But nobody answers."
Eileen Vasquez has also been seeking help. She and her family of five have been unable to reach the manager of the Chatsworth building where they live to find out if the structure is safe. So, until they can be reassured, they sleep at a shelter.
There is little money, Mrs. Vasquez said. The family has already paid this month's rent for an apartment they may not be able to live in. Her husband is unemployed. And Mrs. Vasquez said she needs to get to a laundromat soon to wash her children's clothes.
 
Rental Assistance Funds
 "I feel desperation because I don't know what the next step is going to be," said Mrs. Vasquez, a legal secretary. "I look in the newspapers and all the articles deal with homeowners. We're not homeowners. What do people do who live in apartments? What do we do, just stay in shelters?"
Officials in the Federal Emergency Management Agency announced today that $100 million in rental assistance would be earmarked for people left homeless by the quake. Those in need will be able to apply for assistance and receive rental vouchers. The Department of Housing and Urban Development will pay 30 percent of their rent, a FEMA official said.
The quake and its aftermath has been a humbling experience for many of the displaced, even for Jason Brooks, a 9-year-old boy who said he thought he would always have a roof over his head.
Jason said the ground rocked him to sleep Monday night as he and his mother slept in a park near their apartment in the Van Nuys section of Los Angeles, adjacent to Northridge. The next day he, his mother and grandmother checked into a shelter.
"I thought we'd always be inside, and safe," Jason said, taking a break from the cartoons he and other children watched on a borrowed television set. "My mom helps this homeless guy, and we always wanted to know what it feels like. He's always cold and asking for food. Now, we know."
 
Prayers and Crashing Crystal
 Though many people could not or would not return to their damaged homes to stay, some have tried to retrieve what they could amid the debris.
Jason's mother, Ligia Ortega-Brooks, returned to the family's apartment soon after daylight broke on the morning of the earthquake. While sifting through the debris, she said, she remembered hearing her 63-year-old mother praying in the darkness as her precious crystal crashed to the floor.
"I've worked for everything I've had, by myself, since I was 12 years old," said Ms. Ortega-Brooks. "I'm a survivor. But it made me feel bad that now I've got to start all over again."
The earthquake also shattered something far more fragile, the newly homeless said. With their homes went their peace of mind, their sense of place and peace.
"I feel desperate," Mrs. Casco said. "I feel like I have no hands or feet."
Since the quake, she said, she sleeps with her two daughters cradled in her arms. And even when the local schools reopen, Mrs. Casco said she doubts that she will let her children return. At least not until her nerves have calmed, and the ground has stopped rumbling from aftershocks.
Losing her home has put life into perspective, she said. "Sunday night I went to bed and thought about what I was going to do the next day," Mrs. Casco said. "Now I know it's not what you want to do -- it's what God decides."

BITTER COLD DISRUPTS POWER AND TRAVEL
Record-breaking cold imposed an icy disorder on New York and the rest of the East Coast, from power shortages to disrupted school days, from frozen railroad track switches to scuttled dinner plans. The temperature was 2 degrees below 0 in Central Park at 6 A.M., the lowest ever recorded for the date, and rose to 10 degrees later in the day, making it one of the coldest days in the last half-century. HEADLINE: Ruble Sinks Further in a Whirl of Political Rumors

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Negotiations over a new Russian Government continued in secret today, aggravating confusion and panic over the value of the ruble, which plunged another 6.5 percent in record trading, to a low of 1,607 to the dollar.
In a brief report this evening, Interfax news agency said Finance Minister Boris G. Fyodorov, who has come to symbolize the future of economic reform, was reappointed Finance Minister in a partial agreement between President Boris N. Yeltsin and Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin. 
 But the report left unanswered the key question of whether Mr. Fyodorov will also be named a Deputy Prime Minister, and an aide said Mr. Fyodorov himself remains unsure about the validity of the report, which seemed intended to quiet panic over the future of Russia's reforms.
 
'How Poor We've Become!'
 Ordinary Russians waited in long lines on a bitterly cold day to try to turn their increasingly fragile rubles -- whose value has fallen more than 25 percent this month and almost 15 percent this week -- into more stable dollars. The drop has been even more extreme in private exchange booths, where dollars, when they are available, cost up to 1,950 rubles.
"It's so shameful to see how far my country has sunk," said Tatyana A. Golubentseva, 39, a teacher who had come to an exchange booth in the Izvestia building on Tverskaya Street. "Soon the rate will be 5,000, no doubt. How poor we've become!"
In most Western countries, a run on the currency is met by strong intervention by the Central Bank, to buy currency and especially to raise interest rates. Here the Central Bank chairman, Viktor V. Gerashchenko, has long resisted the idea of pushing interest rates higher than the rate of inflation.
But so far this month, the Central Bank has spent up to $1 billion of its $4.5 billion in hard-currency reserves to keep the ruble from collapsing even faster in the general anxiety.
 
Personalizing Policy
 Since the resignation on Sunday of Yegor T. Gaidar, the architect of Russia's economic reforms, the President and the Prime Minister have been negotiating the make-up of a new Government, which was supposed to have been announced on Monday.
Their main difficulty is the role of the 35-year-old Finance Minister, who has become personalized in the West as the symbol of market reforms. A combative, sometimes arrogant infighter who believes deeply in stabilization and lower inflation as the keys to progress, Mr. Fyodorov has been bargaining to stay in the Government with enough power to make a difference.
As best he can, he has been using the expectations of the West and its fiduciary agent, the International Monetary Fund, that economic reform will continue and even deepen, as Mr. Yeltsin promised President Clinton at their talks here last week.
 
'Chirpiness' May Erode
 American officials have played down Mr. Gaidar's resignation as an inevitable result of his perceived rebuff at the polls Dec. 12: even though his party won the largest number of seats in the lower house, there was a substantial vote of protest against his policies.
But the Washington attitude, described by one Western diplomat as "resolute chirpiness," is unlikely to survive a departure by Mr. Fyodorov.
The result has been a drama played out in secret, though not without a calculated insult: Mr. Fyodorov was refused admission to the Kremlin today to attend a regular meeting of the Security Council, and Mr. Fyodorov has been unable to meet with Mr. Yeltsin, who has kept himself isolated.
After first issuing impossible conditions for his participation in the Government -- which were easy for an offended Mr. Chernomyrdin to reject -- Mr. Fyodorov opened the possibility of a compromise today. As long as he could keep his status as a Deputy Prime Minister as well as Finance Minister, he suggested in an interview with Interfax, he would remain "unless policy changes so much that this would mean an end to reforms."
 
Him or Me
 Mr. Fyodorov seems to have dropped his insistence that Mr. Gerashchenko be replaced at the Central Bank, but he is still demanding that his own rank be higher than that of a Chernomyrdin ally, Aleksandr K. Zaveryukha, a Deputy Prime Minister who is in charge of agriculture.
But having presented the stark choice -- Mr. Gerashchenko or me -- and then backing down, Mr. Fyodorov will find his position weakened even if he does become Deputy Prime Minister.
The Interfax report quoted a Chernomyrdin spokesman, Valentin Sergeyev, as saying an industrialist, Oleg Soskovets, will be appointed the only First Deputy Prime Minister; this would confirm widespread expectations.
Interfax also said Aleksandr Shokhin, a mainstream reformer who broke with Mr. Gaidar, would replace Mr. Gaidar as Economics Minister. The report added that the Privatization Minister, Anatoly B. Chubais; Yuri Yarov, who is in charge of social issues, and Mr. Zaveryukha would remain Deputy Prime Ministers. But the report made clear that the list was incomplete, holding out the possibility that Mr. Fyodorov would be added.
 
Return of 'Reform Communism'
 Mr. Fyodorov's departure would likely mean a Government of Soviet bureaucrats with experience in "reform Communist" cabinets under the former President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a period not known for its economic successes. Russian industrialists and their spokesmen, like Yuri Skokov and Arkady Volsky, would gain considerably more influence.
Mr. Chernomyrdin has made it clear that he regards the fight against inflation as less important than supporting Russian industry and stopping the slump in production. He wants to increase credits and energy subsidies considerably to healthier or more strategic state industries, and to concentrate on export products -- including arms. In fact, the Security Council agenda today was dominated by the topic of increasing arms exports.
In an extraordinary gesture, another reform economist, Grigory A. Yavlinsky, told reporters at the lower house that he was prepared to form a Government to save the nation and could do so in three weeks. Mr. Yavlinsky said he assumed Mr. Chernomyrdin would resign as the economic crisis worsened.
 
A Billion Here, a Billion There
 Given pent-up inflationary demand and an artificially supported ruble, Mr. Yavlinsky said, the collapse of the ruble is in large part a necessary correction. "What is happening now is payment for everything that has been done," he said.
It is an expensive payment, made dearer by the sense of panic. The $1 billion that the Central Bank has spent trying to defend the ruble represents two-thirds of the $1.5 billion that the I.M.F. has been unwilling to lend Russia until it shows a better economic performance, indicating how little leverage such sums have on Moscow.
For Vadim Sergeyevich, 34, a businessmen who found no dollars at the Minsk Hotel change booth, there was nothing but uncertainty. "I came to buy because the rate is falling so fast," he said. "Who the hell knows what's going to happen tomorrow?"
The Baltic nations asked themselves the same thing today, after Foreign Minister Andrei V. Kozyrev suggested Tuesday that some Russian troops should remain in the former Soviet states to prevent a "security vacuum." Ministry officials said today that Mr. Kozyrev was saying nothing new, and that in this case he meant members of the Commonwealth of Independent States, with which Russia has bilateral troop agreements.
"There is no question about any changes in Russia's approach toward the building of its relations with the Baltic states," Grigory Karasin, a ministry spokesman, said.
But Western diplomats suggested Mr. Kozyrev might be trying particularly to warn Lithuania -- from which Russian troops have already withdrawn -- about its recent statements about joining NATO.

HEADLINE: Zairians Strike Over Plan to Close Parliament

BYLINE: By KENNETH B. NOBLE, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Hundreds of thousands of Zairians stayed away from work today to protest President Mobutu Sese Seko's decision to dissolve the Parliament and name a new prime minister.
The general strike, which local analysts called by far the most effective of several efforts in recent months to shut down this country's biggest city, was called by Mr. Mobutu's opponent, Etienne Tshisekedi, who heads a rival government that the President has refused to recognize. 
 Last Friday, in an effort to resolve Zaire's long political impasse, Mr. Mobutu announced that he was dismissing both his own Government, headed by Prime Minister Faustin Birindwa, and that of Mr. Tshisekedi's.
Belgium, the former colonial ruler of Zaire, and the country's main international donors, France and the United States, have recognized Mr. Tshisekedi's Government and called upon Mr. Mobutu to do the same. They have accused the President of clinging to the trappings of power, while ordinary and increasingly desperate citizens carry the burden of his misrule.
Instead, Mr. Mobutu announced that a meeting would be held today in order to merge the two governments and elect a new prime minister. But Mr. Tshisekedi has rejected Mr. Mobutu's proposal, saying the President has no constitutional authority to dissolve his Government, appointed by a transitional council last year.
The meeting today, which Mr. Mobutu was expected to attend, was postponed. But apparently in response to Mr. Tshisekedi's outspoken defiance, the opposition leader's house on the outskirts of the city was surrounded by troops, but by nightfall, there had been no effort to enter the house.
Kinshasa's main business thoroughfare was virtually deserted, and shops, Government offices and markets were closed. And most roads leading into the center of the city, usually congested with traffic, were empty, except for heavily armed patrols.
But while opposition leaders hailed the strike today as an unqualified success, in truth, it is impossible to know how many people stayed away in protest, and how many were intimidated, fearing a violent confrontation between Government troops and the opposition.
Indeed, early this morning shooting erupted near the city's center, and an hourlong power cut plunged many parts of the city into darkness. The reasons for the gunfire were not clear, but Kinshasa has been gripped by increasing lawlessness and economic chaos, and political turmoil since this former one-party state introduced multi-party politics in April 1990.
Kinshasa, with about 5 million people, is believed to be the only city affected by the demonstrations. Most of the country was reported to be calm and functioning as best it could, given that normal Government services were few and often nonexistent.
And paradoxically, what African and Western diplomats fear most is that the apparent success of the protests today may embolden the opposition, leading to a direct confrontation between ordinary citizens and the Mobutu Government -- a confrontation that almost certainly would lead to bloodshed.
"Maintaining the status quo right now may not be necessarily bad," said a senior Western relief official, "because as long as they're talking, they won't be shooting at one another."

HEADLINE: Fed Sees New Indicators of Acceleration in U.S. Economy

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The economy showed fresh "signs of acceleration" as 1994 began, including new factory hiring and strong consumer spending, the Federal Reserve said today.
In its "beige book," which summarizes regional business conditions, the Fed said, "Economic activity continued to expand, with signs of acceleration in some sectors." 
 In the flat, unemotional language habitually used in the central bank's reports, that amounted to the most positive view of the economy since before the 1990-91 recession, said Cynthia Latta, an economist with DRI-McGraw Hill in Lexington, Mass.
The Fed said: "Consumer spending, especially on household-related items, was strong during the holidays in most districts. Manufacturing activity strengthened, and the manufacturing employment picture improved somewhat."
The only real sour note in the report was that "weak economic conditions continued in Southern California." That assessment of conditions was made before the destruction of the earthquake that hit Los Angeles on Monday.
 
Rate Increases Seen
 The report by the Fed today, compiled from interviews conducted before Jan. 10 by the Fed's 12 regional banks, was prepared for a meeting of central bank monetary policy makers on Feb. 3 and 4.
Many economists said they believed the policy makers could decide at the meeting to increase short-term interest rates sometime during the first quarter, in an effort to keep a lid on incipient inflationary pressures as the economy strengthens.
But the price rises generally have been small. And, Ms. Latta said, the strong economic growth found by the Fed as the year ended probably would fade somewhat, delaying an increase in the rates to the end of the first quarter.
"I don't think they will be inclined to tighten quite yet," she said. "Our view is this very strong fourth quarter is temporary. We may well see 5 percent growth in the fourth quarter, but we won't see that in the first half of 1994."
Despite the increased economic activity, the Fed said it had noted "little upward pressure on wages and prices." But, it said, there were widespread reports of rising lumber costs and "scattered labor shortages."
 
Activity in Manufacturing
 Regarding manufacturing, the Fed said some factories in the Cleveland and Minneapolis districts were operating near capacity. Manufacturers were busiest making construction-related products, automobiles, personal computers and capital equipment.
Military-related manufacturing was described as sluggish and clothing manufacturing as lackluster.
The central bank had mildly positive words for the long-moribund commercial real estate markets. It said conditions were still sluggish, but construction and leasing had improved in some markets.
It said, "Residential real estate sales and construction grew robustly in almost all districts."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
AMERITECH CORP. (N)

 BODY:
The Ameritech Corporation, the regional phone company for the Midwest, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 18.7 percent from a year earlier on a 6.1 percent gain in revenues.
Ameritech's earnings of $398.2 million, or 73 cents a share, were far stronger than analysts' expectations. Daniel Reingold of Merrill Lynch had expected a quarterly profit of 67 cents a share, adjusting for a recent 2-for-1 stock split. 
 Richard W. Phelke, Ameritech vice president and treasurer, attributed the rise primarily to a recovery in the economy in the Midwest that increased demand for telephone service.
For the year, growth in the number of telephone lines was 3.3 percent, to 17.6 million lines in Illinois and the four other Midwestern states in Ameritech's service area. Growth was especially strong among residential customers who sought second lines for fax machines and computers.
"We are also working hard to be as competitive as possible," Mr. Phelke said in an interview. Lower interest costs helped and so did attrition, early retirement and other measures that reduced the work force by 4,100 employees, to 67,200 total employees.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
AMR, Citing Strike, Posts $253 Million Loss

BYLINE: By ADAM BRYANT 

 BODY:
The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, said yesterday that a strike by its flight attendants last fall cost the carrier $190 million and led to a fourth-quarter net loss of $253 million.
The five-day strike in November also wiped out a profit AMR would have otherwise reported for the entire year, leading instead to a loss of $110 million in 1993. 
 The strike may give a small lift to other carriers, which have not yet reported their fourth-quarter earnings. AMR officials underscored the fact that the strike had lingering effects on the company's operations.
 
 
Lingering Effects
 "A strike is not like a rain shower, that its effects are gone when the rain stops," said Michael J. Durham, American's chief financial officer. "During the five days, all of the people that were making airline reservations for the future -- and there are hundreds of thousands of people who make reservations every day -- were making reservations on other carriers."
American said Tuesday that it would try to avert the threat of a strike this year when it negotiates with its pilots for a new contract. The carrier and the Allied Pilots Association proposed Tuesday to go to binding arbitration to settle any differences, rather go through a crippling strike again. The new strategy must be approved by the union's members.
Julius Maldutis, an airline analyst at Salomon Brothers, said that while advance bookings were strengthening and excessive capacity in the industry was on the decline, fundamental financial improvements were not occurring as quickly as many people had expected.
"The airline industry recovery appears to be lagging the recovery in the economy," he said, adding that the earthquake in Los Angeles is likely to affect the airline business more than many people might expect.
Although airports were operating shortly after the earthquake struck on Monday, many passengers and cargo shippers continue to be hobbled by its effects, he said.
 
 
After-Tax Charges
 AMR said that besides the five-day strike in November, its performance was affected by special after-tax charges of $62 million related to legal costs and previously announced layoffs.
AMR reported a loss of $3.55 a share in the quarter, compared with a $2.66 loss in the period a year earlier. AMR's operating loss was $162 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a loss of $145 million a year earlier. Revenues rose slightly to $3.59 billion, compared with $3.58 billion a year earlier.
For 1993, AMR said it lost $110 million, or $2.23 a share, on revenues of $15.82 billion. That compares with a loss of $935 million, or $12.49 a share, on 1992 revenues of $14.4 billion.
Although the loss was greater than analysts had expected, AMR's stock closed yesterday at $71.25, up $1.375.

HEADLINE: State of Emergency Declared in Kentucky As Bitter Cold Closes Interstate Highways

BYLINE: By DON TERRY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The Winter of '94 is just a few weeks old, but the people of Kentucky will no doubt remember it for a long time.
Today, for the third day in a row, a state of emergency was in effect for the state, hit hard by a crippling combination of freezing rain, heavy snow and subzero temperatures. 
 All four interstate highways that crisscross Kentucky, nearly 730 miles of snow- and ice-covered roadway, were closed to all but emergency vehicles and those with special state permits, allowing the drivers to risk life and limb on the roads.
"This is the absolute worst situation we've ever had to face as a result of a winter storm," said James M. Everett, executive director of the state's Disaster and Emergency Services. "It's taxing the entire disaster and emergency system."
 
Shortages of Goods
 Shortages of goods and supplies were reported across Kentucky because trucks could not make deliveries. On Tuesday, as many as 900 18-wheel trucks were stranded in the parking lot of a shopping mall in Florence, Ky., 15 miles south of Cincinnati. A short stretch of interstate was opened as a truck escape route into Ohio. For many in Kentucky, the trucks' departure must have been painful, since rural grocery stores are reporting dwindling stocks.
Gas and electric utilities were pushed to the breaking point, with at least one small rural electric utility forced to shut when consumer demand overloaded the system.
In Minnesota, where winter carnivals mock the cold, 20 percent of the public schools were closed today. Half were closed in Minneapolis and St. Paul.
 
Temperatures Turn Around
 Across the rest of the Midwestern and Eastern winter belt, the bitter cold was beginning to loosen its grip today. Temperatures throughout the region began a slow, seductive climb toward zero and beyond after several days of subzero temperatures.
Here in Chicago, the city recorded its sixth consecutive day of subzero temperatures. But by late afternoon, the temperature had climbed to 7 degrees above zero, not shirt-sleeve weather but welcome nonetheless.
By the weekend, temperatures in Chicago were expected to reach the 30's and 40's. "It's going to feel like summertime," a man said today as he hurried along a downtown street, his breath frozen in air.
Today, in Kentucky the temperature hovered near zero, and relief from the brutal weather is not expected until Friday, when the National Weather Service expects temperatures to climb into the mid-40's.
 
Asking for Federal Help
 Gov. Brereton C. Jones toured his frigid state by airplane this afternoon. Mr. Everett said an application to seek Federal disaster assistance was being readied and officials from the Federal Emergency Management Agency had arrived in Frankfort, the state capital.
Travel on the 725 miles of interstate highway was restricted today, except for vehicles that obtain a state permit for delivery of medical supplies, food and fuels. As of noon today, 400 permits had been issued, Mr. Everett said, and several truckers without permits were arrested.
Bob Adelman, the owner of Roadco Transportation, which dispatches trucks nationwide from Cicero, Ill., said his drivers are either bypassing the state or are waiting out the weather in roadside motels.
"That's causing a big-time impact," Mr. Adelman said. "We have freight that goes south, but we're staying out of Kentucky. If something needs to be delivered there, it's just going to have to wait until next week."
Shipments to the East Coast have also been slowed because of the weather and a lack of road salt in New Jersey, Mr. Adelman said.
"I often say this is a time of the year where you separate the men from the boys," he said. "If you go into this season in poor financial shape, this kind of thing will put you out of business. No pun intended, but it's a cold, cold world out there."
 
A Mixed Blessing
 The wicked weather has kept people inside, a mixed blessing, say police and experts on domestic violence.
Although there are no firm statistics available, Billy Davis, the spokesman for the Chicago Police Department, said the cold weather has probably reduced the number of street robberies "because there's nobody out on the streets."
But Carol Arthur, the director of a domestic abuse prevention and treatment program in Minneapolis, said the extreme temperatures combined with cabin fever can cause the stresses that lead to violent assault.
"The man goes out, the car won't start, he comes back in and he takes it out on his partner, that's a real typical scene we see at these times," Ms. Arthur said. "Cold weather is a cause of abuse because it causes all sorts of stresses that aren't normally there: catching the flu, having to stay home from work, having to stay inside. It adds up."
The worst of the storm hit Kentucky on the weekend and early attempts to plow the interstate highways were hampered by jackknifed trucks scattered about the road like a fleet of toys.
"We couldn't get the plows through some sections," Mr. Everett said, adding that plowing is possible now but clearing the road of ice is still difficult. "Salt and other chemicals just don't work in these temperatures," he said.
The economic effect on the region will take some time to determine. Statewide, a record 943 Kentucky National Guardsmen are on duty to help deliver emergency supplies and remove snow.
 
Problems at Plants
 But already some auto assembly plants and other manufacturers, which use "just-in-time inventory" as part of their production process, "are really upset" because supplies cannot reach the plants, Mr. Everett said.
Emergency officials in each county have been asking owners of four-wheel-drive vehicles to help transport doctors to hospitals. Mr. Everett said even he is relying on a volunteer with a four-wheel-drive vehicle to take him to work.
In Kentucky and throughout much of the region, education has been one of the most visible victims of the cold. Schools throughout the region were closed today, keeping hundreds of thousands of students at home and parents scrambling for baby sitters and other day care arrangements.
In Chicago the schools were closed for the second day in a row. It was the first time in the city's history that its public school system, the third largest in the nation with 411,000 pupils, had been shut because of cold weather. The schools are expected to reopen on Thursday.
At Board of Education headquarters, officials were studying the temperature and gauging the wind-chill index like high school students cramming for a college entrance exam.
 
Ohio State Closes
 Ohio State University in Columbus was also closed because of the cold, the first time in 16 years classes had been canceled because of weather.
The weather has also snarled the trucking industry, in some cases tripling costs. Fred Serpe, director of the Illinois Transportation Association, which represents 700 trucking and other transportation companies, said fuel, maintenance and motel costs have been climbing as fast as the temperature has been plunging.
Because of the cold and swirling snow many drivers have been forced off the road and into motel rooms to wait it out. Trucking companies have been forced to keep engines running 24 hours a day, profits and fuel burning away in the bitter wind.
"You can't risk turning the trucks off," Mr. Serpe said. "They might not start up again."
A third of Amtrak's trains into and out of Union Station in Chicago were canceled today. The trains that were running were operating at reduced speeds, Deborah Hare, an Amtrak spokeswoman, said.
"One of our trains sitting in our yard awaiting maintenance was found frozen to the tracks," she said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sometimes you can't even give it away. One merchant in Washington tried yesterday, because, with the cold snap showing no signs of abating, it seemed the only way to move a product that normally sells itself. (Stephen Crowley/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: POLITICAL MEMO;
Whitman's Tax Pledge: A Bold, Risky Surprise

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
In her first hours in office, Christine Todd Whitman has used a surprise announcement about a retroactive tax cut and two executive orders to build herself a political cushion against some of the blows that landed on her during the governor's race.
The Governor, who was inaugurated Tuesday, has also bought time for many of the ambitious goals she set for herself, including her pledge to cut the income tax by 30 percent in her first three years in office. 
 "I think what she did was very smart in terms of a chief executive manipulating symbols," said Clifford Zukin, a political scientist at the Eagleton Institute of Politics at Rutgers University.
One signal came when Mrs. Whitman interrupted her inaugural speech to sign her first executive order, creating a New Jersey Economic Master Plan Commission to develop what she said would be a long-term strategy to make the state an "economic powerhouse."
 
A Political Shield
 With the stroke of a pen, Mrs. Whitman did more than create the commission, which does not yet have any members; she also gave herself a temporary shield against those who would clamor for her to deliver immediately on the promise to restore the state economy.
Today, Mrs. Whitman turned her attention to ethics, which had been an issue in her race last fall against Gov. Jim Florio. She signed an executive order that consolidated and extended financial disclosure requirements for state officials, as well as restoring and tightening provisions affecting blind trusts.
(She also signed an executive order driven by natural, not political events, declaring a statewide energy emergency in New Jersey brought on by a surge in utility use because of the severe winter storm.)
But it was her pledge on Tuesday that she would produce an immediate tax cut that brought a gasp and then sustained applause from the inaugural audience and commanded headlines across the state today.
 
Bold First Installment
 The announcement showed the same kind of boldness that Mrs. Whitman demonstrated late in the gubernatorial race, when she first made her tax-cut pledge.
"There are still some doubting Thomases that Mrs. Whitman would make good on her promises," said Lawrence A. Kudlow, a chief economist for Bear, Stearns & Company who was one of Mrs. Whitman's chief economic advisers during her campaign and transition. "This is symbolic that she will make good."
Mr. Kudlow and Malcolm S. Forbes Jr., president and chief executive of Forbes Inc., were the authors of Mrs. Whitman's tax-cutting plan, and Mr. Kudlow said today that they also were behind Mrs. Whitman's decision to back the retroactive tax cut.
"I sold it to her at the Republican Governors' Conference in Arizona in November," Mr. Kudlow said. "I asked Christie, would she consider a retroactive? I said I thought it made a lot of economic sense and it made some political sense, too. The last time I spoke to her was two Sundays ago at a New Jersey Devils game and I said, 'Are you still solid on the retro?' and she said, 'Yes.' I was thrilled."
 
Timed for U.S. Increase
 Mr. Kudlow said that beyond its political value, the retroactive cut was timed to coincide with the Federal tax increase that took effect on Jan. 1.
"Also, from an administrative standpoint, most tax administrators prefer to operate on a calendar year rather than the fiscal year," he said.
Mrs. Whitman's nominee for State Treasurer, Brian W. Clymer, said on Tuesday that a 5 percent cut retroactive to Jan. 1 would reduce revenues by $300 million for the calendar year 1994. The state is expected to end its 1994 fiscal year on June 30 with at least a $400 million surplus, which means there would be money at hand to pay for the cut plus a bit for the next round.
But the next round, which will begin when Mrs. Whitman unveils her first budget on March 15, will be much tougher.
 
No One-Shot Tricks
 Besides delivering Part 2 of the tax cut, her budget team will have to find ways to close a projected $1.4 billion gap between revenues and spending. Last year the state used a lot of one-shot financial tricks to balance the budget, methods that cannot be used again; also, raises and new benefits will kick in for many state employees under their union contracts.
In moving immediately to deliver on the first installment of her tax promise, Mrs. Whitman also has gambled her political life on delivering the entire amount.
"I think she is tied to the reduction; there is no way out of it," said Dr. Milton Leontiades, dean of the Rutgers University School of Business at Camden. He said that while Mr. Florio's task of raising taxes was very difficult, "Whitman is taking on an equally difficult task of reducing taxes and looking for ways to pay for it. I don't think either one will be especially popular.'
Mrs. Whitman has promised the largest tax cut in the state's history, in part by reducing the size of government and cutting a nickel out of every dollar the state spends.
 
Spending Cut Only Once
 It seems simple in its explanation, but is daunting in application.
Only once since World War II has New Jersey actually cut the total spending in a budget, said Richard C. Leone, who was State Treasurer from 1973 to 1977 during the first term of Gov. Brendan T. Byrne.
In the 1975-76 state budget year, Governor Byrne reduced the state budget by 1.8 percent over 1974-75.
"It was probably, in political terms, much more wrenching than a tax increase because the fights about who would take the hit affected everybody," said Mr. Leone, who is now president of the 20th Century Fund, a policy research foundation in Manhattan. "The budget is the place where all the factors in politics come together. It's going to be very tough."
"I went through something similar and it was no day at the beach," he said. "I made more enemies that year than the rest of my life put together. My nickname became Dr. No."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman conferring with a member of her security staff outside her State House office in Trenton. She was still receiving praise yesterday for a surprise inaugural pledge Tuesday: an immediate tax cut, retroactive to Jan. 1, that is to grow to 30 percent in three years. (Laura Pedrick for The New York Times)
