HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long Bonds Down on Profit Taking

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the longer maturities down on profit taking after Tuesday's price gains and a concern over when the Federal Reserve might raise short-term interest rates.
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond dropped three-eighths of a point, to 9914/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.29 percent, from 6.26 percent on Tuesday. Short-term rates were slightly mixed, with the three-month bill rate at 2.96 percent and a six-month bill at 3.10 percent, down 1 and 2 basis points, respectively. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percent. 
 A report on trade yesterday was of little interest to the market, dealers said. The Government said the merchandise trade deficit in November narrowed to $10.17 billion from an upward revised deficit of $10.9 billion in October. Market expectations called for a deficit number of $10.5 billion, unchanged from the previous month.
 
Focus on Auctions
 Traders instead remained focused on next week's Treasury auctions of new two- and five-year notes and the pace of growth in the first quarter. "We're not really going to get any new information that says if the Fed is going to maintain its present monetary stance or raise interest rates in the near term," one trader said.
Another negative working against the market was a revision of December's National Association of Purchasing Management Index, analysts said. The index was lowered to 57.1, from 57.9, but it was the price component, which was changed to 51.3 from 48.8, that caught the market's attention as a reminder that inflation fears are never far away.
Joseph V. Battapaglia, managing director of Sterling Advisers, a division of Gruntal & Company, said estimates of a fall in economic activity in the fourth quarter had been overblown. Recent numbers suggest not only final strong demand, but also some necessary inventory rebuilding, which would put gross domestic product growth in the first quarter in the neighborhood of 3 to 3.5 percent.
 
Consumer Factors Cited
 The important factors are auto sales and home sales, Mr. Battapaglia said. "Over all, the level of consumer spending continues to be healthy, with some of the keys that turned to neutral from some negatives that were expected." For instance, he said, higher gasoline taxes were more than offset by the decline in energy prices and health care changes went from a two-month project to a one-year project.
"We're going have stable interest rates, more consistent with the 50's and 60's than with recent history, which is the function of steady economic expansion without inflation," Mr. Battapaglia said.
The Federal Reserve's so-called beige book, a regional survey of economic conditions, said the economy was continuing to expand and saw little upward pressure on wages and prices, with loan demand increasing somewhat.
"All in the right direction if the Fed intends to raise rates," said Walter S. Frank, chief economist for IBC/Donoghue, an information service for institutional investors. "It's not enough yet, but if the trend continues they will."
The Treasury announced the terms of next week's two- and five-year note auctions yesterday. The amounts met almost everyone's expectations, with $17 billion in new two-year notes and $12 billion, up $1 billion, in five-year notes.
And in late trading the yield for a two-year note on a when-issued basis was 4.14 percent, while the five-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.10 percent.
 
Family Restaurants Issue
 In the junk bond market, Family Restaurants yesterday sold $450 million of bonds in two parts through underwriters led by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
The deal is among 10 junk issues totaling about $2.2 billion that are coming to market, according to MCM Corporatewatch, a new-issue information service.
For $300 million of Family Restaurant senior notes due 2002, the price was 100 for a yield of 9.75 percent. These notes are callable in five years and rated B-1 by Moody's Investors Service and B by Standard & Poor's.
The remainder of the issue rated B-3 by Moody's and B- by S.& P., included $150 million face amount of senior subordinated discount notes due 2004, which were priced at $726.97 for a $1,000 bond to yield 10.875 percent.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
New Publishers Selected For Fortune and Money

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY 

 BODY:
Time Inc. named new publishers for Fortune and Money yesterday to replace publishers who are retiring.
Stuart Arnold, advertising sales director of Fortune since 1991, was named publisher of Fortune, replacing James B. Hayes. And Betsy Martin, associate publisher and advertising sales director of Money, was named publisher of Money, replacing William S. Myers. 
 Mr. Hayes, who is 55, is retiring after 35 years at Time Inc. and seven years as publisher of Fortune. He is leaving to head a new organization that will deal with public education, a longtime interest. Mr. Hayes said details of the new organization would be announced next week.
Mr. Hayes's retirement comes a few months before the expected retirement of Marshall Loeb, the longtime managing editor of Fortune, who turns 65 in May.
Mr. Hayes said that after several tough years because of the recession, Fortune made a comeback in 1993 with its largest circulation growth ever. Circulation revenues in 1993 were $8 million more than in 1992, he said, making 1993 the magazine's best year in circulation profitability.
Advertising pages in 1993 were up 9.5 percent over the previous year, according to the Publishers Information Bureau.
Mr. Arnold 42, joined Fortune in 1981 as New York sales representative and has served as the magazine's Pittsburgh-based regional sales manager as well as New York manager. In 1989, he left Fortune for a year to serve as associate publisher of Aviation Week & Space Technology.
 
Money's Publisher Since 1988
 Mr. Myers, 59, who has been with Time Inc. for 32 years, has been the publisher of Money since 1988. From 1982 to 1988, he served as associate publisher and advertising sales director for People magazine. He previously worked at Sports Illustrated and Life magazines and at Home Box Office.
Money's circulation for the first six months of 1993 was 2.16 million, up 13.5 percent from 1992, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. Its advertising pages were down 3.3 percent from 1992, according to the Publishers Information Bureau.
Ms. Martin joined Money as New York City sales representative in 1981, rising to manager of the magazine's New England sales group, based in Boston. In 1986, she became head of the sales department of Women's Sports and Fitness magazine and in 1987 was named national ad sales director of Working Woman. She returned to Money as ad sales director in 1988 and was named associate publisher last year.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
BANKAMERICA CORP. (N)

 BODY:
Profits at the BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's second-largest banking company, rose by 4.9 percent in the fourth quarter, to $496 million.
The company earned $1.21 a share for the quarter, slightly less than the $1.23 a share that analysts had expected. 
 BankAmerica, based in San Francisco, earned $1.95 billion in 1993, up 31 percent from 1992.
Like other large banks, BankAmerica saw its holdings of problem assets decline sharply, especially because of improvements in the real estate market. At the end of 1993, the bank held $1.04 billion in problem assets, down 27 percent over the three months.
Suffering from the recession in California, the bank's loans declined to $124.8 billion, from $127.3 billion a year earlier. Lending increased 1.5 percent over the last three months of the year, largely from home mortgages and other consumer loans.
Despite the increase in earnings, the bank's profitability was still modest. It posted a return on equity of 12.9 percent for the year, about the same as in 1992 and far lower than the 18 percent benchmark for highly profitable banks.
But BankAmerica continued to build capital. Its Tier 1 capital -- the Government's main measure of financial strength -- rose to 7.5 percent, from 6.8 percent a year earlier.

HEADLINE: U.S. Drops Its Threat Of Sanctions on Japan

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today dropped its threat to impose trade sanctions on Japan, citing a pledge by Tokyo to open its $20 billion construction market to foreign competition.
"The Government of Japan has addressed all the major U.S. concerns in the Japanese public works sector," the United States trade representative, Mickey Kantor, said at a news conference today. Retaliatory sanctions to bar Japanese builders from the American market will therefore prove unnecessary, he said. 
 But Mr. Kantor pointedly said that the resolution of the public works issue should now be used as a building block to surmount other trade problem areas.
The United States and Japan agreed in July to try to find common ground on a broad economic agenda before next month's meeting between President Clinton and Prime Morihiro Hosokawa.
 
Narrowed Trade Gap Reported
 Separately, the Commerce Department today reported a narrowing in November's overall trade gap, with the deficit with Japan falling to $5.72 billion from October's $6.09 billion.
That blip, however, failed to wipe out a dismal performance for the first 11 months of last year, when the global deficit ran at its worst level in six years, with Japan accounting for the lion's share of the $118.7 billion annual shortfall.
Tokyo disclosed its new construction plan on Tuesday, and Mr. Kantor said it demonstrated "Hosokawa's commitment to reform Japanese procurement and regulatory practices."
Mr. Kantor, after postponing a threat of sanctions last October, had given Tokyo until Thursday at the latest to act in the seven-year building dispute. The construction plan covers more than $20 billion of procurement on an annual basis and will make for a more open and competitive bidding system, he said.
Japanese officials said the plan would open up public works projects to foreign bidders by April and make the entire system of awarding jobs more fair and objective. It would also step up punishment for bid-rigging and bribery, which is endemic in the high-profit works sector.
 
Construction Executives Arrested
 Just Tuesday, another scandal broke when executives at Japan's No. 4 construction company were arrested on charges of bribing a mayor.
Japan and the United States exchanged letters agreeing to monitor access to Tokyo's works sector in annual meetings.
"I hope that this positive step sets the stage for concluding meaningful framework agreements prior to the Feb. 11 meeting between President Clinton and Prime Minister Hosokawa," Mr. Kantor said.
President Clinton has repeatedly put Tokyo on notice that it must right the lopsided flow of trade -- which translates into a $50 billion annual deficit for Americans -- or face retaliation. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen is expected to take the same message when he flies to Tokyo on Sunday to discuss the logjammed economic talks.
"At the request of the President, Secretary Bentsen is planning to meet with Prime Minister Hosokawa in Tokyo on Jan. 23 to discuss the economic framework negotiations," said a Treasury spokeswoman in Beijing, where Mr. Bentsen is traveling.

HEADLINE: Japan's Chief Says U.S. Economists Oppose Trade Targets

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 19

 BODY:
Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan, in a reply to an open letter from American economists, has reiterated his opposition to setting targets for opening Japan's markets.
"I was very gratified and encouraged to note in your open letter that your opposition to managed trade coincides with our views," the Prime Minister wrote in his letter, dated Dec. 27. 
 The letter was provided by a Japanese Government official who wanted to show that the top politicians in Japan, not only its bureaucrats, were opposed to the central American demand in current trade negotiations that quantitative benchmarks be set to measure progress in opening Japan's markets. Some Clinton Administration officials have been hoping that Japan's bureaucrats could be made to budge in the deadlocked trade talks by appealing to Japanese politicians.
 
Part of a Campaign
 While Mr. Hosokawa's views have been stated previously, the release of the letter is part of a campaign by Japan to resist trade targets as the Feb. 11 deadline approaches for reaching several agreements under the new negotiating framework signed by the United States and Japan last July.
Just today, an advisory committee to Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry issued a report saying that targets were undesirable and that market share of foreign products was not an indication of whether a nation's markets were open or closed.
And in a related matter, Japan's Government today resisted requests from the United States to take strong new steps to increase sales of foreign semiconductors in Japan.
The American request and Japanese demurral came during an emergency meeting here today that had been called by the Clinton Administration, which is concerned that the foreign share of Japan's computer chip market has dropped below the 20 percent goal of a semiconductor trade agreement between the two nations.
 
Loves the Letter
 Last September, about 40 economists and Japan experts, mainly from the United States, signed an open letter to President Clinton and Prime Minister Hosokawa, saying that "U.S. demands for managed trade are misguided." Japan's Government loves this letter.
In his written reply to three of the scholars -- Jagdish Bhagwati and Hugh Patrick of Columbia University and Gary Saxonhouse of the University of Michigan -- Mr. Hosokawa said Japan would take "voluntary steps" to increase imports in an effort to achieve a "highly significant" reduction in Japan's current account surplus, as called for in the framework agreement reached between Mr. Hosokawa's predecessor and President Clinton.
But he said Japan "as a matter of principle, has sedulously avoided any approach of setting numerical targets, since such an approach could not fail to lead to excessive government intervention in the market and to managed trade."
Regarding semiconductors, an American trade official said after today's meeting that he was "disappointed" that Japan seemed to show a "lack of appreciation of the seriousness of U.S. concern on this issue." Officials in Washington will now discuss what to do next.
In the 1991 semiconductor agreement, Japan recognized the expectation of the American side that foreign companies could gain 20 percent of Japan's semiconductor market by the end of 1992. The agreement also calls for a "steady and gradual improvement in market access" after 1992.
 
No Crisis, Japan Says
 While foreign share inched above 20 percent in the fourth quarter of 1992, just in time to meet the deadline, it has fallen steadily since then and reached 18.1 percent in the third quarter of 1993 using the American calculation method, and 19.7 percent using the Japanese method.
Japan does not see the situation as a crisis requiring emergency measures, a Japanese trade official said. Sales of foreign chips actually rose in the 1993 third quarter. The reason market share declined was that the size of the market grew even faster, with most of the growth being for the types of chips that Japanese companies specialize in.
The semiconductor agreement has become a key reference point for the current framework talks. The American side uses it as evidence that setting targets is effective. Japan uses it as an example of how the United States takes even a vague goal -- the chip agreement clearly states that 20 percent foreign share is not a "guarantee" -- and treats it as a commitment by Japan.
The Japanese official said the revival of controversy over the semiconductor issue could harden Japan's resolve against numerical indicators in the framework talks. "This is the kind of thing that could happen in the future in the framework if we are not careful," he said.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Rallies Against Yen On Easing of Trade Tension

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar rebounded against the Japanese yen yesterday amid signs of a possible breakthrough in strained trade talks between Japan and the United States. It rose to 111.43 yen in late New York trading, from 110.79 late Tuesday.
Gold prices slipped. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery fell 90 cents, to $392.70 an ounce. 
 The dollar also rose against some leading European currencies. In New York, it was quoted at 1.7462 German marks, up from 1.7460 late Tuesday. The British pound closed in New York at $1.4925, down from late Tuesday's $1.4965.
Growing tension on the trade front sent the dollar to a low of 110.20 yen in early New York dealings. These tensions have caused fears that American officials would push for a weaker dollar to try to hack away at the country's nagging trade imbalance with Japan.
A weaker dollar promotes American exports by making them less expensive abroad while raising the cost of foreign imports here.
Worries about the trade situation subsided yesterday after the Clinton Administration dropped its threat to impose sanctions on Japan, citing a "historic" pledge by Tokyo to open its $20 billion-a-year construction market to foreign competition. Later, a Government spokeswoman said Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen would meet with Japan's Prime Minister, Morihiro Hosokawa, on Sunday. The dollar rallied on the news.
"It increases the chances that the U.S. and Japan will reach an amicable solution to the trade problems," said David Durst, vice president at Bear Stearns. "It suggests Japan may be willing to offer a solution to the problem by stimulating its economy via consumer demand."
Further alleviating concern over the American trade deficit with Japan, the Commerce Department reported that the nation's trade imbalance had improved during November.
"It was a slightly better number," said Jack Griffin, manager of corporate foreign exchange at Fuji Bank. He noted, however, that the gains were somewhat limited as the trade deficit remained large despite the narrowing.

HEADLINE: TALKING WITH: Bernice King;
Shaping Her Own Dream

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
A FEW days before the nation celebrated her father's life Monday, Bernice King was talking about coming to terms with his death.
"I was 16, with our church youth group in the north Georgia mountains, and we had just finished watching, 'Montgomery to Memphis,' a documentary on the civil rights movement," said Miss King, 30, now a minister and law school graduate in Atlanta, and the youngest of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s four children. "When they did the funeral portion, I broke out in tears and left the cabin and went out into the woods, crying and asking God, 'Why? Why? Why?' It was shortly after that time I decided I was through with the church and God." 
 But not long afterward, Miss King found herself drawn back to the church and began moving toward making her father's career her own in a slow, unfinished journey that takes on particular resonance each year, during the King holiday.
Being designated the spiritual heir of a figure as commanding as Dr. King would be a cruel burden for anyone to carry. But from the time she electrified the Ebenezer Baptist Church during the King Day celebration a year ago with a sermon whose every breath whispered and roared her father's vision, that burden has been thrust on Bernice King.
"It's out there, very definitely," she said of the public perception that of his children she is the one most likely to walk in his footsteps. "I don't think I resent it. I'm partly uncomfortable with it, because I know certain things are required for leadership that I have not yet evolved to. But I think people are beginning to see that Bernice knows what she wants to do and doesn't want to do, and she is not going to let you pull her in any direction where she doesn't want to go."
If young John F. Kennedy Jr.'s heartbreaking salute was perhaps the most moving image from the funeral of President Kennedy, the comparable image after Dr. King's assassination in Memphis was Bernice, then a week past her fifth birthday, lying in her mother's lap during his funeral in Atlanta.
Born just before her father left for Birmingham for his historic confrontation with T. Eugene (Bull) Connor's police dogs and fire hoses, Miss King's direct memories of her father are so slender and fleeting she holds tightly to each one. There was a kissing game he played in which each of his children had a little spot, hers on his forehead, to kiss during the all-too-rare occasions when he could be home. More powerful for her is a phantom memory she clings to.
"Strangely enough, about five years after he passed, it seemed as if it was just yesterday that I was jumping in his arms," she said. "I mean literally, I felt like, gosh, it was just two days ago. So, I hold on to that memory. It was only in that last year that I really started understanding that he was my father, and then he was taken away."
But if the direct memories are dim, her spiritual link with her father is profound: from the "call" she said she received to follow him into the ministry to the cadences, wording and rhythms in her preaching that she knows echo his.
Miss King said she considered almost every career other than the ministry. As a teen-ager, she decided to enter politics and made up her mind to become the nation's first African-American and first female President. In college, she considered being a television anchor. She graduated from Spelman College with a degree in psychology and then earned a law degree at Emory University. But a speech on apartheid she gave to the United Nations in 1980 at age 17 made her aware for the first time of her oratorical gifts. And in March 1988, she preached her first sermon at Ebenezer Baptist Church, where her father and grandfather had both been pastors. She was ordained two years later.
Miss King, who chose to be interviewed in the anonymous surroundings of a bare room in her publicist's suburban offices, has her father's round face and large eyes. They are accented by styled dark bangs that fall over her forehead and gold hoop earrings. Before flying out to give a speech at Alabama State University in Montgomery, one of six she did in three states late last week, she wore a high-necked ribbed green shirt, green jeans and brown boots with green socks, although fashion does not appear to be her biggest concern.
Asked if there is any significance to the turquoise-colored pendant around her neck she shrugged. "I just bought it," she said. "It's nothing. I don't even know what it is."
In Atlanta, the King family is treated like royalty, much as the Kennedys are in Boston, with the combination of reverence and resentment that can bring. Besides their mother, Coretta Scott King, there are Yolanda King, 38, an actress, producer and director whose work focuses on social and political issues; Martin Luther King 3d, 36, a former member of the Fulton County Commission, who lost a bid to be elected its chairman last year, and Dexter King, 32, who has an entertainment production company, briefly headed the Atlanta Center, founded in Dr. King's honor, and is active overseeing his father's estate.
All four are single. Asked what she makes of that, Miss King laughed and said: "That's a $100 million question. If I had an answer to that, I think we'd be married. It takes a very exceptional man, who's secure within himself, to have to deal with the public side."
Miss King, whose friends call her Bunny, has both public and private sides, too. From the pulpit, her voice resonates with her father's passion and strength, although she says her style is more traditional Baptist than his, her pace faster, and her concerns more personal. "I think his starting point is sociology, and mine is psychology," she said. In private, her Southern-accented voice animated and conversational, she is relaxed and self-effacing, with more the looks and manner of an eager graduate student than of an angry prophet.
Miss King is an associate minister at the Greater Rising Star Baptist Church in Atlanta, where she heads a singles ministry that the senior pastor there, Byron Broussard, says is a laboratory for the community work she would like to do on a national scale. She continues her membership at Ebenezer Baptist Church, where she sings in the Martin Luther King Sr. Choir. She also helped found AMEN (Active Ministers Engaged in Nurturing), a group that counsels juvenile offenders, and she hopes to expand it to a broader organization working with black youths.
Like her father, she reflects the conservative social roots that have often infused African-American political movements.
"I think if we're going to reclaim or recapture young people, it's going to have to be through the church or through spirituality, because we are spiritual beings whether we like it or not," she said. "People say to me all the time, 'There are a lot of young blacks that are angry,' and I say: 'You know there's nothing wrong with anger. It's what you do with it. It's whether it becomes constructive anger or destructive anger.' "
She is a student as well as a daughter of Dr. King. "There's a sermon he did on hope that I really, really love," she said. "I need to really focus on it and get it in my mind. I like his 'Where Do We Go From Here: Chaos or Community?' because it allowed me to see a side of him that I really respect, an ability to really understand positions and not become defensive, but to take people to another level in what they're doing."
In fact, if she has a problem with her father's legacy it is that it has not been taken to another level, but instead has been ossified into the King of "I have a dream" even though her father had moved past a narrow focus on civil rights toward broader issues of human rights and economic justice. It is striking to hear Dr. King's daughter enunciating a post-civil rights view of race in America.
"For a long time, we as African-Americans have gotten caught up in the victim cycle," she said. "It does not excuse the fact that we are victims, but if we stay caught up in that, then we cannot liberate ourselves, and we certainly can't help to liberate others. It's kind of like, as you grow up as a child, your parents do something to you, and you're 25, 30, 40 years old and you're still blaming your parents for what happened to you. At some point, you have to begin to direct it toward something positive that will help heal the situation."
It's not that the times now don't call for anger or struggle, but the issues that define 1994 are different from those of 1964, she said.
"To me, racism is not as hard an issue to deal with anymore," she said. "It's a challenge that we still need to deal with. But because the laws have been changed, it doesn't threaten as many people. But when you start talking about money, when you start moving to the economic level, that does something else to you."
For now, her focus is on her ministry, counseling and speaking. She said she is not interested in politics but does not rule out the possibility of a broader leadership role in the future.
"I like my privacy," she said. "I don't care for the public side, if only for the expectations and the scrutiny. But I have friends that always tell me that 'you have certain gifts, and it's almost inevitable that you will end up in some kind of leadership role that will challenge the system.' So, who knows?"

HEADLINE: Revlon's Chairman Donates $10 Million To the Guggenheim

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
Barely four weeks after announcing that its landmark Frank Lloyd Wright building would be named in honor of the developer Samuel J. LeFrak and his wife, Ethel, the donors of $10 million, the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum said yesterday that it had received another gift of $10 million, from the financier Ronald O. Perelman.
Part of the gift from Mr. Perelman, who is the chairman of Revlon, will go to commission a sculpture by Roy Lichtenstein that will be placed on or above the sculpture terrace on the exterior of the Fifth Avenue museum's new tower building. The remainder of the gift is an unrestricted cash donation. With its announcement of the gift, the museum formally kicked off a $100 million capital campaign; about $50 million of that amount has now been raised, said Thomas Krens, the Guggenheim's director. 
 But what's left to be named after Mr. Perelman? "There's plenty left," said Mr. Krens. "All the galleries, the roof terrace, the theater, the ramps; SoHo isn't out of the question either," he added, referring to the museum's downtown branch, at 575 Broadway, which opened in mid-1992.
Mr. Krens went on to say that Mr. Perelman's gift "isn't about the naming opportunity." "Ron's been more generous than most people realize," the director said. "He doesn't want his name on things."
 
'Poised for Great Growth'
 "The Guggenheim is a fabulous institution, poised for great growth over the next decade, and I saw an opportunity to help accelerate that growth," Mr. Perelman said yesterday.
Mr. Perelman was elected to the museum's board last February. Another of his companies, the Marvel Entertainment Group, sponsored the Guggenheim's Lichtenstein retrospective, which closed on Sunday.
The Perelman gift was the third $10 million donation a New York City cultural institution had received in the last month. The first was the LeFraks' gift to the Guggenheim (which as a museum is still the Guggenheim, in spite of the fact that the Wright building is now the Samuel J. and Ethel LeFrak Building). Last week, the fashion designer Bill Blass gave $10 million to the New York Public Library, and the public catalogue room of the central research library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street was named the Bill Blass Public Catalogue Room. Mr. Perelman's donation is crucial to the Guggenheim's capital drive, which it has named the Campaign for the Next Century.
"This gift puts us over the $50 million mark," said Mr. Krens, who added that two-thirds of the money raised from the drive would go into capital improvements and a third to the museum's endowment.
 
Expansion, in Manhattan and Out
 At a time when many museums have been cutting back, the Guggenheim has been moving aggressively to expand, and to raise the money necessary to finance its growth. In the last few years, the institution spent $58 million restoring the museum's Wright building; adding the 10-story limestone tower, designed by the Manhattan architects Gwathmey Siegel & Associates; constructing a vault beneath the museum, and purchasing and renovating a warehouse on the West Side of Manhattan.
To pay for these projects, the Guggenheim used $54.9 million in tax-exempt bonds issued through the Trust for Cultural Resources of the City of New York. At the time the bonds were issued, in August 1990, the museum's endowment stood at roughly $20 million, which led to speculation that if the museum could not find the money to pay back the bonds, its art might have to be sold to cover its debt. Museum officials have vehemently denied such a possibility. Mr. Krens estimates that after the capital campaign, the endowment will grow to somewhere between $50 million and $60 million. So far, the director said, the museum has repaid about $10 million of its bonds.
The bond issue for the Guggenheim's uptown space did not cover the cost of renovating the three floors in a building at the corner of Broadway and Prince Street that constitute the museum's SoHo branch. As a result of its increased space, the museum's overall budget has gone from about $10 million before the expansions to $25 million.
"The institution has gone through rapid and dramatic change," said Mr. Krens. "We have tried to develop a blueprint for the institution for the year 2000: to change its image from a small, family-supported institution to a public one. That's already happened."
The director plans to use some of the money for expansion outside of New York City. In March 1992, the Guggenheim signed an agreement with the Spanish city of Bilbao for a museum to be built there, run by the Guggenheim and paid for by Bilbao, with art on loan from the Guggenheim's collection. The Bilbao museum, designed by Frank Gehry and being built now, is to open in 1996. And in Venice, the museum has invested more than $7 million in capital improvements to the Peggy Guggenheim Collection, which the museum acquired in 1970.
"We've turned a leaky, drafty private house into one of the best private museums in Italy," Mr. Krens said of the Venice project. In 1989, the Guggenheim acquired a lease on adjacent property and it now has plans to move its gift shop out of the main building and into that space and to open a cafe.
 
Theater Construction
 But Mr. Krens says New York is still the Guggenheim's primary focus. He said the museum was planning to begin construction in the next month or two on a theater under the main rotunda of the Wright building; he estimated the theater would be completed in about a year.
"Raising money in this economy has been harder than I expected," Mr. Krens said. "Both Ron Perelman and Sam LeFrak are New Yorkers, both are committed to the city and this is really a New York story; that's what it's all about."

HEADLINE: Here Sheep Count, Day and Night

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN 

DATELINE: MILAN, N.Y.

 BODY:
THE cast-iron doorstop is in the shape of a ram. The hooked wool seat pads on the dining room chairs depict woolly sheep. There are fleecy sheepskins over the sofa, and a brochure on the desk touts "Herbal Moth Repellents."
The publications around the house include Sheep! Magazine and National Lamb and Wool Grower. And most of the door frames of the 18th-century farmhouse near Milan (pronounced MY-len), about 100 miles north of Manhattan in Dutchess County, New York, are decorated with an array of best-of-show ribbons. 
 It would be hard not to get the point. "Sheep is it," said Margrit Lohrer Pichler, 48, who with her husband, Albrecht, 53, is a full-time Merino sheep farmer. With its 600-head flock, Morehouse Farm, the Pichlers' homestead, is responsible for reintroducing Merino sheep to the region. Merinos are white-faced sheep that produce the finest and most valuable wool in the world.
In the last eight years, Ms. Pichler, who was once a partner in a Manhattan graphic-design firm, slowly started spending more time on the farm, and the couple's sheep mania grew into a way of life. "Now, the sheep take 150 percent of my time," Ms. Pichler said.
It would be hard to imagine a better commercial for wool than sheep that are out in 22-degree-below-zero temperatures. But there was Mr. Pichler with Sage, a border collie, enthusiastically leading his flock through snow-covered fields toward a barn that serves as a stylish shop for pillows and throws, along with sweaters, caps, mittens and scarfs, all knitted by Ms. Pichler or woven by craftsmen in the area. (Ms. Pichler also sells skeins of wool and knitting kits to shops around the country.) Mr. Pichler stopped to show off a group of ewes he called "the teen-age girls." A weekend shepherd, he is an architect who commutes by train to Manhattan, where he designs ski resorts and private homes for -- no kidding -- Robert Lamb Hart, an architectual firm.
Merino sheep have been living in Spain since the Middle Ages. In 18th-century England, George III had a royal flock. "Sheep came to America in Colonial times and have always been a large part of our history, and Merinos were very popular at one time," said Robert Padula of the American Sheep Industry Association in Englewood, Colo. (his title: the farm flock raw wool services director). And Ms. Pichler pointed out that "in 1805, a ram sold for $1,000, a fortune."
But as the demand for lamb increased at the dinner table and the price for wool declined with the introduction of synthetics, Merino sheep fell out of favor. Today, Ms. Pichler said, they are raised mainly in Australia, South Africa and South America. Because they are slow to mature, "the Merino was never the most economical sheep to raise for meat alone," she added.
Janice Grauberger, the communications director at the sheep industry group, said: "There are no more than 50 people around the United States that do what the Pichlers do. They have to do niche marketing to exist."
The Pichlers' hard-won success has come in part from their unusually sophisticated approach to sheep farming, bringing big-city marketing skills to a down-home endeavor. The Pichlers are in some ways the 90's version of back-to-the-earth hippie farmers of the 60's. But this time around, these savvy farmers have developed farm specialties: reduced-fat goat cheese, free-range chickens and organic mesclun.
The Pichlers' approach to life may be envied even by those who would never think about leaving the city. At Morehouse Farm, they have been able to intertwine business acumen and personal passion.
In 1985, they had put their five-year goals on paper: "To be the most important Merino breeder in North America" and "to have a solid reputation for the finest wool in North America."
But Merino sheep, they soon found out, had an image problem. "Whenever we went to fairs and shows," Ms. Pichler said, "we heard Merinos called greasy, dirty, small animals. The image of the Merino was never updated. People were walking around with the image of that little wrinkly dude that was a nightmare to shear."
The Pichlers have what is tantamount to a full-service operation. They breed the sheep, then shear them when they have a year's growth. The wool is sorted on the farm, then washed in Pennsylvania and sent to mills in Canada and Vermont to be spun.
When asked how their interest in sheep took over their lives, the Pichlers say in unison: "We've always loved animals."
Of course, that's the short, and romantic part of the story. The couple had met each other at a party in Manhattan in 1976, and a year later bought the 35-acre farm for country weekends. Soon, they were adding Friday afternoons, and sometimes Monday mornings.
But from the beginning, "our sheep-raising was going to be strictly business," said Ms. Pichler, who was born in Switzerland and came to the United States when she was 16 years old. Now, she and her husband, who was born in Austria and moved to the United States in the 1960's, farm a total of about 200 acres.
"If you have a meat business," Mr. Pichler explained, "you sell for a clear end, but if you raise sheep for wool, it is similar to raising cows for milk."
Who would have known that a New York City chicken would show them the way?
In early 1983, Ms. Pichler found a live chicken in the Riverside Park, across from her office. "We immediately had visions of fresh breakfasts," she said. But the chicken did not lay eggs. And before the couple figured out that the chicken was a rooster, they had bought two more chickens to keep him company at the farm. "That's when we realized we were stuck," Ms. Pichler said. "We decided we might as well get some other farm animals."
So that's how the first sheep, named Bogardus, came to Morehouse Farm. "We decided to name the sheep after all the roads that led to the Taconic," Mr. Pichler said. But after the 10th sheep, the couple ran out of road names. And after 200 sheep, they resorted to numbers.
Right from the beginning, when they bought three ewes and one ram, the couple were struck with what they described as "the big mystery." "If everyone agreed that Merino sheep grow the best wool," Ms. Pichler said, "why weren't there any around?"
"That's why we started thinking about how to market something that no one likes," Ms. Pichler said.
The couple began by buying the fanciest custom-made livestock trailer. "When we showed up at the fairs with our fancy transportation, people really started changing what they thought about the Merinos," Ms. Pichler said.
The Pichlers soon bought more sheep to expand their flock and, through sales to other farmers, to help re-establish the breed. Their sheep started winning competitions. Soon the Pichlers hired representatives to sell the wool, which now retails for $7.70 for a two-ounce skein in yarn shops, compared with more ordinary wool that costs $3 to $5 a skein. Ms. Pichler uses 8 to 12 skeins for a sweater, which will sell for $325 or more in her shop.
"As far as I'm concerned," Ms. Pichler said, "how can you not love a sheep that makes such beautiful wool?"
That seems to make up for all the hard work involved. During the lambing season, Ms. Pichler often stays up most of the night to check on the ewes. And in the next few weeks, 65 ewes are expected to produce about 120 lambs.
Life at Morehouse Farm is "enjoyable," Mr. Pichler said, "but you don't run to the bank with the money."
One sheep can produce 8 to 20 pounds of wool a year. "The rams, who don't have the stress of lambing, tend to be bigger wool producers," Mr. Pichler said. "When a sheep is under severe stress or develops a high fever, the wool stops growing."
The Pichlers, who spend vacations traveling hundreds of miles to county fairs and livestock shows, have immersed themselves in a sheep-centered life. But these days, with a house filled with dogs, cats, parrots and cockateels and with hills dotted with rams and barns crowded with ewes and lambs, the couple say they have reached their limit. Not that they are considering another career change.
Sitting in their sunny dining room last Sunday, between bottle-feeding the just-born lambs that needed a little extra help, Ms. Pichler said, "I plan to be doing this the rest of my natural life and probably during the next one."
Her husband nodded.
"A few days ago, I dreamt a sheep was talking to me," she added. "I woke up and asked myself, 'Now why would a sheep talk to me?' "
Her husband smiled.
"Well, you talk to them," he said. "So there."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Central Divisions Are Added to Baseball's Lineup

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Jan. 19

 BODY:
The major league owners, continuing their attempt to change the nature of how baseball is run, redrew another part of the game today. They reached agreement with the players association on the realignment of the leagues from two divisions to three and the addition of an extra tier of playoffs.
Although the changes are guaranteed for only the coming season, the agreement is as historic as the new revenue-sharing plan hammered out between the large- and small-market clubs the night before. For the first time, baseball, heretofore the professional sport with the narrowest, most discriminating playoff field, will allow its two leagues to increase the number of playoff teams from two to four and include baseball's first wild-card berth. 
 Those four advancing clubs will include the three division winners and the team with the best record among non-division winners. The number of playoff teams will total 8, compared with 12 for the National Football League, 16 for the National Basketball Association and 16 for the National Hockey League.
The American and National Leagues enter this season not only with East and West divisions but also with Central divisions.
The new league formats will feature balanced schedules under which each team would play two home series and two road series against each other, regardless of division. That means that in the two divisions that have four teams, the West division in each league, teams would play approximately one-fourth of their games against division opponents.
 
Winner Against Wild Card
 Once in the playoffs, the division winner with the best overall record will play the wild-card team, unless the two teams come from the same division. If they do, the wild-card team will play the division winner with the second-best overall record. The other playoff will take place between the remaining two division winners. Once the three-of-five-game series ends, the four-of-seven-game league championship series will proceed, followed by the four-of-seven-game World Series.
After months of negotiations, the new format finally came about on the final day of the annual meetings here because the owners agreed to financially compensate players using one of several formats put forth by the Major League Baseball Players Association.
"Essentially we have committed to accept the union proposal that the players will receive 80 percent of the gate of the first three games," said Richard Ravitch, the owners' chief labor negotiator, who made the announcement.
But Ravitch pointed out that any agreement on this issue beyond this coming season will have to be negotiated as a part of collective bargaining on a new labor agreement.
 
Tried Different Formats
 The agreement is not based on the union's initial demands. The players had tried various formats, including the shortening of the season as well as a complete restructuring of the entire playoff pool system. The owners adamantly refused to negotiate anything but gate receipts.
Historically, the players have received 60 percent of the gate of the minimum number of games required in the playoffs or World Series.
Though the owners did not initially give in to the players' request, in the end, Ravitch said, "The owners did not feel this was the occasion to have extensive bargaining over relatively small amounts of money. This was not an issue of principle. This is to get on to find points of agreement with the union, to work with them to try to get a more rational economic system in baseball. That's what's important."
Though the new format guarantees more playoff berths for players, Donald Fehr, the union chief, chose once again to temper his enthusiasm for this and other developments the owners announced here this week. Those developments included management's renewed quest for a salary cap.
For the second straight day, Fehr questioned the sincerity of the owners' call for partnership. And he said union officials were somewhat puzzled and surprised that they were not invited to make a joint announcement of an agreement that would not have come about without their approval.
 
'Good for the Game'
 Still, Fehr said of the new system, "We think it's good for the game or we wouldn't have agreed to it."
Whether it lives beyond 1994 remains to be seen. "Nobody's quite sure what the public response will be," Ravitch said. "We will learn a lot from this year. But this is a one-year deal. We will proceed with this without prejudice as to how we will deal with this in the future."
That in itself is a marked turnaround from the original concepts the teams put forth. Just last September, at yet another owners meeting, the 28 clubs passed a resolution calling for a new divisional alignment that would be used for a minimum of four years, or the length of the next bargaining agreement, whichever is longer.

LENGTH: 480 words

HEADLINE: Mr. Cuomo's Election-Year Budget

 BODY:
All government budgets are political documents, and election-year budgets even more so. Gov. Mario Cuomo's plan for the coming year in New York State was clearly -- critics say cynically -- written with an eye on the campaign. In its optimism, therefore, it is a far cry from the sharp cutbacks of recent recession years.
Inspired by a glimmer of recovery in New York's economy and his newly declared hunger for a fourth term, Mr. Cuomo has sprinkled his proposals with small tax cuts and modest hikes in spending -- a lot of things to please a lot of New Yorkers. 
 But his message is mixed. On the one hand, he shows signs of shifting to the right to woo conservative voters -- for example, by trimming Medicaid benefits. On the other, he acts as if the nascent recovery makes it O.K. to stop looking for ways to take serious cuts in the state bureaucracy; he proposes to cut only 160 jobs.
On taxes, he focuses on cuts he wants the Legislature to approve, particularly cuts in business taxes -- a good step. At last he proposes to phase out the state's 5 percent tax on hotel rooms that cost more than $100 a night. And give him credit for targeting some fees that are especially aggravating to small businesses and simply cannot be justified. One of them is the $25 charge to every employer for a permit to pay employees by check, a holdover from paydays in decades past when a lot of paychecks bounced.
On a larger issue, Mr. Cuomo says now, as he has said in earlier years, that he wants the state to assume full responsibility for Medicaid benefits. But by failing to include funds for such benefits in his budget, he has once again signaled to the Legislature that they are not a priority.
The idea of a state takeover is not new, and was Governor Cuomo's in the first place. Most other states already pay the full freight. New York should, too, as a matter of fairness to overburdened local governments.
Put in a positive light, Mr. Cuomo's omission may be a calculated political strategy to goad New York City's new Republican Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, to bang on his fellow Republicans in the State Senate, who have blocked this important reform in the past. Clearly, Mr. Giuliani must get in and fight. But so must Mr. Cuomo; his offer to review the matter in 30 days is no substitute for forceful leadership.
Similarly, Mr. Giuliani should work on those same Republicans for further revision in the school aid formula, which is biased toward suburbs (Republican) at the expense of cities (Democratic). But where is Mr. Cuomo? He proposes more state aid for all, but fails to press for needed additional changes in the formula.
It is disappointing that the Governor does not fight harder for overdue reforms he says he supports. But on balance, this budget has some welcome innovations and should challenge the Legislature to repair its defects.

HEADLINE: Law on Cuba Trade Starves the Babies

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I write you as president of the Cuban American Committee for Peace, which has a membership of more than 17,000 Cubans residing in the United States, South America, Spain and Canada. All of us still have family in Cuba. 
 I was appalled by Representative Robert G. Torricelli's Jan. 5 letter, in which he brags of the effects his Cuban "Democracy" Act has had on the Cuban economy. He did not address the effect the decrease of United States subsidiary trade has had in human terms. Of the $718 million in subsidiary trade eliminated by Mr. Torricelli's law, 75 percent has been for food and medicine.
I visit Cuba regularly and have seen a significant change in my family's nutritional status since this law's enactment in 1992. I recently visited my 18-year-old son in Havana, and was disturbed at how thin he and the rest of my relatives have become.
Recently a United States subsidiary based in Canada sought to sell baby food to Cuba. It could not because of the Cuban Democracy Act, which states no United States subsidiary can trade with Cuba. This is what Mr. Torricelli is proud of? We are talking about food for infants, not military weapons. This law is a policy of genocide that seeks to create a Somalia in Cuba.
Mr. Torricelli speaks of democracy's coming to Cuba any day. About a year ago he predicted the Cuban Government would fall in three months.
Average Cubans do not blame their Government for the food and medicine shortages. Rather, they blame the United States embargo. Even human rights dissidents in Cuba like Elizardo Sanchez have spoken out against the Torricelli law. In Cuba, there are 3.5 million children. They are the victims of the Torricelli law.
Mr. Torricelli and other politicians need to start hearing that the climate in the United States is changing. Cuban-Americans are beginning to state that we will no longer allow opportunistic Congressmen like Mr. Torricelli to use a small group of rich, reactionary, Cuban exiles like Jorge Mas Canosa and his Cuban American National Foundation to pursue a policy that brings suffering to our families living in Cuba.
Mr. Torricelli and Mr. Mas Canosa talk of bringing democracy to Cuba, yet the foundation and reactionary groups like Alpha 66 use political harassment and intimidation to silence those who disagree with them. I have received death threats for expressing my belief that the United States should normalize relations with Cuba.
New voices besides ours are being raised in the Cuban-American community -- for instance, Cambio Cubano and the Cuban Committee for Democracy. All of them seek a new policy of dialogue between our two countries. These are the groups to whom Mr. Torricelli should listen.
It is time for this cruel and inhumane embargo to end and for men like Mr. Torricelli to realize that laws like the Cuban Democracy Act are not something of which they should be proud.
 
RAYMUNDO DEL TORO
Linden, N.J., Jan. 12, 1994

HEADLINE: The $6 Trillion Hole in Japan's Pocket

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Many of the world's financial markets have recovered from a decade of excess in which problems were often measured in billions, or even hundreds of billions, of dollars. But Japan is now coping with an even more awesome debacle: the loss of at least $6 trillion from one of the steepest plunges in stock and property values of this century.
And it is not over yet: the markets are just marking the anniversary of a crash that has sent stock and real estate prices down more than 50 percent, with no clear signs yet of a recovery. 
 The decline offers both insights into the Japanese financial system and puzzles that add to the uncertainty over Japan's troubled economic future. When the markets first began their tumble in early 1990, some analysts predicted that the decline could ripple through financial systems around the globe. Yet with Wall Street and some European markets reaching new highs, those fears have proved overblown. Even in Japan there has rarely been even a hint of panic in the air.
 
 
Delayed Agony
 Nevertheless, analysts say, while the Japanese Government has taken a series of steps to dampen the effects of the crash, those efforts may have only stretched out the problems. To give a sense of the dimensions of the crash, the American savings and loan crisis may end up costing about $350 billion. The third-world debt crisis appears to have cost banks less than $150 billion.
Some economists argue that the heavy-handed means the Japanese Government has used -- such as pouring cash from Government pension funds into the market, pressuring big investors not to sell shares and concealing the full impact of the debacle on banks from the public -- may have staved off an abrupt collapse, but at a huge cost that may undermine the financial system.
Japan's huge commercial banks have been unable to lift the economy out of its recession because they have been so battered by a mounting toll of bad loans. And many companies that poured their extra cash into securities investments in the boom years are now finding it difficult to revive their core industrial businesses because of their weakened financial condition. In addition, the reputation of Japan's respected economic planners has been badly damaged.
"The Government and the Bank of Japan thought we could have a soft landing," said Mikio Wakatsuki, chairman of the Japan Research Institute's board of counselors and until recently the deputy governor for international affairs at the Bank of Japan. "We thought we could make it a painless decline. It was maybe a misjudgment."
Takaaki Wakasugi, a professor of finance at Tokyo University and the University of Michigan said: "In the late 1980's, people were living in a dream. They did not understand reality. Right now, in a sense, we're in a state of chaos because of that."
While things have been surprisingly calm on the surface, the biggest victims of the crash, commercial banks, are likely to be impaired for years, analysts say. Japanese banks have been pulling back from the foreign markets they were attacking just five years ago. And Corporate Japan's overseas shopping spree for landmark commercial buildings, golf courses, Treasury bonds and Hollywood studios, much of it fueled by bank lending, has slammed to a halt.
At home, the banks have undermined their futures by continuing to support, often with loans at nominal interest rates, dozens of companies that became badly overstretched through reckless property and stock speculation in the boom years.
Publicly, Japan's 21 largest banks have declared that they have 13.76 trillion yen, or the equivalent of $123 billion, in loans from which they have received no interest payments for six months or more. But analysts say deliberately fuzzy accounting rules conceal the fact that the banks hold at least $270 billion in bad loans and that the figure is rising.
The banks have been hit in two ways. They frequently take property as collateral for loans. The plunge in real estate prices has meant that the collateral they hold on many bad loans is often worth less than half of the loans' face value.
In addition, the banks have put a significant portion of their capital -- the foundation for their loan growth -- into the shares of their corporate customers. With stock prices having fallen, the banks' capital has tumbled, making it harder for them to lift the economy from its malaise.
As a result, banks have been forced to reconsider their basic philosophy on the sort of collateral they accept for loans. They are starting to focus more, for instance, on the ability of property to produce income, rather than just its current market value. Worried about protecting their fragile loan portfolios, banks have also cut back sharply in lending to smaller companies and to consumers.
 
 
Tending the Home Fires
 Companies, too, have had to adjust to the new reality of deflation in the financial markets. Many companies, for instance, were lured into making huge investments in stocks, property and golf courses; they have now refocused on their core businesses.
Corporate treasurers, who had spent freely -- because raising capital in the stock market was so cheap in the boom years -- are being more tight-fisted about investments in research and new operations.
The property market has been even more severely affected. Not only have commercial property prices plunged more than 50 percent in big cities like Tokyo and Osaka, but almost no transactions are taking place.
To sell land is to realize the loss, so companies are sitting on land or transferring it to affiliated companies at prices that bear little relation to real market conditions.
The result has been a sort of slow-motion crash, defying the expectations of many analysts and economists.
"I thought the stock market had gone too high and that it would adjust, but I never thought it would go this low or last this long," said Yoshihiko Miyauchi, chief executive of the Orix Corporation, Japan's largest leasing and diversified financing company. "This is deflation. We haven't had to deal with this kind of thing before."
 
 
Pushing the Yen Up
 It all began with the growth of Japan's so-called bubble economy during the 1980's. Behind the rise had principally been low interest rates and the booming economy of the United States, where Japan sends a large portion of its exports. In September 1985, the Reagan Administration and Japanese officials agreed to send the value of yen soaring against the dollar to make Japanese products more expensive for foreigners, crimping exports. Foreign-made goods became cheaper in Japan, lifting imports.
In fact, there was a temporary reduction in Japan's surpluses, but the shock was a catastrophe for Japanese exporters. They could adjust to a stronger yen, but they needed time, and they needed to make huge investments to improve their efficiency.
The solution was steep reductions in interest rates by the Bank of Japan. Companies did make productive investments -- in fact, they overinvested, building more factory capacity than either the domestic or foreign markets could absorb. And the policy also set off a speculative orgy by flooding the markets with cash.
As investors bid stock prices higher, companies raised record sums by selling new shares: 8.85 trillion yen, or $62 billion worth, in 1989 alone.
The Government finally recognized the artificial nature of the market's rise and the possibility of an uncontrolled collapse, and began trying to ratchet down the market by the second half of 1989. The Bank of Japan began to raise its discount rate, and in the first week of 1990 investors got the message.
In the first two years of the market plunge, stock and property prices lost 611.7 trillion yen in value, or nearly $4.9 trillion, according to the Economic Planning Agency.
 
Market Is Down 51%
 But prices did not drop in a chaotic fury, for the most part. They just went into a sickeningly steep slide as trading volume dried up.
 Since then, it has gradually become impossible for companies to raise fresh capital by selling new shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Even after a recent uptick, the Nikkei index of 225 leading stocks has fallen 51 percent from its peak of 38,915.87.
Publicly, Government officials pledged fidelity to the principles of free-market economics. But it soon became clear that the Finance Ministry had ordered various Government pension funds to pour money into the stock market starting in 1992. Still, the market fell.
"Officially, of course, the Ministry of Finance denies their intervention, but now they have a very big problem on their hands," said Nobuhiko Matsuno, the former head of the ministry's securities bureau and now senior executive director of the Japan Development Bank. "The financial system is very fragile."
It also became clear that the Finance Ministry had been behind another aspect of the boom, the flood of capital Japanese companies sent overseas. The ministry had informally encouraged these investments, in part to relieve concern overseas about Japan's trade surpluses.
 The huge purchases of United States Treasury securities by insurance companies were intended to earn good will by helping the Treasury finance the Federal budget deficits. Those purchases were also regarded as a form of assistance to President Bush's 1988 election campaign by helping to keep American interest rates down; President Bush was regarded by the Japanese Government as less inclined toward protectionism than his Democratic opponent, Michael S. Dukakis.
"We asked life insurance companies to continue to buy U.S. bonds, especially right before the election," said Mr. Wakatsuki, the former Bank of Japan official. "There was a lot administrative guidance. It was unfortunate."
That enormous outflow of what is known as long-term capital abruptly reversed course and turned into an inflow in the early 1990's as banks and other investors pulled back.

HEADLINE: Starts of Housing Soar; Jobless Claims Also Rise

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Builders broke ground in 1993 on the largest number of new homes in four years, the Government said today, reflecting a pickup in the economy. But a separate report on first-time unemployment claims suggested that getting a job remained difficult.
Low-interest mortgages and higher consumer confidence encouraged builders to break ground on a total of 1.29 million new homes last year, an increase of 7.1 percent, the Commerce Department said. 
 In December alone, home construction jumped 6.2 percent from the previous month to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.54 million new homes, suggesting that an even stronger housing market lies ahead.
"There's no question that the housing sector is in the midst of a major expansion," said Marilyn Schaja, an economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities.
 
 
Decline for the Northeast
 In the Western region, which has been struggling to emerge from recession, housing starts jumped 14.7 percent in December to an annual rate of 374,000 units, compared with 326,000 units in November.
 Only the Northeast reported a decline in starts last month, falling 3.5 percent, to 138,000 units.
Last year's total housing starts were at the highest level since 1.38 million units in 1989.
Robert Davis, economist for the Savings and Community Bankers of America, said he expected the December home building pace to continue at least into the second quarter, especially since building permits were up a strong 7.4 percent last month to an annual rate of 1.48 million.
"This is going to be the best year of the recovery cycle, even if it is still a muted recovery," he said.
A robust housing market is a boon to economic growth because it spurs the manufacture of building materials, gives a lift to the home furnishings industry and provides thousands of new factory, construction and finance jobs.
 
 
Spike in Jobless Claims
 But a separate report on labor market conditions cast a pall over the rosy housing outlook.
The Labor Department said today that first-time claims for state unemployment benefits climbed 23,000 in mid-January to 380,000 -- the highest level in six months.
This pushed the average claims rate for the last four weeks up to 346,750 for the week that ended Saturday, from 334,250 the previous week.
The four-week average, which smooths out weekly volatility and is therefore considered a more reliable indicator of job trends, has been inching upward for the last month.
Economists say the jobless figures are skewed in part because the holidays late last year and early this year caused the closing of state offices where unemployed workers file for benefits. Bad weather can also make it more difficult for applicants to go to the offices.
"Between the middle of December and the end of January, these numbers are all over the place, and you can't really draw any conclusions from them," said Cynthia Latta of DRI/McGraw-Hill.
Still, the weekly claims data serve to underline how hard hit the jobs market has been by corporate restructurings, muting the pace of recovery, said Gary Ciminero, chief economist of Fleet Financial Group.
"It certainly is not going to be a normal-paced employment recovery," he said. "It hasn't been since March 1991 and it won't be now."

HEADLINE: Whitman Debating Sale Of the Sports Authority

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman opened the door today to selling off the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, owner of the Byrne Arena and Giants Stadium among other things, as a way of reducing the state's liability for debt and curbing the power of one of the state's most far-reaching independent authorities.
She added that her administration had already begun preliminary talks with potential buyers. 
 "There are a number of those, who are involved with professional sports, who have indicated an interest in being part of the privatization effort," she said. Nationally, very few major professional sports stadiums or arenas are in private hands, and there is wide variation in the financial health of those that are.
As Governor, Mrs. Whitman ultimately controls the board of the Sports Authority and can veto its decisions. Selling the stadium, race tracks and arena would presumably require legislative approval for the disposal of public assets. But officials of the authority said that its $870 million in bonded debt was tightly controlled by bondholder covenants and bond trustees, making it hard to pay the bonds off before maturity.
That figure includes debt for construction of the Atlantic City Convention Center, the rebuilding and expansion of Rutgers Stadium, and funds for the Meadowlands sports complex.
A buyer of the sports complex would have to retire about $450 million in bonded debt for its arena, stadium and race track.
 
Many Overlapping Debts
 Since the authority's debt was revised in 1992, each site in its holdings no longer has its own separate bonded debt, but is covered under multiple overlapping bond issues. It would be difficult to separate an arena here, a stadium there, for separate sale at different times.
John Samerjan, the Authority's chief spokesman, said the authority would not comment directly on the question of selling the sports complex, but he added that the authority members would naturally cooperate with the Governor in her inquiries.
Mrs. Whitman's thinking on the sale, she indicated, still focuses more on questions than on answers.
"We are interested in knowing: What are the possibilities of selling the arena and selling the stadium?" she said. "What is the status of the bonds, what needs to be done in order to accomplish that, to insure that the state sees the revenues to pay off the bonds associated with the original construction costs?"
 
Toronto Sets Example
 There is only one modern example of a municipality's selling a major professional sports venue: when Toronto last year sold the Skydome, home of baseball's Blue Jays and Canadian Football League's Argonauts, to a private investment group. The sale price was nominal -- "pennies on the dollar," said Robert Baade, a Lake Forest College economist, who said Toronto was motivated less by immediate need than by a desire to avoid future liabilities.
Governor Whitman has been a critic of the authority since it refinanced its debt in 1992, partly to raise money for a new Atlantic City Convention Center. It led to a $17 million annual subsidy from the state, which is likely to increase with work on the Convention Center this year.
During her campaign for governor, Mrs. Whitman spoke of curbing the power of the state's many operating authorities, and she has specifically discussed "privatizing" New Jersey's professional sports infrastructure. Her comments this afternoon came after she announced four new appointments to the authority's 13-member board, which owns and operates the Meadowlands Race Track and the Monmouth Park Race Track in Oceanport, as well as Giants Stadium and Byrne Arena.
 
Jets and Maybe Yankees
 The agency also built the State Aquarium in Camden, and is rebuilding Rutgers Stadium in Parsippany.
The authority successfully lured the New York Jets to Giants Stadium, and there were talks involving the office of the former Governor, Jim Florio, and George Steinbrenner about moving the New York Yankees to northern New Jersey. The agency lost a vote at referendum in 1987 that would have publicly financed a baseball stadium in the Meadowlands.
"Absolutely," the Governor replied when she was asked whether her instructions to the new sports authority members included a mandate to study the sale of authority assets.
The new Governor dismissed the suggestion that she was still angry about how Mr. Florio, in his last weeks in office, overrode her objections and signed a two-year contract extension for Robert E. Mulcahy, president of the authority. He will be paid $175,000 a year.
The authority was created in 1971 to build the Meadowlands Race Track; the stadium, completed in 1976, and the arena, built in 1981. Until the mid-1980's, revenues from the race track paid the development costs of both the stadium and the arena, but the rise of casino gambling in Atlantic City drew gambling dollars away from the horses.
 
Taxpayers Brought In
 When refinancing was explored, it was found that the authority no longer had the combination of assets and cash flow to support the new bonds, and the state was brought in.
Public authorities have many critics in New York and New Jersey; conservatives in particular call them tools by governors and legislatures to incur public debt without obtaining constitutionally required ballot approvals from the public.
Although it cannot refinance its debt by itself, the agency is still in the black, according to its financial statement for 1992, the latest available. It took in $197 million that year, with expenses of $160.7 million, before taxes and debt interest. It paid $24.5 million in debt interest, and $3.8 million in payments instead of taxes to the state and municipalities.
As a public agency, the authority may not make a profit, but must distribute any money left over from expenses to retire debt.

HEADLINE: At Center Of Storm With Cars In Tow

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Through a blur of 12-and 16-hour days this week, Dave Sandstrom has witnessed just about every variation of what arctic air and ice can do to the internal combustion engine and the human spirit.
He's seen people deliriously grateful to see him and his green-and-white tow-truck, and others so angry or cold that they'll yell even at their would-be savior. He's jump-started an array of batteries, fixed flats while the owner cowered indoors, opened and closed ice-fused door locks, and learned to diagnose a frozen fuel line with the first sputtering cough of the engine. 
 Mr. Sandstrom, a 24-year-old with a thin mustache, a shy smile, and two sweatshirts under his coat, is one of the small army of tow-truck drivers plying streets and highways as cold weather continues in the region and much of the nation. Like the demand for electricity and extra blankets, Mr. Sandstrom's overwork is yet another barometer of the cold snap's grip: cars that decline to go.
"It's the winter from hell," said Steve McNeish, the manager of automotive service at the American Automobile Association's Hartford affiliate.
 
A New Record of Misery
 At the Automobile Club of New York, the AAA affiliate that serves New York City and some of its suburbs, a 10-year-old one-day record of 9,000 calls was broken with 10,000 requests for help. A club serving central New Jersey recorded triple its normal volume.
Here in Hartford, where the AAA club dispatches 246 trucks in central Connecticut, an all-time record fell on Tuesday with 1,700 calls, then was shattered again on Wednesday, when about 2,000 motorists cried for help, half of them with dead batteries.
For Mr. Sandstrom, who moved back to his home state of Connecticut from Florida just six weeks ago, the pace has meant postponed meals, lost sleep, and -- far from the least of his troubles -- cold feet.
"Steel-toed boots," he said, sliding behind the wheel of tow-truck alpha-six and blasting the heater against the sub-zero chill just before dawn this morning. "Once the steel gets cold, they never warm up."
Like the cars themselves.
"Colder than Russia!" said an enthusiastic Ludmila Gooper, an immigrant from Ukraine who was one of Mr. Sandstrom's early-morning customers. Ms. Gooper got a flat tire on Wednesday night, she said, and damaged the wheel by driving on it because she couldn't bear the thought of getting out and finding another way home.
 
After Neglect, Cars Protest
 Christine Powers, another stranded rush-hour commuter, said she believed the cold weather was sending a message to her through her wounded Saab.
"It's telling me it wants to move to Florida," she said, looking at her silent and unstartable car, as Mr. Sandstrom attached the claw hooks to the rear wheels this morning in West Hartford. Ms. Powers said she relied on her friends for rides as her car has staggered through the last few weeks, starting, then not starting. "It's a mixture of a cold thing and car thing," she said.
Mr. Sandstrom's boss, Eddie Hohl, owner of Eddie's Evergreen Mobil, said he believes this cold snap has hit cars harder because owners aren't keeping up on maintenance the way they used to. With the recession still biting hard, people are putting off things like tuneups and winterizing, he said, and the result -- when the wind chill is at 30 below and the pressure is on -- is that more carburetors flood and more batteries give up the ghost.
 
Little Patience
 But don't tell that to Joe Parent. Mr. Parent, a 70-year-old West Hartford resident, bought a new battery just last week when the old one died of the cold. This morning, however, his sky-blue 1977 Ford Maverick was again going nowhere, and again a tow-truck was pulling to his door for a jump-start.
"You're much better than the last guy," he said to Mr. Sandstrom.
Some motorists, apparently, will have nothing to do with a car that can't take the cold. One woman, who declined to give her name, insisted that her car be towed away this morning even though it would start perfectly well and the only problem was a door that would not latch shut. She said she feared getting into an accident and flying out.
Mr. Sandstrom argued, briefly and tentatively, that her mechanic -- not at the Evergreen garage -- would probably move the car indoors and the mechanism would thaw by itself. But to no avail. Take it away, she said. Mr. Sandstrom obliged.
"The customer is always right," he said, climbing into the cab.
