HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Are Up for Treasury Issues

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Prices of Government securities rose yesterday on expectations that the Federal Reserve will not move to tighten credit any time soon.
In December, investors were concerned that the Fed would increase short-term interest rates. But since the release of December employment data on Jan. 7, the market has increasingly seen near-term Fed tightening of credit as more unlikely. "Maybe by April, the market will be back on alert," said Matthew F. Alexy, a Government trading specialist at CS First Boston, referring to the swings in investors' expectations. 
 The 30-year bond rose 12/32 yesterday, to 9926/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.26 percent, from 6.29 percent on Wednesday.
 
 
Interest in Shorter Maturities
 Buying was strong in shorter maturities yesterday, traders said. Rates on bills with shorter maturities declined modestly. The three-month bill fell 3 basis points, to 2.93 percent, and the six-month bill fell 2 basis points, to 3.08 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
The supply of Treasury securities and the market's ability to absorb it drew investors' attention yesterday before next week's Treasury sale of $25.2 billion in bills and $29 billion in two-year and five-year notes. The Government will also announce next week the size of its 52-week bill auction. On Feb. 2, it will disclose the size of its quarterly refunding, which some market participants believe will be about $40 billion.
In when-issued trading before next week's auctions, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 4.08 percent, down 6 basis points from the previous day, and the five-year notes were offered at a price to yield 5.03 percent, down 7 basis points.
The impact of a stronger-than-expected housing report was lessened by a surge in weekly jobless claims. The Commerce Department said housing starts rose 6.2 percent in December, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.54 million new home s. Initial claims for state unemployment benefits rose to 380,000 in the week that ended Saturday, the highest since the week of July 24 last year, when claims were 395,000.
Some dealers were suspicious of the surge in jobless claims, citing the measure's volatility as a reason for caution. "I don't believe anyone views today's jobless claims as indicative to what is going on out there," one trader said. Some economists said the jump in first-time claims was linked to seasonal quirks and did not reveal a sudden weakening in the labor market.
Mr. Alexy of CS First Boston said, "We had a couple of elements in balance yesterday -- a strong December housing figure on one hand and on the other some signs of a bit of cooling in labor activity, either the result of year-end factors or weather conditions."
"As a result, the housing numbers neutralized the impact of the jobless claims," he said.
 
Regional Manufacturing
 Another bit of economic data released yesterday, the Philadelphia Fed index, a measure of regional manufacturing activity, showed a retreat to 34.2 in January from 42.9 in December. A surge of business activity in December took the index to its highest level since 1983, analysts say. Although the January reading was lower, it was nonetheless among the highest readings in almost 10 years, indicating continued improvement in the manufacturing sector.
Mr. Alexy said the significance of the Philadelphia Fed report is its reading of first-quarter activity rather than fourth-quarter growth. "Consequently, the data on January economic activity tend to carry a higher weight with the market than fourth-quarter activity," he said.
Mr. Alexy said investors holding significant amounts of cash would move out of shorter-term bills to invest in higher yields in the intermediate maturities, given a three-month window of opportunity before the Fed takes action.
 The nation's severe weather conditions caused the Federal Reserve Board and other Government agencies in Washington to close yesterday. The release of regularly scheduled Fed figures on the monetary and reserve aggregates was also delayed.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Intentions of Bundesbank Depress Value of the Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The dollar weakened against European currencies yesterday on speculation that Germany's central bank will be slow to cut interest rates.
Gold prices declined sharply. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for February delivery fell $4.80 an ounce, to $387.90. Traders said gold was set for a correction after recent gains. 
 The dollar bounced around in jittery trading, rising and falling as the Bundesbank released new information on its short-term monetary policy for Germany.
The bank's announcement that it would hold official interest rates steady initially put pressure on the dollar. Higher German rates make assets denominated in marks more attractive than investments in dollars.
The dollar was hit with another blow when the Bundesbank said it would distribute money-market liquidity at a fixed rate of 6 percent over the next two weeks, the same rate that has held since November.
Many traders had hoped that the bank would permit variable-rate tenders, which may have allowed interest rates to fall.
Further confusing currency markets was a Bundesbank move to lower reserve requirements, which would normally increase liquidity and depress interest rates. But the bank later said it would manage rate changes with its weekly money tenders.
"The Bundesbank made a very smart move," said Joseph Cambria, foreign exchange manager at Banque Paribas. The bank's actions allow it to inject more money into the economy while keeping rates high, he said.
In late New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.7375 marks, from 1.7462 marks on Wednesday.
The dollar showed little movement against the Japanese yen, with most dealers sidelined before a meeting Sunday of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen with Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokowa and Finance Minister Hirohisa Fujii of Japan. In New York, the dollar slipped to 111.37 yen from 111.43 yen.
The British pound closed in New York at $1.4975, up from $1.4925 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates, compared with Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.4555 Swiss francs, down from 1.4610; 5.9110 French francs, down from 5.9340, 1.3109 Canadian dollars, down from 1.3113, and 1,696 Italian lire, down from 1,700.

HEADLINE: FIGURE SKATING;
Prosecutors Weigh Moves After Arrest Of Gillooly

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Jan. 20

 BODY:
District attorneys from Oregon and Michigan met here today to discuss where and how to proceed against four men charged in the assault on the figure skater Nancy Kerrigan as a Multnomah County grand jury met to hear evidence in the case.
The full extent of the grand jury's work was unclear. But among those who appeared were Al Harding, the father of Tonya Harding, Kerrigan's skating rival, and Diane Rawlinson, Harding's skating coach. 
 "We are continuing to look into this case," said Norman W. Frink, a deputy district attorney for the county.
The grand jury's work came on a day when prosecutors were considering how much more evidence they might be able to find. With Harding's former husband, Jeff Gillooly, among those charged, and with grounds to believe he has implicated her in the assault, the prosecutors could try to focus on him or use leverage to gain any direct evidence he might have against his former wife, who has not been charged. The couple was divorced last August but continued to live together until Harding declared on Tuesday that they were separating again.
 
No Federal Charges
 Both have denied involvement in the case, but Gillooly, who is 26 years old and unemployed, and three other men have each been charged with one count of criminal conspiracy to commit assault, a felony that under Oregon sentencing guidelines carries a maximum of three years in jail and a fine of $200,000. The United States Attorney in Portland, Jack C. Wong, said today that he did not expect any Federal charges against the men.
A conviction for anyone without a criminal record, like Gillooly, on the conspiracy charge in Oregon could often result in his serving the full term, minus up to 20 percent of the time for good behavior, said Andrejs I. Eglitis, the senior Deputy District Attorney for Oregon's Clackamas County. Eglitis, who is not involved in this case, said the fine is rarely applied.
Michael Schwartz, a criminal defense lawyer in Detroit, said that the stiffest penalty under Michigan law for such an assault for a first offense in which there was not permanent injury was most likely to be 18 to 24 months. He said offenders there often are given probation and no jail time.
Because of the attack, which happened on Jan. 6 in Detroit, Kerrigan was unable to perform in the national championships, an event Harding went on to win. Since then, all four of the men charged in the case have spoken to Federal investigators, who say that all but Gillooly have confessed.
One of the men, Shawn E. Eckardt, told authorities that Gillooly had told him Harding had twice called the skating rink on Cape Cod where Kerrigan trains to learn when she would be practicing. The authorities say their evidence shows that the times were sought so that another man charged, Shane M. Stant, could carry out the assault.
Investigators say they have telephone logs that show four calls were made to the rink from the Gillooly-Harding residence during the time in question.
When Stant could not find an opportunity, he traveled to Detroit and carried out the assault, the investigators say. They say he has admitted this in a confession.

 
 
Eckardt Implicates Harding

 
 According to Eckardt's confession, Gillooly implicated Harding. Harding's lawyer has already stated that Eckardt has a reputation for embellishing events. These two sides had even more to dispute after an interview with Eckardt appeared today in The Oregonian newspaper of Portland.
In recalling a conversation at the Clackamas Town Center Ice Rink, where Harding generally trains around midnight, Eckardt said in the interview that Gillooly told him Harding had given him permission to spend $6,500 to carry out the assault. Eckardt said Harding approached him and said she was "disappointed that these guys weren't able to do what they said they were going to do. And why hasn't it happened yet?"

 
 
Not in Statement of Evidence
 The official version of events as recounted by the authorities included no reference to such a conversation. Robert C. Weaver Jr., the lawyer representing Harding, said that he had been aware of everything Eckardt had said about his client to the authorities, including the conversation at the rink. However, he declined to characterize how the statements could affect her legal position.
Harding, 23, met with investigators on Tuesday for nearly 11 hours and emerged clinging to her denials. Weaver said she has resumed training and "is skating remarkably well."
It remained unclear whether prosecutors had any additional information about Harding. Two law-enforcement officials close to the case said they expected Gillooly's lawyer, Ronald H. Hoevet, would eventually discuss a plea bargain with the authorities. But Ellen Daniels, Hoevet's assistant, said that no conversations have been held with the Multnomah County District Attorney's office.
Weaver said the next step in the case would be the indictment of the four men, which would come next week if a grand jury is convinced enough evidence exists to proceed.
Also, prosecutors are deciding whether they have better cases against the men in Portland or Detroit.
Vote on Harding Called Off
The United States Figure Skating Association retreated Thursday from a previous statement by a top official that a vote would be taken next week by the association's 45-member international committee on whether Harding should remain on the Olympic team. Claire Ferguson, the association's president, who told of the balloting plan on Tuesday, said that no vote is scheduled at this point.
"Right now, we don't have anything to base a recall vote or a vote of confidence on," said James Disbrow, chairman of the skating association's international committee. "If something requiring us to take a vote breaks, we'll take a vote."

HEADLINE: HOCKEY;
Bourque, at 33, Is Still Mr. Defense

BYLINE: By JOE LAPOINTE

 BODY:
Ray Bourque will probably still be a Boston Bruin when the team leaves Boston Garden for its new arena in 1995. It only seems as if Bourque was playing when the old barn opened in 1928.
Now 33 years old and a 15-year veteran, Bourque is in Manhattan for the National Hockey League All-Star weekend. He will appear in Madison Square Garden tomorrow in his 13th midseason classic, where he is the career leader in assists with 10. 
 Today he is likely to excel once again in the puck-shooting segment of the skills competition.
"I've won it three of the last four years," said Bourque, a smile spreading across his craggy facial features under bushy eyebrows and a bristly haircut. "The pressure will be on me this year."
Over the weekend, some of Bourque's Eastern Conference teammates and Western Conference rivals probably will ask him for his autograph or for a souvenir stick.
"There's a lot of things that one exchanges," said Bourque, who might do some swapping himself. "The odd jersey. Some sticks. It's a time to get a lot of stuff autographed by a lot of the top players."
As the league takes its midwinter break, Bourque still remains one of its top stars and best ambassadors, one of the classiest members of the senior class. He leads all defensemen in points with 53 on 13 goals and 40 assists this season.
Off the ice, Bourque's resume begins with family values and ends with charity work. In a sense, Bourque's understated elegance is appropriate for this thus-far uneventful season, filled with too many games ending with score lines like Florida 3, Anaheim 2.
"Ray understands that he is a role model as a superstar and he takes pride in it," said Gord Roberts, another one of Boston's veteran defensemen. "He's the kind of a guy who leans out the bus window to sign that last autograph."
Mike Milbury, Boston's assistant general manager, said Bourque "knows right from wrong and how a player should conduct himself both on and off the ice. He has earned the respect of his teammates and of his colleagues around the league. He loves coming to the rink."
Bourque is from St. Laurent, a working-class suburb of Montreal. His mother died from cancer when he was 12 and his father struggled financially. "The family was poor as church mice," said Steve Freyer, Bourque's agent.
Lise Desmarais, Bourque's older sister, said she still lives in the old neighborhood and neighbors come to her and her husband "if they have a need to see Raymond" about their problems or requests. One such recent case was a young hockey player whose father died from cancer. His coach brought the boy to the Forum to meet Bourque.
"Ray told him 'I know how you feel,' " said James Desmarais, Bourque's brother-in-law. Lise Demarais said the Bourque family grew up in an apartment house on Crevier Street that had eight units and 54 children stacked from floor to ceiling in bunk beds.
 
A Messy Signing
 In St. Laurent, a slice of fried bologna served on Saturday night is called "Crevier Steak." It's meat for families having a good week financially.
"We weren't from a rich background," said Bourque's sister. "My mother lost a few babies and there were a few handicaps. And five of us are alive, healthy and strong."
Bourque signed a new contract last fall, but the signing was preceded by an unpleasant salary arbitration with the Bruins' general manager, Harry Sinden, the first such confrontation of Bourque's career. Bourque lost and was awarded $2.25 million, instead of the $4.25 million he requested.
"It was extremely painful and very difficult," said Freyer, Bourque's agent. "Harry Sinden was on a crusade to protect his salary structure and to make a statement to the league that someone had to draw the line in the sand. We kept our mouths shut and let Harry do his end-zone dance."
 
Might Be a Bargain
 When feelings calmed down and negotiations resumed, Sinden and Bourque settled on a five-year, $12.5 million deal that saved face for both sides. The length is flattering for an athlete older than most of his colleagues, and perhaps a wise investment for Sinden; Bourque might be a bargain in five seasons, if market prices keep increasing.
Perhaps this is why he works to keep what he has earned. Because of off-ice conditioning in the summer, Bourque remains in top shape, still playing about 30 minutes each game. He has won the Norris trophy as the league's best defenseman four times and is a top contender this season.
Roberts said Bourque has talked to him about the two Stanley Cup rings Roberts earned while playing in Pittsburgh. Bourque would like one, too, although it's not quite an obsession. Milbury, a former player and coach, has had similar conversations with Bourque.
"He knows it's a very elusive thing, and that a lot of it is fate and luck," Milbury said.
"I don't lose sleep over it," Bourque said.
"But, obviously, it's something I'd love to have," he added. "It's the one thing lacking in my career so far. I'm always optimistic that, every year we go into, I always hope and I always think that we are going to have a good shot to get there. I take care of myself. I do a lot of working out in the summer time and it pays off. I really love the game. I think that's the big thing. I really enjoy myself and I think it shows up in my play."
 
A Master at Work
 It certainly does, along with many other things. To focus on Bourque for an entire game is to witness and enjoy a blend of energy, savvy and skills of the highest order. Such a game was played Wednesday night in Montreal, a 3-3 tie. Only eight seconds after the opening faceoff, Bourque took the puck at his own blue line and suddenly fired it more than 100 feet at the Montreal net. Goalie Patrick Roy of Montreal had to react quickly to block the surprise shot.
On defense, Bourque frequently broke up Canadiens' passing combinations with interceptions and, with one economical motion, he would sweep the puck away with passes that started attacks in the other direction. Such moments drew murmurs of admiration from the hockey sophisticates in the Forum.
In Boston's attacking zone, Bourque sees the wide angles well, finding teammates like Joe Juneau with long passes and picking his spots to jump deep from the blue line toward the net. Against Montreal, he helped create Cam Neely's power-play goal with a pass to Juneau. When protecting his own goalie, Bourque has the knack of holding, hooking and shoving opposing forwards just long enough to nullify the danger but not long enough to get penalized.
Kirk Muller, one of Montreal's power forwards, was frequently frustrated by Bourque's tactics, but not bitter.
"He's very strong on his skates, you can't bump him off the puck, you've got to battle him all the time," Muller said. "He uses his strength and he's smart about it and he can hold you off without getting those penalties. He's having a great year. Sometimes he controls the game even now. Players admire his durability and his consistency."

HEADLINE: North Korea Reported to Balk at Inspection Terms

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 20

 BODY:
In a setback for Clinton Administration hopes that inspectors would soon be heading into North Korea's nuclear complex, the International Atomic Energy Agency said today that North Korea had rejected inspection procedures the agency says it must carry out to determine if nuclear weapons are being developed.
The inspections of seven sites were agreed upon in principle last month by the United States and North Korea, and several weeks ago the State Department said it expected a final agreement with the agency in just a few days. Instead, a standoff has developed over just how extensive an inspection North Korea will allow. 
 In an interview today, Michael McCurry, the State Department spokesman, said the United States fully supported the agency in its discussions with North Korea. "If the I.A.E.A. is unhappy, we are unhappy," he said.
He said that if North Korea did not agree to specific arrangements with the agency, then Washington would not agree to new high-level talks that Pyongyang wants to improve relations.
Mr. McCurry added that without an agreement, the Administration "will have to look for alternative means of resolving this dispute," specifically, asking the United Nations to impose economic sanctions.
More than a week ago the agency, an arm of the United Nations, submitted to North Korea a list of sites it would need to visit. Inspectors have been barred from some sites for a year; cameras installed to monitor activity have run out of film at many others.
North Korea has replied that "there were a significant number of measures on the list that will not be allowed," said David Kyd, the agency's spokesman in Vienna.
Mr. Kyd said Hans Blix, the director general of the agency, had made it clear to North Korea that "this is not a negotiation." He said the agency would not back down on any of the items on its inspection list.
"We told them that we will not send an inspection team unless there is full agreement," Mr. Kyd said. "We had thought there would be a crinkle or two, but this is substantial."
The United States has said that if North Korea permits the inspections to go forward and reopens its dialogue with South Korean officials, then Washington and Pyongyang could move to broader discussions about diplomatic ties and aid. But it has also said that any inspection plan would have to satisfy the atomic energy agency.
So far that has not happened.
One official said North Korea gave permission to visit all seven sites, but objected to many of the procedures the agency insisted on, especially with regard to a five-megawatt nuclear reactor and a small plant that converts fuel rods into plutonium.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Clinton Insists on Compliance
 WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (Reuters) -- President Clinton said tonight that it was clear North Korea was trying to develop a nuclear weapon and that he would keep up pressure to make North Korea honor a nuclear treaty.
Mr. Clinton, appearing on the CNN program "Larry King Live," said Washington would remain "very firm about not wanting Korea to join the family of nuclear states."
"We're working as hard as we can to be as firm as we can" to persuade North Korea to admit inspectors.

HEADLINE: Rebellion in Mexico Is Putting the Heat on Salinas

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Accustomed to battling inflation, not insurrection, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari and the inner circle of advisers who helped him rebuild the economy are struggling to extinguish the rebellion in Chiapas and avoid a political crisis that could imperil his party's hold on Mexico.
The fighting in southern Mexico may have stopped for now, but with 2,000 armed rebels still hidden in the rain forest, newspapers, business people, intellectuals and ordinary citizens are asking why the shooting started and how to keep it from happening again. 
 Did Mr. Salinas's almost single-minded focus on economic changes like privatizing state-owned businesses, holding down salaries to reduce inflation from more than 150 percent to single digits, and signing the North American Free Trade Agreement lead him to ignore -- or worse, cause -- social unrest of the type that exploded in Chiapas State as the year began?
Were the administration's technocrats, trained in United States universities and expert in macroeconomics, too aloof from ordinary people to hear their complaints?
 
'Things Have to Change'
 Did the governing party's unwillingness to run clean elections and share political power lead the indigenous people to take up arms in a desperate attempt to bring about change?
Uneasiness with the current system of Government existed before the uprising, but the violence seems to have intensified feelings. Sergio Aguayo, a member of the Mexican Academy of Human Rights, said the Chiapas uprising had left many Mexicans feeling a profound moral ambivalence.
"Nobody wants violence," Mr. Aguayo said, "but we all realize things have to change, and they have to change fast."
Television shots of dead rebels are a public relations nightmare for Mr. Salinas, who has spent much of the last five years building a new image of Mexico as a modern, free country. But more important is what image prevails on Aug. 21 when the governing party, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, tries to retain the presidency it has controlled since 1929.
Mr. Salinas himself is prohibited by the Constitution from running again, but the party's candidate -- selected by the President -- is so closely identified with him that political analysts here believe that damage to Mr. Salinas's image and popularity will carry over. Until now, the strongest asset of the candidate, Luis Donaldo Colosio, has been the continuity he represented.
 
Opposition Is Invigorated
 Mr. Colosio is now expected to put some distance between himself and Mr. Salinas while his campaign focuses on the well-being of all Mexicans. To succeed, he will have to convince voters that current injustices will end even if his party's long rule does not.
Challenging that premise will be an invigorated opposition, led by Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, who in 1988 came closer to defeating the party candidate than anyone else in 65 years.
Mr. Cardenas's stalled campaign now has a delicate opportunity. In a recent survey by a Mexico City public opinion company, 61 percent of respondents said the conflict in Chiapas could have been avoided, and almost 40 percent said they held the Government responsible for what happened.
Mr. Cardenas's advisers say that he has worked hard to prove that he was not connected with the uprising and did not favor it. He also wants to make clear that his leftist candidacy will not result in a radicalized, violent Mexico But his main campaign theme, that Mr. Salinas's economic revolution has benefited a few at the expense of the poor, will gain resonance because of the tragedy in Chiapas.
 
Fissures Within Party
 Chiapas seems to have caused a number of fissures within the Institutional Revolutionary Party that could deepen by next August.
The party's oldest and most entrenched factions, represented by the 93-year-old union leader Fidel Velazquez, have tried to blame Mr. Cardenas's Democratic Revolution Party for inciting the Chiapas uprising. Mr. Velazquez, who fought in Mexico's 1910-1917 revolution, has also become increasingly critical of Mr. Salinas's handling of the conflict. He is against granting an amnesty, as Mr. Salinas has proposed, and has said that instead of being invited to the negotiation table, the rebel army should be "exterminated."
Mr. Salinas's selection of Manuel Camacho Solis, the popular former Mayor of Mexico City, to head the peace negotiations also has complicated Mr. Colosio's life because it puts Mr. Camacho back into the political running after he was passed over for the party's presidential nomination in November.
Mr. Colosio formally kicked off his campaign last week, but the fanfare was greatly overshadowed by events in the south. The party had to work hard to emphasize the parts of Mr. Colosio's campaign speech in which he said that "the spilling of blood is not the way" to a better future.
 
A Daunting Challenge
 The political challenge facing Mr. Salinas is daunting. He has to end the rebellion, patch up relations with the rebels and the millions of poor Mexicans who morally support them, and devise a way to put Mexico's economic reforms back on track, all before any hint of prolonged or expanded violence can scare foreign investors or endanger the election.
He started out with an iron fist, unleashing the Mexican Army. But even with bombs and 15,000 troops the army could not quash the rebellion in the few days Mr. Salinas was willing to give, and the troops were badly embarrassed.
As the guerrillas, who call themselves the Zapatista National Liberation Army, headed into the lush hills where they would be more difficult to find, Mr. Salinas shifted to a political tack, declaring a unilateral truce and offering to negotiate peace.
In this crisis, Mr. Salinas has done what few Mexican Presidents have ever done, admit that he has made mistakes. Looking haggard and stressed, he went on television on Jan. 10 to announce a Cabinet shake-up and to concede that the Government "didn't work as it should have."
Specifically, he was referring to Patrocinio Gonzalez Garrido, the minister of the interior and former Governor of Chiapas State, the site of Mexico's first significant guerrilla movement in 20 years.
Mr. Salinas replaced Mr. Gonzalez the same day.
 
Social Reform Urged
 But a columnist, Adolfo Sanchez Rebolledo, and other critics have said that the righting of errors should not end with Mr. Gonzalez.
"Mexico can and should take the opportunity to accelerate the transition to democracy, opening a clear perspective to social reform," Mr. Sanchez Rebolledo wrote in La Jornada of Mexico City. "There's no excuse not to do it."
Mexican officials will go so far as to say that Chiapas may be a symptom of what's wrong with Mexico. But in Mexico City the graffiti of rebel sympathizers proclaims, "Chiapas is Mexico."
Like Peru, Argentina and other Latin American countries with newly opened economies but disaffected poor, Mexico is being forced by civil unrest to reconsider its path.
Salinas aides say that the Chiapas uprising was an isolated incident that in no way undoes the accomplishments of the last five years. That, critics counter, will be determined in August.

HEADLINE: U.S. Sees Double Blow to Russia Reform

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Clinton Administration officials voiced serious concern today about the announced resignation of Russia's Finance Minister, Boris G. Fyodorov, an advocate of rapid economic reform, fearing his departure could slow Moscow's move to a market economy.
American officials hesitated to express worry when another leading reformer, First Deputy Prime Minister Yegor T. Gaidar, resigned last Sunday. Trying to put the best face on that resignation, which came on the day President Clinton left Moscow after meeting President Boris N. Yeltsin, American officials said they were still confident that reforms would continue to move apace, in part because Mr. Fyodorov was still in place. 
 Today, however, with Mr. Fyodorov saying he would not stay in the Government, Administration officials could hide their disappointment no longer.
 
'We're Disappointed'
 Reacting to Mr. Fyodorov's announcement, a senior Administration official said: "We're disappointed. These two guys had credibility with the international community. We had worked extremely closedly with them."
Another senior official said: "This is a source of concern. The important thing is they make good on their commitments to continue with reform."
Lee Hamilton, the Indiana Democrat who is chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said: "I look upon this as a serious setback. We have put a lot of confidence in these two gentleman as reformers. We have looked to them as the intellectual leaders. It almost certainly means a slowing down of reform."
Mr. Hamilton said he feared that the resignations would give more power to Russia's central bank president, Viktor V. Gerashchenko, who has not been nearly as intent on combating inflation.
 
Assurances From Yeltsin
 During his visit to Moscow, Mr. Clinton accepted Mr. Yeltsin's assurances that there would be no slackening in the pace of reform, even though it was evident then that he would have trouble delivering on his pledge. Russia's parliamentary elections on Dec. 12 produced a marked shift in power, with those supporting Mr. Yeltsin doing much less well than expected.
The parties that now dominate the parliament -- ultranationalists and former Communists -- want to slow reform, and the people around Mr. Yeltsin conceded even as he met with Mr. Clinton that he had no choice but to give those parties a stronger voice in the government.
The Gaidar and Fyodorov resignations, coming so soon after Mr. Clinton's visit, were undeniably embarrassing to the Administration, and White House officials strained to put an optimistic gloss on the changes. They suggested that Mr. Yeltsin was forced by the elections to shake up his Cabinet and that he would make sure that true reform would emerge, although at a slower pace.
 
I.M.F. to Visit Russia
 Officials at the International Monetary Fund declined to comment on the changes in the Russian Cabinet, but they have often praised Mr. Gaidar and Mr. Fyodorov because they favored speedy reforms and tough measures to clamp down on inflation.
I.M.F. officials were to visit Moscow over the next few weeks to discuss Russia's economic program. Since Mr. Fyodorov was the I.M.F.'s main interlocutor, one official said those talks would probably be delayed.
According to Administration officials, Russia has received about $6 billion of the $24 billion in aid that was promised last July in Tokyo at the summit of the Group of Seven industrial nations. The I.M.F. has lent $1.5 billion, the World Bank about $340 million and the industrial nations have issued about $4 billion in bilateral export credits. About half of the $24 billion is expected to come from the I.M.F., but is contingent on Russia's progress on economic reforms.
 
They Favored Reforms
 Mr. Gaidar and Mr. Fyodorov were known for favoring such measures as removing price controls, rapid privatization of state-owned enterprises, slashing credits that keep inefficient enterprises afloat and severely restraining growth in the money supply to hold down inflation.
They often battled with more conservative members of the cabinet who believe it is important to provide enterprises and farms with billions of rubles in subsidized credits to keep them afloat and unemployment low.
About the only thing the Administration was happy about was that Anatoly B. Chubais, a Gaidar and Fyodorov ally, was remaining as Deputy Prime Minister in charge of privatization.

HEADLINE: German Politics: A Step Forward, a Step Back

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, Jan. 20

 BODY:
At the start of an election year that will decide the fate of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's 12-year-old conservative coalition Government, German politics seems to be staggering around in circles.
Rather than dealing quickly with the larger than expected economic and social problems that followed unification in 1990, German political parties have been debating them endlessly. 
 They agree that budget cuts are necessary to reduce the country's growing deficits, then vote spending increases that require more cuts. They agree that Germany should have a seat on the United Nations Security Council, then debate inconclusively about whether German troops can take part in peacekeeping operations outside their borders.
Recently, the subject has been whether to move the capital from Bonn to Berlin, something West Germans swore for 40 years that they would do when their country was reunited. After it finally was reunited in 1990, many politicians had second thoughts.
Though the German Parliament had voted then to make Berlin the capital again, opponents -- Rhinelanders accustomed to running the country, taxpayer groups who thought that cost of $11 billion was too much and the Bonn branch of Mr. Kohl's own party -- mounted a fierce rear-guard action.
Last month, Mr. Kohl's Government said it would move, definitely, between 1998 and 2000. Last week, leaders of all the major parties in Parliament met in Mr. Kohl's offices and decided yet again to move to Berlin, between 1998 and 2000. This time they really meant it -- maybe. Another vote by the whole Parliament is scheduled for next week.
The paralysis has not been total, but it has sometimes been close to it. While millions of asylum-seekers streamed into Germany after the end of the cold war, the parties debated endlessly about changing the country's Constitution to tighten eligibility for asylum, finally lurching to a decision last summer. Mr. Kohl's Government managed a decision last year to send 1,700 German peacekeeping troops to Somalia, but it will withdraw them when American forces leave in March.
There is constant talk that the problems of dealing with far-right violence against foreigners, converting eastern Germany to a free market economy during the worst recession since the end of World War II and other unexpected consequences of the post-cold-war period may be solvable only by a "grand coalition" government.
A grand coalition would unite Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats, Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel's Free Democrats and the opposition Social Democrats, and perhaps other groups as well. It would be necessary in any case if neither of the big parties won enough votes to form a coalition with the Free Democrats, who have played a balancing role since the 1960's.
"Nobody wants a grand coalition, but it could become unavoidable," Wolfgang Schauble, the parliamentary floor leader of the Christian Democrats, said on Wednesday, but he was confident that the next Chancellor would still be Helmut Kohl.
That will not happen if Rudolf Scharping, the 47-year-old Premier of the state of Rhineland-Palatinate, who became the Social Democrats' leader last summer, has his way. He hopes that a string of state elections beginning in Lower Saxony on March 12 will bring his party to a 40 percent share of the national vote for the first time since the 1970's and end the Kohl era.
Mr. Scharping has begun moving his party from the left-wing fringes, where it had been since its last Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, was replaced by Mr. Kohl in 1982. But so far, he has not been able to get it to agree to a larger peacekeeping role for Germany in the United Nations.
Public opinion polls show his party would win 37 to 39 percent of the national vote now, with 32 to 36 percent supporting Mr. Kohl's Christian Democrats -- down from 44.3 percent in the 1990 elections.
More alarming to many politicians in a country where well over 80 percent of the voters exercise the franchise is that public opinion surveys now show that more than a quarter of those polled are so disillusioned with politics they do not plan to vote at all this year.

HEADLINE: Almost a Nation: The Kurds in Iraq -- A special report.;
Kurds Rebuilding Shattered Land, Winning a Precarious Autonomy

BYLINE: By JOHN DARNTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ERBIL, Iraq

 BODY:
High in the treeless plateaus and snow-capped mountains of northern Iraq, Kurds are rebuilding their devastated towns and villages and drawing them together into a de facto state that stops just short of nationhood.
Almost three years after they rose up in the wake of the Persian Gulf war and were crushed by the forces of Saddam Hussein, close to four million Kurds live an autonomous -- but precarious -- existence. 
 They are dependent on $145 million in annual emergency aid through the United Nations. Their lives are shielded by United States, British and French planes that fly daily over a protected zone north of the 36th parallel to keep Iraqi troops at bay. And they are beset by internal strains and divisions, including a fundamentalist Islamic movement said to be sponsored by Iran.
 
Neighbors Feel Threatened
 Neighbors on all sides, from Syria to Turkey to Iran, feel threatened by their own Kurdish minorities, and so a strong independent Kurdish state whose borders are internationally recognized is a long way from reality.
Nonetheless, the nascent quasi-state of "Kurdistan," a dream of Kurdish people for 75 years, is inexorably taking shape.
The Iraqi Kurds have an elected parliament evenly divided between two rival parties. They have kept 24 hospitals and smaller clinics running, despite shortages of drugs and spare parts for machines. They have a court system, a police force and a 36,000-strong army formed from an uneasy merger of the two main groups of guerrilla fighters. They run nearly 1,500 primary and secondary schools and have added a second and a third university. Some instruction is in the once-forbidden Kurdish language.
"We are proud of our achievements so far, but we still live under mortal threat from the Iraqi troops," said Massoud Barzani, the 47-year-old tribal leader and head of the Kurdish Democratic Party.
Clad in the traditional garb of red-and-white checkered turban, brown jacket and baggy trousers fastened with a cummerbund, Mr. Barzani was sitting in his mountain retreat at Salahaddin. Behind him was a spectacular vista of brown plains, rounded foothills and a single road snaking for miles up to his headquarters.
He listed the Kurds' problems. There is the "double embargo" -- international sanctions imposed against Iraq and within that an internal embargo by Baghdad to undermine the Kurds' economy. There are "the terrorist campaign launched against us by Baghdad" and shelling from the Iraqi lines, where tens of thousands of troops are encamped within sight, and shelling from Iran, which is aimed at Iranian Kurds inside Iraq.
"Also," he said, "we suffer from regional tensions and a worsening economic situation and living standards, which threaten our stability."
But somehow the Kurds' quasi-state keeps on going and in some ways is getting stronger. It has already lasted longer than the only state the Kurds have ever had, the Mahabad Republic, which was founded by Mr. Barzani's father, Mustafa, in Iran after World War II and lasted 11 months.
"Two years ago there were regions with no sign of life," Mr. Barzani said. "Now, there are thriving villages."
 
The Quasi-State
Trying to Ease Fears of Neighbors
 Like everyone in an official position, Mr. Barzani goes to great lengths to insist that "Kurdistan" is not a secessionist state. The goal, at least for the moment, is to create a truly autonomous region within a federation, and to work for the overthrow of Mr. Hussein, Iraq's President, and the installation of a democracy in Baghdad. "We recognize the territorial integrity of Iraq," he said.
Accordingly, emblems of nationalist sentiment are played down. True, the huge portraits of Mr. Hussein have been taken down and replaced by murals of guerrilla martyrs. But Kurdish flags do not fly over buildings. There is no Kurdish currency or passport stamps. Many Iraqi laws are still in place. Even the insignia on some military uniforms are Iraqi.
There is a sense of play-acting to much of this. Everyone knows that the elaborate show of limited aspirations is intended to assuage the fears of surrounding countries, which have Kurdish populations of their own and fear insurrection.
The Kurds, an ancient, indigenous non-Arabic people, number about 20 million altogether and are clustered mainly in the border areas of northern Iraq, Syria, southeastern Turkey and western Iran. Their resistance to outside domination is legendary and summed up in the Kurdish saying, "Our only friends are the mountains."
For the Iraqi Kurds, Turkey is the lifeline. It has the only connection with the outside world, a road that winds through the plains and foothills of southeastern Turkey and crosses the Iraqi border at a narrow bridge at Habur. Virtually every other land route into the region is closed.
And Turkey, which has 10 million Kurds, is struggling to quash a Kurdish independence movement, the Kurdish Workers Party, which is waging a campaign of violence. Ankara is perhaps the most nervous capital of them of all.
To keep their own region alive, the Iraqi Kurds have been cooperating with Turkish forces to expel Turkish Kurds camps from the mountainous border area, a move that deeply disturbs some of them since it sets Kurd against Kurd.
"We have to be realistic," said Hoshyar Zebari, spokesman for Mr. Barzani's Kurdish Democratic Party. "We are totally dependent on one route from Turkey. We have to search out the middle ground. That's why we seek a balance between Kurdish rights and autonomy and the territorial integrity of Iraq."
But in discussions with many Kurds, that balance drops away. "What do I want for Kurdistan?" repeated Jwan Rshad, a 21-year-old student at the University of Salahaddin, clutching her books to her chest. "Simple," she said without a moment's hesitation. "Independence."
 
The People
Deprivation Is Common
 The Kurdish region in Iraq is a breathtaking juxtaposition of sharp mountains and rounded rolling hills, brown and green, thrust high into the sky. They are criss-crossed by electric pylons and huddled herds of long-haired goats tended by young boys and old men wrapped in padded jackets and turbans.
The towns and cities are bustling. Narrow streets are crowded with honking cars and carts pulled by donkeys, past open-fronted stores crammed with goods. The buildings are squat and angular, made of stone, stucco and cinder blocks. There is a confusion of minarets, telephone poles and wires overhead and puddles and piles of debris underfoot. There are boys selling cigarettes from trays around their necks, fruit stands piled high with oranges, and women draped in black carrying burdens. On the outskirts of towns stacks of canisters filled with gasoline are arranged in towering constructions.
The scars from Iraq's response to the 1991 uprising and from an earlier decade of suppression by Baghdad can be seen everywhere. More than 4,000 villages and hamlets have been destroyed.
Seven hundred thousand people in the western province of Dohuk have not had electricity for five months -- something to do with problems in a generating station, Baghdad has said. The explanation is not believed here.
In the east, the city of Sulaimaniya has swollen with refugees to 800,000, twice its pre-war size.
Most of the 1.5 million who fled to Turkey and Iran have returned, but many of their homes are gone. International relief agencies are able to supply supplemental food to 700,000 people deemed to be "at risk." While there is no overt starvation, officials say, signs of malnutrition are spreading.
It is not that the harvest was bad. Last year's crop of wheat and barley was plentiful, though harmed somewhat by disease and grasshoppers. The problem is that a program for the Kurdish government to buy up the harvest was not entirely successful, and much of it was smuggled out.
Inflation is running at 100 percent annually. Largely because of international sanctions on Iraq, supplies brought by truck through Turkey are one-fifth of what they were a year ago. With unemployment almost a meaningless statistic -- more than 85 percent of the people have no job -- tax revenues are a trickle.
"It's not that there isn't any food in the market, because there is," said Kosrat Rasoul, the Kurdish prime minister. "It's that people can't afford it. The average monthly wage is now about $6; you can't buy 20 kilos of flour for that."
The oil-rich region around Kirkuk and the city of Mosul are still in Iraqi hands and are being "Arabized," meaning that Kurdish families are being expelled. For fuel, Kurdistan depends on a thin flow of kerosene and gasoline from Baghdad, which turns it on and off like a spigot.
Among the worst areas are relocation villages outside Sulaimaniya like Said Sadiq, a squalid encampment of some 40,000 refugees. Two years ago they lived in tents, but now those have given way to more permanent structures, pathetic huts of rock walls without mortar and tin roofs held down by stones.
"It's not living like a human being; it's just surviving," said Rashid Jabar, an elderly man who was born in a small village in the Zagros Mountains. Helives with his wife and daughter in a dark, cramped hovel heated by a kerosene stove. They receive a daily ration of flour, sugar and chick peas, and fetch water from an open pipe that is often dry.
"I can barely do anything," he said. "I am weak. I have had four operations. I see no future. We are just waiting for the mercy of God."
 
The Atrocities
Poison Gas From Iraq
 The scars of Iraqi atrocities are not hard to find.
About 15 miles to the south of Erbil, is a village of crude cinderblock dwellings called Qoush Typa, once a center of anti-Iraq resistance. Today it is informally called "the village without men" -- a literal description since the day in July 1983 when Iraqi troops surrounded the town and took away all males above the age of 12. Some 8,000 disappeared and have not been seen since.
Now, when foreigners come to visit, women draped in layers of black come pleading for help in finding out what happened to their husbands and sons.
"Saddam has taken all of our men," moaned Qudrat Derwish, a woman in her 50's. "We are in need of help."
Perhaps the deepest scar is in the town of Halabja, close to the Iranian border, which had once been a hotbed of insurrection.
On March 16, 1988, Halabja became famous. It was there that the world first became aware that Iraqi forces were using chemical weapons against the Kurds.
"It was 20 minutes to 6 in the evening," recalled Shawkat Haji Mushir, who at the time was the commander of local guerrilla forces numbering about 1,200. "There had been an artillery attack at noon, so all the windows were smashed. Suddenly eight military planes came over, and they started to bombard the town. All over the place. Right near here where we are sitting.
"We noticed something peculiar. At first when the bombs exploded, they produced a low, muffling sound. And then a yellowish cloud. It didn't rise. It fell to the ground easily, covering everything.
"Most people died on the streets trying to get out of town. Some ran to the river and jumped in. Some tried to hide inside their houses, but they were trapped there, and they were killed inside. The windows, you see, were broken."
At least 4,000 people, and perhaps as many as 6,500, were killed, according to villagers and human rights groups.
In addition to mustard gas and phosgene, neurological gasses were used, scientists and experts who visited the village afterward have said. Survivors have described a hellish scene in which people acted strangely, often breaking out in peals of laughter, moments before they died.
"It was frightening, horrible," said Mohammed Faraj Ahmed, an art teacher, who said he had covered himself and his two daughters with wet towels and managed to escape. "Around the town it was mined, so we were afraid. We reached the border of Iran and got medical treatment. For three or four weeks, we couldn't see. We couldn't recognize each other by sight, only by voice."
"Thousands of children were among the dead," he said. "A colleague I know buried five of his own children."
Now, even Halabja is slowly coming back to life. Some of the buildings are ruins, but others have been reconstructed. Debris has been cleared away from the main street, riddled with muddy potholes. Shops are open. Perhaps 10,000 people live there, including 600 orphans.
 
The Politics
Tensions Rise In Rival Parties
 Erbil has the hustle of a provincial capital.
On a recent day the high court was in session. Inside a crowded blue courtroom ringed by neon lights, under a single overhead fan that did not work, a nervous 22-year-old man stood behind wooden bars, on trial for the murder of two of three members of a free-lance BBC team that disappeared in March 1991.
On the same day, parliament was in session across town. It meets in a wood-lined chamber, also lighted by neon, with six rows of curved seats for the delegates in tribal clothes and business suits.
This time, it convened to hear a speech by Lord Archer, the British novelist and a member of the House of Lords, who has taken a special interest in helping the Kurds. He was roundly applauded when he read a letter from Prime Minister John Major of Britain promising to force Iraq to comply with United Nations resolutions.
The parliament is split, with 50 seats for Mr. Barzani's Kurdish Democratic Party and 50 seats for the rival Patriotic Union of Kurdistan, headed by Jalal Talabani. Five seats were set aside for Assyrian Christians. Islamic fundamentalists, who won 4 percent of the vote in the May 1992 elections, were offered seats but declined.
Now, tensions are growing between the main parties, especially between the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan and the fundamentalists. In the last week in December fighting broke out between the groups, and more than 100 people were killed. The fundamentalist leader, Sheik Osman Abdul Aziz, has been given protective shelter by Mr. Barzani.
Members of the Patriotic Union warn about the dangers of the fundamentalist movement. They say fundamentalists have been taking over mosques and, bankrolled at $2 million a month by Iran, are becoming active in the slums of the collective villages.
"These groups are working with Iran and Afghanistan," said Hero Talabani, the wife of the Patriotic Union leader. "They want to take over Kurdistan and use it as a stepping stone to take over all of Iraq."
"They have a lot of money," she said. "They distribute food and the Koran and the chador for women. Look how many women are covering their heads. One young girl I know said she was told by an Islamic teacher: 'If you don't wear a scarf, when you die they will be able to drag you to hell by grabbing your hair.' "
Always there is the sense that Iraqi troops are close at hand and that the fate of the Kurds' could be hanging by a thread. If the allied forces end their protective air cover, the Iraqis will invade, Kurdish leaders predict, and then there will be a bloodbath and a mass exodus into Turkey and Iran.
At the town of Kalak just south of here, all that separates the Kurds from the Iraqis is a rickety bridge.
Capt. Mohammed Hussein stared across it recently and estimated that there were probably 4,000 Iraqi soldiers and 40 tanks and pieces of artillery dug in the hills there. If they come, he said, he would summon all the guerrillas in the region and defend the bridge the best he could.
As he talked, several cars traveled from the Iraqi side. The Kurds inside complained about their treatment at the Iraqi checkpoint. One said the Iraqi soldiers had taken away her medicine. Another said they had carried off all their apricots. A third said they had siphoned half a tank of gas and tossed it onto the ground.
Meanwhile, a bus crossed from the Kurdish side, filled with young men. They were soccer players from Erbil, off to play a match in Mosul, the captain said. He shrugged and laughed. "The Iraqi clubs won't come over to play on our side," he said, "so we have to play all the games over there."

HEADLINE: U.S. PLANS TALKS ON VIETNAM CLAIMS

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Continuing to tiptoe toward ending the trade embargo on Vietnam, the Clinton Administration announced plans today to open talks with Hanoi to settle millions of dollars in financial claims arising from the Communist defeat of the South Vietnamese Government in 1975.
The Administration is leaning toward lifting the embargo, and today's move appears part of orchestrated efforts to clear the way toward ending the embargo and minimizing the political backlash to such a move. 
 The American Legion, the Disabled American Veterans, and relatives of servicemen missing in action are eager to keep the embargo and have begun a campaign to warn the President that lifting it would be unpopular and politically dangerous.
 
Political Soundings
 Administration officials reached a consensus at an interagency meeting last month to end the embargo, but officials said that before making that politically sensitive move they first wanted to make political soundings.
State Department officials said Washington and Hanoi were still discussing dates for the talks, which some experts estimate involve more than $200 million in claims for confiscated property, including claims related to the seizure of the American Embassy.
Administration officials maintained that the claims dispute was not an obstacle to lifting the 19-year-old embargo, but resolving it could reduce overall tensions. Last July President Clinton said the only factor he would weigh in determining whether to end the embargo was if Hanoi was cooperating in providing "the fullest possible accounting" for the 2,239 Americans listed as missing in Indochina.
The announcement today follows several other recent moves that the Clinton Administration has made to minimize the political backlash to ending the embargo. Last week, it announced plans to start talks with Vietnam about improving its human rights performance, and it also began the biggest excavation efforts since the war ended to search for remains of Americans. In addition, the Administration has sent Adm. Charles R. Larson, commander of the American forces in the Pacific, to Hanoi to assess Vietnam's cooperation in helping Washington learn about the missing.
 
Bentsen Is Optimistic
 Despite the vigorous campaign by veterans' groups, the Administration still appears to be leaning toward lifting the embargo. Last Tuesday in Bangkok, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said he was optimistic that the embargo would be lifted soon.
"As has been the case with other countries on other issues, a stategy of engagement with Vietnam may be the most effective way to promote our goal of accounting for P.O.W.'s and M. I. A. 's from the war," he said.
To help sell an end to the embargo, the Administration is arguing that the best way to learn more about Americans missing in Indochina would be to increase ties with Hanoi and increase the American presence in that country. But the American Legion argues that the best way to force more cooperation from Hanoi is to maintain the leverage of economic sanctions. In the Administration's view, even if it removes the embargo, it can hold diplomatic relations as another carrot.
"I think the Vietnam embargo is going to be history," said Gary L. Ackerman, a Democrat from Queens who is chairman of the House Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific."That's pretty much a foregone conclusion. I just think it's a matter of the politically correct timing."
 
Clinton and the Draft
 Administration officials concede that the embargo decision is especially difficult for President Clinton because of his steps to avoid the military draft in the Vietnam War and because of allegations that Commerce Secretary Ron Brown received money to help push for closer ties with Vietnam.
Some officials fear that Republicans on Capitol Hill will accuse the President of selling out the M.I.A.'s if he lifts the embargo. But the Administration has taken comfort in the fact that five Republican senators have over the last month spoken out in favor of lifting the embargo.
Administration officials also acknowledge that it is taking American economic interests into account in deciding whether to end the embargo. They note that American businesses have been forced to wait on the sidelines while Vietnam links up with foreign businesses.
For instance, officials at the Boeing Company -- the company that Mr. Clinton has often trumpeted as the nation's leading exporter -- note that because of the embargo Boeing lost an order for four 737's that Hanoi had tentatively agreed to buy. Hanoi instead obtained the needed planes from Airbus, the European consortium.
 
Criticized by Veterans
 Veterans' groups criticize the Clinton Administration for even considering economic factors in the equation. In a letter to the President, the Disabled American Veterans said, "It would be deplorable and deceitful to give up our nation's quest for the fullest possible accounting of our missing servicemen just to pad the bottom lines of a few American corporations."
For the most part, businesses have refused to lobby vigorously on this issue because they do not want to give the impression that they are uncaring about the nation's M.I.A.'s.

HEADLINE: Phony Air Controller Pleads Guilty in Radio Hoax

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: ROANOKE, Va., Jan. 20

 BODY:
An unemployed janitor who was dubbed the "Roanoke Phantom" after he took to secured air waves posing as an air traffic controller pleaded guilty today to giving pilots false information.
For six weeks last fall the janitor, Rodney E. Bocook, 27, instructed both commercial and general aviation pilots to break off their landings at the last minute and change altitudes and direction as they approached the Roanoke Regional Airport here. 
 Investigators said Mr. Bocook had learned what frequencies to use by following instructions found in publicly available manuals, and had used a widely available radio transmitter. Some pilots followed his instructions, investigators said.
Federal aviation officials said there had been no accidents as a result of the misinformation and directions he had given pilots.
But John Butler, an agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, testified: "The confusion over the airwaves could ultimately have created a midair collision or other aircraft disaster. During one departing flight, his directions, had they been believed and followed, would have caused the pilot to fly into the mountains surrounding the airport."
 
Signals Traced to Old Car
 Mr. Bocook's airwave piracy finally ended when investigators for the Federal Aviation Administration tracked him down by using radio receivers and directional antenna equipment. Investigators said they had traced the signals to an old Buick, from which Mr. Bocook was transmitting his false instructions to pilots while cruising on the outskirts of the airport.
Mr. Bocook, who pleaded guilty to giving pilots false information and using profane language over the airwaves, could be sentenced to 22 years in prison and fined up to $250,000. He was expected to be sentenced within 45 days.
Tony Anderson, Mr. Bocook's lawyer, said he would seek a reduced sentence because of Mr. Bocook's cooperation with the authorities. He also said his client had a diminished capacity to understand the difference between right and wrong.
"He did not have a true appreciation for the seriousness of his conduct, both factually and mentally," Mr. Anderson said. "The motivation was not malicious."

HEADLINE: THE EARTHQUAKE;
Crowds Besiege U.S. Agency for Earthquake Aid

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 20

 BODY:
An angry, tearful crowd pushed against the doors of a Federal disaster-relief center today as it was opening at the epicenter of Monday's earthquake. Thousands more ringed the block on a day when an urgent need for food, water and shelter clashed with bureaucratic procedures.
The Federal Emergency Management had just opened the center in Northridge at 1 P.M. when 15 people without appointments shoved their way in for interviews. Outside, about 4,000 other applicants for assistance were growing increasingly restless. 
 "Get the kids out of there!" a police officer ordered as he called for backup to control the crowd. "They're going to suffocate."
 
Critical Housing Shortage
 Three days after the earthquake, the need for shelter and emergency relief has became the most urgent issue here, with tens of thousands of people camping in parks and playing fields and uncounted others staying with friends. Officials warned that the need for shelter could become critical this weekend, with forecasts of heavy rain and temperatures in the 40's. Some of the newly homeless said they were searching at least for sheets of plastic to protect themselves.
"The housing problem is bigger than any of us expected," said Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing, as he surveyed the scene at the Northridge emergency office. "Houses that we thought were marginally damaged are proving to have basic foundation damage. I expected a lot of people but not this many."
He told ABC News: "When you fly over it you really can't see the problem. But then you get down on the road or in front of the house, and you see that it's fallen off its foundation and it is completely unsafe and is going to have to be demolished."
 
'We Need Money and Food'
 At the relief center in Northridge, one of 11 to open today, people who had been waiting since dawn shouted and jabbed their fingers at the face of Lourdes Pagano, a FEMA volunteer, who arrived at midday and announced that only those few hundred who had made appointments over an emergency hotline could be helped today. The others were told to get an application and return another day. Officials warned that a completed application did not guarantee aid.
"Just give us somewhere to stay, just a roof," said Jaime Narvez, 16, who has camped out in a playing field with his family since the earthquake. "We need money and food. We need a place with running water."
At the relief centers, FEMA was taking applications for grants of up to $12,200 from low-income victims. Residents could also apply for Small Business Administration loans of up to $120,000 for rebuilding businesses or homes.
Up to 10,000 vouchers for housing aid will be provided to low-income applicants, with only a two- to three-day waiting period, Mr. Cisneros said. "Steps are being taken to make the process work," he said.
He said these steps include the immediate release, announced today, of $100 million for housing, the opening of a 12th relief center in the city and the dispatching of mobile relief vans to Red Cross shelters to supplement the centers.
"It's been a rough day, but we are here five days earlier than Loma Prieta," he said, referring to the 1989 earthquake in the San Francisco area in which 63 people died.
Before the housing vouchers are released, however, the agency will send its own inspector to verify the damage to the homes of applicants, said Kate Smith, a housing specialist at HUD.
 
Death Toll Reaches 51
 Throughout the San Fernando Valley, where the earthquake caused the most damage, residents hurried to remove furniture and belongings from their cracked and shaken homes as building inspectors moved from house to house condemning buildings and pasting up yellow signs reading, "Enter at your own risk."
As they began working their way through the city, building inspectors have so far determined that 3,116 buildings had suffered some damage and that 718 buildings had been destroyed.
"I am homeless," said Connie Ortega, an unemployed film costume designer who showed up at the FEMA center in Santa Monica. "I don't have any place to live. I don't have any money. I never thought it would happen to me."
The dimensions of Monday's destruction continued to grow in other ways today. The death toll rose to 51, matching the official coroner's count of fatalities in the 1992 riots. Hospital officials said 4,604 patients had been treated and released from emergency rooms since the Monday morning quake; 716 patients had been admitted to hospitals.
As aftershocks continued to shudder through the region, nearly 200 patients were evacuated from St. John's Hospital in Santa Monica because of structural damage, and a bridge was closed in Burbank, restricting traffic to major movie studios.
Inside the FEMA center at the Winnetka Community Recreation Center in Northridge, Monique Patton, one of the lucky applicants, moved from table to table with her 8-year-old daughter, Sharrika, repeating the story of her losses: a home, a lifetime of belongings, a quiet daily routine.
At her first stop, Mrs. Patton, a receptionist at a pharmacy, was denied a Small Business Administration loan. At her second, she was given an application for the state's Individual Family Grant Program to cover her personal losses.
When she was told, at her third stop, that she would need to wait two to three days for temporary housing, she began to cry. "My main concern is housing," she said. "We need it right away." She was told to return to a Red Cross shelter.
 
Exercise in Impatience
 At other disaster relief centers the scene was calmer but no less frustrating. At the Sylmar Recreation Center in an open field, officials said about 200 people would be processed today. Hundreds of others were waiting as long as three hours to get appointments for processing on other days.
Many applicants were uncertain whether their homes would need to be demolished or could be rebuilt, and many of them were applying for assistance on insurance deductibles.
In the face of the crush, officials extended the centers' hours from 7 P.M. to midnight and provided buses to transfer applicants from Northridge to less crowded centers. As darkness fell, some people left their daylong places in line to line up for buses that would take them to join new lines elsewhere.
Even the lucky people who were processed today received no tangible relief other than crisis counseling. Their biggest accomplishment was to receive applications and control numbers, which in coming days could produce new housing or loans.
"I don't know why I'm still standing here; maybe they'll change their minds," said Jackie Fard, whose children had been waiting for her in the car for three hours.
Homeless now, and with her custom jewlry business at a standstill, Mrs. Fard said she had nowhere else to hurry to today. "I'm afraid that if I leave they'll give out more applications, and if I stay, they won't," she said. Like thousands of other victims of the earthquake, she stayed.

HEADLINE: U.S. and China Widen Accords On Civil Rights

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said today that China and the United States had agreed to reopen Chinese prisons to American customs officers to insure that their factories are not making products for export to the United States.
The accord gives some fresh momentum to the Administration's drive to get China to loosen up on human rights so that President Clinton can justify to Congress a renewal of China's preferential trade status in June. Chinese movement on the prison labor issue is one of the key conditions President Clinton has laid down. 
 "I'm pleased to announce today that we have made some progress on the prison labor front," Mr. Bentsen said in a speech to 200 academics at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. "Our Governments have agreed on measures to insure more effective prevention of exports made with prison labor. China has also agreed to permit inspections of five prisons alleged to be producing goods for export."
An agreement with the Bush Administration in 1992 on this subject fell apart after only two inspections.
The understanding today, coupled with the agreement between Washington and Beijing earlier this week to curb Chinese textile exports to the United States and the recent release by China of a few prominent political prisoners, suggests that the Administration's new policy of aggressive engagement with Beijing may -- and American officials stress the word "may" -- be starting to pay off.
It is not known how China will respond to the other demands, which include an accounting for all its political prisoners, visits to political prisoners by the Red Cross, emigration rights for families of dissidents who have fled and protection of Tibet's cultural heritage.
Secretary Bentsen declined to characterize the importance of the recent Chinese moves, or to say whether he felt China and Washington were finally on their way to resolving enough of their differences for President Clinton to feel comfortable renewing Beijing's trade status, which allows China to export products to the United States at the lowest possible tariff rates.
"That is for the President to decide," Mr. Bentsen said, after a day that also included talks with President Jiang Zemin and the Central Bank Governor, Zhu Rongi.
 
Protection for Compact Disks
 Mr. Bentsen said Mr. Zhu promised him that Beijing would increase its efforts to enforce copyright laws, and in particular work to end the widespread practice here of pirating American compact disks. On Friday, the Secretary will preside over the reactivation of the China-United States Joint Economic Committee, a forum the countries once used to iron out economic differences but which has been shut since the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre.
Speaking of the prison labor issue, though, Mr. Bentsen said it was "one of the more significant" of the demands laid down by President Clinton in his executive order last June. That order stipulated the conditions the President wanted met before he would renew China's most-favored-nation status, as the trade designation is known.
Customs officials from the Treasury Department and diplomats at the Embassy have been negotiating the prison-labor issue for two months with a team from China's Justice Ministry, Foreign Ministry and Ministry of Foreign Trade and Economics.
 
Allowing for Inspections
 In 1992, the Bush Administration and China reached an understanding that allowed American inspectors to visit prisons suspected of producing goods for export to the United States. American law prohibits prison imports. Last spring, the Chinese did allow Customs officers to visit two prisons, after a great deal of haggling. After that experience, further access was denied.
In his executive order, Mr. Clinton stated that, among other issues, he would not renew China's trade status unless he determined "that China is complying with the 1992 bilateral agreement concerning prison labor."
Last fall, the two countries began talks to revive the memorandum. The Chinese, however, seem to have perfectly timed their concessions and the conclusion of these negotiations to coincide with Mr. Bentsen's visit.
 
Three Key Points
 The new understanding reached today calls for these terms:
*China is to give regular and timely reports when the United States asks for information about the possible use of prisoners to make products for export.
*Customs officials are to visit prisons more frequently, including five visits approved today. The United States Ambassador, J. Stapleton Roy, said one of those five sites, the Red Star tea farm, a suspected prison-labor project along the southern coast, was visited today by a Customs inspector.
*The United States is to give China regular and timely reports on any such prison visits so Beijing will know what violations, if any, are uncovered.
"We are pleased where we stand," added Ambassador Roy. "But the crux of the matter is whether we can continue this level of compliance up to the time when the President makes his decision in June."
Mr. Bentsen is to fly on a United States Air Force jet to Shanghai on Friday. According to American diplomats here, it marks the first time the Chinese have allowed a visitor other than a head of state to fly around China in his own aircraft. It is a small point, but indicative of the degree to which the Chinese seem to be going out of their way to make Mr. Bentsen's visit a success.

HEADLINE: Stillness Along the Potomac

 BODY:
Make no mistake, the Big Chill is serious business. As the Times headline said yesterday, this week's record-and-bone-breaking cold has disrupted "power, travel, and life in general." Trains have been canceled, stores closed, emergency blackouts ordered. The one redeeming feature in all this misery is that we may learn to survive with a smaller Federal Government.
Actually, we may even learn to live with fewer lawyers, or at least with lawyers working fewer hours. The noted firm of Arnold & Porter sent everyone home at 4 P.M. Wednesday, causing high anxiety. "It's a major economic decision for an organization that bills by the hour," the firm's managing partner told The Washington Post. 
 Meanwhile, the Office of Personnel Management in Washington -- responding to an emergency request by the Potomac Electric Power Company -- closed government offices for all but "essential personnel" at 3:01 P.M. Wednesday and kept them closed yesterday. It told "essential staff" to dress warmly inside the office and to use the stairs instead of the elevators.
Think of the identity crises this worthy directive must have caused. People of unquestioned essentiality -- the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, for example -- could obviously go to work confident that no one would question their intrinsic importance. In fact, the Chairman could probably have done anything he wanted.
But what of those wretched souls on the very cusp of indispensability? Does one stay home and concede one's inconsequence? Or does one dress warmly, hustle to the Interior Department and climb the stairs only to hear the boss say, "You've overreached, Rutherford; go back to bed"?
Yet think of the pluses. Think of all those faxes that never needed answering, of all those lobbyists with nobody to buttonhole, of all those bad decisions that never needed taking. And -- just possibly -- of all those empty offices that never needed filling. Hillary Rodham Clinton's staff is larger than F.D.R.'s during the Depression, and Vice President Gore's is larger than F.D.R.'s during World War II. Are all those people necessary? Nature, for one brief, frozen moment, has imposed an answer.
