HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Price Of Korea

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL

 BODY:
For Americans, the most dangerous foreign problem of the moment is neither Bosnia, the Mideast nor Russia but the one they are paying the least attention to. It is playing itself out in Washington, Vienna and a country only a handful of Americans have ever seen, or want to.
If any crisis boils over, the one guaranteed to involve American forces is North Korea's drive for nuclear weapons. The crossroads for both countries could be four or five weeks away. 
 U.S. Government experts believe North Korea already has a nuclear explosive device, or is a screwdriver away, so close that it has to be considered as nuclear-armed.
Americans remain casual because the Clinton Administration, which inherited the latest Korean problem from the Reagan and Bush Administrations, has not spoken lucidly and fully about it to the public.
Faced with the possibility of war with North Korea, the Administration has done a "lousy job" of explanation to the public -- the sum-up of one high official. After poking around, I think the reason is that Mr. Clinton is not keen on saying that if North Korea does not do as he asks his options run from risky to unacceptable.
For that, the American people can blame not Mr. Clinton but a quintessential act of appeasement and betrayal that took place a year before he was born.
In 1945, after World War II, America turned over half of Korea, a unified country brutally colonized by Japan, to Joseph Stalin.
Add the last seven years of American diddling about North Korean moves to nuclear power and here we are -- way up the creek of our mistakes, waiting for the President to produce a magic paddle.
Mr. Clinton is asking North Korea to allow unconfined scheduled and unscheduled inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency, based in Vienna.
But North Korea has delayed and defied for so long that there is no guarantee that the safeguards left behind to spot violations between on-site inspections are now credible -- that camera batteries functioned continuously, for instance.
U.S. officials say that every passing day puts another nick in the credibility. And this week North Korea stalled agency inspections again. In mid-February the agency will meet in Vienna to decide on that. If it says North Korean delays could have allowed it to push unseen toward nuclear power, what then? Mr. Clinton would have to answer in any full briefing of the public.
Economic sanctions? To make them work, China, North Korea's ally, would have to agree; it has not.
How about bombing out North Korea's nuclear plants as Israel did in Iraq in 1981? But the U.S. does not know where all North Korean facilities are. Also: the Iraqi plant was not in operation. North Korea's are hot. What would be the fallout?
And consider this, brought up by Paul Leventhal, president of the Nuclear Control Institute: North Korean retaliation to bombing could result in vastly more fallout in the South than in the North.
South Korea, he says, has nine nuclear electric-power plants within easy range of North Korean bombers. They total 7,600 megawatts. North Korea has 5 megawatts at its suspect operating reactor, and 30 megawatts in a plant under construction. North Korean retaliatory bombing could bring Chernobyls, multiplied.
With only hard military options, the Clinton people talk in cool, careful language. That can be upsetting to the appeasement-wary. But the Administration denies, flat out, that it has accepted one-shot inspection to appease the North.
The U.S. hopes that North Koreans will accept the carrots of recognition, economic ties and maybe "peaceful" nuclear technology. That last could be an invitation to more trouble.
Two things might slow Pyongyang's risk-prone Communist monarchy. One is a private written Presidential promise -- if they bring it all to war they will be hanged when captured, no Saddam deal.
And without sacrificing his human rights stand, Mr. Clinton could tell the Chinese straight: Join us in embargo of North Korea or count us gone, along with any Beijing-Washington economic and political future.
On the North-South dividing line stand some American soldiers whose parents were not even born when the betrayal of Korea took place. Appeasement has a long life. Another generation always gets stuck with looking for the magic paddle.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: The Fed's Not Broken, So Don't Fix It

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is ironic that the Federal Reserve System, having maintained a stable price level, should come under essentially political attacks. 
 Representative Henry Gonzalez wants the Fed to publish its Open Market Committee deliberations with speed, to allow every political jackdaw to peck at them. And Senator Paul Sarbanes urges that the presidents of the 12 regional banks should be appointed by the President of the United States. This would subject the system to the baleful political influence it was designed to avoid and has successfully flourished without.
The Administration, through Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, wants to strip the Fed of its ability to regulate the banks whose deposits the Fed is charged to control. This is like telling the police to regulate traffic without arresting offenders. Other highly placed members of the Administration (perhaps the President himself) are screaming for the Fed's head in anticipation of a rise in interest rates -- which anyone with a sense of history knows is bound to take place, and should, to defend the purchasing power of the dollar.
Meddling with the Fed's performance politically can only vitiate its effectiveness.
 
SIDNEY WERTIMER
Clinton, N.Y., Jan. 13, 1994
The writer retired as a professor of economics at Hamilton College.

HEADLINE: Serbia Sanctions Make West Feel Better

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Strangling Serbia's Democrats" (Op-Ed Jan. 11), Veran Matic argues that the West's economic sanctions against Serbia have undermined the educated elites in Belgrade and so strengthened, not weakened, Slobodan Milosevic's political base. He ignores three crucial facts. 
 (1) President Milosevic held onto power during the collapse of Communism by adopting the Serbian nationalist program as his own in 1989, two years before the war started. Mr. Milosevic's popularity among ordinary Serbs, and their willingness to embrace a "Greater Serbia" ideology, did not result from, but caused the Yugoslav collapse and the war.
(2) Yes, there are many liberal-minded and courageous opponents of Great Serbian nationalism in Belgrade (Vesna Pesic's Civic Alliance; the weekly magazine Vreme; Mr. Matic's own Radio B 92), but they are a tiny minority with no chance of gaining power, sanctions or no. The only popular opposition parties that might be better than Mr. Milosevic are infected with the nationalist virus and would not undo the ethnic cleansing of Bosnia, if they could.
(3) Sanctions have had little practical effect on Serbia's conduct of the war and mainly soothe the Western conscience for failing to aid Bosnia.
In the end, the reason for sanctions is moral, not practical. If we refuse to lift a finger to defend Bosnia, at least the sanctions slightly redress the moral balance.
The "despair and apathy" Mr. Matic describes as afflicting residents of Belgrade are hardly comparable to the sufferings the people of Sarajevo and the rest of Bosnia have endured for 21 months, but at least they are a tiny taste for the Serbian people of their own medicine. If they want to stop the sanctions, all they have to do is wake up from their evil dream of Greater Serbia.
 
JAMES BARHAM
Lancaster, Pa., Jan. 11, 1994
The writer, a translator, lived in Belgrade for four years.

HEADLINE: New York Vote in '90 Humiliated Governor, Not His Opponent

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I take exception to your description of my campaign against Gov. Mario M. Cuomo as resulting in a "humiliating loss" for the Republican Party in 1990 (front page, Jan. 8). More than 850,000 citizens and residents of New York State voted for me and against Mr. Cuomo in the 1990 campaign. 
 Not so bad when you realize that I was the 19th (or whatever) gubernatorial choice of the Republican Party, which never, ever, supported me in the campaign. I and my staff got those 850,000-plus votes pretty much by ourselves.
The Marist College poll predicted, as did many in the news media, that I would not receive even 10 percent of the votes cast. I received 22 percent. The same poll predicted that Herbert London, the Conservative Party candidate, would get even fewer votes than I did. He got 21 percent. Incidentally, no matter how it is put, I got enough votes to keep the second line for the Republican Party.
Mario Cuomo was depicted as the 800-pound gorilla of politics, and the figure that was tossed around was that he could get 65 percent of the votes cast. He was the one humiliated because he got only 53 percent, with all the money, the state organizations behind him and the unions.
Mr. Cuomo just gave a State of the State Message that went down the same economic and financial lines I did, only I was four years earlier.
I warned that the state would suffer enormous job losses, and I have, unfortunately, been proved right. I warned that crime was getting out of hand, and that the criminals were taking control of the cities and the neighborhoods.
I called for perpetual imprisonment of constant offenders of capital crimes, and the Governor now follows suit. I talked about the need to cut taxes and how the city and state hotel taxes were detrimental to tourism, and now the Governor wants to reduce those taxes. I called for increases in the police forces, and now the Governor is advocating the same thing.
 
PIERRE A. RINFRET
Nantucket, Mass., Jan. 10, 1994

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By NADINE BROZAN

 BODY:
RON D. DANIELS, the former executive director of the National Rainbow Coalition and deputy manager of the Rev. Jesse Jackson's 1988 Presidential campaign, has been named executive director of the Center for Constitutional Rights. He succeeds Miriam Thompson, who resigned to work as consultant on social justice issues.
The center, which litigates cases on issues like human rights, racial inequality and governmental misconduct, has offices in New York and Greenville, Miss. It was established in 1966 by lawyers who had worked in the civil rights movement in the South. 
 Mr. Daniels, 51, the author of a syndicated column that appears in more than 100 newspapers, is a visiting associate professor of black studies at the College of Wooster, in Wooster, Ohio. He will commute between the school and the organization's New York office until May.
"It has an extraordinary record in a range of fields, from racial justice and economic rights to international human rights," Mr. Daniels said yesterday. "As the first African-American director, I want to expand our relations with constituencies in the communities of color, and think we must increase our work on women's rights, on the environmental justice movement and in economic rights, with an emphasis on full employment." NADINE BROZAN

HEADLINE: Dow Soars To a Close Above 3,900

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average passed another milestone yesterday by closing above the 3,900-point level for the first time. The breakthrough came just two weeks after it punched through 3,800.
Stocks have been buoyed all year by signals of steady economic growth, low interest rates, improving corporate profits and the belief that inflation is no immediate threat. Investors hungry for better returns are also pushing prices higher. 
 Joseph V. Battapaglia, managing director of Sterling Advisers, a division of Gruntal & Company, said he thought the market could go significantly higher. "We're in an era of low inflation, relatively stable interest rates and expanding global open economics," he said. "In that situation, America's large industrial base is well positioned to enjoy a new bout of expansion."
 
Dow Up 47.28 on Week
 Dennis E. Jarrett, chief market analyst for Kidder, Peabody & Company, said he believed the market was headed toward 4,000 points and perhaps past that.
Yesterday, the Dow industrials, the most widely followed stock market indicator, rose 22.52 points on the day and was up 47.28 points for the week to finish at 3,914.48.
Unlike on Thursday, when nearly all the other market barometers set closing highs, only the Nasdaq composite index set a record, finishing at 794.28, up 1.25 points. But the other indexes are still near record highs.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange totaled 346.2 million shares, up from 310.5 million traded on Thursday. While volume was heavy, the number of advancing and declining stocks showed a split market, as losing issues outpaced winners by 1,086 to 980.
The gains made by the Dow and in other quarters of the market came on the back of strong earnings reports from well-known companies like Caterpillar and improved outlooks for companies like Apple Computer.
Investor interest in cyclical stocks, which tend to rise quickly when economic growth picks up, also helped bolster blue-chip stocks.
But a softer bond market concerned with the pace of economic growth in the first quarter, and when and how much the Federal Reserve might push short-term interest rates higher, limited yesterday's stock market gains, analysts said. As rates rise, bonds can become a more attractive alternative to stocks.
Mr. Battapaglia said other factors fueling interest in stocks included the waning of inflation and renewed competitiveness in American industry.
"You're going to see ongoing strength in the capital-goods sectors, that include industrial companies such as Caterpillar, Detroit Diesel and General Motors," he said. "The technology sector, now intertwined with the capital-goods sector, has also led the stock market's expansion, with the best examples being Motorola, Texas Instruments, Intel, and even I.B.M., which just now is becoming competitive."
 
Railroads Seen as Strong
 Strength is also likely to be found in transportation stocks, particularly railroads, Mr. Battapaglia said. "They not only benefit from the natural recovery of the business cycle; they have gone through restructuring efforts way earlier than the basic industrial," he said.
Strong sectors over the last six to nine months include consumer cyclicals, which are best represented by automobiles, technology and the recent rejuvenation of basic industries like paper and forest products.
"That tells you the ones to avoid: the consumer staples; the financial sector, which has faded, and energy, which has not been beneficial in anybody's portfolio for the last year or two," Mr. Battapaglia said.
Among individual issues, Caterpillar, the Dow's mainstay yesterday, surged 4 5/8, to 98 5/8, after the company posted better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings of $1.46 a share.
Apple Computer rose 3 1/2, or 11.7 percent, to 33 3/8. Late Thursday, the company reported that its first-quarter net income fell 75 percent, but some analysts remained bullish on the longer-term outlook. Smith Barney Shearson raised its recommendation as did Merrill Lynch and Cowen & Company.
 
Despite Higher Earnings, a Drop

 
 Pairgain Technologies dropped by 2 to finish at 11 1/2, even though its third-quarter earnings rose to 17 cents a share, compared with 10 cents a share a year earlier. The company said its 1994 revenues would not match those of 1993, and Hambrecht & Quist downgraded the stock.
Shares of Mr. Coffee, the producer of automatic drip coffee makers, rose as much as 22 percent yesterday in Nasdaq trading to close at 14, up 2 1/4, a day after it said it had received an offer to enter into merger talks with a potential buyer it did not name. Sunbeam-Oster has been mentioned as a likely buyer.
Eldec surged as much as 32 percent in Nasdaq trading on news that several companies had expressed an interest in acquiring the aircraft systems manufacturer. The stock closed up 1 1/2, or 19.4 percent, to 9 1/4.
Shares of Computer Associates dropped by 3, to 38, extending their decline for a second day on heavy volume, after the company posted slower-than-expected revenue growth for its third fiscal quarter.
Silicon Graphics shares rose 1 3/4, to 24 7/8, on the New York Stock Exchange after the company reported strong fiscal second-quarter earnings late yesterday.
In Tokyo, Japanese stocks closed slightly higher yesterday. The Nikkei index of 225 issues ended at 19,307.43, up 123.51 points, or 0.64 percent.

HEADLINE: Japan's Trade Surplus Rises

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Japan's trade surplus, a chronic sore spot in its economic relationship with the rest of the world, soared to a record $120.4 billion last year, the Government reported today.
The 12.9 percent increase over the 1992 level came despite the sharp rise in the Japanese yen's value, which tends to weaken sales of Japanese exports and increase sales of more affordable foreign goods in Japan. 
 With the United States, Japan's trade surplus registered a third straight rise in 1993, gaining 15.2 percent, to $50.19 billion from $43.56 billion, the figures released by the Japanese Finance Ministry show.
The surplus with the European Union fell for the first time in three years, to $26.32 billion, down 15.6 percent. The trade surplus with Asian countries exceeded that with the United States for the first time at $53.59 billion, up 28.8 percent.
Japan calculates trade figures on a customs-clearance basis, in which freight and insurance costs are included in imports but not in exports.
Its snowballing trade surplus has been a major source of friction with trade partners, including the United States and European and Asian nations. They contend that entrenched protectionist Japanese policies hurt their economies by restricting access to Japan's domestic markets.

HEADLINE: U.S. Is Setting Up Tent Cities As Nerves Fray After Quake

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The National Guard began erecting tent cities for earthquake victims today as jittery public officials promised other relief efforts for angry residents waiting in long lines to apply for aid.
The tumultuous opening of the Federal relief centers on Thursday prompted officials to dispatch National Guardsmen in riot gear today to patrol the lines that snaked through parks, fields and streets outside the centers. 
 At a center in Northridge, Dong Kim waited today to apply for aid to cope with the loss of his house and damage to his dry-cleaning business in the San Fernando Valley from the earthquake on Monday.
"They don't give us any suggestions and they don't give us any attention," he said. "They only give applications."
James Lee Witt, the director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, conceded that officials were surprised by the scope of the disaster.
"We probably underestimated the amount of people seeking assistance," he said this afternoon. "We were trying to hurry and help the victims and put in a much quicker system."
The National Guard erected the first tents this afternoon in a park in the Canoga Park section in the San Fernando Valley, about five miles from the earthquake's epicenter in Northridge. The tents, which are like those used in Florida after Hurricane Andrew in 1992, can hold as many as 1,500 people.
Officials said the death toll from the earthquake was now 55. Maj. Gen. Bill Stewart of the California National Guard estimated that 8,000 people were staying in shelters and 6,000 others in parking lots, parks or other public places.
He said the guard would erect tent cities at six places around the city, with space for at least 6,000 people. The tents will be equipped with generators and lights, General Stewart said, and various agencies will deliver food. He said the Guard's goal was to have a place inside for everyone before rains forecast for Saturday night.
Despite the urging of disaster officials, thousands of people have refused to move to Red Cross shelters, preferring to stay near their damaged homes.
Many residents of Hollywood, where old brick buildings were severely damaged, have refused to leave the area. "They don't want to leave their belongings, so they're living on the streets," said Jackie Goldberg, who represents the Hollywood area on the Los Angeles City Council. "People are very concerned about being separated from their families and their belongings."
Henry G. Cisneros, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, who is in Los Angeles to help direct relief efforts, talked to reporters at a briefing in Encino today. "It's very important that people go to the shelters where there's food, medical aid, security, warmth and dryness," he said. "You hear children with wracking coughs."
Mr. Cisneros also said the Government would suspend normal procedures and immediately issue rent vouchers for temporary housing. The agency had planned to issue vouchers only after inspectors verified that applicants' homes were uninhabitable.
"All of us are in this for the long run, for as long as it takes," Mr. Cisneros said. "No one is going anywhere."
Nineteen additional relief application centers will be opened this weekend, bringing the total to 30, he said, and Federal employees will be flown in to help reduce long lines.
June Addams, a secretary and mother of three who was in line at a center in Van Nuys, said she viewed the shelters as a last resort. "They're overcrowded, noisy and it's hard to sleep," she said. "You have to stand in line for everything, food, to go to the bathroom."
 
Fear of Shelters
 Some people in line at relief application centers said they feared that the Red Cross shelters, set up in armories and other buildings, would be unsafe if another strong earthquake or aftershock hit. A series of aftershocks hit the area again today, four of them registering 4.2 or higher on the Richter scale of ground motion.
Applicants gasped and laughed nervously as the ground rocked under their feet during an aftershock this afternoon as they stood outside the relief center in Northridge. Some who had been vigilantly guarding their places in line by the building bolted toward the open field when the ground began to tremble. An emergency official who was about to brief reporters sprinted away from the building.
City inspectors, who are trying to determine whether tens of thousands of buildings are safe to inhabit, have looked at 2,800 buildings, identifying nearly 2,400 as damaged to some degree and another 440 as unsafe. They estimated that the damage to buildings alone is at least $376.8 million.
It will be days or weeks before many homeowners and apartment dwellers learn the extent of the damage to their buildings.
The aftershocks today damaged two Los Angeles police stations, the Wilshire Division and the Pacific Division, both on the west side of the city. Both stations were still being used.
Although the subway in downtown Los Angeles sustained no visible damage from Monday's earthquake, officials said the line would be shut down over the weekend to allow technicians to evaluate the structural soundness of the 1.8-mile stretch of twin tunnels where the trains run.
Education Secretary Richard W. Riley will travel to Los Angeles this weekend to join Mr. Cisneros, and other Administration officials who have been here since Monday.
 
Schools Are Closed
 Classes at Los Angeles public schools were canceled all week, and at least 35 of the 650 schools in the nation's second-largest school system may be too unsafe to use when classes resume on Tuesday, officials said.
For those who make it to the front of the lines at application centers or who reach on the Federal Emergency Management Agency's "800" number, a variety of assistance is available. In addition to temporary rent assistance, which can last as long as 18 months, some people may be eligible for low-interest loans of up to $100,000 to cover repairs to their homes and $20,000 for loss of personal property. Loans to damaged businesses could be as much as $1.5 million.
Some families may qualify for cash grants of up to $12,200 to cover disaster-related expenses under a California program. Assistance with Social Security, tax preparation, crisis counseling and earthquake-related unemployment benefits are also available.
 
Dissatisfaction with Politicians
 As victims struggled through a fifth day of frustration, some began to look for someone to blame. Criticism was scattered and unfocused, but it was clear that politicians on all levels have much to fear if the hardships continue.
"I'm a little tired and I'm a little angry," said Eddie Robles, a 67-year-old retired postal worker who had been standing in line for hours. "There's a lot of promises and a lot of red tape. It's just the system." He blamed Gov. Pete Wilson, who, he said, "made a lot of promises he's not keeping."
Marie McCullough, an inspector at a lock factory, focused her frustration on President Clinton. "It sounded real good yesterday: we'll have you in and out, no waiting," she said. "I'm homeless and living in a tent and I'm mad."
After spending four nights in their car or in lean-tos, Alfredo Deleon and his family prepared to move into the National Guard's large canvas tents.
"The babies are getting sick; my daughter has a cough," Mr. Deleon said. "Nighttime is really cold and we all squeeze together."
Monday's earthquake destroyed Mr. Deleon's home in the valley and the pizza restaurant where he worked. His children's school is damaged and closed. When he and his wife, Graciella, and their two small daughters crawl into the musty tents with two dozen other people, they will carry with them almost everything they have left.
Like many of the thousands camped in parks, he is wary of shelter under a roof. "What will happen when there is another earthquake?" he said.

International 2-5
 
JAPAN LAWMAKERS REJECT REFORM
The upper house of Japan's Parliament rejected a political reform package, a stunning defeat for the Prime Minister, who had promised to end corruption. The vote left the Government in chaos. 1
THE FALLOUT ON TOKYO'S ECONOMY

HEADLINE: JAPANESE PREMIER LOSES SHOWDOWN ON VOTING REFORM

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
In a stunning defeat for Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa, the upper house of Parliament today voted down a political reform package that was at the center of his bid to end corruption in Japan's political system.
The surprisingly large margin by which Mr. Hosokawa lost, 130 to 118, resulted largely from the defection of some Socialists in his governing coalition who feared that the overhaul of the electoral system would eliminate many of their party's seats. 
 Tonight leaders in all parties said the six-month-old Government was in chaos, and some speculated that it could collapse within weeks without accomplishing the one goal it was elected to achieve.
 
'On the Edge of the Cliff'
 "We are standing on the edge of the cliff," Tsutomu Hata, the Foreign Minister and Deputy Prime Minister, said on Japanese television. He said he could not "deny the possibility of a dissolution" of Parliament, leading to another round of elections in which Mr. Hosokawa's coalition would battle for a stronger mandate.
The Prime Minister vowed to try to revive some form of the legislation before Parliament goes out of session in a week, but his position has been greatly weakened.
Apart from political reform, the defeat threatens to derail, at least temporarily, progress toward Mr. Hosokawa's other goals: deregulating the country, weakening the iron grip of the bureaucracy and beginning an era of political and economic openness that would benefit the Japanese as well as their trading partners.
 
No Consensus on Economy
 With weeks or months of turmoil ahead, the eight-party coalition Government seems unlikely to agree on how to jump-start an economy mired in recession or on how to conclude a critical trade agreement with the United States.
If Mr. Hosokawa remains in office and meets with President Clinton in three weeks as planned, he seems certain to plead for more time on the trade accord. [News analysis, page 5.]
One bill in the political reform package rejected today would have banned corporate and individual contributions to individual politicians, a system that bred the bribery and influence-peddling scandals that brought down Japan's long-governing Liberal Democratic Party in July. It would also have instituted public financing.
Another would have redrawn every electoral district and changed the system so that just one representative rather than five or six would serve each district.
Though the Socialist Party leadership endorsed the four bills that made up the political reform program, some legislators saw it as their own political death warrant. A number feared that if Japan's cautious voters were choosing only one candidate per district, they would select a conservative.
In the end, 17 of the 73 Socialists in the upper house defected and voted no, and 3 did not show up. Only 5 Liberal Democrats joined Mr. Hosokawa's forces and voted yes.
 
Three Options, None Attractive
 While confusion reigned tonight over how Mr. Hosokawa would extract himself from his problems, he seems to face three main options, none of them very attractive.
The first is to take the bills back to the lower house, where the governing coalition is much stronger, and seek to override the upper house vote. That requires a two-thirds majority, though, and he stands almost no chance of winning. Even if the bills were approved, the coalition would still be in tatters, and a new one might have to be formed.
The second option is to form a committee of both houses that would race to come up with a compromise piece of political reform legislation before Jan. 29, when the parliamentary session ends. But any such plan would be greatly diluted and then would have to pass both houses by majority vote. Mr. Hosokawa might even be required to adopt wholesale a weak proposal made last year by the Liberal Democrats, which would in turn probably prompt more Socialists to bolt.
"There is a possibility that this strategy could succeed," said Minoru Mo rita, a prominent political commentator. "But it is not a high probability." Most Liberal Democrats privately advocate maintaining the status quo in which they thrived for decades. The Liberal Democrats have been looking for a way to kill the political reform effort without appearing to oppose it; now they have their chance.
The third option is for Mr. Hosokawa to resign or dissolve Parliament and call new elections in the hope of ridding the coalition of the Socialists and replacing them with candidates advocating broad changes in the electoral and financing system.
But Mr. Hosokawa made clear today that he desperately wanted to avoid a national vote. With the Japanese economy stuck in one of its worst downturns since the end of World War II, partners in the Government coalition fear that the public would see an election as an irresponsible move that would delay economic stimulus packages and tax cuts for months.
Asked at a news conference tonight about dissolving Parliament, Mr. Hosokawa said, "I am not considering such a course."
"We have to do something to allay the public's fears about the economy," he added.
Mr. Hosokawa's only real chance for survival is to prompt another rebellion within the opposition Liberal Democratic Party, which like his coalition has been slowly unraveling.
His Government was formed last year when dozens of Liberal Democrats left the party because it stalled on political reform. Since then a half-dozen more have left. But to survive, the Prime Minister would need many more, enough to allow him to oust many Socialists without losing his coalition's bare majority in Parliament.
The Liberal Democrats, who have steadily avoided addressing the issues that caused their party to spin apart, have vowed to try to return to power by forming a coalition of their own.
 
Liberal Democrats Are Split
 With the winds blowing so much in favor of overhauling Japan's system, the Liberal Democrats feel they have no choice but to publicly back reform, though the party is deeply split about what kind to favor. Many, for example, were alarmed by Mr. Hosokawa's plan to make it illegal for companies or individuals to donate money directly to politicians, because they cannot imagine life without that financing.
During the vote in the upper house today, the Liberal Democrats broke out in cheers as the 17 defecting Socialists marched up to the podium that dominates the chamber and cast green markers than indicated "no."
The drama of the vote and the confusion it touched off amounted to a remarkable spectacle for most Japanese, who for decades have been accustomed to one of the world's most stable governments and for whom the outcome of parliamentary votes has almost never been in doubt. It was a measure of the unpredictability that has suddenly gripped Japan that every major newspaper in the country failed to forecast the outcome of today's vote.
Since 1989 four Japanese Prime Ministers have lost their jobs, two because they were caught in scandals and two because of their failure to pass political reform legislation. Ultimately that failure touched off Japan's miniature political revolution last summer.
 
Done In by His Allies
 In the end, Mr. Hosokawa was sabotaged not by the Liberal Democrats but by the Socialists, his political allies.
For months strains have been building between the Socialists and the rest of the largely conservative coalition over issues ranging from Mr. Hosokawa's move to open Japan's rice market to plans to revive the economy. But the differences were papered over. The Socialists swallowed hard and voted with the coalition, knowing it was the only way to keep the Liberal Democrats out of power.
Some Socialists who broke ranks today argued that the proposed reforms in the electoral system would ultimately squeeze out smaller political organizations and eliminate dissenting views from national politics altogether.
"Since the characteristic of this country is conformity rather than diversity, Japan could end up being more autocratic, more monolithic," Masao Kunihiro, a leader of the Socialists who bolted, said in an interview the other day. "It is a pretty horrifying thought."
Of roughly 500 seats in the lower house, about 270 would be directly elected from districts under the reform bill. The rest would be at-large representatives drawn from party lists according to the proportion of votes each party received.
"I regret the vote, but we will still keep trying," Mr. Hosokawa said tonight of the reform package. "We still have time."
No one seems to know why Mr. Hosokawa let the bills come to a vote, eight days before the end of the session, without having all of his votes lined up. Some saw it as a sign of a lack of savvy about the backroom dealings of Tokyo.
One of Mr. Hosokawa's biggest problems is that he has been unable to articulate clearly how the reform bills would really change Japan -- make the system less corrupt and more responsive to voters.

HEADLINE: Health Care Plan Isn't Cast in Stone

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Health care experts in Congress and the Clinton Administration have begun to identify areas of possible compromise as they prepare for negotiations over President Clinton's plan to redesign the nation's health care system.
In informal discussions with Congress and in interviews, Administration officials have expressed a willingness to compromise on important details of Mr. Clinton's plan, including cost controls and the structure of purchasing groups through which most Americans would obtain health insurance. 
 From the time he sent a bill to Congress in October, Mr. Clinton has voiced a general willingness to negotiate on nearly all elements of his proposal except the guarantee of universal health insurance coverage. Congress, which reconvenes on Tuesday, is already pressing the White House to translate that open-ended commitment into compromises on specific issues.
 
'Open to Discussions'
 Lawmakers and Administration officials say it is too early to start making deals or to begin formal negotiations. But through informal discussions they have identified several areas of potential compromise: Federal limits on private health insurance premiums, the structure of insurance purchasing cooperatives, known as alliances, and proposed cuts in the growth of Medicare and Medicaid.
"We are open to discussions in all three areas," Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, said in an interview. "We are well aware that they are likely to be the subject of negotiations."
Similarly, Ira C. Magaziner, the health policy coordinator at the White House, said: "We want to achieve the President's fundamental goals. We are certainly willing to listen to other people's ideas about how to accomplish those goals. There is no perfect solution."
Ms. Shalala said she and the President believed that "we ought to have open minds as we move through discussions with Congress," so long as the final legislation provides a comprehensive package of health benefits for all Americans and curbs medical costs.
The Administration's flexibility is in part a concession to political reality. The White House is responding to criticism that the proposal is too large and unwieldy and vests too much power in the Government. The critics include Democrats like Representative Jim Cooper of Tennessee as well as many Republicans.
The Administration is also trying to rebut the idea that there is no health care crisis and that the need for change is less urgent now because medical inflation sank last year to the lowest level in two decades.
A big reason for the slowing increases in health care prices, economists in and out of the Government say, is the expectation that Congress will pass a bill to increase competition, control costs and promote the use of managed care.
 
'It's Premature'
 There is broad bipartisan support for the President's goal of guaranteeing health benefits for all Americans. But many lawmakers have expressed skepticism about details of his plan, particularly in the areas identified as ripe for negotiation.
Jeffrey L. Eller, a White House spokesman, said "it would not be prudent -- in fact, it's premature" -- to talk publicly now about possible compromises. Robert O. Boorstin, another White House spokesman, said, "It's not in the interest of the American people for Congress and the Administration to negotiate through the press."
In the first area of negotiation and possible compromise, premium limits, Mr. Clinton has proposed an elaborate scheme for Government regulation of health insurance premiums, under which a Federal agency would set enforceable "premium targets." If spending exceeded the target in one year, payments to doctors and hospitals could be reduced the next year to make up the difference.
A Democratic Congressional aide said: "Premium caps have a serious problem. They are hated by left and right." Conservatives see them as excessive Government interference with the market; some liberals favor more direct regulation of doctors' fees, hospital charges and drug prices.
Some members of Congress say the premium limits proposed by Mr. Clinton are too tight and must be loosened if Congress retains them at all. Under the Clinton proposal, the growth in per capita premiums would be limited to the percentage increase in the Consumer Price Index, starting in 1999.
Under Mr. Clinton's proposal, most people would obtain coverage through the regional health alliances. All companies with 5,000 or fewer employees would have to participate in these purchasing groups. Each state would be carved up into one or more alliances. No alliance could cross state borders. Each alliance would have exclusive authority to buy care for people living in its territory.
Mr. Magaziner said the purchasing pools needed to be big enough that insurance risks could be spread across a large number of consumers, all paying roughly the same premiums, regardless of whether they had a history of illness or disability. But a Federal health official said there was no magic in the number 5,000, and Mr. Magaziner said, "We are certainly willing to hear other people's ideas" on this and other questions.
Many members of Congress say they want to reduce the size of the alliances proposed by Mr. Clinton, and some Administration officials say they are willing to consider such changes.
 
Medicare and Medicaid Plans
 Another major question is whether the alliances should be mandatory, as Mr. Clinton wants, or voluntary, as some members of Congress prefer. These lawmakers say they intend to remodel the alliances so that they have less regulatory power than Mr. Clinton wants.
The President proposed dozens of changes in Medicare and Medicaid, the programs for the elderly and the poor, to slow the growth of those programs and to help finance other benefits. Most proposals would limit payments to doctors and hospitals, while some would require beneficiaries to pay more. Some would also provide new benefits to the elderly.
Members of Congress say they are unlikely to accept all the cutbacks proposed by Mr. Clinton. Influential lawmakers from New York and Chicago are resisting proposals to curtail Medicare payments to medical schools and teaching hospitals. Democrats from big cities are balking at Mr. Clinton's proposal to reduce payments to hospitals that serve disproportionate numbers of poor people, saying many such hospitals will need assistance even if their patients have insurance.
Administration officials say they are willing to consider alternatives that produce more modest savings in Medicare.
Mr. Clinton's proposal to require employers to buy health insurance for their workers appears to have substantial support in the House of Representatives. Members of the House Ways and Means Committee predict that their panel will recommend such an employer mandate. In the Senate, by contrast, Administration officials say they worry that supporters of the requirement for employers to pay for health insurance may be outnumbered by Republicans and conservative Democrats who oppose it.
Another vulnerable spot in Mr. Clinton's bill is his proposal for the Government to pay 80 percent of the cost of health insurance for early retirees who would otherwise be covered by their former employers in private industry. Representative Pete Stark, the California Democrat who is chairman of the Ways and Means Subcommittee on Health, said that would "give away tens of billions of dollars to major corporations for unfunded retiree liabilities."

HEADLINE: Arab League May End Its Boycott Of Businesses Dealing With Israel

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: CAIRO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
The Arab League will consider scrapping its 43-year-old boycott of companies that do business with Israel at a meeting of its Foreign Ministers in March, the League's Secretary General said today.
The Secretary General, Esmat Abdel-Meguid, said after a meeting with the American Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, that the 22-member body would decide collectively whether to end the so-called secondary and tertiary boycotts of Israel. 
 Mr. Brown, who described the decision as a "significant breakthrough," said the United States' "preference would be for the entire boycott to be eliminated."
Mr. Abdel-Meguid said, however, the primary boycott was not discussed in his talks with Mr. Brown and that it would be maintained because Israel is still occupying Arab land. But the Arab League secretary went on to say he hoped the reasons for continuing the boycott "will fall away as quickly as possible."
 
10,000 Companies Blacklisted
 The secondary boycott blacklists some 10,000 companies that conduct business with Israel. The tertiary ban is directed at companies that deal with those on the blacklist. Arab states imposed them along with a primary boycott of all direct commercial and trade activities with Israel in 1951. As recently as last May, the Boycott Office added 13 companies to the list of those who conduct business with Israel.
The boycott has cost Israel $20 billion in export opportunities and $16 to $32 billion in lost investment, according to estimates prepared by the Federation of Israeli Chambers of Commerce.
A lifting of the boycott would theoretically allow Israel to tap into a huge Arab market of 250 million people and stimulate economic growth in the Arab world.
Israeli and American officials were hoping that the signing of the peace accord between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization in Washington in September would encourage Arab countries to ease the sanctions. But Arab officials have said that will not be possible before a comprehensive settlement.
Arab states have also said they intend to maintain their economic weapon until Israel eliminates its nuclear arsenal and reaches an agreement on water sharing.
But an Arab League official said the lifting of the secondary and tertiary boycotts is more likely since President Hafez al-Assad of Syria made a commitment to peace with Israel during his meeting with President Clinton in Geneva on Sunday.
"The Geneva summit strengthened the hand of the Arab parties that want to eliminate the sanctions," said the official. "We hope to remove the boycotts and eventually to lift the primary boycott in the framework of a comprehensive settlement."
Mr. Brown, on a weeklong tour of the region that has included visits to Saudi Arabia, Israel, Jordan and the West Bank, said Arab government officials and private businessmen are adopting a "pragmatic view" of the Middle East's economic future.
"I would argue that the boycott is crumbling of its own weight," he said. "Companies that have been placed on the so-called blacklist are in fact doing business in many Arab countries. It is clear that there is a significant erosion of the boycott in practice."
Last week, he said, a major Israeli business delegation was received by the King of Morocco.
Kuwait, once one of the strictest enforcers of the embargo, has dropped its blacklist of companies with business interests in Israel but said it would stick to the primary boycott. And other countries, Mr. Brown said, no longer enforce the secondary sanctions.
But the Arab League official said a continued stalemate between Israel and the P.L.O. could threaten the chances for lifting the boycott. The two sides have failed to resolve disputes, delaying the Israeli withdrawal from the West Bank town of Jericho and the Gaza Strip.

HEADLINE: A Setback for Economy and U.S. Trade

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's devastating loss in Parliament today set off an upheaval in Japan's politics, but in practical terms, it seems likely to have an even greater impact on the country's faltering economy and its frayed relations with the United States.
Mr. Hosokawa had hoped that the legislation to clean up Japan's scandal-ridden electoral system would be the crowning achievement of his reform-minded Government, but in recent months the effort had become a bottleneck. 
 Because the governing coalition had decided that everything had to wait until the political reform bills were approved, there has been no significant progress on the urgent issues of pulling the world's second-biggest economy out of deep recession or concluding a deal with Washington on reducing Japan's towering trade surpluses.
 
New Problems for U.S.
 In both areas, the prospects have suddenly grown even more uncertain, creating some unpleasant new difficulties for the Clinton Administration.
Late last year, American officials began to relax some of the trade pressure on Mr. Hosokawa and expressed patience with his goal of passing the reform bills in the belief that he represented the best hope for a major opening of Japan's economy.
As was the case with Russia, where the United States threw its support behind President Boris N. Yeltsin, the Clinton Administration has been relying more on an individual in Japan than on a society or a political process.
With Mr. Hosokawa's future suddenly in jeopardy and another realignment possible among Japan's parties, American officials are being forced to reconsider the approach. Their political support for Mr. Hosokawa did not help him noticeably, and economic problems were not addressed.
 
Cloud Over Economic Package
 The Government had been expected to present a package of emergency measures to stimulate the economy next week, including an increase of perhaps $100 billion in public works spending and a big tax cut. Prices on the Tokyo stock market soared recently in anticipation of approval of the long-delayed measures.
Now Mr. Hosokawa is so preoccupied and so weakened politically that nobody expects the recession to be tackled right away, a development that is sending a shiver of apprehension through the business sector.
Even if a compromise package of electoral reform is hastily cobbled together and passed next week, as some are predicting, the divisions in what remains of Mr. Hosokawa's Government run so deep that the politicians are unlikely to override critics of its economic plan. The Finance Ministry, for example, is fighting large-scale reductions in income taxes on the ground they will create huge budget deficits.
The problems with the United States could be even trickier, and more frustrating for both sides.
Mr. Hosokawa is to meet with President Clinton in Washington in three weeks, in part to conclude a trade agreement that Mr. Clinton has said will be one of the cornerstones of future relations with Japan.
The Clinton Administration had vowed that it would succeed where previous administrations have failed by obtaining guarantees from Tokyo of tangible increases in American exports to Japan and reductions in Japan's surpluses. Japan's overall trade surplus came to more than $120 billion last year, and the surplus with the United States alone came to more than $50 billion.
The summit meeting on Feb. 11 was going to produce Japan's first down payment on that policy, with agreements to open the markets for autos, auto parts, medical equipment, insurance and telecommunications.
The Clinton Administration was also anxious to extract a promise that Japan would take strong measures to re-energize the economy.
 
A Breakthrough Is Unlikely
 But even if his Government survives until then, Mr. Hosokawa is expected to remain so weak that it is unlikely he will be able to face down the Government bureaucracy and produce the breakthrough that some in the Clinton Administration had been hoping for.
Over the last two weeks, the trade negotiations have grown unusually bitter, with American negotiators suggesting that the Japanese have been acting in bad faith, and the Japanese accusing the United States of trying to brutishly interfere in their markets.
The slow pace presents a stark choice to President Clinton. He can criticize Mr. Hosokawa for failing to satisfy American demands, and thus possibly weaken further a leader he clearly regards as an agent of change, or he can ease the pressure and give the Government time to rebuild, and risk fierce criticism in Congress from those who feel the United States has been manipulated.
"The meeting was already bound for failure," said Yukio Okamoto, a former senior Foreign Ministry official. "The American expectations were too inflated from the start. This is going to be unfortunate for the U.S.-Japan relationship."
Haruo Shimada, an economics professor at Keio University, said the Prime Minister "will go on the trip just waiting to be victimized. Clinton is likely to be unsatisfied. It could be a very destructive kind of summit."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 The cable television industry, in an effort to stave off Federal legislation aimed at restricting violent programming, plans to create a rating system with independent monitors who would grade programmers. The plan also endorses the introduction of a device that would allow cable subscribers to automatically block out programs that are rated violent. The broadcast networks appear likely to accept at least part of the plan. [Page 1.]
 The Los Angeles earthquake and brutal winter weather in the East and Midwest have severely tested the nation's retailers. New technology has helped distribution systems respond to some of the logistical nightmares such disruptions can cause. [37.]
 
Companies
A Federal judge in New Orleans approved the largest class-action settlement stemming from the limited-partnership fraud scandal at Prudential Securities. The ruling means that more than $90 million will be returned to about 115,000 investors. [37.]
In another switch, the board of Paramount Communications terminated its merger agreement with QVC Network and urged shareholders to back the latest bid from Viacom Inc. QVC's investment bankers contended that the board was misled. [37.]
Boeing, seeing a small pickup in the airline industry, has scaled back the jobs reduction it had planned for 1994 by 14 percent. And the company said it would add employees at a plant in Kansas. [39.]
Departing from Japan's tradition of lifetime employment, Toyota Motor is planning to hire some automobile designers for high salaries under one-year contracts. The auto maker hopes to revitalize its design department by attracting talented people who do not want to spend their entire careers at one company. [39.]
After two years of losses, Caterpillar posted a strong gain for 1993. Its shares jumped in heavy trading on the Big Board. [39.]
Westinghouse Electric reported a steep loss of $478 million for the quarter, as a result of a $750 million charge to cover the cost of layoffs and a streamlining of the company. [39.]
Immunex, a biotechnology company that merged with Lederle Laboratories' oncology business in June, named Lederle's president as its new chairman and chief executive. [39.]
 
International
 China agreed to give greater access to American and other foreign banks. The announcement by Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and the Beijing Government said China would also allow foreign banks to do business in local currency. Mr. Bentsen also said the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, would visit Beijing to consult on monetary policy.[37.]
The Arab League will consider ending its 43-year-old boycott of companies that do business with Israel at a meeting of its foreign ministers in March. About 10,000 companies are blacklisted. [2.]
Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa's defeat in the Japanese Parliament is expected to further delay efforts to lift the economy and to reach trade accords with the United States. [5.]
 
Markets
 The Dow Jones industrial average broke through the 3,900-point mark for the first time. The advance by the blue chips was propelled by several strong earnings reports. [37.]
The price of the Treasury's 30-year bond slipped in light trading amid some worries that political uncertainty in Japan could lead Japanese investors to sell their Treasury holdings. [46.]
Gold prices fell sharply for the second day as investors sold off in frustration over the market's failure to reach $400 an ounce. [48.]
The dollar recovered against the yen and European currencies. A political defeat for Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan prompted an early selloff in the dollar. But bargain hunters later drove the currency back up. [48.]

HEADLINE: 2 Western Economists Quit Russia Posts

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Two leading Western economists resigned today as advisers to the Russian Government, saying the "aims and policies" announced by Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin mean the end of fundamental economic reform.
In response, Mr. Chernomyrdin's spokesman quoted him as saying the new course of reforms "of course contains elements of Western market economics, but mainly takes into account the special characteristics of our state, people and Russian traditions." 
 Mr. Chernomyrdin had never used the services of the Western economists, Jeffrey Sachs and Anders Aslund, in any event, the spokesman, Valentin Sergeyev, told the Itar-Tass news agency. He quoted the Prime Minister as saying, "The mechanical transfer of Western economic methods to Russian soil has done more harm than good."
Mr. Chernomyrdin's remarks may simply be the result of wounded patriotism. But combined with his statement Thursday that "the period of market romanticism is over" and his instructions to a first meeting of the new Cabinet today to help industrial enterprises increase production, his new comments will fuel Western concern that the Russian economy may spin into hyperinflation as efforts to control the money supply are abandoned.
 
Slower Approach Favored
 Mr. Chernomyrdin favors a slower, softer transition to a market economy, with more state support for Russia's huge inherited enterprises and their extensive work forces. He encouraged the new Cabinet -- minus the reformist Yegor T. Gaidar and Boris G. Fyodorov as Economics Minister and Finance Minister respectively -- to try to avoid confrontation with the newly elected Parliament, where Communists and ultranationalists outnumber reformers in the lower house.
While Mr. Chernomyrdin probably represents the political consensus of Russians just now, Western diplomats and economists fear that his stress on state support for industry and agriculture, without the presence of a strict Finance Minister, will result in spiraling inflation by April, a collapsing ruble and reduced living standards.
As Mr. Sachs and Mr. Aslund prepared to move their staff out of Government offices and find private foundation support for their Russian economists, aides to an otherwise silent President Boris N. Yeltsin stressed his continuing devotion to "economic reform" and his need to compromise with political reality in forming the new Cabinet, dominated by Soviet-era bureaucrats and managers.
And a debate began to swirl around the culpability of Western nations and institutions in the perceived collapse of Western-style and Western-endorsed economic reforms.
 
'Stabbed Us in the Back'
 Mr. Fyodorov was particularly bitter about post-election comments by Strobe Talbott, the American Ambassador at Large to the former Soviet Union who has been chosen to be the new No. 2 official at the State Department.
"He actually stabbed us in the back," Mr. Fyodorov, who is 35 and can be outspoken and brash, said of Mr. Talbott late Thursday night. After the strong showing of anti-reform parties in the elections, Mr. Talbott said in Washington that the lesson for Russia might be "less shock and more therapy," a quip that was interpreted as new policy and that received enormous play in Russia.
As stated, it implied that "shock therapy" had been applied by the reformers in Russia and had created significant popular hardship, though Mr. Talbott stresses that his statement in context was a call for broader reform, not slower reform, with more attention to social protections.
 
Used by Opposition
 Mr. Talbott, after unhappy reactions from Moscow and other Administration officials, especially in the Treasury Department, retracted the essence of the remarks. But by then, Mr. Fyodorov said, "they were publicized very much by the opposition." Without meaning to, he said, Mr. Talbott "helped the opposition, and he helped certain forces to influence the decision-making process here."
Mr. Gaidar and Mr. Fyodorov have argued that they have never been able to apply real "shock therapy," at least not after the spring of 1992, and that the biggest pain in Russia has resulted from too little radical economic reform, not too much.
"When Strobe Talbott says less shock and more therapy," Mr. Fyodorov said bitterly, "I'd like to ask him what kind of shock therapy is it when inflation is 20 percent a month, where there have been only five bankruptcies up until now, when official unemployment is only 1 percent? Or is he not familiar with shock therapy in other countries?"
In an interview, Mr. Talbott responded to Mr. Fyodorov's remarks by saying: "Our position has always been -- and is now -- that Russian reform should go forward full speed. That is in the interest of the Russian people, and it will also enable the international community to support the reform process."
Dee Dee Myers, the White House spokesman, also defended Mr. Talbott, saying his comments about "less shock, more therapy," had been taken out of context from a news briefing where he called for broad and rapid reform and a stronger safety net.
At the daily White House briefing, she said, "Strobe's position and the position of others in the Administration, including the President, starting with the President, are that the Russian economy needs continued reform and help in cushioning the impacts of reform on the Russian people."
 
Gaidar Doesn't Blame Yeltsin
 Mr. Gaidar said today that he did not blame Mr. Yeltsin, who wants to continue reforms, but that he must adapt to reality. "If the democrats had been united and had run the election campaign better, the President would be in a better position now," he told the Interfax news agency.
His comments were echoed by a Yeltsin aide, Pyotr Filippov, who told Itar-Tass that Mr. Yeltsin "has to keep balance between various forces" and might support a Fydorov deputy, Sergei Dubinin, for Finance Minister.
Russian officials said Mr. Chernomyrdin was looking at another experienced Soviet-era official as Finance Minister, Vladimir I. Shcherbakov, 45. He had worked for huge Soviet automobile plants and became Minister in 1991 of what had been Gosplan, the state planning committee, as it tried to shift toward economic forecasting under Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
In separate telephone interviews, Mr. Sachs and Mr. Aslund said that no official had asked them to resign, and that they would continue to work outside the Government with a group of Russian economists they had gathered in a Finance Ministry working group for economic reforms.
Mr. Sachs said the Talbott remarks were unfortunately seen in Moscow by the reformers "as an abandonment of these people, and it felt that way in the political fight under way." But he said the largest responsibility for the collapse of this effort at classic reform lay with the International Monetary Fund, which had been charged with carrying out Western efforts to help economic change in Russia.
Mr. Aslund said the new Government marked an end to fundamental economic reform. "After vacillating back and forth on reform, Russia has now really abandoned the course of fundamental reforms," he said. "The new policies will be destabilizing, with big social costs. But there is no going back to the command economy."
He said he was not optimistic that the country would again turn to the reformers. "They are extremely poorly organized now," he said.
The Gorbachev-era reform economist Pavel S. Bunich was more optimistic in comments to Delovoy Mir. Corrections to reform were needed, he said, but no more than 15 degrees. "But I'm convinced that nobody will dare go further, not Chernomyrdin or anyone else," he said. "And this means that nothing terrible or tragic will happen."
Pravda had its own view on this 70th anniversary of Lenin's death, predicting, "The democratic crusade against Lenin is close to its inglorious end."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Clinton Cites Inflation

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (Reuters) -- President Clinton said today that he did not think reform was over in Russia, but that his Administration was worried about whether Russia will be able to cope with its inflation.
"What we're concerned about obviously is whether they'll be able to manage their inflation problem," Mr. Clinton said. He spoke at the start of an Oval Office meeting with King Hussein of Jordan.
Mr. Clinton said how much economic help Russia gets from the international community "will be directly related to what kind of reforms they decide to undertake," adding that "they'll have to make those decisions for themselves."
"We're prepared to help and do what we can," he said. The United States was prepared to help set up job training, unemployment assistance and other "support systems" that a market economy needs, he added.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar in Recovery vs. Yen And Rises in Other Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar gained ground in the foreign exchange market yesterday, staging a strong recovery against the Japanese yen that carried it higher against European currencies as well.
The dollar had crumbled against the yen overnight on fears that Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa of Japan would have little ability to deal with urgent economic problems or frayed United States trade ties after suffering a crushing political blow. 
 Mr. Hosokawa, who was swept into office as the head of a coalition government chosen by an electorate tired of political scandals, had staked much on passage of an economic reform package. But Parliament rejected the package yesterday.
 
U.S. Action Foreseen
 The White House has repeatedly put pressure on Japan to stimulate its economy and relax restrictive trade barriers to allow the United States to sell more goods there. Barring progress on those fronts, dealers suspect the United States may press for a stronger yen as a way to trim Japan's trade surplus. Yesterday, Japan reported that its trade surplus with the rest of the world soared to a record $120.4 billion last year.
 But the dollar's selloff was short-lived, as bargain hunters, convinced that a robust American economy argued for a stronger currency, scooped up dollars.
"A lot of people were looking to buy at the lower levels," said Ken Nixon, corporate sales officer of Harris Trust and Savings Bank in New York. "When the dollar fell through 110 yen, they jumped on board and the rally snowballed."
The outcome of tomorrow's meeting of Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, Mr. Hosokawa and the Japanese Finance Minister, Hirohisa Fujii, could determine the dollar's direction, dealers said.
The dollar rose to 111.55 Japanese yen in late New York trading, from 111.37 yen on Thursday.
Earlier, the dollar touched a low of 109.70 yen in European trading overnight before rebounding as dealers bought back some dollars sold earlier this week. The dollar fell Thursday against most currencies after Germany's central bank failed to cut interest rates.
The dollar rose to 1.7524 marks in late New York trading from 1.7375 marks on Thursday.
Meanwhile, the British pound closed in New York at $1.4917, down from $1.4975 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with Thursday's quotes, included: 1.4674 Swiss francs, up from 1.4555; 5.9470 French francs, up from 5.9110; 1.3113 Canadian dollars, up from 1.3109, and 1,706 Italian lire, up from 1,696.

HEADLINE: Bank Rules Are Eased By China

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Jan. 21

 BODY:
China's Finance Minister agreed today to allow some American and foreign banks to expand into some cities of China now closed to them and to accept deposits in Chinese currency.
American and other foreign banks have been pressing the Beijing Government to open more areas of the country to foreign financial service companies, which hope to play a lucrative role as a bridge between China's tremendous appetite for investment capital and the huge interest abroad in investing in the development boom here. Infrastructure investment in China alone between now and the end of the century is expected to top $500 billion.
 
Joint Effort Is Revived
 Finance Minister Liu Zhongli's announcement of wider access in financial services came as part of a joint statement from himself and Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, after a meeting of the two nations' Joint Economic Committee. The committee, founded in 1979, had been a forum in which China and the United States worked out economic problems, but it had not met since the 1989 Tiananmen Square massacre. It was revived today by Mr. Bentsen and Mr. Liu. 
 They agreed to start meeting again annually and to establish sub-Cabinet groups that would deal with monetary and banking policy, exchange-rate reform and investment and economic cooperation.
 
Planning a Visit
 Mr. Bentsen also announced that the chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, planned to visit Beijing to consult with the Chinese authorities on monetary policy. The Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Bentsen also said, is discussing an agreement to help China establish and regulate "an effective securities market." And, he said, the Treasury's Customs Service will provide China with assistance in monitoring trade.
All of this reflects the Clinton Administration's effort to step up engagement with China along a broad front. The idea is to give the Beijing authorities a greater incentive to meet American human rights demands that are the condition for renewing China's preferential trade benefits in June.
The most important initiative from the Chinese side was the Finance Minister's commitment to expand the range of opportunities in China for American banks and financial service companies, particularly the right of foreign banks to do business in local currency -- the renminbi.
American officials said that what this commitment meant was that some American and other foreign banks would be allowed to expand the number of cities in which they could open branches. Also, a few of them would be allowed for the first time to accept accounts in Chinese currency. This would also give foreign banks the opportunity to expand beyond the relatively limited area of financing trade, to providing small-business loans, mortgages, car loans and inventory loans -- all in local currency.
Most of the world's largest banks are doing business in China in a limited way now, including some of the largest financial institutions in Japan, Western Europe and the United States. Among the American banks are Citibank, Bank of America, Chemical and Chase Manhattan. Generally, these banks have representatives in Beijing and Shanghai or other cities in China to offer trade financing and other services. But they cannot accept deposits under existing regulations.
Like so many other Asian nations, China has been reluctant to open domestic banking markets to foreign financial institutions for fear of losing some control over the money supply. At a time when inflation in China is running at 20 percent annually and the Government is trying to better control credit, this is an important issue.
Chinese officials refrained, for now, from specifying which new cities will be open to foreign bank branches, or which foreign banks will be involved in the experiment with local currency deposits.
Secretary Bentsen said this experimental move was important, but he added that he had strongly urged his Chinese counterpart to liberalize the financial services market quickly to benefit "both China and the United States."
Before leaving Beijing for Shanghai, Mr. Bentsen summed up his talks with Chinese leaders by saying that "there has been progress but more remains to be done," if the Chinese hope to have their most-favored-nation trade benefits renewed in June.
While Mr. Bentsen expressed the Administration's satisfaction with Thursday's agreement allowing more inspections of Chinese prisons to insure that their factories are not producing goods for export to the United States, he stressed that this was only part of what President Clinton was demanding as a condition for renewing the trade benefits, which allow China to export its products to the United States at the lowest possible tariff rates.
An accounting of China's political prisoners and visits to them by the International Committee of the Red Cross were two other important American demands, which China is considering but has not yet met.
"I hope sufficient progress can be made so we can put this issue behind us and there will not be an annual review" of the most-favored issue any longer, Mr. Bentsen said.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 46; Column 4; Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 545 words

HEADLINE: Treasury Bonds Dip in Light Session

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury bonds slipped in a light, uneventful session yesterday as traders treaded cautiously ahead of financial uncertainty over the weekend.
The price of the Treasury's main 30-year bond dropped 3/16yesterday to 9920/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.28 percent, from 6.26 percent on Thursday. 
 There was little fresh economic news to push Treasury bond prices outside the narrow range of buying and selling that has dominated trading so far this year.
"The market has been stuck in a range since the beginning of November and nobody seems to want to do much to get out of it," said John Canavan, an analyst with Stone & McCarthy Research Associates Inc. in Princeton, N.J.
 
Traders Cite Japan's Ills
 Traders were cautious after Japan's Parliament rejected an economic reform package yesterday. The vote came after the Tokyo stock market closed. Traders said they were worried that the Nikkei index of 225 leading issues could plunge when trading renews on Monday. This could force Japanese investors to sell their holdings of United States Treasury securities -- taking profits in bonds to minimize their stock losses.
At the same time, traders are concerned about the market's ability to digest a coming flood of fresh securities. The Treasury is scheduled to sell $17 billion in two-year notes on Tuesday and $12 billion in five-year notes on Wednesday, the first of several auctions over the next month.
The Banco Nacional de Comercia Exterior of Mexico priced $1 billion in bonds in a global offering that analysts said met mixed demand from investors worried about political violence in Mexico. The deal was viewed as meeting weaker demand than the only other global note offering from a Latin American issuer, Argentina's $1 billion sale in December.
Underwriters originally hoped to sell the 10-year notes at a yield of 1.50 to 1.55 percentage points above the comparable Treasury note, but ended up selling them at 1.60 to 1.65 percentage points above, said John Atkins, a corporate bond analyst for Technical Data.
That reflected caution among investors who wanted to earn a higher return to be compensated for uncertainty in Mexico, including recent turmoil in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas, he said.
"Something like this military uprising goes a long way to dampen sentiment for a country's closely held credits," Mr. Atkins said.
Prices of short-term Treasury securities were unchanged to 1/16 lower, and intermediate maturities fell 1/8 to 5/32 , the Telerate Inc. financial information service reported.
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, fell 1.05, to 1,310.74.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 3.01 percent as the discount rose one-hundredth of a percentage point, to 2.95 percent. Six-month yields rose to 3.19 percent as the discount rose two-hundredths of a point, to 3.11 percent. One-year yields held at 3.47 percent as the discount held at 3.35 percent.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 10325/32 , up 3/32 from Thursday. The average yield to maturity was 5.51 percent, down from 5.52 percent.
