HEADLINE: Beliefs;
Index of Good Deeds: Down 25. Index of Good Thoughts: Up 4. Index of Prejudice: Unchanged.

BYLINE: By Peter Steinfels 

 BODY:
President Clinton will deliver his State of the Union Message this Tuesday from the Speaker's rostrum of the House of Representatives. But symbolically he will also be occupying the Presidency's bully pulpit. It will be surprising if the President does not seek to assess the moral and spiritual state of the nation as well as its political and economic condition.
Others, however, have been beating him to the punch. Recently, a group of social scientists, including the polltakers Daniel Yankelovich and Everett C. Ladd, the political scientist Norman Ornstein and the sociologist Seymour Martin Lipset, answered a call to assess "The Moral State of the Union." 
 The invitation came from The Responsive Community, the quarterly journal of communitarianism. That is the movement, mainly of maverick liberals, that tries to marry typically liberal concerns for civil rights and economic welfare with traditionally conservative concerns about the ability of families, neighborhoods and schools to build character and foster personal responsibility.
The resulting articles turned out to be more of a debate than an assessment. It was a Ping-Pong match between familiar cries of alarm over rising rates of violent crime, family disintegration and teen-age suicide and equally familiar reminders that Americans have always bemoaned the moral excesses of the moment and contrasted them with the good old days.
Even if this go-round was inconclusive, the very idea of measuring "the moral state of the union" remains intriguing.
What the communitarians had in mind, of course, was something more systematic, more comprehensive, than the opinions preachers volunteer on Sundays and taxi drivers dispense any day of the week. As it turns out, others have had the same idea.
William J. Bennett, a former Secretary of Education and anti-drug czar, is about to publish a slim paperback volume titled "The Index of Leading Cultural Indicators" (Touchstone, Simon & Schuster). It claims to be "a comprehensive statistical portrait of our moral, social and cultural condition."
Then there is the even slimmer "Index of Social Health" that appeared last October. Published annually since 1987 by Fordham University's Institute for Innovation in Social Policy, which is in Tarrytown, N.Y., the index is meant to provide "a method of monitoring the social well-being of American society."
Both reports are inspired by the hope of doing for the nation's social, cultural and even spiritual life what measuring sticks like the Index of Leading Economic Indicators, the Consumer-Price Index, the Gross Domestic Product or the Dow Jones Average do for the economy.
Is that a doomed attempt to measure the unmeasurable? Is American society just too big and too riddled with contradictory tendencies to be squeezed into any set of numbers?
How do you register the kindness of neighbors and the generosity of strangers during floods, fires and earthquakes? Can you balance them against riots or drive-by shootings or the silent plaintiveness of "no radio" signs in parked cars to reach some bottom line about the moral state of the union?
Those constructing social indexes would agree that generosity or fear cannot be quantified. But they would argue that figures on charitable contributions or the number of citizens who feel they cannot go out at night provide a reliable substitute.
The differences among these three reports deserve to be noted, however. Mr. Bennett is perfectly clear about what his statistics mean to him. "Exploding social pathologies," he writes, are leading "to the decline and perhaps even to the fall of the American republic."
This decline-and-fall outlook may have influenced Mr. Bennett's choice of cultural indicators and the way he presents them. Crime, juvenile homicides, school dropouts, teen-age pregnancies and out-of-wedlock births are there, as they are in the other reports. He adds abortion, time spent watching displays of violence and sex on television and a host of other bleak details.
He does not deal with the kind of data cited by Mr. Ladd and Mr. Lipset, indicating, for example, that many social norms about lying, stealing and marital fidelity remain intact in American society; that Americans are much more likely to believe in absolute moral standards than Europeans and Canadians; that cheating in schools, while still widespread, has actually decreased since 1959. (Of course, Mr. Bennett might reply that the problem of cheating has been eclipsed by problems like drugs and guns in the corridors.)
Not content to let the statistics speak for themselves, Mr. Bennett adds interpretive quotations from Plato, George Washington, Hillary Rodham Clinton and a host of others, including communitarian academics. The book carries a blurb from Rush Limbaugh, who some people feel is a leading cultural indicator all by himself.
The brief "Index of Social Health" is a very different kind of document. It sticks to the neutrality of numbers. It puts a heavy emphasis on economic conditions like unemployment, poverty among children and the elderly and the gap between the rich and the poor.
Finally, on the premise that the nation's social health is not so much shaped "by any one social problem, but by the combined effect of all of them," the report combines its findings on 16 separate social problems into a single index of social health.
Unlike Mr. Bennett and the communitarians, the Fordham index does not try to sort out moral factors from economic ones. The convergence occurs in its somber conclusions: the nation's social health has declined by more than half since 1970, from a level of 74 on the index to one of 36.
Two weeks ago some of the contributors to The Responsive Community's issue on "The Moral State of the Union" discussed their views at a public meeting in Manhattan. Amitai Etzioni, the journal's editor, said the cautions against alarmism were well taken.
Nonetheless, he added, "The time to rebuild your home is when the first major cracks appear, not when the foundations have crumbled."

HEADLINE: Whitman Concedes Chance Of Higher Property Taxes

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that her plan to cut income taxes should not force New Jersey municipalities to raise property taxes to make up for reductions in state aid. But she warned that she would not hold herself responsible if local spending decisions prompted higher taxes.
"I can't guarantee anything over areas over which I have no control," Mrs. Whitman told reporters here after a speech to the winter meeting of the Republican National Committee. She said she should not be blamed if, for example, localities made wage settlements exceeding the amount of state aid they receive. 
 "There's going to have to be a level of discipline imposed at all levels of government, but my responsibility is to insure that the cuts that we talk about in order to meet the tax cut are not so Draconian as to require that local taxes go up," the Governor said.
 
A Call for Discipline
 Throughout her campaign, Mrs. Whitman said she saw no reason why her proposed 30 percent income tax cut over three years should force property tax increases, while Gov. Jim Florio warned repeatedly that it would. Her remarks today acknowledged that possibility, but she took pains to say it would not be her fault.
On Thursday, the Governor's Treasurer-designate, Brian W. Clymer, said in his confirmation hearings before two state Senate committees that localities would have to become more efficient or risk service cuts and that the state would send in auditors to help find local savings. He insisted that not every dollar in state cuts need translate into an added dollar in local taxes.
At another point today, Mrs. Whitman said: "What I have indicated to my Treasurer that I want to see stay the same is current levels of municipal aid, but if the municipalities are going to go into their own negotiations, and not institute discipline on themselves, or counties are going to do the same thing and to continue to give contracts that are far above the rate of inflation or what they can anticipate in seeing in new revenues from the state, then they're going to have a problem."
William G. Dressel, executive vice president of the New Jersey League of Municipalities, said that he took the Governor at her word and that he hoped the state would reduce waste and avoid cutting aid to localities.
 
Binding Arbitration Criticized
 But he warned that even maintaining the current levels of state aid would amount to cutting it, since local costs are rising markedly.
And he noted that municipalities sometimes have relatively little control over their labor settlements with the most costly workers -- uniformed emergency service workers. That is because state law imposes binding arbitration in disputes, with the settlements based on past practice and pattern with little regard for a municipality's ability to pay.
He said Mrs. Whitman might wish to propose changes in the law to require arbitrators to consider ability to pay.
"Will taxes go up?" Mr. Dressel said. "Well, taxes will go up if we're talking about maintaining the same level of funding and the same level of services, because the costs of operating local governments have gone up. I can absolutely assure you that for every dollar cut in state aid there will be a dollar increase in local taxes."
 
A Focus on New Jersey
 In her luncheon speech to state and national Republican Party leaders, Mrs. Whitman drew warm laughter when she noted the persistent skepticism that had greeted her pledge to cut the income tax.
"I think the only time that I got 10 days much less two weeks off of not having to answer 'Are you really going to cut taxes and how do you think you can possibly do it and isn't this crazy?' was when Ed Rollins chose to talk to the entire press corps of Washington, D.C., at breakfast," she said. In a boast later denied and discredited, Mr. Rollins, her campaign aide, said that the Whitman campaign had paid groups to suppress black votes.
"And I know he was really only doing it for my best interests and distracting the press, but I could have thought of better ways," the Governor said.
Asked later if the eyes of Republicans around the country would be judging her success or failure in carrying out the cut, she flashed a smile and quickly replied: "New Jersey is all I care about, and it's going to make a real difference to New Jersey, so that's what I'm focusing on."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
PACIFIC TELESIS GROUP

 BODY:
The Pacific Telesis Group said yesterday that it lost $391 million in the fourth quarter, mostly as a result of a reorganization, but its profits from operations were also below expectations.
The Baby Bell based in San Francisco said earnings were reduced by $670 million because of special charges for a revamping that is expected to eliminate 10,000 jobs by the end of 1997. Pacific Telesis reported a profit of $287 million for the quarter a year earlier. 
 Without the special charges, the company said its operating profits were $279 million, or 66 cents a share, down 3 percent from $287 million, or 71 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
William N. Deatherage, a telecommunications analyst for S. G. Warburg, said the poor California economy had served to depress earnings, noting that the company's Pacific Bell phone unit had just 3.6 percent growth in new business lines compared with a 6 percent increase for Ameritech, which serves markets in the Midwest. He predicted that Pacific Telesis, which is expected to complete the spinoff of its cellular and paging units by May, would have flat operating earnings of $2.60 a share in 1994.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Layoff Plan Scaled Back 14% at Boeing

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 21

 BODY:
Seeing a glimmer of hope on the economic horizon, the Boeing Company today scaled back the work force reduction it had planned for 1994. With a go-ahead from the airlines for its new 737-700 aircraft, Boeing said it would begin adding employees at its plant in Wichita, Kan.
Nearly a year ago, facing canceled orders and an airline industry in worldwide recession, Boeing cut production and said it would have to trim its work force by 28,000. Today's projected reduction, coupled with the 17,000 jobs eliminated last year, would result in a total cut of 24,000 jobs, or about 14 percent fewer. Analysts said a modest recovery in the airline industry, together with the successful introduction of its new plane, had made Boeing management more optimistic.
 
Adding 1,000 Jobs in Wichita
 Boeing, the largest producer of commercial aircraft, said it would cut 7,000 jobs this year in Washington State and 1,000 more at other locations; this reduction includes 1,451 jobs eliminated this month. The Seattle company plans to add 1,000 jobs to its work force in Wichita, for a net job loss of 7,000. As of Jan. 1, Boeing employed about 116,155. 
 "The 7,000 layoffs they are projecting now is better than I thought," said William B. Whitlow, an analyst with Pacific Crest Securities in Seattle, who added that he had been anticipating 10,000 jobs would be cut in the Puget Sound area alone. "This is an indication the company is feeling a little bit better about the outlook," he said.
Shares of Boeing rose 62.5 cents today, to $45.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Analysts were cautiously optimistic about the company's outlook for 1994.
"The encouraging aspect is the aggregate loss is smaller than previously expected," said Wolfgang Demisch, an analyst with BT Securities. "That's partially because of a little bit of incremental business they didn't bargain for at this time last year. But there are also some signs of improvement in the airline picture."
 
New Noise Rules Help
 The outlook at Boeing has been brightened by new noise rules that go into effect this year, mandating that airlines either retire 25 percent of their older, noisier aircraft, or have a fleet made up 55 percent of craft that meet the so-called stage 3 requirement for the quietest planes. While larger carriers like American and Delta are already in compliance, many smaller operators will have to accelerate purchase of new planes.
And while domestic air travel was down last year, global air travel increased by 7 percent. Airlines are also benefiting from lower fuel costs, and expect more business if the economy continues to improve.
Frank Shrontz, Boeing's chairman and chief executive, said the company's business plans would require some hiring to obtain necessary skills. "We will hire only if we cannot fill jobs from inside the company, recall laid-off employees or retrain existing employees to meet our needs," he said.
Boeing has in the last few years put into effect new manufacturing processes based on shorter cycle times and continuous work flow rather than the completion of jobs in batches. While these are considered more efficient, any production error can have more serious and costly ramifications than in the old method, Mr. Demisch said. This makes the company more reluctant to lay off experienced workers, he said.
"For Boeing, there has to be some real incentive to start thinking about what do we do if business improves," Mr. Demisch said. "You don't want to pay to lay people off, only to have to pay to put them back on the work force. The cost of laying people off has risen."
Boeing said its job reduction would be accomplished through a combination of attrition and layoffs. Mr. Shrontz said he expected the majority of the reduction would occur during the first half of the year.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Gold Skids $6.10 as Assault On $400 Mark Fails Again

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Gold prices skidded to a six-and-a-half-week low yesterday as investment funds bailed out after the market's repeated failure to reach $400 an ounce.
Gold for February delivery dropped $6.10 on the Commodity Exchange in New York to $381.40 an ounce, the futures contract's lowest daily settlement since Dec. 7. 
 Other precious metal prices also fell sharply. March silver plunged 15.3 cents, to $5.122 an ounce on the Comex. April platinum deliveries sank $8.60 on the New York Mercantile Exchange to $380.90 an ounce.
The selloff followed a $4.80 drop in the gold market Thursday after its latest failure to reach $400 became the last straw for investment funds and other speculators. Gold last traded above $400 in early August. It peaked on Thursday at $394.20.
 
Reminiscent of August
 The funds "do battle as they approach $400," said a metals analyst, Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential Securities Inc. "When the market can't break above that, it sells off."
She said the action was reminiscent of August, when repeated failures to push the market to $410 set off a plunge to less than $350 by mid-September. But a similar crash does not seem likely this time unless the February contract drops below $380, she said.
George Milling-Stanley, precious metals analyst with Lehman Brothers Inc., said he had not expected gold to reach $400 because fundamental supply-and-demand factors did not justify such a price. If it does not find support at $380, the market could fall to $375 or lower before demand picks up in the spring, he said.
He noted that Chinese demand had been weaker this year than last, and Japan, mired in recession, had reduced its consumption of gold, silver and platinum.
On other commodity markets, oil prices finished little changed after a week of ups and downs in reaction to bitter cold in parts of the country, followed by forecasts for higher-than-normal temperatures. Light sweet crude oil for March delivery fell 2 cents, to $14.94 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
February heating oil rose 0.07 cent, to 48.03 cents a gallon, and February unleaded gasoline rose 0.10 cent, to 42.04 cents a gallon. February natural gas climbed 5.5 cents, to $2.305 for 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: LAW;
Dividing Pension Funds In Divorce Settlements

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen 

 BODY:
WHEN couples in their 50's and 60's divorce, retirement benefits can be an important part of the financial arrangement.
Although money in tax-favored retirement plans generally cannot be assigned to another person, the Internal Revenue Code provides for an exception, a qualified domestic relations order, known by the initials Q.D.R.O. and pronounced quadro. 
 This type of court order allows a specified amount to be paid to a spouse or former spouse from a pension or profit-sharing plan or any other tax-favored retirement plan.
"It's a vehicle that can satisfy both parties," said Milt Pickman, senior tax partner in Anchin Block & Anchin, a New York firm of certified public accountants.
In a recent case described by Mr. Pickman, a company president who divorced his wife to remarry had $1 million in a profit-sharing plan. Under a Q.D.R.O., the plan's administrator paid $500,000 into an individual retirement account set up for the ex-wife. She was 56, so the financial settlement was structured for her to receive alimony until she was 59 1/2, when she could begin withdrawals from the I.R.A. without penalty.
"The basic advantage for the wife is that she got control of the money," Mr. Pickman said. "She can withdraw it as she needs without worrying about whether he'll send a check every month, and she can leave money in the account to her children. For the husband, the advantage is that it is pretax money, like alimony."
In this case, there is another advantage for the husband. Under the 1986 tax law, people may generally set aside up to $750,000 in tax-favored retirement plans, but people whose accrued benefits exceeded $562,500 on Aug. 1, 1986, were allowed to make "a grandfather election."
Now, because of strong market performance in recent years, many who made that election may find they have what the I.R.S. considers to be excess accumulations and eventually will face excess distribution penalties. The Q.D.R.O. reduces the accumulation without affecting the amount protected by the grandfather election.
Samuel J. Friedman, senior tax partner in the New York law firm of Hall, Dickler, Kent & Friedman, which has a large matrimonial practice, said middle-aged divorces were increasing. Some people wait until their children are grown to separate, and "economic stress is leading to marital stress," he said. People who are laid off or forced into early retirement sit about the house depressed, he explained, and then their marriages fall apart.
Frequently, money in pension funds "is the dominant asset" for such couples, he said. Many executives aged 50 to 55 have accumulated substantial pensions, but have squandered everything else, he said.
How pension money is divided may depend in part on the type of plan. The administrator of a defined-benefit plan, which pays a set amount each month to retirees, may pay a specified portion of those regular benefits to the former spouse. In the case of defined-contribution plans, including I.R.A., Keogh and 401(k) plans, a lump sum can go to the former spouse. If the payment is paid directly into an I.R.A., taxes are deferred.
Seldom is a Q.D.R.O. the entire financial settlement in divorce, Mr. Friedman said. Usually the order is combined with a division of property -- in accordance with state law and the couple's agreement or the court's dictate -- and sometimes with alimony or child support.
"It is a cash asset and readily predictable," Mr. Friedman said. People find paying alimony so distasteful that they often stop after a short time, and collection for the former spouse becomes difficult. Pension plan administrators are far more reliable.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Of Course Crime Pays

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER

 BODY:
Every politician in the United States obviously intends to run against crime as soon as possible. It is a noble strategy with a fatal flaw; to wit, it leaves a dearth of pro-crime candidates for crime-hating statesmen to run against.
Many politicians, saying they fear that a complete absence of crime-loving candidates will end their dreams of serving the public, have asked my help. And so, seizing the chance to mix business and patriotism, I announce formation of a company called the Pro-Crime Party Inc. 
 For crime-hating politicians the Pro-Crime Party Inc. will provide candidates ready to stump in favor of such acts as armed robbery, auto theft, burglary, running a disorderly house and swindling the greedy with the old dropped-pocketbook scam.
Every one of our pro-crime candidates comes equipped with a standard speech for delivery at a public rally. If television news shows fail to use sound bites from the speech, our pro-crime candidate will deliver it in a paid political telecast, or in 10-, 20- or 30-second commercials, provided his opponent will pay for the television time.
Sample line from speech: "God forbid that this great country ever see the day when the voters choose to be governed by a man who would imprison his fellow citizens for committing those historic American felonies known to our forefathers as . . ."
Here the anti-crime politician using our services can insert in our pro-crime speech two crimes of his own choosing. There may be an additional charge for the basic speech if customers want our candidates to endorse the more distasteful crimes.
For instance, customers who want our pro-crime candidate to wage a gloves-off, no-holds-barred campaign in favor of murder and arson will naturally be charged considerably more than those who are content with a campaign on behalf of more driving with suspended licenses and decriminalizing the act of impersonating a policeman.
The basic fee entitles anti-crime politicians to choose one of the following three bumper stickers for our pro-crime candidates' cars: (1) "Criminals Don't Bother People, People Do"; (2) "Support Your Local Drug Pusher"; (3) "John Gotti Said It, I Believe It, And That Settles It."
Please note that our candidates are honest working people. They are not criminals, nor even politicians, and will not engage in criminal acts to assure victory for anti-crime politicians.
For a supplemental charge, however, they will participate in staged "Moments of Illegality," illustrating what they hope to accomplish for the advancement of crime if elected.
In a typical "Moment," our candidate, visiting Washington, is accosted on the Capitol steps by a lobbyist wearing tasseled loafers and offering an illegal campaign contribution. Turning to the camera, he says:
"Can you believe, my fellow Americans, that under our present criminal-hating law I am forbidden to let decent citizens like this lobbyist give me so much money that even after buying the election I'd have enough left over to buy a 30-room house plus a little island in the Aegean for a summer place?"
Production costs of these "Moments" must, of course, be borne by the customer. (These include the cost of supplying tasseled loafers.) We supply free of charge, however, two videotapes of the "Moment," suitable for showing at lodge luncheons and League of Women Voters meetings.
Now what about debating? What is a campaign without a debate these days? Since our pro-crime candidates are honest working people rather than politicians, most are neither capable of nor interested in political argument.
For this reason we train each one to memorize an argument in praise of criminal drug activity. Its burden: Drug crime provides a living income for many thousands of poor, uneducated and unemployable young men. Moreover, since it flourishes in poor neighborhoods, its victims are mostly the poor.
If the crime did not exist, all those unemployable young men desperate for money would inevitably be forced to turn to other crimes, which might bring them down on unpoor neighborhoods where the victims would be the unpoor. In short, the illegal drug business is a blessing to the unpoor, and we ought to leave it alone.
We have designed this argument to cue the authentic anti-crime candidate to his explanation why practically everybody should be in prison, in most cases, forever.

HEADLINE: Slower, but Surer, Arms Curbs

 BODY:
The U.S. has traditionally tried to stop the spread of nuclear arms by talking nations out of wanting the weapons in the first place or by denying them the technology to make arms. But now that proliferation ranks high among the dangers to U.S. security, the Clinton Administration faces pressure to pursue a third course, military action.
Nonproliferation hawks, impatient with the traditional tactics of diplomacy and denial, cite the gulf war and the subsequent disarming of Iraq as proof that force works. President Clinton has wisely resisted. While keeping the military option in reserve, he has focused on diplomacy and on curbing trafficking in nuclear components to keep countries like North Korea and Iran from building bombs. 
 What currently has the hawks in full cry is North Korea's delay in resuming international inspections. At a minimum, they want to impose economic sanctions, backed by a naval blockade, but some also advocate air strikes.
The hawks routinely cite Iraq as evidence that air power yields results, But their argument is unconvincing. The 1981 Israeli attack on Iraq's Osirak reactor did not destroy Saddam Hussein's nuclear program but only drove it underground. Nor did allied bombing during the gulf war succeed. It took persistent international inspectors to root out Iraq's bomb-making infrastructure.
Economic sanctions are less risky than air strikes, which could provoke a violent reaction from a volatile country like North Korea. But there's no assurance that an economically strangled North Korea would welcome inspectors or shut down its nuclear program, and it might turn belligerent. The North's record of double-dealing makes Congress and the bureaucracy understandably skeptical about diplomacy. And South Korea is uneasy about having the U.S. deal directly with the North. That's why it takes courage for President Clinton to try diplomacy first.
The President is on equally sound footing in trying to make it harder for countries to ship arms-producing technology to nations that covet their own nuclear arsenal. He needs to persuade countries that possess such technology to impose tighter export controls on their manufacturers.
The U.S. has traditionally granted allies access to American dual-use technology that could be employed both for weapons and for peaceful purposes like nuclear power plants. But it has denied such technology to foes. Now it must deny dual-use technology to states that export it to renegades like Iran and persuade others to do likewise.
The Administration can also improve the climate for nonproliferation by accelerating negotiations to ban all nuclear testing by 1995.
Mr. Clinton's approach has had some success in South Africa, Belarus, Kazakhstan and Ukraine. Yet the Pentagon is prudent to hedge against failure by preparing now for a war against a nuclear-armed foe. Developing smart bombs to penetrate underground weapons factories and improving intelligence make sense so long as military countermeasures do not shift the focus from the first line of defense -- the strategy of diplomacy and denial.
That strategy may not be as sensational as air strikes. But it runs less of a risk, and slowly but surely, it is showing results.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: When Does Reform Toward Indian Peoples of the U.S. Begin?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"The Other Mexico" (editorial, Jan. 4) contrasts the "free market" of northern Mexico with the subsistence agriculture and native peoples OF Chiapas in southern Mexico, and calls for land, economic and government reforms to respect the rights of Indians. Then, ignoring United States political and economic realities, you make a shockingly naive statement: "If Mexico is to take its place among the democracies of North America, the gap between economics and politics -- and between the two Mexicos -- urgently needs to be bridged." 
 Do you not know there is another United States, of land theft, poverty and Government repression, the United States of native Americans?
For example, consider the great Sioux nation. In the treaty of 1868, the United States pledged to preserve western South Dakota as our permanent home, yet when gold was discovered in 1876, the United States made war on us and stole the Black Hills -- our sacred lands. Today, 1.5 million acres (of 7 million taken) are "Black Hills National Forest." When we petition for their return and are put off, it is clear that the national forest is a higher priority than national honor.
The theft of our most valuable resources has left the Sioux nation poor, the poorest of the poor. For example, Shannon County on the Oglala Sioux reservation is, according to the 1990 census, the poorest county in America. Ziebach County on our Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation, is the seventh poorest county in America. With this terrible poverty comes disease and early death for our people. Infant mortality, diabetes, heart disease and alcoholism are at third world levels.
At the same time, our inherent right to self-government has been shackled by the heavy hand of state and Federal governments. Most recently, the Supreme Court undermined the Constitution's principle of freedom of religion in its refusal to protect peyote as the sacrament of the Native American Church. Americans have a tendency to disregard all this, while pointing self-righteous fingers at other nations.
So, if Mexico must undertake land, economic and government reform toward Indian people "to take its place among the democracies of North America," then the United States must undertake land, economic and government reform to heal lingering wounds and finally fulfill the wonderful aspirations set forth in the Declaration of Independence and the Constitution.
 
MARK C. VAN NORMAN
Tribal Attorney
Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe
Eagle Butte, S.D., Jan. 13, 1994

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Florida Hopes Fears Will Fade From Memory

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
FLORIDA'S $31 billion a year tourist industry began 1994 hoping that the memory of violent attacks on visitors to the state, including the murders of 10 foreigners, might finally be receding. The results for 1993 were "clearly mixed," said Mayco Villafana of the Greater Miami Convention and Visitor's Bureau. The state estimates that the number of visitors to Florida increased by 1.9 percent, to about 41.3 million, but acknowledges that the bulk of that growth came before September, when the killing of first a German and then a British tourist produced a wave of canceled trips in markets around the world.
Europeans in particular still appear to be nervous about vacationing in Florida, especially Miami. Robert Todak, general manager of Art Deco Hotels, a group of four hotels in the chic South Beach area of Miami Beach, said there "has been a definite decrease in European travel into South Beach" in the last quarter of 1993. "Primarily we deal with European tour operators, and they are down." Tourism officials suggest that not just violence, but unfavorable changes in exchange rates and an economic slowdown in Europe have also contributed to the drop. 
 That, of course, is bad news for the operators of restaurants and tourist attractions, as Arthur Hertz, owner of the Miami Seaquarium, discovered last month after Germany and Argentina played a soccer match in Miami considered a possible preview of the 1994 World Cup final. "There was a group of 350 Germans that was supposed to come, and over 100 canceled in Germany," Mr. Hertz recalled. "Of those who didn't cancel, only 78 came here to Seaquarium. The rest didn't want to leave the hotel."
Some American tourists have proven equally leery. When Florida State played Nebraska in the Miami's Orange Bowl for the national college football championship on Jan. 1, a few Cornhusker fans lodged themselves in hotels more than 100 miles away, rather than staying in Miami. But those who opted for more convenient quarters were quoted in local press accounts, which Miami officials distributed nationally, as saying that the dangers of the city had been overblown and that they never felt threatened.
The falloff would be even worse but for tourism from Latin America, where strong economic growth and a more fatalistic attitude about violence have contributed to a double-digit increase in visits to Florida. A long article in a recent issue of the Brazilian news magazine Veja, for instance, concluded that Miami is as safe as, if not safer than, Rio de Janeiro or Sao Paulo, which helps explain why Miami and Orlando are crowded this month with Argentines, Brazilians, Chileans and Peruvians on their summer vacations.
The real test, however, will come this spring and summer. "We're in the critical booking period right now for those seasons, and we don't know yet how it is going to turn out," said Gary Stogner, a spokesman for the state government's tourism bureau. But Mr. Villafana added: "You can't have the cumulative effect of the crime tragedies we've had in 1993 and not expect it to have an effect. I think crime is something we will have to be dealing with seriously for the entire year."

HEADLINE: UP AND COMING: Jeff Williams;
On TV, He's Brilliant On Stage, He's Twisted

BYLINE: By ANDY MEISLER

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
IN "BIRDLAND," THE NEW ABC series set in a mental hospital, the actor Jeff Williams plays Dr. Lewis Niles, a very young, very nerdy, very physiology-oriented psychiatrist about whom everybody, including the audience, asks: "How can such a brilliant, caring clinician be so naive and out of touch with his feelings?"
In person, Mr. Williams, who has been an actor ever since he left college nine years ago, looks even younger than he does in a lab coat, and that inspires a different question: How can a person who's been working so hard for years be so calm in the face of what might become national recognition and financial stability? 
 "As far as I'm concerned, I'm unemployed," says Mr. Williams.
Filming of the last of six initial episodes of "Birdland" was completed in Vancouver several weeks ago. With positive reviews, the show premiered Jan. 5 and had the highest ratings in its Wednesday at 10 P.M. slot. The next week, it slipped to second behind "48 Hours" on CBS, but given the paucity of popular one-hour dramas, there is a good chance ABC will order more episodes.
"Birdland," a comedy about the problems of hospital staffers and patients, provides Mr. Williams with his first regular role in a TV series. The show stars Brian Dennehy as Dr. Niles's boss, a psychiatrist whose methods are as seat-of-the-pants as his colleague's are not.
Dr. Niles, says Mr. Williams, "has always focused only on academics. He hasn't taken a lot of time to develop the personal skills. Maybe some of it is fear of the world at large. And I think that's a part of his attraction to Brian's character. Brian takes risks and screws up a lot. Lewis kind of admires a bit of that courage."
Walter Parkes, the creator and executive producer of "Birdland," agrees with that analysis. "The Brian-Lewis relationship is the cornerstone of the show," he says, adding that Mr. Williams was the only actor he seriously considered for the Niles role. "He's very idiosyncratic. When you write a line of dialogue, you hear it in your head one way, but Jeff always manages to subvert or amplify that anticipation -- usually making the line better."
Mr. Williams says: "On television I usually play shy, brilliant good guys. On stage, I'm usually cast as a crazed, twisted killer. Those are more kind of fun parts, you know?"
Mr. Williams was born in Los Angeles, the son of teachers, and attended Sarah Lawrence College. His professional career has jumped from coast to coast. In Beverly Hills, he parked cars and had guest spots in shows like "Facts of Life," "The Cosby Show" and "Remington Steele."
Five years ago he moved back East, where he became a member of the acclaimed Naked Angels OffBroadway troupe and played a killer in the controversial play "Generations of the Dead in the Abyss of Coney Island Madness" at the Long Wharf Theater in New Haven.
A few weeks ago he watched the premiere of "Birdland." Did he leap up and shout "I've made it!"?
"No," he says. "I jumped up and shouted, 'I'm comfortable!' "

HEADLINE: DANCE;
A Plie Grows in Brooklyn

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
Walk down scruffy Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn, past scattered neighborhood shops, the familiar Brooklyn Academy of Music receding in the distance. Turn right on Douglass Street, near the Gowanus Canal, and continue down the usually deserted block. Enter the door of a building as unremarkable as all the others on this industrial street. It is like tumbling down Alice's rabbit hole. A giddy, chipped mosaic-floored hallway leads to a stairway of wooden planks. Three flights up is the Gowanus Arts Exchange, an oasis, serene yet bustling.
The air is filled with an improbable mix of tapping feet, flamenco music and endlessly ringing telephones. During the day, the studios may be filled with performers rehearsing for a show or children learning how to dance. In the office, a space partitioned off the small lobby, a woman is likely to be working on a newsletter or meeting with dancers, musicians or producers. At night, the larger of the two studios becomes a little theater, simple but well equipped, for programs of dance, music and theater by artists from the neighborhood, the city and beyond. One night, a dancer and a violinist may be found winding around each other in a dreamlike collaborative duet; another night, a comedian may be found portraying a dithering fund-raiser gone amok. 
 Some of the productions are terrible. Many of them are vital and even refined -- and go on to higher-profile venues, such as Dance Theater Workshop in Manhattan. But underlying them all is the invigorating sense of a questing spirit at work -- in the classroom and rehearsal studio as well as on the stage.
The Gowanus Arts Exchange is one of the hundreds of small grass-roots cultural centers that are scattered throughout New York and give the city a large measure of its reputation for artistic vibrancy. That vibrancy seemed threatened earlier this month when John S. Dyson, Rudolph W. Giuliani's deputy mayor for economic development and finance, raised the possibility of shifting city arts financing to larger, better-known institutions that attract tourist dollars and offer significant numbers of jobs. The small institutions, some 400 of which receive city arts money, tend to be faceless, yet they represent the life of the imagination to many New Yorkers who might otherwise never be exposed to the arts. They are home to artists in need of room to experiment and even to honorably fail.
In terms of its size and mission, the nine-year-old Gowanus center is fairly typical. It receives scant attention from the Manhattan media for its performances, which occur over 30 weekends a year, and for its classes -- 22 a week during the current winter term. A little less typically, it has become known among performers and producers of experimentalist dance and theater as a place where art grows, due in large part to the sophistication and wide-ranging interests of its director, a former dancer and choreographer named Marya Warshaw-Chu.
The center's budget is small. Last year, its income was $127,100, with $10,800 of that coming from city and state sources. (Gowanus gets no money from the Federal Government.) Receipts from the box office were $17,900, from tuition, $66,500. The year was a difficult one, and the center just about broke even, but it expects to come out ahead by roughly $2,500 in 1994.
Gowanus probably wouldn't go under if it lost its annual grant -- $2,500 in 1993 -- from the Department of Cultural Affairs, the city's major source of money for the arts. But should more than one piece fall through in the intricate jigsaw of income sources that make up its budget, the center could easily fold. Last year, it nearly closed because of a combination of rising expenses, cuts in government financing and a drop in student enrollment in one semester. If that had happened, Brooklyn would have lost one of only two year-round performance spaces in the borough, the other being BAM.
The center will never generate the kind of money or jobs Mr. Dyson talked of. But like the city's larger cultural institutions, Gowanus has had to cut programs because of dwindling resources and it is unable to expand some of its most useful programs, such as the one that provides arts education to the borough's public school children. The center sends artists and performers trained to work with children into two of the Brooklyn public schools with no other arts programming.
STANDING AT THE CENTER OF this enterprise, and functioning as something of a pragmatic earth mother for it, is Ms. Warshaw-Chu, 43, who has worked at the Gowanus center since it was founded in 1985 as an outgrowth of Elise Long's Spoke the Hub Dancing company. When her nearby studio became unavailable, Ms. Long and four friends bought an abandoned soap factory on Douglass Street. Gowanus takes up most of the top floor, occupying a 5,500 square-foot space that was renovated with money from the city and other public and private sources. The windows of her office overlook a largely Hispanic working-class neighborhood, one within walking distance of the brownstone neighborhoods of Prospect Heights, Fort Greene, Carroll Gardens and Cobble Hill, and that is home to many creative artists.
A small, dark-haired woman with large sympathetic eyes, Ms. Warshaw-Chu is the only full-time employee on a three-person administrative staff. She lives in Park Slope with her husband, Ben Chu, a public health physician, and two sons. Trained at the Merce Cunningham Studio in Manhattan, she choreographed for a time but preferred the process to the product.
Ms. Warshaw-Chu clearly relishes the interaction among different groups of people that tends to occur at the center. She remembers a dressing-room conversation during which two teen-age girls began talking about menstrual cramps. "Suddenly there was common ground between two young women of as radically different economic and cultural backgrounds as you could find," Ms. Warshaw-Chu said. "In a workshop setting, things get broken down about prejudice and difference and fear."
The center offers instruction in modern, jazz, ballet and African dance, with some special classes for boys and toddlers; classes in painting and sculpture are also available. In a typical week this month there were about three rehearsals a day, seven days a week. Four performances were held at the center this month. By spring, performances jump to 15 a month.
The program for which the Gowanus is best known is its Outback series, a monthly showcase for dance, performance art and music by new and seasoned artists, all chosen by audition. "The name was coined in the 80's when it was still like, 'Oooh, if I get on the subway to Brooklyn, I mean, will I get back?' " Ms. Warshaw-Chu said wryly. "That remains a struggle for us, though once people get here they come back."
Children, too, perform at the Gowanus center in a variety of programs, including Kids Outback, in which young Brooklynites selected by audition present their own dance, music and theater. In addition, the center's Young People's Performing Workshop, a group of 14 children ranging in age from 11 to 15, appears at Gowanus and at nearby nursing homes, schools and festivals.
Martha Bowers, a choreographer, relishes her work with Gowanus's youngest performers. "I've done pieces for professional companies and university students," Ms. Bowers said, "but this is the most fun. The only thing is, they're so adept at providing their own ideas that sometimes it's hard to convince them that you're the choreographer."
Children make up much of the audience for the center's annual Groundhog series for families, but Outback draws the most varied crowds in terms of geography, race and ethnic background. A typical Outback audience member tends to be from 25 to 45 years old, from Brooklyn or downtown Manhattan and from a low- to middle-income family.
One regular audience member is Mark Winther of Prospect Heights, who with his wife, Jane, and their daughter, also visit the Brooklyn Museum and BAM. "We go to a fair amount of Broadway shows," said Mr. Winther, a telecommunications consultant who works in Manhattan. "But we're always looking for newer stuff that is innovative and a little risky. You lose so much if all you're left with is the Met and Carnegie Hall."
Most of the Gowanus's special programs have their own audiences, particularly those devoted to work by gay men and lesbians, blacks and Hispanics. In April, there will be a festival of women's music and performance art. "We did men before the Joyce," Ms. Warshaw-Chu said with a smile, referring to a series at the Joyce Theater in Manhattan devoted to choreography by men.
Artists, for their part, talk of the center's distinctive energy. "It's such a hub," said Ms. Bowers, who also rehearses, studies and performs at Gowanus. "There's a constant flow of people. When I dance there, I'm not isolated in a space that only serves downtown dancers. People don't just talk about the best massage."
The center offers grants of free rehearsal hours to professional artists living in Brooklyn. Free rehearsal time is also a feature of the Gowanus's residency program. George Emilio Sanchez, a performance artist, and Reggie Wilson, an up-and-coming young choreographer, are the current beneficiaries of the two-year residency programs.
Mr. Sanchez rented studio space to rehearse a new piece in 1991 at the center, which is near the home he shares with his 3-year-old daughter Amalia, now a dance student at the center. He ended up as co-curator of Gowanus's popular and innovative "Borderlands/La Frontera" festival last spring. That led to the residency, during which Mr. Sanchez developed "Latindio," a solo piece that will be performed next month at Dance Theater Workshop in Manhattan. Mr. Wilson's full-evening "holy" will also be performed next month at the workshop.
MANY ADULTS HAVE FOUND their way to the Gowanus center through their children. Charlotte Phillips, a Brooklyn Heights pediatrician, spends Friday nights at the theater, watching dance with her husband and daughter, a center student. Mr. Winther became a Gowanus regular after his daughter began to study there. And Shelley Weiss, a family therapist from Park Slope, learned about the performances when she signed up for classes for her son, who had been enthralled by the dancing of Michael Jackson.
Ms. Weiss, who also heads OUTmedia, which seeks media visibility for gays, soon found herself part of Ms. Warshaw-Chu's wide-ranging network of advisors as a consultant on the center's gay and lesbian programming. "Marya, as a straight woman, was so comfortable with the necessity of presenting this work," Ms. Weiss said. "I think it's breaking new ground." Much of this work is drawn from the performers' lives and experiences, which, Ms. Warshaw-Chu said, makes it "very accessible."
Ms. Warshaw-Chu sounds as if she would like to cast her net over Mayor Giuliani, too. "It's easier to decide what's good and what's not good about something that's been done since the beginning of the century or been done every year by a ballet company or an established artist that everyone knows we need to cherish. It's much harder to establish that among younger artists and new kinds of art forms.
"But because it's harder doesn't mean that it's less valuable. And not to value the people in funding organizations who recognize that is to lessen the ability of this administration to build consensus among New Yorkers."
The city needs to work with artists, she said, not against them. And it needs to understand that the transforming experience of art doesn't occur only in large, formal institutions. "I'm glad we've held on," she said. "I'm glad we're able to do the work we're doing. But there should be more of us."

HEADLINE: WHAT'S DOING IN;
St. Thomas

BYLINE: By JAMES G. COBB; JAMES G. COBB is an editor in the Business Day section of The Times.

 BODY:
Of the three main United States Virgin Islands, St. Thomas is the most cosmopolitan, bustling and unabashedly commercial. Many Caribbean islands have white sand, aquamarine seas and lush mountains, but few display luxury goods in such abundance. A commercial hub long before Blackbeard prowled its waters, St. Thomas is now a prime destination for cruise ships, whose passengers rush ashore -- quite in the spirit of 18th-century buccaneers -- in pursuit of duty-free booty.
Others still come to get away from it all, even if a wave of development that followed Hurricane Hugo in 1989 sometimes gives a jolt of urban American reality. Along with new resorts and fast-food restaurants, there is now a Kmart and a Hard Rock Cafe, and luxurious homes have blossomed like frangipani on the northern and eastern hills. The sidewalks and narrow alleys of downtown Charlotte Amalie (pronounced ah-MAHL-ya), the territorial capital and St. Thomas's only real town, prove that there can be gridlock in paradise.
 Charlotte Amalie, St. Thomas's first permanent European settlement, dates from 1671. Set on a grand circular harbor, the town was laid out by planners in Denmark who had never seen the mountainous, 32-square-mile island, and it has kept much of its colonial charm. (Facing a plan mandating streets on near-vertical surfaces, local builders substituted long stairways; exploration by foot is thus strenuous but rewarding.) With a paucity of through streets and vertigo-inducing roads through the mountains, driving is an exercise in patience and caution, particularly because traffic moves on the left, in cars with left-hand drive. 
 Danish control of the Virgin Islands ended in 1917, when the United States, concerned about a potential German threat to the Panama Canal, bought St. Croix, St. John and St. Thomas for $25 million. The self-governing unincorporated territory has a nonvoting delegate to the House of Representattives.
 
Where to Shop
 Since Charlotte Amalie was declared a free port in 1755, opening it for trade with the European powers and the growing American colonies, the island has moved to a mercantile beat. Jewelry, liquor and electronics stores, interspersed with shops offering china, linens and perfume, crowd Main Street. Jitneys take cruise ship passengers downtown; most stores also have outlets at the Havensight Mall near the dock.
United States residents may bring home $1,200 in goods free of duty, with the next $1,000 each subject to 5 percent duty. Members of a household may make a joint declaration, entitling a family of four to a $4,800 duty-free allowance. There is no sales or luxury tax. Best buys include unmounted gems (duty-free for Americans, no matter the price), gold jewelry and watches. Knowing just what one is looking for, and its mainland price, helps to insure a good deal. A knack for bargaining can also help.
Reputable establishments offer dealer warranties and certificates of authenticity and generally avoid the sidewalk barker come-ons that grow more shrill as one moves west on Main Street. Sales tags at Little Switzerland, (809) 776-2010, which has four shops in St. Thomas, carry real prices, not a markup that leaves room for haggling. Swiss watches (among them Rolex, Omega, Baume & Mercier, Swiss Army) include styles not found in most department stores. Another high-line jeweler, H. Stern, has six locations on St. Thomas; (809) 776-1939 or (800) 524-2024.
At Royal Caribbean (809) 776-4110, 23 and 33 Main Street, a women's Movado Classic Museum watch, advertised in New York for $395, was recently bought for $235, or 40 percent less, after prolonged bargaining. A. H. Riise, 37 Main Street, (809) 776-2303, has a mind-numbing selection of liquors, plus jewelry, linens and tobacco. Cardow, with nine stores, says it has 20,000 rings on display at 1 Main Street; (809) 776-1140.
Most visitors leave with rum in hand. Local brands like Cruzan cost less than $3 a fifth, and if you buy any spirits produced in the territory you are allowed to take six bottles, rather than the normal five bottles, back to the States duty free.
 
What to Do
 The beach at heart-shaped Magens Bay, over the mountains north of town, has often been called one of the world's prettiest. It is the only beach with an admission charge (50 cents, 25 cents children 11 and under, $1 parking) and has changing rooms, food service and a gift shop. The calm waters are ideal for first-time sailors, and small craft can be rented on the beach (about $20 hourly). Snorkeling gear is also available.
Jet skis and wave runners, fast and maneuverable power skimmers for one or two seated riders, can be rented for $30 a half hour from Mad Max, (809) 775-5178, near the Emerald Beach resort on Lindbergh Bay or for $40 at Blue Dolphin Water Sports, (809) 777-7100, extension 2224, near the Sugar Bay Plantation hotel, where windsurfing equipment can also be rented for $25 an hour. Coconut Cruises, (809) 775-5959, makes half day ($45), daylong ($85), dinner ($60) and sunset cruises ($35) on trimarans that accommodate about three dozen passengers; trips include meals, snacks and an open bar.
Most tourists make at least one excursion to St. John, two-thirds of which is the Virgin Islands National Park and where each uncrowded beach seems to surpass the one before ($3 one way for a 20-minute ferry that leaves every hour from Red Hook on the East End, $7 for the 45-minute ride from Charlotte Amalie).
Chris Sawyer, who owns dive shops on St. Thomas, offers two- and four-hour scuba dives ($50 and $70) and night dives twice a week from $50. Allleave from the Stouffer Grand Beach Resort, (809) 775-7320.
The underwater observatory at Coral World, (809) 775-1555, provides a 360-degree look at coral life. At 2 P.M. divers hand-feed sharks in the Predator Tank. Admission $14, children 3 and over $9. Open daily from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M.
 
Events
 Many cultural events take place at the Reichhold Center for the Arts at the University of the Virgin Islands on a hillside overlooking Brewers Bay, (809) 774-8475, including folk dances by the Caribbean Dance Company on Feb. 18 and 19 and Feb. 25 to 27. Classical concerts (tickets $20 in advance, $25 at door; schedules from [809] 775-1929) are often held in Tillett Gardens in the Tutu area, the site of arts and crafts studios. From March 19 to 21, local artists and artisans will sell original works at the Arts Alive festival.
Carnival follows Easter in the Virgin Islands, and it will take place this year from April 17 to 30. The Carnival Food Fair offers a chance to sample dishes like kallaloo (a stew of meat, seafood and greens) and drinks prepared with sea moss or soursop, a local fruit. A predawn dance through the streets on April 29, the J'Ouvert Morning Tramp, is followed by the Children's Parade that day. On April 30 the Adults' Parade is led by Mocko Jumbies, stilt dancers in extravagant, brightly covered costumes.
 
 
Where to Stay
 Many big resorts offer the use of tennis courts, fitness centers and nonmotorized water sports equipment at no charge to guests. Winter rates are given unless otherwise noted; a hotel tax of 7.5 percent is additional.
With striking views from the mouth of the harbor, Marriott's Frenchman's Reef is the sprawling giant of St. Thomas hotels, with 420 rooms starting at $275 for a double.
Budget: Although far from any beach, the Mafolie Hotel has a view of the harbor from 800 feet up a mountain. The 23 rooms are modest but serviceable. Doubles from $97; (800) 225-7035, fax (809) 774-4091.
 With a similar, although lower, vantage point from Government Hill in town, Hotel 1829 has 15 guest rooms in a house built by a French sea captain for his bride. The house has a grand porch that doubles as a pricey restaurant popular with tourists. Double-occupancy rooms start at $80, harbor-view doubles from $170; (800) 524-2002, fax (809) 776-4313.
 Luxury: The Grand Palazzo Hotel calls to mind a palace on the Riviera, with pale walls, classical columns, tile roofs and canyons of pink Italian marble in the public areas. The 152 suites include juniors for $450 and two-bedroom units at $1,125; (809) 775-3333, fax (809) 775-4444.
 Condos and villas: Ocean Property Management handles 50 furnished condos in resorts, chiefly on the East End. Studio to two-bedroom units rent for $135 to $355 a night, including maid service; (800) 874-7897, fax (809) 775-5901.
McLaughlin Anderson Vacations, (809) 777-4737, rents about 40 villas, nearly all with swimming pools, by the week. Winter rates range from $875 for a small cottage with an outdoor shower to $7,000 for mansions that include the onetime estate of the author Herman Wouk.
 
Where to Eat
 Restaurants are generally informal and open-air, but prices can rival those of Manhattan's most elegant dining rooms. Casual dress, even shorts, generally passes muster, but reservations are advisable. Except as noted, prices are for dinner for two with wine or one drink plus dessert.
 Each of the big hotels has several restaurants, and a few have gained renown. Agave Terrace, perched above Water Bay in the Point Pleasant resort, has a cozy bar, a steel band on Tuesday and Thursday nights, and local seafood prepared in myriad styles and sauces. Among desserts with a tropical lilt: Mango Creme Caramel and an ice-cream concoction called Coconut Snowball. About $75. (809) 775-4142.
 At Grand Palazzo, the elegant Palm Terrace serves afternoon tea ($8 each for nonguests) and Continental dinner (over $100 for two) amid towering palms and high-backed cane chairs with a view toward St. John. Reservations for both: (809) 775-3333, extension 511.
 Provence, a stylish year-old bistro in the Frenchtown district, looks over fishing boats bobbing in the harbor. An antipasto table includes dozens of dishes, and there is an extensive wine list. Specialties include bouillabaisse and pepper-encrusted sea bass. About $70 for two. (809) 777-5600.
 Victor's New Hideout, in an industrial area near the airport, serves local dishes like conch chowder, plantains and fungi (pronounced FOON-jee, it is a cornmeal-and-okra fritter). About $60. (809) 776-9379.
 Panchita's on the waterfront serves Mexican fare. The second-story dining room is an ideal place to watch the hillsides light up at sunset as cruise ships head to sea. About $40. (809) 776-8425.
For a picnic near Magens Bay, Udder Delite Dairy Bar has hot dogs and the like. But the real attractions are liqueur-flavored milkshakes like the Jamoco ($2.75), of chocolate ice cream, coconut ice cream and Kahlua. (809) 775-2501.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 5; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2315 words

HEADLINE: Rewriting Rules for East Side Avenues

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
AFTER eight years of study and debate, a major rezoning of the Upper East Side -- intended to curb growth, change building forms and bring an end to plazas that often seem to benefit developers more than anyone else -- will be taken up tomorrow by the City Council.
One measure, a remapping, would limit development potential by reducing the size of sites along the avenues on which the largest buildings are permitted. 
 The other measure is meant to create a 30- to 35-story "tower on a base" building form. The lower floors of these structures would line up with neighboring buildings and the upper floors would be set back, in contrast to more monolithic 40- or 50-story skyscrapers, isolated on plazas, that current zoning allows.
The second measure would also eliminate the 20 percent development bonus generated by plazas for residential buildings.
The rezoning was approved unanimously by the City Planning Commission last month, while Mayor David N. Dinkins was still in office. It is supported by the two Republican Councilmen from the Upper East Side. It is also endorsed by the Manhattan Borough President and Community Board 8, which sponsored the remapping, as well as the Civitas civic group, which has been advocating many of these changes for eight years.
"The City Council should recognize the power of community-based planning," said the Borough President, Ruth W. Messinger, "and should see the extent to which this proposal balances neighborhood preservation with good development options."
But the measures face opposition from the real estate industry, which has demonstrated considerable muscle at the Council recently. In December, for example, the Council extended Section 421a tax abatements for the developers of large apartment buildings in mid-Manhattan and lower Manhattan. Two months earlier, the industry obtained several 11th-hour concessions before the Council passed a waterfront zoning plan.
And unlike the waterfront plan, the Upper East Side measures come to the Council as political orphans, the products of a mayoral administration that is no longer in power. Nor do they have a prime spokesman, since Richard L. Schaffer stepped down as chairman of the Planning Commission on Dec. 31.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani had not taken a position on the rezoning as of early last week, said a spokeswoman, Karen Crowe. But Fran Reiter, the Deputy Mayor for planning and community relations, was meeting with city planners and real estate executives in an effort to reach a decision.
The remapping would reduce to 100 feet, from 125 feet, the width of zones along Third, Second, First, York and East End Avenues, from 59th to 96th Street, where the largest buildings are permitted. This would mean that high-density development would not reach as far into low-rise mid-blocks.
It is estimated that future construction at 24 likely development sites in these avenue zones would yield about 1,700 new housing units under the remapping, as opposed to 2,500 units if the zones remain 125 feet wide.
The Real Estate Board of New York believes that remapping "would result in a significant decrease in privately financed affordable housing," said Warren Wechsler, its first senior vice president. He referred to "80-20" housing projects, in which developers can obtain financing through tax-exempt bonds by setting aside 20 percent of the units for lower-income tenants. If there is a decrease in market-rate units as a result of rezoning, Mr. Wechsler noted, there will be an accompanying decrease in new lower-income units. "From the standpoint of social and housing policy," he said, "that's a factor that the Council has to take into account."
THE Real Estate Board is also opposed to design controls that would pack a building's bulk -- from 55 to 60 percent of its floor area -- at or below a 150-foot level.
These controls would apply not only to the Upper East Side but also to parts of First Avenue, from 34th to 59th Street; Second Avenue, from 17th to 59th Street and Third Avenue, from 15th to 39th Street. A few blocks on Sutton Place and Lexington, Park, Madison, Fifth, Ninth and Tenth Avenues would also be affected.
"The apartment layouts in such a packed arrangement tend to be relatively deep, inefficient and less filled with light and air than apartments in a thinner, less dense structure," Mr. Wechsler said. "Because the apartments and the retail spaces are -- from the market point of view -- less alluring, it makes the project itself less promising economically."
Instead of eliminating the plaza bonus, the Real Estate Board has suggested a series of requirements: for example, that plazas be no smaller than 1,200 square feet overall and no narrower than 30 feet, uninterrupted by entrances to the building or garage.
"In parts of the city that are short on space, it would be a shame to lose an amenity that provides space," Mr. Wechsler said. "Maybe the key would be to look at successful examples and come up with regulations that encourage a more successful result."
City planners feel equally strongly that the time for plazas and extremely tall towers along the eastern avenues has passed.
"We believe this is a tower district -- but not 40 to 50 stories high," said Robert E. Flahive, director of the Manhattan office of the City Planning Department.
Existing zoning rules require that buildings cover no more than 40 to 50 percent of the site on which they stand, leaving the rest for plazas, side yards and rear yards.
The rules, geared to maximum coverage, did not anticipate that builders would seek minimal lot coverage in order to construct the tallest buildings possible. This came about because of advances in construction methods, Mr. Flahive said, and because a premium was placed on skyscraping apartments during the 1980's condominium boom.
"Higher floors had a cachet in the market," he said. "You were selling views. You were selling privacy. So developers quickly began moving to a building form that emphasized height. Towers of 40 or 50 stories began having a coverage of 20 to 22 percent."
The summit was quite literally reached at the 55-story Trump Palace, at Third Avenue and 69th Street, Mr. Flahive said.
"Zoning wasn't effectively controlling these buildings," he said. "In addition, we were concerned about plazas."
Plazas pose particular problems in co-op or condominium buildings where the developers who received the zoning bonus are no longer involved, Mr. Flahive said. "The person who benefited is long gone," he said. "The co-op or condo board has no ongoing benefit. Plus, it's a maintenance headache and a quality of life issue" -- if the space is used as a campground by homeless people or a ballcourt by school children.
"Plazas were very poor bargains for the city, as far as we were concerned," said Mr. Schaffer, the former planning chairman. "They were poorly designed, underutilized and became privatized outdoor vestibules."
An Upper East Side civic group called Civitas sounded many of these themes in 1986 in a planning study and a short film, both of which were titled "No More Tall Stories."
"The majority of the plazas which were built to get the bonus are currently unused and unusable as neighborhood amenities," the study declared. "The claim that greater openness is afforded by such plazas is compromised by the fact that larger buildings block out more of the sky and create uncomfortable winds."
While Fifth, Madison, Park and Lexington Avenues already had zoning to maintain their architectural character, the Civitas study said that on the five avenues east of Lexington, "current zoning encourages buildings that are strikingly out of scale with the existing neighborhood."
Among other things, Civitas urged that the avenue zoning districts be narrowed to 100 feet and that the plaza bonus be eliminated.
Three years later, the City Planning Department issued its own report, "Regulating Residential Towers and Plazas," which proposed the tower-on-a-base structure and recommended limiting the bonus for plazas.
In 1992, alternative building models were studied at the Environmental Simulation Center at the New School for Social Research. Joining in the exercise were the Real Estate Board, Civitas, the Planning Department and the Oculus committee, a group convened by the editor of Oculus, the newsletter of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
"It brought all the parties together at a place that was neutral," said Genie Rice, the president of Civitas. No single proposal or overall agreement emerged from these sessions but Ms. Rice noted points of consensus like the need for street walls that line up with neighboring buildings.
At the same time, Community Board 8 decided to proceed with its own rezoning initiative, as permitted under Section 197c of the new City Charter.
"WE worked with the Department of City Planning on all of our concerns," recalled Warrie Price, who stepped down last month as chairwoman of the board. But on the matter of narrowing the 125-foot avenue zones, she said, "it became very evident that they just were not going to move."
What made it possible for the community board to undertake the rezoning proposal was the technical assistance provided by the Borough President's office, Ms. Price said.
Otherwise, it would be "very difficult for local groups to do this because of the money, time and effort involved," said Craig Whitaker, an architect who worked with Civitas and on the rezoning application.
Ms. Messinger offered political support as well as technical assistance.
"We, in fact, endorsed the change," she said. "This major initiative of cutting back the depth of avenue buildings has the specific benefit of protecting the existing side-street affordable housing stock."
(The Real Estate Board, for its part, has said that the affordability of the existing housing stock within the 25-foot strips that are to be rezoned "has neither been established nor is it ensured.")
The staff of the City Planning Department did not embrace the community-sponsored proposal at first, maintaining that its own "tower on a base" proposal would suffice and that changing the depth of avenue zoning would not itself have a significant effect.
BUT members of the City Planning Commission, who were reviewing both measures, came to believe that the community-sponsored rezoning "did a couple of important things that were not done by the department's proposal," Mr. Schaffer said.
"It had the effect of very modestly cutting down the density on the Upper East Side," he said, "and it reduced the incursion of new buildings into the midblock."
"As everything went through the review process, the package became extremely attractive to everyone," Mr. Schaffer said. "It certainly seemed like an efficient and intelligent approach to have them both go through the process together."
Ms. Rice, of Civitas, said "the combination of the two are an excellent package."
The goal, Mr. Flahive said, is to outline a building form that would have a "meaningful base, integration between the tower and base and an interesting penthouse."
A base at least 60 feet high -- the height of a typical five-story tenement -- would be required, and the base would have to be either at the sidewalk line or recessed no more than eight feet.
The tower rising from this base would have to cover at least 30 percent of the lot. This rule, Mr. Flahive said, "would stop towers with 20 percent coverage, which adds 50 percent to the height."
Exceptions would be granted for features that added architectural interest to the building. For example, if the base of the building contained recesses and dormers, the tower coverage could be reduced to 28 percent, adding two additional floors. Also, the top four floors could have less than the minimum coverage if each were 20 percent smaller than the floor below, resulting in a stepped series of penthouses.
In buildings with only 30 percent coverage, at least 60 percent of the floor area would have be placed at or below the level of 150 feet. If the coverage rose to 40 percent of the lot, 55 percent of the floor area would have to be placed at or below 150 feet.
"These regulations will give us buildings between 30 and 35 stories," Mr. Flahive said.
And that has the neighborhood cheering.
"There is almost unanimous community support for the proposal," said Councilman Charles Millard, who represents part of the Upper East Side. "The reason is that Community Board 8 is the most densely populated community board in New York and people feel the need for relief."
"I HOPE that developers will recognize that with the waterfront plan and the recent expansion of 421a, they have been well treated by the Council in recent months," Mr. Millard said, "and that they would therefore not stand in the way of such an important community initiative."
Councilman Andrew S. Eristoff, who also represents part of the Upper East Side, said, "I think there will be some grumbling but, in the end, I feel the Council will take note of the broad coalition that is working for this change and will approve it."
From the sidelines, Mr. Schaffer said it would be "hard to judge" how the Council will vote on the measures. But he noted that they were approved by all 13 of the planning commission members.
"You've got 13 people appointed by seven officials coming together," Mr. Schaffer said, "so it was very clear that a very diverse commission felt strongly that these changes were important. That's a major plus. That makes a very strong statement."
Tomorrow's public hearing is at the Council's zoning and franchises subcommittee, headed by Walter L. McCaffrey, Democrat of Queens, who said he expects the panel to vote in the first or second week of February. It would go next to the Land Use Committee and then to the full Council.
