HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut;
A Housing Market Recovery, Step by S- l - o -w Step

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
SHAKING out Connecticut's housing market as the recession fades reveals a virtually unscathed southern Fairfield County and the rest of the state in various stages of a mostly sluggish recovery.
The 25 to 30 percent decline in housing prices since 1989 appears to have bottomed out and houses in all eight counties are selling in an uneven pattern. As old houses sell, new ones are being built. But Connecticut Department of Housing data show that the numbers are not overwhelming. For the year that ended on Nov. 30, 1993, 7,191 one-family housing starts were recorded, compared with 6,742 the previous year. 
 The loss statewide of 100,000 residents since 1989, due largely to corporate and military-industry shrinkage, did not, according to many real estate dealers, appreciably affect home sales as much as did an unemployment rate that rose from a low of 3 percent in 1988 to 7 percent in 1992. It has now backed off to 5.8 percent, helped by 9,000 new jobs at the Foxwoods Casino in Ledyard.
"Prices of existing homes," said Peter Helie, president of William Pitt Realty in Stamford, "can be expected to rise 4 to 5 percent annually through the end of the decade."
At the close of 1993 one-family houses in Greenwich sold for an average of about $850,000, up $20,000 from 1992, according to William Pitt statistics, which also showed Stamford dipping by almost $10,000, to $339,700, and Westport rising from $491,200 to $517,000.
"The trend now is toward home purchases as opposed to refinancing," said Leah Colihan, spokeswoman for Union Trust-First Fidelity in Stamford. The 30-year fixed rate for a loan up to $203,150 is 7 percent, with 2 points. On a "jumbo" mortgage of $600,000 or more the rate is 7.25 percent, with 2 points.
Citibank, based in Stamford, charges 7.375 percent, with no points, on the lower amount, and 7.875 percent, with no points, on jumbo mortgages.
"As rates rise the adjustable mortages become more attractive," said Mary Stachura, director of marketing for the bank. Current adjustable-rate mortgages are 5 1/4 percent, with a 2-point annual cap and a 6-point cap over the life of the mortgage.
In the Hartford region, sales are up 14 percent, according to Christopher Boynton, spokesman for the Greater Hartford Association of Realtors, covering 16 towns.
"Hartford proper increased by 32 percent," he said, noting that half the sales were below $220,000 and that the homes were predominantly pre-World War II vintage.
"A lot of fix-up is required," he said.
Robert De Angelo, president of the New Haven Board of Realtors, said that "housing values that have been declining are starting to stabilize, and sales for the past year were up 2 percent, to about 3,500 units, but there is enough inventory to last another couple of years."
The focus of new-home construction is on the one-family house built under contract for an individual buyer, but some developers are working on new subdivisions or taking over old ones from builders who were unable to complete them.
General Builders Supply of Brooklyn, a major provider of building materials for New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Connecticut, is experiencing "an improved climate in new-home construction," said David Poliscook, its financial officer, "but less so in Connecticut than in the other states."
In Milford, Baker Firestone of Pleasantville, N.Y., is building Lexington Green. Plans for the 162-unit development were approved for a former developer. Thirty one-family homes have been sold and a dozen are under construction, priced from $149,900 to $179,900 on varying lot sizes. They have three or four bedrooms and one and a half or two and a half baths.
Because of the moribund commercial real estate market, Robert Scinto, who owns 2 million square feet of commercial space he has built since 1982 in six Fairfield County towns, has switched to home development.
"We own a lot of land bought in the 80's for commercial development," he said, "but with no demand for the next three or four years we are building a subdivision called Rosebud in Trumbull and we will start on another project in Fairfield this spring."
Ten of Rosebud's total of 16 homes have been sold, five are occupied and five are under construction. Prices of $235,500 and $239,900 include 2-car garages, three bedrooms, two and a half baths, carpeting, air-conditioning and all appliances. "Basically, empty nesters are buying," said Mr. Scinto.
Crystal Homes, a company in Milford, has put together two of what eventually will be four modular homes off Imperial Avenue in Westport, presold at around $600,000 each. Built by Haven Homes in Pennsylania, they are designed with the buyer's specifications on computer.
"We erect modulars from $160,000 to $800,000," said Robert Small, president of Crystal Homes, "completing the foundation, site work and house in 60 to 90 days."
With higher lumber costs adding $10,000 to the price of a 4,000-square-foot house, builders are seeking alternatives.
"WE will use more steel," said Burton Rubin, of Burton Garret Associates of Mount Kisco, N.Y., "and sto -- a new word for synthetic stucco, being used in many high-end homes. It cuts heating and cooling costs by 40 percent, comes in many colors, doesn't crack and has a nice flat finish."
Some of his company's custom homes in Fairfield County are built on a trade-in, trade-up basis: The company buys the owner's old house and builds the new one, eliminating the risk of the owner's having to carry two homes.
"If the old house sells for more than the price fixed by an independent appraisal the client keeps the difference," said Mr. Rubin. "If it sells for less, we still pay him the appraised amount." The new house is priced higher than the old one, of course.
Burton Garret homes cost from $300,000 to over $1 million and range in size from 2,800 to 11,000 square feet. "Construction costs are the same anywhere in the state," Mr. Rubin said, "but a house in Litchfield County will cost five times less than one in Greenwich because of the availability and lower cost of land."
Indeed, the runup in Greenwich home prices since 1980 has resulted in the town's rejecting four revaluations done since 1990, and some large property owners are selling off acreage to reduce their taxes and acquire some ready cash.
"Fourteen years ago a house that cost $500,000 has a market value today of $5.2 million," said Mark Branchesi, the town assessor.
And James Sandy, the town planner, said: "People with 10 acres in a four-acre zone are spinning off the extra acreage. The lots can sell for $700,000 to $1 million or more."

HEADLINE: DINING OUT;
Satisfying Brunches for Wintry Sundays

BYLINE: By PATRICIA BROOKS

 BODY:
AN UPBEAT remedy for winter's cabin fever is to go out for Sunday brunch. Brunch is pleasant any season, of course, but in winter the leisurely and cozy aspects of it seem especially suitable indoors.
There is another good argument for going out for Sunday brunch -- an economic one. Often a three- or four-course prix-fixe brunch is a relatively inexpensive way to entertain. 
 The Sunday brunch trade has become so competitive that many places provide such an abundance that a brunch is the equivalent of a midday Sunday dinner. Some restaurants offer the inducement of live music.
Here are a few appealing Sunday brunches that we have sampled on recent Sundays.
We enjoyed a lively brunch, complete with rambunctious tuba and banjo music, at the MEETING STREET GRILL in Westport, where a fixed price of $16.95 bought a choice of five juices, eight appetizers and nine entrees. As befits a restaurant with a regional menu, the brunch choices had a Southern/Southwestern accent. We also could have ordered from the a la carte lunch menu, but who could pass up starters like she-crab soup (creamy and authentically Charlestonian), barbecue beef quesadilla with avocado salsa or smoked salmon with pickled okra and grilled bagel chips? Not us.
The prix-fixe entrees were just as seductive: blue corn-blueberry pancakes with maple pecan butter and apple-smoked bacon, Belgian-style waffle with homemade country sausage, French toast with Grand Marnier and fresh strawberries and crab and crawfish cakes with lemon-fennel remoulade and fresh vegetables. Even the Meeting Street eggs (a house version of eggs Benedict) had a special touch, with Southern tasso ham and roasted red pepper hollandaise.
Accompanying all this was a basket of miniature jalapeno cornpones, sticky buns, buttermilk biscuits, banana pecan bread and blueberry muffins. Request a ground-level table; upstairs service was unusually slow because the kitchen is downstairs and our put-upon waiter had to clamber up and and down stairs frequently, resulting in long delays between courses.
Meeting Street Grill, 1563 Post Road East, Westport. 256-3309. American Express, Mastercard and Visa accepted. Reservations accepted. 12 to 2:30 P.M.
CAFE CHRISTINA, also in Westport, dishes up a low-key brunch to the mellow background music of a jazz duo of acoustical guitar and bass. There is no brunch menu per se, but in addition to regular lunch entrees (including our favorite risotto fritters, served with a refreshing green salad and grilled mushrooms for $9.50), there are three brunch entrees at $12. Especially tasty were the two poached eggs with grilled pancetta and spinach on crispy polenta with fontina cheese sauce and whole wheat French toast with homemade breakfast sausage (very spicy slices), warm maple syrup and spiced apples. The setting, in the former library-revised into a touch of Italy (with walls painted in sunny pastels), seems especially laid back on a wintry Sunday.
Cafe Christina, 1 Main Street, Westport. 221-7950. Major credit cards accepted. Reservations only for groups of five or larger. 12 to 3 P.M.
Sunday brunch at STONEHENGE in Ridgefield has long been a Fairfield County tradition, but the happy secret is the excellent value it represents. The sum of $24 buys an appetizer, salad, entree, dessert, coffee or tea and a glass of wine. What makes this so remarkable is that the choices in each menu category are all tempting, and many of the entree selections are as suitable for Sunday dinner as for lunch. Though the menu changes weekly, eggs Benedict is a constant.
Our most successful choices on a recent Sunday were French onion soup, followed by a light mixed green salad, then an entree of wild mushroom ravioli in an Alfredo sauce, served with buttery carrot slivers and broccoli. Apple tart (including an excellent crust) with vanilla ice cream was an irresistible dessert. Service was on the slapdash side, but the restful, well-appointed dining room, with views of the pond and snow-etched trees and bushes made the experience a winning one.
Stonehenge, Route 7, Ridgefield. 438-6511. Major credit cards accepted. Reservations recommended. First seating is at 11:30 A.M., second at 2 P.M. (though it is possible to reserve a table between those times).
The area's most unusual Sunday happening is at RESTAURANT MICHE MACHE, South Norwalk, which features a gospel brunch. After diners have consumed a delicious Southern-style buffet of fried chicken, smothered pork chops, red-eye gravy, cheese grits, black-eyed peas, collard greens and other tasty vittles, the hourlong songfest begins.
Jean Cheek and Faces, a professional Broadway gospel singer and her vocal choir and keyboard performer, joyfully belt out song after song and encourage audience participation. For us it was a memorable day that bears repeating. The $25 tab for the works -- buffet, nonalcoholic beverages and entertainment -- is a real bargain.
Restaurant Miche Mache, 18 South Main Street, South Norwalk. 838-8605. Major credit cards accepted. Reservations essential. Seatings between 12 and 12:30 P.M., show begins at 1:15 P.M.
Everything at L'ABBEE in New Canaan seems custom made, from the attentive service to each brunch dish. There is no prix-fixe menu, but there is a congenial a la carte mix of brunch specialties featuring eggs and other entrees, from about $9.50 to $14.50. There is always an omelet du jour, a sumptuous eggs Benedict, French toast and griddlecakes with a choice of berries. Our brunch favorite was buttermilk griddlecakes with blueberries, served with hot syrup. L'Abbee's aromatic hazelnut coffee is a signature and is especially satisfying at Sunday brunch. The prime tables are in or near the windows; the rear room seems to us a bit too dark for daytime (though romantic at night).
L'Abbee, 62 Main Street, New Canaan. 972-6181. American Express, Mastercard and Visa accepted. Reservations accepted. 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M.
Other places in the area where we have enjoyed agreeable and well-priced Sunday brunch are the HOMESTEAD INN, 420 Field Point Road, Greenwich (869-7500), where you can dine in front of a roaring fire and the entree price ($18 to $24) includes appetizer, dessert and beverage, and the ROGER SHERMAN INN, 195 Oenoke Ridge, New Canaan (966-4541), where the prix-fixe $22.75 brunch includes appetizer, soup or salad, entree and dessert.
Fairfield County has no exclusive on Sunday brunch. Connecticut's most famous is probably the Hunt Breakfast at the GRISWOLD INN, 36 Main Street, Essex (767-1812), with a $12.95 meal-and-a-half buffet (children under 6 free). Among many other attractive winter brunch spots around the state are the SIMSBURY 1820 HOUSE, 731 Hopmeadow Street, Simsbury (658-7658), with a $16.95 all-you-can-eat brunch buffet in an inn setting; BACCI'S, 900 Main Street South, Southbury (262-1250), with a four-course (and champagne) $18.95 brunch, served in front of a fire; BOULDERS INN, Lake Waramaug, Route 45, New Preston (868-0541), with a three-course $16.50 brunch; APRICOTS, 1593 Farmington Avenue (Route 4), Farmington (673-5405), with a three-course $11.95 brunch overlooking the Farmington River, and the HARVEST AT BALD HILL, Junction of Routes 169 and 171, South Woodstock (974-2240), with a $13.95 brunch (choice of entree, baked goods, dessert and coffee).

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: January 23, 1994

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2970 words

HEADLINE: Economic Revolution: The 10-Day Tour

 BODY:
Secretary of the Treasury Lloyd Bentsen boarded a plane nearly two weeks ago for an inspection of two huge transformations -- the move from Communism to a free market in Russia and the surge from poverty to modernity in the space of a generation by 2 billion people in Asia. His journey, intended to promote American business and economic interests, brought home to the Secretary and his entourage the striking contrast between the tentativeness of the transition in Russia and the ferocity of it in Asia.
What follows is a diary of this journey by Thomas L. Friedman, chief economics correspondent of The New York Times, who accompanied the Treasury Secretary. 

Shannon, Ireland, Jan. 11
 First stop, Ireland.
What does Ireland have to do with this trip? Well, don't tell America's competitors about this, but members of the United States Cabinet still fly around the world in a museum-quality fleet of Boeing 707's maintained by the Air Force. These planes are so old they cannot fly to continental Europe in one leap; hence the refueling stop in Shannon, which adds three hours to the trip to Moscow.
Secretary Bentsen's plane -- U.S. Air Force 26000 -- is the same plane that brought John F. Kennedy's body back from Dallas in November 1963. Yes, the United States Secretary of the Treasury is off touting American technology, software and financial services to the world's big emerging economies, flying in a puddle-jumper designed in the 1950's. Traveling the information highway by Pony Express.
 
Moscow, Jan. 12
It is Day One and Mr. Bentsen and his top aide, Lawrence Summers, the Under Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, spent it closeted with senior Russian economic officials. They basically told the Russians that the United States would squeeze its Western allies and lending institutions to speed up aid to Russia -- but only after it sees a firm commitment by the new Russian Government and parliament to restructure the budget, curb the money supply, put into bankruptcy most of the inefficient state industries and spend some of the savings to help the unemployed.
Mr. Bentsen seems sober about the prospects of the Russians heeding any of this; it's not the economics, it's the politics of it all that seems so daunting.
"I know a little something about the difficulty of writing a budget," said the former chairman of the Senate Finance Committee.
Mr. Bentsen's staff was preparing the Secretary for a meeting with Viktor V. Gerashchenko, chairman of Russia's Central Bank and a source of American sobriety because of his penchant for printing rubles to solve every budget problem. A top Bentsen aide suggests the Secretary begin his meeting with Mr. Gerashchenko by dusting off his putdown of Dan Quayle: "I know Alan Greenspan. Alan Greenspan is a friend of mine. And you, Mr. Gerashchenko, are no Alan Greenspan."
Mr. Gerashchenko later reinforced American concerns about his competence when he joined Mr. Bentsen in opening the first Citibank office in Moscow. Mr. Gerashchenko was shown the Citibank computer, which was running a software program called Micro Banker. "I understand the meaning of a bank," said the Russian Central Banker to his hosts. "I like the words 'micro' and 'macro,' but not in economics. I don't understand all this stuff about micro and macro."
 
Moscow, Jan. 13
Secretary Bentsen and Secretary of State Warren Christopher split from the talks between President Clinton and President Boris N. Yeltsin to preside over the opening of the American Chamber of Commerce in Moscow, closed since the Bolshevik revolution. What was striking about the remarks by Mr. Christopher and Mr. Bentsen was how similar they were. Each man said he saw it as his top responsibility today to promote American business abroad. Mr. Christopher says diplomacy is now economics and Mr. Bentsen says economics is now foreign policy.
Listening to them captured the degree to which their jobs have merged in the post-Cold War world. The Secretary of the Treasury can no longer do his job without spending a good deal of time as a traveling salesman for American business and the Secretary of State will have little job to do if he confines himself to the classical diplomacy of arms control and peacemaking.
They even share a common jargon now. Mr. Summers remarked that as he was sitting in on the Clinton-Yeltsin talks at the Kremlin he was struck at how the word "tough" was being used by the participants. In the old days, it referred to a Russian or American leader's willingness to risk military confrontation in pursuit of strategic advantage. But in the Clinton-Yeltsin meetings, he said, "Tough was being used to refer to how strongly opposed you were to inflation."
Tough was also being used by the American businessmen at the chamber lunch to describe trying to operate in Russia.
"Not only is it risky in terms of economics, but there are a lot of contract laws that are lacking to protect business," said Max W. Dajnowicz, head of the General Motors operations in Russia. "There are no laws of repossession, for instance. If a customer does not make payment, you can't go and repossess what you sold. So everything is conducted with cash. The second problem we have is the escalating crime. It is very difficult for foreigners to come in here. We are very obvious, very exposed, and we usually carry more money than the average citizens. So we are targeted quickly.
"Another huge problem is taxes," he said. "The cars we bring in here to sell are taxed at 134 percent. A $20,000 Chevrolet all of a sudden costs $34,000. On top of the taxes, they want to test all of our cars to make sure they are safe for the Russians. Get this, they want us to pay for the tests -- $25,000 per model!"
His advice to American businesspeople thinking of opening shop here: "Analyze the situation very carefully before you come. A lot of companies have come here and left here very disenchanted with a lot fewer dollars in their pocket."
 
Moscow, Jan. 14
Mr. Bentsen, who is 72, was looking a little worn out today. It may be from trying to keep up with the grueling pace of President Clinton. Or it could be the after-effects of the 24-course meal -- ending with moose lips -- that Mr. Yeltsin served the American delegation at his country home last night.
As Mr. Bentsen was leaving the home, the Russian President gave him a bear hug and, through a translator, whispered to him: "You are going to get me my money, aren't you?" Mr. Bentsen just smiled.
The Treasury Secretary washed out the taste of moose lips ("they're like mush," he reported) by touring the Red October chocolate factory, one of the more successful state-owned enterprises that has been turned into a private company owned by the workers. (All the same, what looked like a life-sized white-chocolate statue of Lenin still graces its lobby.) In a burst of solidarity, Mr. Bentsen ended the tour by opening his wallet, plunking down $20 and buying one share of the company from its director, Anatoly Duarsky.
Mr. Duarsky, a former Communist Party member with the pear-shaped physique of someone who enjoys sampling his own wares, invited reporters into his office for tea and bonbons and talk about what it is like for a manager to make the transition from socialism to capitalism in the space of one year.
He held his head tightly in his hands as though trying to keep it from exploding and described the biggest thing about being a capitalist: "I have more worries. I have to study the relevant legislation every day of my life. I have to think what to do next because of that legislation. You have to think about everything. I am sorry I was born so early. If I had been born 15 years later, it would have been wonderful."
Despite privatization, Mr. Duarsky said, the Government has not lost entirely its habit of telling him where to ship chocolates. Last month he was told to send some containers to the far north, before it was cut off by the winter snow and ice, even though it seemed unlikely he'd be paid. So what did he do? He shipped them.
"You have to show understanding," explained the capitalist-in-training. When we responded that Nestle would not treat the citizens of Alaska so kindly, he answered: "It would not be right if we stopped delivering merchandise there just because they can't pay."
 
Jakarta, Indonesia, Jan. 17
We're moving up in the world. The White House switched our plane in Moscow and we're now flying in the Air Force Boeing 707 that brought Richard Nixon to China in 1972.
Secretary Bentsen spoke this morning to the American Chamber of Commerce in Indonesia. What a difference from Moscow! In Moscow, the American businessmen began their meeting by having a local minister lead them in a prayer for the Russian economy. Here, Secretary Bentsen spoke for about 15 minutes and then told the businessmen he would answer their questions for 30 minutes. After 15 minutes, there were no more questions. The Indonesian economy is so hot, and so open to Americans, that they all just wanted to get back to work.
"Everybody has meetings, nobody has time," Sean Kendall Richardson, a young lawyer just dispatched here by the New York firm Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, said as he breezed out the door. "We've got more work than we can handle."
How does doing business here compare with New York?
"The most striking thing is that it is not adversarial -- everyone just wants to get the deal done," Mr. Richardson said. "Nobody wants to get anybody else angry. There is no need to get anybody mad with an economy growing this fast."
Indeed, Indonesia is now the world's fourth-most-populous nation, with 180 million people. Rich in natural resources, from timber to oil, and led for 25 years by a relatively stable dictator, President Suharto, it is exploding economically. In the last 25 years, the number of Indonesians living below the poverty line fell to 15 percent from 60 percent. Mr. Summers tells us that over the last 100 years the American economy grew sevenfold. Indonesia and the other Asian "dragons" will do that in one generation, he said.
In the process, Indonesia is expected to spend about $110 billion on infrastructure between now and the year 2000, in part to link its 13,000 islands through advanced telecommunications. But American businesspeople are grossly underrepresented here, compared with Japan and the European Community, which is one reason the Treasury Secretary has come to hoist the flag.
Jakarta is orderly, clean and a kaleidoscope of flora. Coming here from wintry Moscow feels like someone changed the channel to color from black and white.
"I go away for six months and come back and I don't recognize some streets, that's how fast building is going up," said John M. Daniels, general manager of P&O Spice Island Cruises, and a resident here for 16 years.
Edward R. Gustely, a refugee from I.B.M. who opened a consulting firm called PAK here to help newcomers break into the market, says working in Jakarta can be stressful, but not like Moscow.
"The stress here comes from trying to focus on all the opportunities, because there are so many," he explained. "Sometimes you don't know where to turn next. I guess it's like America was in the 1950's and 60's, when people were sure that tomorrow would be better than yesterday."
 
Bangkok, Thailand, Jan. 18
Secretary Bentsen visited the Thai Stock Exchange today and was mobbed by Asian reporters. For the first time since we left Washington his Secret Service guards had to form a protective cordon around him, as some 25 photographers and television cameramen jostled each other to take his picture with a competitive ferocity normally reserved for Michael Jackson and Madonna. It was very odd. Mr. Bentsen seemed bemused.
The explanation, Thai journalists said, was that this is a mercantile culture, with a booming economy and a stock market that doubled in value between September and December, enriching millions of Thais. Every street corner exudes commercial activity. This is a place that respects economic power, so the American Treasury Secretary gets the celebrity treatment.
Also, many Thais are hungry for more American presence. They resent the fact that after the Vietnam War ended Washington seemed to lose interest in Thailand. Japan filled the void. Now many Thais want us back more than ever to play the role of balancer between them, Japan, Vietnam and China -- both militarily and economically. It is a reminder of how America's continued security role around the world can also be good for business.
Said Thanong Khanthong, a financial editor with The Nation newspaper in Bangkok: "People here are suspicious of the Japanese domination. The Japanese are everywhere. All of our daily life is involved with Japanese products. You watch a Japanese television, listen to a Japanese radio, drive a Japanese car, shower with Japanese soap and tell time with your Japanese watch. We want the Americans to counterbalance them."
At a luncheon speech Secretary Bentsen gave to the Thai Bankers Association, it was striking to hear some Thai businessmen complaining of the same sort of migraine headaches that Mr. Duarsky, the Russian chocolate maker, complained about. But here, the source of headaches is a different kind of change, not from socialism to capitalism, but from rudimentary capitalism to high-speed capitalism.
"What happened here in the early 1990's," explained Chaktip Nitibhon, general manager of Banque Indosuez, "is that the business sector grew so fast it simply outstripped the legal and financial infrastructure. So, since 1991, the Government has passed 270 new financial and regulatory laws to facilitate the next stage of development. They set up a securities and exchange commission to police the stock market; they reduced tariffs so more industries here would have to compete with the world market; they passed all sorts of tax and environmental laws."
What that means for Thai businessmen, Mr. Chaktip said, "is that everything has speeded up. You have to be reading the paper every day, keep up with all the news and then check with the Government that the news that is printed is correct. It's exhausting."
 
Beijing, Jan. 21
The latest joke in Beijing is that China has a new national bird -- the crane, because the skyline here is dotted with construction cranes. In fact, the satellite dish and the crane seem to have replaced the hammer and sickle as the symbols of the post-Communist world.
Shortly after arriving, Mr. Bentsen went off to Zhonganhai, the walled compound near the Forbidden City where Chinese leaders live and work, to meet Prime Minister Li Peng and his deputies. Every one of the Chinese officials arrived in a new Mercedes sedan. It seemed to underscore the way the old Stalinist political structure here is surfing along on a surging, increasingly free market economy that the leaders have unleashed below.
China is still a politically repressive place. A Bentsen aide had an important document disappear from her room while it was being guarded by Chinese security when she was out.
While such Stalinist shenanigans were going on on the 12th floor, though, in the lobby they were selling every important newspaper in the world, which any Chinese can buy. Indeed, the police state here is being gradually undercut by the proliferation of new sources of information that are demanded by a free market connected to the global economy.
On the roof are three satellite dishes, one pulling in CNN, another the BBC and another Japanese television. Pirate satellite dishes are in Chinese homes all over town. In the newspaper is a story about how Chinese universities are banning students from wearing their beepers to class because too many go off at once.
On the way to his meeting with Prime Minister Li, Mr. Bentsen drove through the very intersection where that lone, heroic Chinese student stopped the tank during the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989. Today, on that very corner, is the biggest McDonald's in the world. If that same student were to stop a tank there today, a huge Ronald McDonald would be in the picture.
Both Prime Minister Li and the Central Bank chairman, Zhu Rongji, spent a great deal of time in their meeting with Mr. Bentsen grilling him about his impressions of Russia and explaining to him why China's reform approach was so different and why there was no need here for "shock therapy." Some American officials interpreted this, in part, as China's leaders' way of saying: Don't even think about pressing us on the same sort of radical political changes that Russia is undergoing. China can't tolerate that.
But American officials also detected a certain sibling rivalry in the Chinese leaders' intense interest in their former Communist comrades. Russia and China are like two brothers who both left home at the same time. One is making it big on Wall Street and the other is still looking for a steady job. With more than a hint of mischievousness, China's leaders seem to be saying to Mr. Bentsen: "So, I understand you saw my brother Ivan last week. Tell me, how's he doing?"
Such scenes are a reminder of what this trip has really been about: great historical experiments unfolding before our eyes, not in laboratories, but in the real world. One, in Russia, is an experiment to see whether it is possible to build democratic political institutions before a functioning market economy is in place.
The jury is still out, but Moscow is heavy with a mood of pessimism. China is an experiment as to whether it is possible to develop a thriving free-market economy without democratic political reform. Here, the jury is also still out, but, to look around this place, it is not obvious that they will fail.

The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: January 23, 1994

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1521 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary: January 16-21

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
 
A Stubborn Public Finally Admits It: Things Are Looking Up
In some ways, public opinion is shamelessly fickle, but on the economy it's like a huge tanker -- it takes massive force to make it change direction. For months now, the economic numbers have been consistently strong -- whether on car sales, unemployment or housing starts (which just took another jump). Reflecting this vigor, stock prices are setting records almost daily. But not until last week did the public finally sign on. A poll showed that for the first time since mid-1990, when recession began chipping away at spirits -- and at George Bush's job security -- half of Americans expressed confidence in the economy. So it's no surprise that President Clinton, who can thank the recession for his job, now has the approval of 54 percent of the public. One heartening figure: A year ago, 40 percent of Americans feared for a family member's job; that's down to 21 percent. 

Out of the Rubble . . . Metrolink
There's always a silver lining. Sometimes, as in last week's earthquake in Los Angeles, you just have to look harder. Try this: The construction industry should pick up. (One catch: How will construction workers get to their jobs?) Or this: The mess could spur legislation requiring earthquake insurance, so taxpayers would pay less of the tab. Of the $15 billion-plus in damage, insurers will pick up only $1 billion or so. But the true silver lining may be that some Californians made a startling discovery -- it's possible to take a train to work. Ridership on Metrolink, opened in 1992, was up 50 percent after the quake. It's a wrenching change. "There's always that bond to your car," said one true Californian. But another discovered a well-known joy of mass transit: You can read the paper.
 
Always in Season: Tax Cuts
It's funny how at crucial moments politicians talk of tax cuts. Last week, sprinting out of the gate as New Jersey's Governor, Christine Todd Whitman vowed to cut state income taxes immediately. And Mario Cuomo, having just ended the latest will-Cuomo-run? vigil, said he'd cut business taxes. The approaches differed, but the message was the same. Mr. Cuomo: "New York State believes in business." Ms. Whitman: "New Jersey is open for business." Each wants to end the migration of employers to low-tax states. But will either state ever be a cheap place to do business?
 
A Closer U.S. Look at Fish
Fish can be killers -- sometimes because they eat you; more often because you eat them. About 9,000 Americans die annually from food poisoning, many from tainted fish, so people have grown suspect of anything that comes of age in increasingly troubled waters. The average person now eats 8 percent less seafood than in 1987. So last week the Government said it would start keeping an eye on the industry's safety procedures and require shellfish to be labeled by origin. All fish must come from water the Government says is clean -- assuming it can find any. The seafood industry loves the idea -- its image has nowhere to go but up -- but consumer groups say the rules will not do enough. And the rest of us will just have to be sure not to swallow any "Born in Maine" labels.
 
New York Banks on the Mend
Two years ago, New York's banking giants, loaded with real estate loans that promised nothing but trouble, seemed headed for the endangered list. But they've been rescued by a combination of stable real estate prices, which help them sell foreclosed properties, and low interest rates, which help borrowers pay off loans. Last week Chase, Citicorp and Chemical said loan losses fell sharply in the fourth quarter, and all reported solid profits.
 
COMPANIES
 
At Chrysler, Success Is Routine
Detroit is suddenly so mighty the stock market looks at the most stunning news and says, "So what?" After Chrysler said last week that its quarterly earnings had nearly doubled, to a record $777 million, the stock inched ahead almost by reflex, then promptly slipped back even more, to end the week at $60.25. But then again, just look at this stock, which a few years ago was being practically given away -- in September 1990 it sold for less than $10, and in the last year it has nearly doubled. It's not alone, though: its Big Three siblings are also roaring ahead.
 
Seagram Worries Time Warner
You'd think any company that survived one bloody takeover battle would be exempt from such distractions for a decent interval. But that ignores the new obsession with media companies, which are seen as holding a key to the fabled information eight-laner. Paramount is surrounded by suitors, and now Time Warner, which not long ago emerged from its own scuffle with Paramount, thinks it's hearing taps on its door too. Seagram has been quietly buying Time Warner shares, saying last week that it had raised its stake to 11.7 percent from 10.4 percent -- as an investment. "Obviously, Time Warner feels threatened," one observer put it, and it quickly laid plans to flood the market with new shares if necessary to dilute the value of any intruder's stake. But Time Warner is costly prey: at current prices, it's worth $15 billion.
 
But You Know You're in Fashion
A lot of it's understandable, in a strange sort of way. A trendy name on a handbag whispers to the world that you're a person of immense taste. A car's name in big letters on a windshield screams: "I am who I am. Want to make something of it?" But . . . underwear? Unless your office attire does not normally include pants, a fashionable name on your underwear makes a limited impression. But that hasn't stopped Calvin Klein's men's underwear business -- propelled by ads that look downright painful in sub-zero weather -- from being highly profitable. Last week Warnaco paid $64 million for the business, with Warnaco's chairman, Linda Wachner, justifying the purchase by saying, "People are always going to wear" underwear. But will they always be willing to pay for such an invisible fashion statement?
 
I.R.S. Eyes Pennzoil's Billions
You thought the Pennzoil-Texaco-Getty mess was over? Think again. The labyrinthine battle seemingly ended in 1988, after four years in which a lot of lawyers burned up a lot of stockholder money. In the settlement, Texaco paid Pennzoil $3 billion for mucking up its plans to buy Getty. But the I.R.S. kept its eye on that $3 billion, and last week Pennzoil said the agency wanted nearly $1 billion of it in back taxes. Pennzoil, it seems, used $2.2 billion to buy Chevron shares, calling it a tax-free replacement for Getty shares. But the I.R.S. says the money looks a lot like income, and wants its cut. So now, you guessed it: appeals, court fights, and the lawyers' meters will start running again.
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Cracks in the Japanese Dream
When Japan ruled the world, Japan Airlines luxuriated in the nation's wealth. Travelers were pampered with extra flight attendants, and pilots commuted by limousine. So it's a fitting symbol that as Japan's economy has been battered, the airline -- Government-controlled until 1987 -- has been badly humbled. Business travelers are cutting back, and such foreign carriers as United are proving potent rivals. Last week all this took a heavy toll, as J.A.L. -- facing an annual loss of about $235 million -- said it would slash its work force by 5,000, or fully 23 percent. Just wait til Southwest Airlines, a truly fierce rival, makes it across the Pacific.
 
Toyota is not laying anyone off, but it also made a radical departure last week from the idea of lifetime employment. Seeking to revitalize its design department, it said it would start hiring some car designers just a year at a time. In Japan, such white-collar contract workers are rarities.
 
In Russia, Reform Must Wait
In spite of what some in the West may think, market economies are not made in a day. That, at any rate, seemed to be Boris Yeltsin's message last week when he named a Cabinet less focused on radical economic reform. Yes, he had just promised President Clinton that he was committed to change. But in the end, as one diplomat said, "the West was probably irrelevant." The final blow came when Russia's Finance Minister, Boris Fyodorov, a staunch reformer, resigned rather than take part in this new approach -- one that is expected to spark inflation, further eroding the value of the ruble.
 
China Makes an Effort on Trade
China seems to be taking seriously the Administration's threats to cut off favorable trading status unless it makes some changes. In the first of two breakthroughs last week, China and the United States resolved a dispute in which the White House had threatened to cut Chinese textile imports by more than $1 billion as China agreed to slow the growth of exports. Later in the week, China agreed to open its prisons to American inspectors to make sure prison labor is not fueling the export mill. It remains to be seen whether this is all just window-dressing to allow President Clinton to justify extending trade favors, or whether China is making a true effort.

HEADLINE: Here's a Switch: Now They're Fighting Over Garbage

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
WHO owns garbage?
That is not a trivial question, because garbage disposal has grown far more complicated than simply paying someone to haul it away and dump it in a hole. 
 Towns and villages, under mounting pressure to be kinder to the environment, are making big investments in recycling and disposal centers. This "green" approach, though, is usually not the cheapest one, at least in the short run, and private trash haulers insist that if they can do the job for less, they should be allowed to.
But such unfettered competition poses problems. For one thing, towns say that if they are to justify a substantial investment in trash-handling, they must be assured of receiving all local garbage and recyclable materials -- that without this guaranteed volume, the system does not make economic sense. Also, if private haulers are allowed to undercut local programs, towns will be thwarted in their environmental efforts.
 Thus, many municipalities argue that they should make the rules. In fact, 27 states now have laws that allow local governments to impose controls on garbage handling.
But the privately owned haulers and processors who dominate the $63 billion-a-year trash industry are crying foul. Just as recycling markets are developing, and portions of the trash can are gaining value, they say, local governments are grabbing for materials once handled by the private sector.
This dispute is at the heart of a case pending before the Supreme Court -- a case involving Rockland County, N.Y., that could create ripples nationwide. If the Court does not prove sympathetic to local control, it could hurt the ratings of bonds issued to cover incinerators and disposal centers.
Who would have thought a few years ago that a battle would be raging over the nation's trash? As one local landfill after another was closed by state regulators, and as some politicians stood defiantly against importing another state's garbage, a landfill crisis appeared imminent. But owners of huge rural landfills welcome the trash, and new techniques make it ever cheaper to get it there, so from a strictly economic standpoint that crisis has all but evaporated.
So the battle lines have formed over whether towns have the right to all local garbage -- what has come to be called "flow control."
"Flow control is anticompetitive," said Alan Blakey, a spokesman for the National Solid Waste Management Association, which represents trash collectors and sorters.
And Hershel Cutler, executive director of the Institute for Scrap Recycling Industries, said, "It's an economic issue." His group represents many companies that reprocessed materials long before recycling came into vogue, and he said municipalities are trying to grab valuable recyclable materials at the expense of private companies.
But to public officials forced into action by state law, the issue is the ability to build waste-management facilities that will be economical to operate. "Without flow control, how can we plan?" asked Michael D. Diederich Jr., an assistant county attorney in Rockland County, northwest of New York City. He said local governments need the assurance of a steady supply of material before they can sell the bonds needed to build recycling and composting plants.
While environmentalists want to recycle as much as possible, the payback for different materials varies widely. If the private sector can drain valuable material out of the system, it could change the economics for local governments, making it harder for them to float bonds or pay them off.
The issue is of more than passing interest in Rockland, because a lawsuit arising from an ordinance enacted by one of its five towns, Clarkstown, is pending before the Supreme Court. Since the case will probably establish the court's view of the extent to which governments can control garbage, it is of considerable interest nationwide.
Environmentalists are keeping an eye on the case as well, but some have mixed feelings about it because flow control has been used in the past largely to assure a steady supply of trash to feed incinerators. Environmentalists take a dim view of incinerators because they are likely to be a source of air pollution and tend to divert attention from alternatives like recycling.
But some environmentalists see a place for flow control. "To get into the recycling game, vendors building processing plants need some certainty," said John Ruston, a solid-waste specialist at the Environmental Defense Fund in New York.
And Allen Hershkowitz, a scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council in New York, said, "If the Supreme Court decision wipes out flow control, it could hurt recycling long-term."
The Supreme Court case, C & A Carbone v. Clarkstown, N.Y., developed as a result of a law adopted by Clarkstown in 1990. It directed that all trash collected in town go to a single transfer station, where valuable material could be separated and the remainder packed into large trucks for shipment to out-of-state landfills and incinerators. The charge to dump at the transfer station, known as the tipping fee, was set at $81 a ton.
The Carbone company had operated a hauling and material separation operation in the town since the mid-1980's, and it continued to bring materials from outside for processing and disposal. But Carbone was charging just $70 to $72 a ton, said Ricki H. Berger, one of the company's lawyers. Carbone executives could not be reached for comment.
The company's operations drew the town's attention in 1991, when a truck carrying Carbone material got into an accident while driving illegally on the Palisades Parkway. Clarkstown demanded that all wastes Carbone processed be sent through the town's transfer station. Carbone objected, saying that because some of its waste came from out of state, it was protected by the commerce clause of the Constitution. The case was heard by the Supreme Court in December, and a ruling is expected in March.
Even though the case is off the central issue because Carbone handled mainly outside trash, a broad ruling could affect the ratings of billions of dollars of bonds sold to finance incinerators. As Moody's Investors Service noted recently, "Some solid-waste facilities protected by legal flow control charge substantially higher tipping fees than other relatively nearby facilities." The New York State Legislature has given Rockland the authority to adopt a flow control law, although it has not yet done so.
Still, county planners are drafting a waste disposal plan that appears to incorporate the latest in environmental thinking. Michael A. Cech, the county's solid-waste manager, said four new plants are on the drawing board to process the 1,000 tons of garbage generated in the county daily. One new plant will be able to squeeze that much recyclable material out of trash before the rest is sent for disposal. In contrast, at a typical transfer station recycling takes second place to assembling huge loads to be trucked away.
ALSO in the works is a composting plant where sewage sludge will be mixed with leaves and other yard waste, and possibly low-grade paper like newsprint, and turned into a rich soil additive. Another building will be used to collect such hazardous household wastes as bug sprays, gasoline and paint. Each type of waste will be stored separately until there is enough for shipment.
The last plant is intended to recycle construction and demolition debris and bulky items like old appliances.
"We are looking at a 49 percent to 59 percent recycling rate once the system is in operation," Mr. Cech said. But it will also require an investment of $40 million to $50 million, money that bond market investors may be reluctant to supply unless the plants have an assured source of material.
And as with most things environmental, the chief threat to the desirable solution is the presence of a cheap, but dirty, alternative. "Does the private sector have the right to come in and say we can dispose of garbage in a sleazy landfill more cheaply?" asked Mr. Diederich of Rockland.
Even if putting trash in landfills is cheaper now, that does not take into account the eventual cost of dealing with environmental problems caused by those landfills -- or the resources that can be saved by recycling.
Rockland officials say they are not interested in intruding on individuals' rights to dispose of their property as they wish. "If you have an old clothes dryer and you can get $15 by taking it to a scrap yard, go right ahead," Mr. Cech said. "If you want to give your newspapers to the Boy Scouts, fine. But once you put those things out on the curbside, they are pollution and they belong to us."
Mr. Diederich said it is unfortunate that the dispute has gone all the way to the Supreme Court. "Why can't a community decide how to manage its own waste," he said, "without outside entities coming in and saying, 'We want part of that'?"
The officials say flow control is so essential to their plans that they are working on alternatives in case the Supreme Court rules against them. Chief among the plans is what is known as economic flow control, as opposed to legal flow control. The plan would be to assess taxpayers, who pay for garbage disposal already, so that the tipping fee at county-owned plants could be lowered to the point where private disposers could not compete. The county would own the plants and set basic policy, but they would be operated by private contractors.
In the end, Congress may have to decide how much control communities have over their own trash, and who owns it.
The chairman of the transportation and hazardous material subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, Representative Al Swift, Democrat of Washington, said late last year: "I think it is likely that Congress will have to address flow control in some fashion early in the next session."

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Helsinki Soars Amid Signs of Recovery

BYLINE: By Richard W. Stevenson

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
SCANDINAVIA has had a rough time economically for the past several years, and nowhere have times been tougher than in Finland. Only now, after a three-year downturn that could justifiably be called a depression, is the Finnish economy showing signs of life.
But on the Helsinki Stock Exchange, investors shed their doom-and-gloom attitude more than a year ago. After selling furiously as the Hex index fell from over 2,000 in 1989 to about 550 in the fall of 1992, they have since bid stock prices up sharply, making the market one of the world's best-performing last year. The index more than doubled to end 1993 at 1,580. And after a bull run in the first few weeks of this month, it is already up by another 18 percent or so this year, hitting a 12-month high on Thursday before closing slightly lower Friday at 1,856. 
 "To say it's been quite a year is an understatement for anyone involved in the Finnish equity market," said Jerry Raybold, the senior manager for equity trading and sales at Kansallis-Osake-Pankki Bank, Finland's largest commercial bank.
Finland's economic problems began with the collapse of its trade with the former Soviet Union, which until the late 1980's purchased more than 20 percent of Finnish exports. "It was as if the United States disappeared from the U.K.'s trade account," said Nicholas Stevenson, an economist with S. G. Warburg Securities in London.
The economic woes were exacerbated by the downturn in the world economy, which further hurt Finland's export-oriented industries. In addition, the Government continued to keep its currency tied to a basket of European currencies, forcing it to raise interest rates sharply.
By mid-1992 the economy was in free fall. Gross domestic product had shrunk by more than 10 percent over two years. Unemployment had risen to 18 percent, from under 5 percent. Exports had been choked off by the strong currency.
So the Government abandoned its stable-currency strategy, devalued the markka twice by nearly 30 percent in trade-weighted terms and began slashing interest rates. Exports again began flowing, bolstering corporate results, especially in key industries like paper and pulp.
The Government also stepped in to bail out the ailing banking sector, easing investor fears of a financial crisis.
The combination of falling interest rates and improved export results sent many investors back into the stock market early last year. At the same time, the Government removed some tax and regulatory burdens that had made investing in equities in Finland relatively unattractive, and it liberalized rules on investing through mutual funds. Moreover, it loosened regulations on investments by foreigners.
The resulting flow of funds into the market and the surge in share prices attracted considerable attention from international investors, including big institutions, Mr. Raybold said. From just over 10 percent of market capitalization in 1992, foreign ownership has jumped to as much as 25 percent, he said.
Despite the rapid rise in stock prices, analysts said there is no reason to think the market has peaked. At a time when most European markets are regularly setting new records, the Helsinki exchange remains below its all-time high of 2,009 in March 1989. Mr. Stevenson of S. G. Warburg said that non-financial stocks in Finland are currently trading at 12.5 times projected 1994 earnings, compared with 15.5 times 1994 earnings for the same universe of stocks in Britain.
In addition, the export boom seems to be helping the domestic economy begin to recover, although unemployment remains stubbornly above 18 percent and the Government's budget deficit amounts to nearly 20 percent of G.D.P.
Next month the nation will hold the final round of its presidential elections. Both candidates -- Martii Ahtisaari, a diplomat who is a member of the center-left Social Democrats, and Elisabeth Rehn, the current defense minister who is a member of the small center-right Finnish People's Party -- favor Finland's application to join the European Union.
Mr. Ahtisaari favors more spending to help alleviate unemployment, while Ms. Rehn is a fiscal conservative. But because Finland's president is primarily responsible for foreign affairs, with the prime minister in charge of domestic policy, the election is likely to bring little in the way of immediate change in economic strategy.
"You can't rule out a setback at some point for profit-taking, but fundamentally this market has more potential," said Keld Holm, a Scandinavian economist at Lehman Brothers in London. "Some of the domestic stocks could benefit because there should be room for them to improve margins."
Mr. Raybold said that among the stocks attracting the most attention from foreign investors was the Nokia Group, the Helsinki- based telecommunications and electronics company, which operates in 36 countries.
He said investors have also been attracted to the Metra Corporation, which makes diesel engines for marine and power generation use, and also has subsidiaries making bathroom fittings and magnetic keys for door locks. Metra is a classic export play, with 90 percent of its sales outside Finland.
Repola, one of the giant paper companies, has done well, Mr. Raybold said, and other analysts said that signs of improvement in worlwide paper and pulp prices could help the entire forest-products sector.

HEADLINE: Small Store, Big Move

BYLINE: By ANNE-MARIE SCHIRO 

 BODY:
FOR more than 40 years, Jimmy's has been a Brooklyn landmark, offering high-fashion men's and women's clothes to a well-heeled clientele that finds comfort in its family atmosphere. Now, the owners of Jimmy's -- Jimmy and Gloria Jacobs and their daughter and son-in-law, Betsy and Dominick Lepore -- have embarked on a risky venture: opening a boutique in Manhattan in a high-competition zone when the economy is not being kind to retail businesses.
On Friday, a miniature branch of Jimmy's opened at 150 East 72d Street, in an apartment building that is a short stroll from Madison Avenue's designer boutiques. 
 "People may think it's a bad time for a new store, but I think the time is right," Mr. Lepore said. "People are making money again, and I think things are going to get better."
Behind a lace-curtained door in the building's lobby is a room decorated like a French salon, with sponged gold walls, a shiny parquet floor, a huge gilt-framed mirror, black armchairs and a mammoth round mahogany table under a brass chandelier. "I wanted to create a golden environment that would be flattering to women," said Mrs. Jacobs, who called on Andrew Rubenoff, a set and lighting designer who grew up with her daughter, to remodel the interior.
Two side walls display clothes by designers like Karl Lagerfeld, Gianfranco Ferre, Genny, Mary McFadden, Thierry Mugler, Gemma Kahng, Sylvia Heisel and Pamela Dennis. A small area of men's sportswear includes offerings from Donna Karan, Prada and Fusco. There are also handbags by Prada and Judith Leiber, with plans to add shoes, belts and jewelry.
"The lady who becomes our customer wants it all," Mrs. Jacobs said. And that customer can afford to spend $900 for a vest or $2,000 for a cocktail dress.
In the back is a tiny kitchen, where wine, cheese, coffee and soft drinks are stocked to pamper customers. The idea is to attract affluent young East Siders, with a degree of personal service that has almost vanished.
"We wanted an intimate atmosphere," Mrs. Jacobs said. "But we didn't want a big, big place."
They still have their big store in Flatbush, at 1226 King's Highway, which will double as a sort of stockroom for the new boutique.
"We don't really know what the Manhattan customer will want," Mr. Lepore said, "so we can move merchandise back and forth. We've started with the first spring goods delivered, but there'll be a lot more designers represented when their orders come in."
And there will always be a Jacobs or a Lepore on hand. "Jimmy's is Jimmy's no matter where it is," Mr. Lepore said.

HEADLINE: ABOUT CARS;
Spending the Yule in a New Silver Spur

BYLINE: By Marshall Schuon

 BODY:
FOR a change, I did my Christmas shopping the right way. It wasn't any earlier, mind you. Nor did I do the shopping in a catalogue. I did it in a new Rolls-Royce.
There is something very nice about rolling up to Pier One Imports in a Rolls. And, of course, I was chauffeured. I had my son driving while I sat in the back on my wallet. 
 But I was cheered to be gliding around, sort of saying, "Ho, ho, ho," and thinking that life wasn't all that bad. It was, I thought, the way things ought to be.
I didn't even mind that the $189,900 Rolls was the bottom of the British company's line.
Actually, prices for the Rolls and Bentley models range from $147,100 for the Bentley Brooklands to $337,100 for the Rolls Silver Spur limousine. But, despite the big-buck gross that those prices imply, Rolls-Royce has been hurting.
For one thing, there has been the recession of the past years, not just here but everywhere. And so Rolls has downsized. It has cut its staff to 2,200, down from 4,700, by using buyouts and early retirement, and it reckons (company's word, not mine) that it can now break even by selling only 1,300 cars a year.
That is just about what Rolls sold worldwide in 1993, with 380 of the cars coming to the United States. This year, according to Reg Abbis, the company spokesman, the numbers should be a bit better. And increased productivity, along with the shorter staff and new markets, should mean that Rolls will sail happily into the next century.
"We had two years of very heavy losses," Abbis said. "But now those losses have been stemmed, and we've developed markets in places that weren't there before. For instance, we hadn't sold a Rolls in Russia since Lenin."
America, however, remains the most important market for the company, whose cars have filled a peculiar niche for almost 90 years. And, just for the record, it was on May 4, 1904, that Sir Henry Royce and Charles Stewart Rolls met for lunch and planned their partnership at the Midland Hotel in Manchester. A May ceremony will mark the event at the hotel, which is now a Holiday Inn.
"There's a new feeling of buoyancy because of what we've done," Abbis said. "We now have a streamlined force that is more attuned to what is needed. The craftsmanship is still there, but -- as has been said -- we want to take the grunt out of making the car."
Under the new regime, virtually every car is made to order, taking the company back to its beginnings. And customers are being urged to individualize their purchases. "We'll do whatever they wish, providing it's tasteful and legal," Abbis said.
The bread-and-butter car is the Silver Spur III, new this year and with 70 major engineering changes, including dual air bags, antilock brakes, a redesigned and higher-powered engine, improved ride characteristics and a smoother automatic transmission.
The test car was a black four-door with black vinyl roof and red pinstriping, a beautiful car with whitewalls and chrome, a grille that takes a day to make by hand, and a huge hood that flows out to the horizon where the Flying Lady stands. One nice thing about the long hood, incidentally, is that you can see where everything is, including front fenders and the nose of the car, marked by the Spirit of Ecstasy, that valuable silver hood ornament that has a separate theft alarm all her own.
Flanked by new headlights, the hood opens from the rear on counterbalanced hinges, revealing a revamped engine for 1994. The giant 6.7-liter V8 is hidden under a large black plastic shroud, which reminds you of the myth that Rolls once had a sealed engine compartment. The shroud does have an attractive aluminum opening, however, and that shiny grille is matched by the finned aluminum valve covers.
Rolls has always been coy about its horsepower ratings, noting simply that power "is sufficient." But the word is that the big V8 now produces something more than 250 horses, and it does it smoothly and with enough oomph to make the 5,440-pound car quicker than one would expect.
Rolls also has prided itself on the quiet of its cars, and the new Spur is no exception. For '94, the suspension has been stiffened, but the ride is still whisper soft, falling between a big European sedan and the mushy Detroit products of old. The General Motors transmission, too, has been tweaked to make its shifts all but imperceptible.
Inside, the car was just plain (read fancy) gorgeous, a symphony in black leather upholstery and burr walnut trim with lighter inlays of boxwood. Two-inch-thick lambs-wool rugs were there, too, just to drive home the point.
The seats, buckets in front and a bucket-molded bench in back, were outlined in red leather piping, and all were electrically adjustable, with a rare reclining feature for those in the rear.
Rolls also has finally added dual air bags up front, with the new passenger bag mounted behind a wood panel in the leather-topped dash. Below it is a large glovebox that hides switches for the trunk and the theft alarm.
Unfortunately, the button-bedeviled dash is not particularly well arranged, although the company says it has made improvements over previous models. The ignition key goes into a slot to the left of the leather-wrapped (excuse me, hide-wrapped) wheel, and the instruments consist of a 150-m.p.h. speedometer and gauges that show the status of temperature, fuel, volts and oil pressure.
There is, of course, full power equipment and a keyless entry system, a la General Motors. Also, like Cadillac, the new Rolls has a parking brake that releases when the column-mounted lever puts the car in gear, and there is an electrochromatic mirror that automatically keeps reflected high beams out of your eyes.
The most amazing thing, though, is the rear compartment, whose long legroom is complimented by soaring headroom, thanks to the rather square and formal roof line. A fold-down center armrest holds the standard cellular telephone and three remote controls, one each for the 10-speaker radio, the trunk-mounted compact-disk changer and the optional VCR.
The $4,000 video system displays its magic on two Sony screens mounted in the back of the front-seat headrests. The pictures are crisp, but I was only halfway watching when I pulled out my wallet on the way to the mall.
I discovered that I had $12, and I made what seemed an appropriate comment to my son. "Ah, humbug," I said.

HEADLINE: The World;
Russia's Reform Train Isn't Exactly an Express

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
THE installation last week of a new Russian Government, without Yegor T. Gaidar and possibly without his comrade-in-reform Boris G. Fyodorov, inspired no shortage of doom-laden predictions, including: hyperinflation, a cut in living standards, a fixed ruble, price and wage controls and a general collapse that would hand the country over to someone like Vladimir V. Zhirinovsky in the 1996 presidential elections, if not sooner.
Unfortunately, some of these prophecies are likely to prove true unless the Prime Minister, Victor S. Chernomyrdin, and the Central Bank chairman, Viktor V. Gerashchenko, are correct in their fervent belief that Russia is special and follows its own economic laws. 
 Mr. Gaidar, 37 years old, whose party did badly in December's elections, resigned because he had lost influence and didn't believe Mr. Chernomyrdin would fight inflation, now about 15 percent a month and rising.
Mr. Fyodorov, 35, the Finance Minister, said he did not expect to be part of the government after Mr. Gerashchenko, the chief dispenser of industrial subsidies, and a socialist in charge of agriculture weren't fired by Mr. Chernomyrdin, who wants slower reform and more state funds for factories and collective farms.
After the success of Communists and ultra-nationalists in the elections, Mr. Chernomyrdin, who chose not to run at all, became irreplaceable for President Yeltsin. He represents Russia's real power structure -- the bureaucrats, directors and party elite who still run the country -- and needs no confirmation by Parliament.
Arguably, the economic policies of the old Russian legislature that Mr. Yeltsin disbanded in September and shelled in October have now become the Chernomyrdin doctrine, which may not represent progress but does more accurately reflect the consensus of this huge nation disoriented by change.
In Washington, those who weren't engaged in a rather precipitate hunt for who lost Russia were worried that Moscow was on the march, rushing to re-unite the lost flock of the Soviet Union. Clinton Administration officials expressed concern about inflation but trust in Mr. Yeltsin's commitment to democratic and market reforms. So soon after Mr. Clinton's summit meeting here, what choice did they have? STEVEN ERLANGER

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Adam Smith Was No Gordon Gekko

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
TO most Americans who have even heard of him, the 18th-century Scottish philosopher Adam Smith is simply the patron saint of conservative economics, the face on ties worn by Reagan aides, the name on the door of a libertarian think tank.
But to a growing and politically diverse fraternity of economists, historians and philosophers, the popular image of Smith is little more than a caricature. To them he is the father of all economics, a brilliant observer of social institutions, the source of all current theories of how societies become prosperous. 
 "Smith has been misappropriated and misunderstood," said James Buchanan, a conservative economist and Nobel laureate at George Mason University. "He was certainly not an extreme advocate of laissez faire."
And at a time when hundreds of millions of people in former communist states are struggling to create viable economies, Smith admirers are urging more people to go back to the source.
Smith, a Scottish university professor, tutor to a duke and, finally, customs official, lived from 1723 to 1790. A leading figure in the Scottish enlightenment, his two major books, "The Theory of Moral Sentiments" and "An Inquiry into the Nature and Causes of the Wealth of Nations" are to democratic capitalism what Marx's "Das Kapital" was to socialism.
Smith's cynicism toward government and devotion to individual liberty made him a symbol of conservatism within a century of his death. But his fundamental insight was that charity alone, while essential, would not suffice to create prosperity. "It is not from the benevolence of the butcher, the brewer, or the baker that we can expect our dinner, but from their regard to their own interest."
Smith's "invisible hand" is often misinterpreted as implying divine approval of greed. What Smith actually said is that self-interest, not charitable impulses, motivated butchers, brewers and bakers to feed society. Every individual, he concluded, is "led by an invisible hand to . . . without intending it, without knowing it, advance the interest of society."
"Smith didn't say greed is good," said Robert Nozick, a conservative philosopher at Harvard, echoing Gordon Gekko's motto in the film "Wall Street." "He thought that a free market economy was so structured that it led people pursuing their self-interest to end up serving the common good."
In his time, the philosopher was hardly a conservative. He thumbed his nose at church, university and empire, and inspired French revolutionaries, American suffragettes and Japanese political reformers. "My Adam Smith isn't the guy on the ties," said Paul Samuelson of M.I.T., the liberal economist and Nobel laureate, who has argued that Smith's scientific genius was underrated. "He was for trade unions, he believed in public works and he was very suspicious of businessmen."
Smith is also often thought of as being indifferent, even hostile, to the poor. On the contrary, he was not opposed, as a matter of principle, to redistributing income: He wanted to tax horse carriages so that "the indolence and vanity of the rich is made to contribute in a very easy manner to relief of the poor."
This champion of market forces is frequently misperceived as advocating no role for government. But Smith regarded national defense as a bigger priority than "national opulence" and supported public works.
In response to the new defenders of Smith's legacy, free-market advocates say they still prefer their emphasis on the conservative aspects of his thought. "We're trying to work out ways in which business can be conducted with less of a nanny state," said Dr. Eamonn Butler, director of the Adam Smith Institute in London. "What Adam Smith rails against is restraints on trade. That makes him extremely appropriate for us."
Though invoked as an authority by conservative governments around the world today, Smith in his own time was regarded with suspicion. Emma Rothschild, an economic historian at Cambridge University, reports that Scotland's leading newspaper devoted a mere dozen lines to Smith's obituary while allocating 65 lines to a "former quartermaster with an interest in barometers." She said British journalists were equally "disobliging," complaining that Smith tended to incite discussion of subjects that, as one obituary put it, "have become too popular in most countries of Europe."
The man himself is a far cry from the "simple Scottish professor" invoked by Victorian conservatives, said Ian S. Ross of the University of British Columbia and author of a forthcoming Smith biography. Smith adored Voltaire, was at ease in Parisian salons and preferred the latest novels and plays to Greek philosophers. And, though he was apparently homely and absent-minded, as the Victorians claimed, he was witty enough at dinner to cause a French countess to fall for him. Said Professor Rothschild, "All of us are just so fond of Smith, it's very nice to think he's being rescued."

HEADLINE: The World;
Iran, the Sequel: New Actors, but the Same Lines

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
WOVEN almost invisibly through the Iran-contra report on the Reagan Administration's arms-for-hostages trading and the cover-up that followed are reminders of the two fallacies that governed American dealings with the revolutionary regime in Teheran at the time.
The first fallacy: That there were good Iranian moderates eager to cooperate with the United States and worthy of its trust. The second: That the United States was somehow capable of playing them off against the bad radicals, in a way that would restore America's alliance with its one-time partner in the Persian Gulf. 
 The eight years since Robert C. McFarlane, then the national security adviser, arrived in Teheran bearing a cake in the shape of a key and a Bible signed by President Reagan have also shown that if there are constants in the Iran-America relationship, they are negative: Both countries deeply distrust each other, and they have national interests that are inimical.
Even after the Iran-contra debacle, there was a time of relative optimism, when it seemed as if Iran was headed on a new course that promised economic reform and better relations with the West. Its neutrality in the gulf war against Iraq and its help in winning the release of the last American hostages held in Lebanon even led the Bush Administration to briefly consider -- and then rule out -- tangible rewards for the regime.
But in the last two years, Iran has again become more difficult to deal with. President Hashemi Rafsanjani's campaign to control the bureaucracy, privatize the economy and promote economic development has failed. By contrast, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, who succeeded Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini as spiritual leader, has asserted himself by meddling in the Sudan, supporting radical Palestinians in Lebanon, opposing the talks between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization, and snuffing out any positive signals toward Washington.
"The reading of Rafsanjani as a pragmatist who wanted to re-engage Iran with the rest of the world was not wrong," said Shaul Bakhash, a historian who has written about Iran. "But the circumstances have changed. Iranian behavior has become more inconsistent, incoherent, more radical, its foreign policy more sensitive to what the regime believes is necessary to be an international leader. To an extent, it's a reversion to the early years of the revolution."
For the Clinton Administration, Iran's importance to America has diminished as well. American hostages are no longer held by Iranian-backed terrorists. The breakup of the Soviet Union ends concerns that Iran could move into Moscow's orbit.
On one level, the Clinton Administration's stated strategy toward Iran has been consistent: no intention of overthrowing the regime, no acceptance of preconditions for a dialogue, and no compromise on the American demand for change in Iranian behavior on issues like its quest for a nuclear weapon, and support for terrorism.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, branding Iran an "international outlaw," has led a campaign (unsuccessful so far) among America's allies to deprive Iran of equipment useful to its military. The Administration has also opposed international lending to Iran and the rescheduling of its debt. "Our efforts are aimed at pressuring Iran to change its behavior across the board, and, in the meantime, to contain its influence and constrain its troublemaking capabilities," Mr. Christopher said last week.
The Administration has also fine-tuned its approach since Martin S. Indyk, the National Security Council's Middle East specialist, articulated last May a strategy that treated Iran and Iraq as equally bad rogue regimes to be met with "dual containment." In July, before the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Edward P. Djerejian, who was then an Assistant Secretary of State, declined to use that expression, saying there "are obvious distinctions" between the countries. The message was that no matter how badly the Iranian clerics behaved, they were simply not in the same league as Saddam Hussein.
 
Inconsistencies
 Neither the American nor the Iranian policies are completely consistent, however. Although the United States bans imports of Iranian goods, and has a strict ban on the export of weapons and militarily useful equipment, it allows American companies to sell Iran a wide range of things -- consumer goods, oil drilling and engineering equipment, chemicals and gas turbines.
In a triumph of commerce over politics, Iran has abandoned its revolutionary pledge to ban American goods and Iranians can now wear genuine Levis, drink Coca-Cola, drive Chryslers and smoke Winstons. The State Department says Iran bought $750 million in American goods in 1992, a 14-fold increase over 1989.
More important for Iran's economy, while American oil companies are forbidden to trade in Libyan oil, American oil companies are the largest purchasers of Iranian oil, buying it on the open market and selling it outside the United States. When officials are asked why, if Iran is truly an outlaw state, the United States does business with it at all, the reply is straightforward: If we don't trade, someone else will.
Despite Iran's current lust for things American, there is still deep-seated antagonism there toward icons of America. In downtown Teheran recently, an enterprising businessman took advantage of the absence of copyright laws, secured the proper approvals and slapped a pair of McDonald's golden arches on the front of his restaurant. Five thousand customers showed up the first day. Officials didn't like it. A few days later he was ordered to take the sign down.
