HEADLINE: The World;
Living With North Korea's Bomb

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
IT has been 28 days since the world was informed that North Korea probably has developed one or two nuclear bombs. Yet Asia has not been engulfed by the war that once seemed imaginable the moment President Clinton received such news from the Central Intelligence Agency.
The Pentagon has not gone on alert. North Korea is not menacing its neighbors with nuclear threats. Japan and South Korea have not declared that they, too, will become nuclear powers. They seem vigilant, but calm. 
 The biggest thing going on in most Asian countries, North Korea excluded, is one of the most spectacular economic booms ever.
Who has time for war, many Asians ask.
Most analysts agree it would be too easy and wrong-headed to survey North Korea's nuclear threat and say, as many Asian businessmen have, 'So what?' But it may prove equally wrong-headed as national policy to imply, as the Clinton Administration has, that the moment North Korea gets the bomb, the next step is war or blockade or economic embargo (which could lead to war).
The most ardent American opponents of nuclear proliferation, while standing on the noblest of principles, may have inadvertently begun to scare many of the people they are seeking to save, because most Asian governments long ago thought through the consequences of war on the Korean Peninsula. They have considered the likely destruction of Seoul and the heavy loss of life; the wreckage of South Korea's $300 billion economy, the flood of refugees into China and the costs of reconstruction that Japan and others would be asked to pay.
Japan in particular is leery about the staggering cost of all wars and the ambiguous results of many. Having helped to finance the allies in the Persian Gulf war, the Japanese later observed with disbelief and some bitterness the $100 billion or more in devastation to the economies of Iraq and Kuwait. The human toll has never been finally tallied, and Saddam Hussein, while hobbled in his ambitions, remains in power.
A number of Asian leaders, conscious of Kim Il Sung's aggressive and unpredictable record, are no less nervous about a nuclear-armed North Korea than are the White House and State Department. But they have been asking whether the cost of a conventional war over North Korea's bomb-making program could easily be more costly than the damage wrought if one of the illicit bombs were used in a surprise attack. Of course, such an attack would certainly draw the massive retaliatory response that Mr. Clinton icily described last year while standing at the 38th Parallel armistice line: "It would be the end of their country."
 
Capable of What?
 Assuming North Korea could roll a crude bomb into South Korea on a freight car or jury-rigged on an aircraft, is this a military capability? Or is detonation simply an invitation to extinction, like a man holding a lightning rod in a thunderstorm who revels, at the instant of his incineration, in his ability to clutch the power of the heavens?
Harry Harding of The Brookings Institution in Washington recently observed that the Clinton Administration and its allies, who earlier had drawn a line in the sand over any North Korean nuclear capability, now seem more focused on preventing a "deployable capability" -- a bomb that could be fitted into the nose cone of a missile and exploded at the right moment on its target. This would require another big leap by North Korea.
Some Asian analysts are even thinking of anti-ballistic missile defenses, erected with American help, that would simply render North Korea's nuclear threat inert.
Part of the reason that countries like China, Japan and South Korea are not eager for a showdown is the belief that once Kim Il Sung dies -- he is 81 now -- North Korea may begin to moderate and evolve into a society more like the prosperous, stable and more politically tolerant success stories of Asia.
Thus, while reports that Pyongyang may now have nuclear arms are fervently unwished for, the crossing of this threshold may move the debate about American policy in Asia to a more practical question: If North Korea has the bomb, is there a way to live with this reality while seeking to change it through nonconfrontational means?
The Clinton Administration has not addressed this question in public. It is concentrating on counting up the ounces of missing plutonium that may help prove that Kim Il Sung has crossed the line Mr. Clinton said he must not be allowed to cross.
But as each day passes, the contradictions in American policy only seem to grow. A partial success this month, when North Korea agreed to reopen some of its nuclear facilities to inspection, may be unraveling. Pyongyang has refused to meet the demands of the International Atomic Energy Agency for access to atomic laboratories.
Any new deadlock could hoist American policy back to the precipice, and Mr. Clinton and his advisers will have to ask whether another year of brinkmanship is the right way to proceed. He may determine that short of war, pressure on North Korea simply does not work. And war may not be worth it.
After all, pressure did little to deter Pakistan and South Africa from acquiring the bomb in the 1980's. And, in South Africa, a hostile government evolved and eventually decided to dismantle its nuclear arsenal.
In 1964, when China exploded its first atomic bomb, it was regarded as dangerous and unpredictable, and had proven so by bloodying American forces in the Korean War. After that, the very allies Mr. Clinton is now concerned about, Japan, South Korea and Taiwan, lived in the shadow of Soviet and Chinese nuclear threats for decades.
Their faith in the American nuclear umbrella has been the greatest overall factor for insuring their long-term disinterest in pursuing their own nuclear arsenals. If that faith is well placed, then Mr. Clinton's options may be broader than he thinks, and could include a fuller diplomatic engagement of North Korea, like the one he is trying with China -- so far, all to the good.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 1; Column 5; National Desk

HEADLINE: CRIME IS BECOMING NATION'S TOP FEAR

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

 BODY:
Crime now rivals the economy in the eyes of Americans as the single most important problem facing the country, but they are divided over whether Republicans or Democrats are best able to do something about it, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
The sharp rise in concern about crime helps assure that it will be a front-line issue in this election year. But there is also a widespread sense that the country is powerless to deal with it, with most Americans saying they do not expect violence to decline significantly in the next few years. 
 The poll also found that many Americans seemed to question President Clinton's assertion that the health care system was in such a state of crisis that he must begin working on it before coming forward with his welfare reform plan. Asked which issue the Government should concentrate on first, 43 percent chose health care and 49 percent welfare reform.
 
Filling a Vacuum
 While people put the economy at the top of the agenda for years, anxieties about the economy have diminished in recent months, and crime has filled the vacuum. Asked to cite the single biggest problem facing the nation, 19 percent said crime or violence, with an additional 2 percent saying guns. Fifteen percent cited health care.
Among economic issues, 14 percent said the state of the economy concerned them most, and 12 percent unemployment or jobs.
The next most cited issue, at 5 percent, was the deficit, a major issue in the 1992 campaign. An issue that was once a dominant concern, drug abuse, was cited by 3 percent.
The telephone poll of 1,146 adults nationwide underscores why the political parties are battling so intensely to claim the crime issue as their own: Republicans may have lost the edge as the party seen as best poised to preserve law and order, leaving the potent political issue up for grabs.
Thirty-one percent said the Democrats had an advantage in dealing with crime, while a group of identical size cited the Republicans. The poll, conducted Jan. 15 to 17, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
The failure of either party to make itself the clear law-and-order champion helps explain why fighting crime was emphasized last week in speeches at the winter meeting of the Republican National Committee in Washington. Acknowledging the Democrats' inroads, Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, said yesterday that Mr. Clinton had "a big advantage" in the public relations battle over crime. "They go out in the Rose Garden and it's on the nightly news, in all the papers," he said.
Indeed, Mr. Clinton is expected to make crime a theme of his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, arguing for the crime bill that has passed the Senate but awaits House action.
 
Concern Over Economy
 The proportion of Americans who mention economic issues as the single most important ones before the nation is only about half the 54 percent who cited them in January 1992. Over the same period, the combined number of people who cited crime, violence or guns as the top problems has risen from 2 percent to 20 percent. The 15 percent who now cite health care also represent a major increase, from 3 percent two years ago.
Americans have clear beliefs about which party is better able to handle health care and economic matters.
Fifty-nine percent said the Democrats were more likely to improve the health care system, and only 20 percent said the Republicans. On economic questions, Americans expressed the view that the Democrats were better able to handle unemployment, while the Republicans were more likely to make sure the country is prosperous.
On another issue, 61 percent of the people surveyed said they would be willing to pay higher taxes to provide job training and public service jobs to help people get off welfare. Despite this apparent willingness to support such programs, many Americans still hold negative images of welfare recipients. Sixty-three percent said most welfare recipients did not want to work, and 48 percent said most people collecting welfare could get along without it if they tried, a finding that has remained steady for 18 years.
People were divided over the wisdom of forcing a woman with young children on welfare to work; 45 percent said she should be required to work, while 40 percent said she should be able to stay at home and take care of her children.
The lack of faith that one party would be better than the other at handling crime may reflect a general feeling among Americans that the problem has become intractable.
While people expect both the economy and health care to improve in the next few years, they hold out no such hope about crime. Sixty-seven percent said they expected the national economy to be in good condition by the end of Mr. Clinton's term in three years, while 66 percent said they expected significantly more Americans to be covered by health insurance. But only 29 percent said they expected crime to be reduced by then.
 
Contradictions on Crime
 The frustration about violence could be based on unfounded fears. Despite studies showing that crime had generally held steady in the past year, 73 percent said crime had increased in the country, and 58 percent said crime had risen in their own communities.
Yet there has been no appreciable increase in the last 20 years in the degree to which people say they fear walking at night within a mile of their homes. The proportion who are frightened is now 42 percent. Fifteen percent of the respondents said they or a family member had been a victim of crime in the past year, only slightly more than the 12 percent who reported such victimization in 1987, when The Times and CBS News last asked the question.
Still, 39 percent said they had done something special in the last year or so to protect themselves or their family against crime. The most mentioned step, taken by 7 percent of adults, was installing a house alarm, while 5 percent said they had bought a gun or now carried one. Other steps included getting a dog, carrying tear gas and being more aware on the street.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate Market Rebounds in New York Region

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO

 BODY:
After five years of slumping sales and plummeting prices, the residential real estate market in the New York region is starting to rebound, according to housing analysts.
Though the recovery is not as robust as in other parts of the country, like the Southeast and the Rocky Mountain states, the precipitous slide that saw home values in the region plunge by double-digit rates in the late 1980's and early 1990's appears to be ending. 
 Prices in most parts of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were generally flat in 1993, but that included a depressed first quarter.
 
Gaining Momentum
 The turnaround, however, was clearly apparent in the growth of home sales last year and the decline in the numbers of homes on the market. In Westchester County, for example, sales rose for the second year in a row in 1993, by 9.3 percent, and the number of homes offered for sale last year dropped by 600, or by 7 percent.
Real estate brokers attributed the increase in home sales to a number of factors, including lower interest rates, eager first-time buyers, and an economy that most analysts believe is slowly gaining momentum.
"We are just starting to see some pick-up, mostly because of the favorable interest rates" said Amos Ilan, an economist with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "As long as you have favorable interest rates, that will continue."
Housing analysts cautioned that although sales, and in some places prices, are rising, buyers and sellers should not expect the real estate market in the tri-state region to bounce back to prerecession highs anytime soon.
Even so, there were signs of vigor in some sectors of the market. Prices for all homes in Fairfield County, Conn., for example, rose by 5 percent, to $204,750 from $195,000, while sales increased by 7 percent, according to The Commercial Record, a real estate newspaper in South Windsor, Conn.
Elsewhere, condominiums in Manhattan rose an average of 9.3 percent in sales price in 1993, to $335,788 from $307,080 the year before, while the number sold increased by 20.7 percent, according to Yale Robbins Inc., a real estate research company in Manhattan.
 
Condos vs. Co-ops
 Condos have become popular in Manhattan among foreign buyers and investors, who find them easier to buy, sell and rent than apartments in restrictive co-op buildings, many of which are also burdened by high maintenance costs and are often viewed as less financially stable, carrying with them the burden of separate underlying mortgages.
Perhaps because of these drawbacks, the co-op market continues to lag. A study by Douglas Elliman, a Manhattan real estate brokerage, found that co-op prices in Manhattan fell 3.1 percent in 1993, to $95,788 per room, from $98,820 per room, continuing a slide of more than 25 percent since 1989.
Brokers said that many co-op buildings in New York still have a large number of unsold apartments that are owned by the buildings' sponsors. A glut of smaller units in less-than-prime neighborhoods, in many cases co-ops converted in the market's heyday of the early and mid-1980's, have also pushed overall prices down.
"There is an oversupply of studios and one-bedrooms," said Alan Rogers, managing director of Douglas Elliman, who added that prices tended to rise slightly -- or showed smaller declines -- for larger apartments, like those with four or more bedrooms, or those in more established areas, like the Upper West Side.
Prices also drifted downward for co-ops and condominiums in the suburbs and for all types of housing in areas hit hard by job losses and population declines, particularly parts of Connecticut, the lower Hudson Valley and Long Island.
 
Connecticut's Picture
 In Connecticut, for example, sale prices statewide fell 0.4 percent to $134,500 from $135,000 while the state's overall population fell 0.1 percent, or by about 2,000 people.
"The rest of the state would look a lot worse if it wasn't for Fairfield County," said Vincent M. Valvo, editor of The Commercial Record.
For the first 10 months of 1993, home prices fell significantly in Hartford County, by 4 percent, to $125,800 from $131,000, and in New Haven County, by 2.4 percent, to $122,000 from $125,000, in large part because of layoffs at insurance companies and defense contractors.
Even in most of the depressed areas, however, sales increased last year. In Hartford County, for example, they rose 3.4 percent and in New Haven County by 1.9 percent.
The phenomenon of decreasing prices but increasing sales occurred throughout the region last year and may set the stage for higher prices in the future, housing analysts say.
While sale prices decreased for Manhattan co-ops, the number sold increased by 1.3 percent. In northern New Jersey, home prices fell 0.1 percent, to $184,300 from $185,700, but sales rose 1.3 percent. The median price of a single-family home sold in New York City declined by 1.8 percent to $162,000 from $165,000, based on figures as of June 30 of last year and compiled by the city's Office of Tax Policy. The number of sales in the city, though, increased by 7 percent.
 
Westchester Sales Up
 In other areas, prices declined by 2.7 percent, to $240,000 from $246,600, in Westchester County, but the number of sales there rose by more than 9 percent.
"We saw multiple offers for the first time in a long time," said Savo Fries, president of the Westchester Multiple Listing Service. "These were from buyers who wanted to nail down a good price before interest rates changed."
Though interest rates have risen since last fall, they are still substantially lower than in the 1980's. The average 30-year fixed-rate mortgage today carries an interest rate of 7.16 percent, and adjustable-rate mortgages, with a two-point annual cap and a six-point lifetime cap, average 4.31 percent, according to HSH Associates, a mortgage information firm in Butler, N.J.
The drop in rates means that a home buyer taking out a $150,000, 30-year, fixed-rate mortgage would now pay $1,014.12 a month compared with $1,434.16 a month in 1986, when the average rate was 11.05 percent. The current first-year monthly payment on the average adjustable-rate mortgage would be $743.19.
The decline in rates helped encourage Kathy Salerno to sell her $160,000 Cape Cod-style home in Woodhurst, N.J., and buy a $380,000 split-level with an in-ground pool in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., in December.
"Because of the economy, we could pick and choose what we wanted," said Ms. Salerno, a human resources director for NYNEX in White Plains. "This was the perfect time for us to buy a home. For investment purposes, the market can only go up -- it can't go down."
Alan Yassky, a real estate broker in Spring Valley, N.Y., and past president of the New York chapter of the National Association of Realtors, said that home prices in 1993 would have been higher in many areas had it not been for an unusually bad first quarter.
"The market not only appears to be stabilizing, but it is becoming rather healthy," he said.
Apart from sales and prices, another measure of the vibrancy of the real estate market is new construction. In Northern New Jersey, for example, the number of housing units authorized by the state rose 20 percent last year over 1992, according to the New Jersey Department of Labor.
 
Some New Projects
 Even in areas where real estate prices continue to lag, developers have begun new projects. In Milford, Conn., near New Haven, Baker Firestone of Pleasantville, N.Y., is building 261 single-family homes ranging in price from $149,000 to $200,000. So far, 31 have been sold and a dozen are under construction.
"Last year was our best in 27 years," said Christopher T. Baker, manager of Baker Firestone, which built 536 homes between New Jersey and Massachusetts in 1993, compared with 86 in 1992. "Value is the key."
"Interest rates are holding steady, as are prices, and people are starting to realize that we are at the bottom of a market, and things are coming back," he said. "People want to buy because they are afraid interest rates -- or prices -- could change, and they could be priced out of the market again."
Home construction levels, however, remain far below the figures of the mid-1980's, particularly in New York, where new building fell 3 percent in 1993.
Moreover, the value of all new residential construction in the 17-county New York region, $2.3 billion, was about the same in 1993 as it was in 1992, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Mr. Ilan, the agency economist, added, however, that the figure had declined in every previous year since 1986. "We could be turning the corner in '94," he said.

HEADLINE: CONGRESS IS FACING HEALTH CARE BILL AND FULL AGENDA

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 22

 BODY:
The House and the Senate come back to work on Tuesday expecting to be judged on how they deal with health care, the biggest domestic issue Congress has confronted in three decades.
It may even prove to be the most complicated task that Congress has ever faced, involving far more crosscurrents than the civil rights bills of the 1960's or the economic measures of the New Deal. And before the issue actually comes to the floor in either House, it must make its way past scores of conflicting interest groups like the elderly, the hospitals and the various factions of the insurance industry, and through five major Congressional committees. 
 Otherwise, the second session of the 103d Congress faces a daunting agenda that might claim a place in history on its own. But this year the other issues are likely to remain in health care's shadow.
 
A Full Plate
 Congressional leaders and President Clinton have promised to try to pass major "reforms" in the way the Federal Government deals with welfare, crime, banking, telecommunications, foreign aid, job training and Federal aid to education.
With the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll showing that only 30 percent of the public approves of how Congress is doing its job, its leaders hope to dim those doubts with legislation on campaign financing, some reorganization of the way Congress does its own business and perhaps still more trimming of the Federal budget.
But after last year's budget bill froze the total that can be spent on all programs requiring annual appropriations, this summer's reruns of the annual spending battles will be even more intense than usual.
 
All Eyes on November
 The first spending dispute of the year will come soon. Republicans, according to Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, will demand that earthquake relief for California be offset by spending reductions elsewhere. Thomas S. Foley, the Speaker of the House, said Democrats would argue that it should be considered an "emergency," outside the regular pay-as-you-go rules for the budget.
Then in late February, the Senate is likely to go into an extended battle over a proposed constitutional amendment requiring a balanced Federal budget. If the measure receives the necessary two-thirds vote, the House will consider it next.
As in every other even-numbered year, Congress will be legislating with elections in mind, bringing more grandstanding amendments and more time off for "district work periods" and other opportunities to campaign and raise money. All 435 House seats and 34 of the 100 spots in the Senate will be up, and for most members, Election Day on Nov. 8 is the most important day of the year. Republicans, who now have 175 representatives and 44 senators, expect modest gains in each house.
An increasingly partisan tone can be expected as Election Day nears, but Republicans are wary of letting Democrats mask their own divisions with accusations of Republican obstructionism. "We don't have any gridlock plan," Mr. Dole said.
It seems unlikely that last year's absolute partisanship on budget votes, when no Republicans voted with Mr. Clinton, will be repeated.
But how much collaboration there will be, especially on health care, is an open question. In the more partisan House, it seems unlikely that more than a handful of Republican votes can be found for any plan resembling Mr. Clinton's, with its requirements that employers pay for most of their workers' health insurance and that each state set up insurance purchasing cooperatives to negotiate with insurance companies.
Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the deputy Republican leader, said that if Mr. Clinton was willing to compromise and work for "a health solution that is in the center and involves personal responsibility more than bureaucracy" he might obtain significant Republican backing. But that could cost Mr. Clinton many of the 93 House Democrats who already prefer a program to the left of his, the "single payer" scheme that would have the Government and not the insurance companies pay the bills.
House Democrats are ready to try to get the needed 218 votes just from their own ranks if they have to. Their success will be tested first in March or April in the Energy and Commerce Committee, headed by Representative John D. Dingell of Michigan, which will act first on the bill.
But that approach has no applicability in the Senate, where at least a bit of bipartisanship is required to pass almost anything. It takes 60 votes to break a filibuster that blocks action, and there are only 56 Democrats.
 
Searching for Compromise
 Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, has said hopefully that health will be a "high risk" issue to filibuster. But he and other Senate Democrats like Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts and Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York are searching for health care compromises that can bring a dozen or more Republicans along. So far they have just one, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont.
Mr. Foley said health care's prospects might depend on what lawmakers heard in their districts, "whether members come back with a sense of urgency." He predicted that lawmakers would spend more time than usual listening to each other when they return this week.
Mr. Dole said Senate Republicans would be talking to each other, too, trying to arrive at some common stance. They now have four differing bills they support, and Mr. Dole said, "If we can't come together on some common package, we may find ourselves sitting in the bleachers somewhere."
There is no solid timetable for health care. Mr. Moynihan plans to hold hearings in the Senate Finance Committee through April. Mr. Kennedy's Labor and Human Resources Committee is ready to vote any time but will probably wait while he tries to line up Republican support.
 
Committee as Microcosm
 In the House, Mr. Dingell is likely to force the first votes, having given his subcommittees until March 4 to finish their work so the full committee can take up the bill. The Michigan Democrat learned the gospel of health care from his father, an earlier Representative John D. Dingell, who in 1943 joined in introducing the first national health care bill.
The veteran chairman's committee, with 27 Democrats -- including several nervous freshmen and a few moderates -- along with 17 Republicans, is fairly representative of the House itself. Thus, a victory there would be a bigger boost for Mr. Clinton than success in the more heavily partisan Democratic ranks of the Ways and Means or Education and Labor Committees, which will also deal with the bill.
While most Congressional leaders expect major health care legislation to be passed, none will offer a road map to enactment. And some worry that Congress will fail to agree on any bill at all, as the public expects. A Times/CBS News Poll of 1,146 adults, conducted by telephone from Jan. 15 through 17, showed that 56 percent of the public expected failure and only 39 percent predicted success. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus three percentage points.
If "by some unfortunate fact, we do not pass it," Mr. Dingell said, then Democrats should be ready to try to turn the 1994 election into a referendum on the health care issue.

HEADLINE: THE EARTHQUAKE;
Quake and Freeze May Interrupt Economy's Growth in Short Term

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
The California earthquake and the Arctic cold in the East together may shear as much as half a percentage point or more from economic growth this quarter, some economists say, but later this year they may actually give the economy a boost.
While the earthquake and the freeze are expected to slow growth this winter as transportation is disrupted, factories are shut and consumers huddle at home, by the spring and summer, growth should increase as people spend to replace objects that were destroyed and rebuild from the earthquake.
 
Sophisticated Guesses
 Indeed, some economists say that by the end of 1994, the country's employment and Gross Domestic Product are likely to be slightly higher than they would have been without nature's intervention. 
 Although the estimates of damage from the earthquake in Los Angeles are still little more than sophisticated guesses, the growing sense among business executives, government officials and economists is that the impact will be larger than that of the San Francisco earthquake in 1989, which resulted in about $6 billion in damage. The devastation could fall between that of the flood in the Midwest last year ($12 billion) and that of Hurricane Andrew in 1992 ($30 billion), they say.
"This is larger than San Francisco," said Wesley Ooms, an assistant vice president for State Farm Insurance. "I don't think it's more than Andrew."
Forecasters at DRI/McGraw Hill, a research company in Lexington, Mass., are among those who this week scaled back their estimates of growth in the first quarter because of the quake and the cold, and raised their estimates for the second quarter. DRI reduced its first-quarter estimate to an annual rate of 2.5 percent, from 3.2 percent, because it expects weaker retail sales, less production and fewer new jobs. DRI has cut its forecast of job growth in January by 40,000 jobs, to 150,000, from 190,000.
The impact of the cold wave, though less visible than that of the earthquake, has also been pronounced. "When day after day cities are setting new records for cold by a substantial margin, it's an incredible event," Mr. Ooms said.
In most of the frozen Northeast, more people have been killed than in the quake, large companies have closed because of power shortages and ice and snow have slowed freight and travelers, and kept shoppers away from malls. Home building has come to a standstill.
How much the icy weather will affect quarterly growth depends on how long it lasts. So far, the damage is being done in January and, by the time the quarter is over, lost production and sales may be recouped. The freeze is forcing homeowners to add to the economy's growth by buying more heating fuel and paying for plumbers and new pipes, sometimes with insurance checks.
"The cold doesn't get us headlines, but we pay out a lot of money" Mr. Ooms said. "It's the frozen pipes; we call it the silent catastrophe." He added that insurers might pay as much for this cold snap as they did for Hurricane Hugo in 1989, nearly $5 billion.
 
'A Positive for G.D.P.'
 While natural disasters are not good for the economy, they can temporarily lift growth after the initial disruption. "Floods, hurricanes and earthquakes are very bad for people, but they tend to raise the G.D.P.," said Alan Blinder, a member of the Council of Economic Advisers. "Generally you see a small dip in the G.D.P. in the short run, then a bigger rebound. This has to be a positive for G.D.P. this year."
"By no stretch of the imagination is California better off because of the earthquake," he added. "If you lost a $100,000 home, and, as a result, worked harder and earned $10,000 more next year, G.D.P., which is a measure of production, is ahead. But you're not ahead."
The impact of the quake will be felt for years, mostly, of course, in California, which has been stuck in a deep recession for more than three years.
The quake has disrupted the Los Angeles economy -- closing its biggest shopping malls, snarling traffic and keeping thousands too preoccupied to go to work, much less go shopping -- and is likely to knock down tourism, which had started to show signs of life this summer. Widespread damage to highways has created havoc for truckers and turned some commutes into four-hour travails. That could depress productivity for years and also prompt more businesses and workers to move out.
But while the quake might postpone a sluggish economic recovery in California for a few months, economists said, it is not likely to prevent it from happening.
One reason, of course, is that the Clinton Administration, with an eye on the 1996 election and California's 54 electoral votes, is likely to pull out all the stops to help the State.
"This will be the President's excuse for a California aid package," said David Schulman, chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers. The President has already pledged $45 million in emergency highway funds and more.
Even if Washington were not inclined to be more generous than usual, economists said, the net effect on California's G.D.P. and employment -- if not on its quality of life and business environment -- later in the year was apt to be positive.
 
No 'Wrecking Ball' Seen
 "We see a very gradual recovery by mid-summer," said Larry Kimbell, director of the University of California at Los Angeles's Business Forecasting Project. "I don't see a wrecking ball that knocks us back into recession," added Jack Kyser, chief economist of the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles County. "Basically, you have a hiccup on the road to recovery for Los Angeles. You'll get a recovery in 1995."
After looking at the construction boom that followed Hurricane Andrew, Mr. Kimbell said as many as 10,000 jobs could be created in the Los Angeles area.
"We've got four or five emergency contracts now," said John Cash, chief financial officer of the Kasler Holding Corporation, a heavy construction company. "People are clamoring for solutions. Theoretically, the money's available. Now the state just has to figure out how to make it happen."

HEADLINE: Consolidated Edison Urged To Freeze Electrical Rates

BYLINE: By NORIMITSU ONISHI

 BODY:
Consolidated Edison, which has been pursuing a 2 percent rate increase for several months, should instead freeze its electricity rates for at least one year, the New York State Attorney General, G. Oliver Koppell, urged yesterday. He asserted that savings from lower interest rates and operation costs should be transferred to customers.
The increase requested by Con Ed, if approved by the State Public Service Commission, would add a little over $1 to an average customer's monthly bill beginning in April. A typical residential customer, using 300 kilowatt hours a month, pays about $50. 
 In 1992 Con Ed and the commission agreed on a three-year plan to raise rates, which have climbed by about 5 percent in each of the last two years. But appearing at City Hall in lower Manhattan yesterday with members of the State Consumer Protection Board, Mr. Koppell said changing circumstances now made the plan unfair to customers.
 
Helped by Interest Rates
 Mr. Koppell said that the plan was drawn with 1992 interest rates in mind and that the utility was now benefiting from lower borrowing costs. "They've fired people and reduced costs, and that should also be looked at," he said.
The Attorney General backed his petition by pointing to the Long Island Lighting Company, which announced last month that it would freeze rates for 1995 and 1996, citing lower interest rates and oil costs, as well as more purchases of cheaper power from sources outside Long Island. For 1994 Lilco customers saw a 4 percent rate increase, which is expected to bring the utility $85 million. Earlier this month Mr. Koppell called on Lilco to cut its rates, instead of merely freezing them.
Con Ed officials said they based their request for a 2 percent increase on improvements to equipment, rising operation expenses and slightly more expensive power that it must buy from independent producers. "We believe it's modest and reasonable," said Bruce Wittmer, a spokesman for the company. "It brings the average residential bill to what it was 10 years ago."
The utility's rates did not change from 1983 to 1987, when they were cut by 3.1 percent. In 1992 rates rose 4.5 percent. Last year, after the utility had requested a 6.5 percent raise, the commission approved a 5 percent increase.
Con Ed, whose rates are among the highest in the country, has 2.9 million electricity customers in New York City and Westchester County.
 
Underground Equipment
 Mr. Wittmer said Con Ed had already won preliminary approval from the commission for the third of its three increases over three years. If approved, the 2 percent increase is expected to amount to $90 million. The commission typically makes rulings in March, and the increase, if approved, would go into effect on April 1.
"Most of our equipment is underground, which makes it very costly, and as it gets older, it must be replaced," Mr. Wittmer said. He said that the utility had not dismissed any of its employees but that retirements and attrition had reduced the work force considerably over the last five years.
Although those opposing the increase did not dispute the extra costs that Con Ed has incurred recently, they said the costs were offset by today's lower interest rates and shrunken payroll. Richard M. Kessel, executive director of the State Consumer Protection Board, pointed out the utility had 17,588 employees in November, down from 18,933 in September 1992.
 
11.6 Percent Profits
 The board, which by law represents consumer interests before the Public Service Commission, has said consistently that three-year rate agreements are harmful to customers' interests.
Mr. Kessel said the commission now allowed Con Ed to earn profits of 11.6 percent. He and the Attorney General have asked the commission to reduce Con Ed's return on equity to 10 percent, in part to meet a goal of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.
"The Governor has instructed me to try to get rates frozen in the 1990's," Mr. Kessel said. "Stable rates are critical for the region's economy, particularly in an era when we're trying to bring back the region from a prolonged recession. To attract new jobs we must get Con Ed's rates, which are among the highest in the nation, to be stable."

HEADLINE: NEW CANADA CHIEF WINNING APPLAUSE

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OTTAWA, Jan. 20

 BODY:
Short on panache and vision, long on prudence and street smarts, Jean Chretien has enjoyed an unusual honeymoon with Canadian voters.
Since his Liberals won a commanding majority in the House of Commmons three months ago, the country's 20th Prime Minister has increased his approval rating not by deferring tough decisions but by making a series of them politically palatable. 
 "He has scarcely put a foot wrong politically," said Norman Hillmer, a professor of history at Carleton University in Ottawa, "and the tone has been one of integrity and real care with resources."
Mr. Chretien's approval of the North American Free Trade Agreement, without heavy criticism even though it is still opposed by a majority of Canadians, is illustrative.
He had said he would sign on only with major concessions from the United States. Although concessions were not forthcoming, he declared victory anyway and now, like the Conservatives he used to criticize, vows to seek better trade opportunities abroad.
 
His Low-Key Approach
 Helping Mr. Chretien sell even retreaded policies has been a low-key, businesslike approach to governing, in contrast to the more imperial style of two of his predecessors, Brian Mulroney and Pierre Elliott Trudeau.
The Prime Minister's decision to cut some of the perks of office has also made him far more friends than enemies. No more free shoe shines or subsidized haircuts for members of Parliament. Members are even losing their $400 annual allowance for framing pictures. Gone is the armor-plated Cadillac limousine for the Prime Minister, who now rides in a Chevrolet Caprice.
"The optics play really well," said Mary Taber, political columnist for The Ottawa Citizen. "My father, who voted for the Reform Party, has been quite impressed. These are things people can relate to."
Mr. Chretien has managed to take other politically risky decisions without harming himself. He canceled a $3.75 billion helicopter contract that meant job losses in places like Montreal and Winnipeg. He scrapped the previous Government's plan to privatize Pearson International Airport at Toronto, the country's largest.
 
Street-Wise Politician
 Analysts credit his street-wise political instincts. Mr. Chretien, who likes to call himself "the little guy from Shawinigan," in Quebec, has been in public life for the last 30 years.
"While Mr. Chretien, like former U.S. President Ronald Reagan, may lack the finely nuanced grasp of policy matters," said Edward Greenspon, the Ottawa bureau chief of The Globe and Mail, "he possesses the best-tuned political antenna in the business. He plays politics by ear and is blessed with near-perfect pitch."
Yet the pitch sometimes errs, as in the appointment of a minister, David Anderson, who was suing the Government over the loss of patronage perks. As soon as the opposition and the press learned of the suit, Mr. Chretien made sure that either Mr. Anderson dropped it or left the Government. The litigation was dropped.
Mr. Chretien's appointment of his nephew, Raymond Chretien, as Ambassador to the United States, also sent out some confusing signals, even though the nephew is a respected career foreign service officer. The Prime Minister stuck by the decision.
Mr. Chretien has so far found himself in hotter water internationally.
 
Embarrassment Over Bosnia
 Because of inadequate briefings, attributed to attempts to save money through staff reductions, the Government ended up contradicting itself during the recent summit meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. First Canada said it would accept no NATO bombing in Bosnia, only to acknowledge the next day that it would.
It has also taken criticism because of the mistreatment of Canadian peacekeeping troops in Bosnia. In one incident, 11 Canadians were held by drunken Bosnian Serbs, who fired shots near the soldiers before releasing them.
Yet polls show support for Mr. Chretien even greater than during his election triumph on Oct. 25. A Gallup survey taken Dec. 3-14 found that 56 percent backed the Liberal Party of Mr. Chretien, up from 51 percent in November and 41 percent in the election. Another poll, conducted Dec. 15-20 by the Angus Reid Group, placed the approval rating at 61 percent.
But Mr. Chretien has yet to deal with the two mega-issues that will define his tenure: cutting the deficit while meeting campaign promises of jobs and economic growth, and managing the problem of his native Quebec. The province is again threatening secession, this time supported by a huge bloc of separatist members of Parliament.
An avid federalist, Mr. Chretien says he does not believe that Quebecers will vote to separate. The answer will come within the first two years of his watch, and is likely to be a cliffhanger.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
In Connecticut, a Wait For Would-Be Candidate

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
John G. Rowland, a former Republican United States Representative from Waterbury, Conn., came within a whisker of beating Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. in the 1990 race for governor. Since then he has been his party's presumptive front-runner for 1994, a heavyweight without portfolio whose every appearance in or out of state politics has begged the question of his future.
And Mr. Rowland has milked the suspense for all it is worth, delaying and postponing an announcement of his candidacy for months, while hinting strongly that he would indeed run again. The tease has worked, at least to the extent of making the declared field of candidates appear to be standing on stage waiting for his appearance. 
 But as the weeks of fund-raising and publicity efforts by his rivals have rolled by, Mr. Rowland's absence has begun to beg another question: When does a grand dramatic entrance simply become a late start? Mr. Rowland finally formed a campaign committee nearly two weeks ago, allowing him to begin soliciting money, and said last week that he would make his formal announcement on Jan. 31. His major opponents, meanwhile, had already raised more than $800,000 before Mr. Rowland could even put his toe in the water.
"It's rather late," said Francis J. Collins, the campaign chairman for Pauline R. Kezer, the Republican Secretary of the State who announced her plans last year and formally declared her candidacy for governor earlier this month. Mr. Collins said he believed Mr. Rowland's "continuing delay" in formally stepping into the race reflects badly on his character.
"The only conclusion I can come to is that it reflects some indecision on his part," Mr. Collins said.
Nonsense, said Francis G. Brennan, the political director for the Rowland campaign. Mr. Brennan conceded that Mr. Rowland had promised to make his announcement last fall after the November municipal elections. The date was pushed back, Mr. Brennan said, when it became clear that the field of candidates was not that strong. As for fund raising, he said he has no doubt that Mr. Rowland can raise at least $2.8 million -- his 1990 total, which took 13 months to assemble -- in the 10 months left before Election Day.
"There was no need for us to join the herd," Mr. Brennan said. "There is a timing to everything."
 
Carville to Skip Campaigns
 James Carville, the "Ragin' Cajun" adviser to President Clinton, star of the current documentary "The War Room," and -- with his wife, Mary Matalin, a big budget author -- apparently has no time for New Jersey, where his last campaign, managing the race of former Gov. Jim Florio, ended in an upset defeat last fall. He said this week that other commitments would prevent him from running this year's re-election campaign for Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, even though Mr. Carville managed his campaign six years ago.
"Except for a little work for Gov. Zell Miller down in Georgia and Senator (Harris) Wofford in Pennsylvania, I'm not really working this year," Mr. Carville said in a telephone interview from his car the other day. "Our book is due in August and I'm too busy."
Enter David Eichenbaum. Mr. Eichenbaum, it was announced last week, has signed on as manager of the Lautenberg campaign. A New Jersey native who was press secretary to Carol Mosley-Braun's winning Senate campaign from Illinois in 1992, he has also worked for the presidential campaign of former Senator Paul Tsongas of Massachusetts, and for Representative Rosa DeLauro of Connecticut. The Lautenberg team will be rounded out with the Washington-based media firm of Grunwald, Eskew & Donilon, one of whose partners, Carter Eskew, also worked for Mr. Lautenberg in 1988.
Together with his partner, Mandy Grunwald, another major Clinton adviser, Mr. Eskew is a triple threat in Senate races in the region this year; they are also working for Democratic Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York and Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut.
 
The Big City -- Maybe
 Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport is running for governor on a claim of having turned around Connecticut's largest city. But his city just may be shrinking.
According to a new ranking issued this week by Connecticut Policy and Economic Council, a Hartford-based research group, Connecticut's capital city edged out Bridgeport -- the longstanding No. 1 -- by about 1,000 residents in late 1992. The study used estimates by the State Department ofHealth Services showing Hartford with 140,040 residents, to 139,160 in Bridgeport.
The 1990 United States Census, still the official count, showed Bridgeport with about 2,000 more residents than Hartford, and a state projection issued several years ago also predicted that Bridgeport would grow through the 1990's while Hartford would shrink in population.
Beyond bragging rights, the new municipal order, if sustained, would likely affect grant and aid formulas. But State Senator Alvin W. Penn, a Democrat who represents Bridgeport in the Legislature in Hartford, said the capital has always somehow obtained disproportionate gain when money was being distributed anyway, and that if being No. 1 in population also means being No. 1 in problems, he'll gladly pass the baton.
"There has been no financial gain from being the largest city," he said. "It still feels like we're last."
A New Seat of Power
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman came to office promising change, and she has started to make good on that promise immediately, both politically and in the decor of the Governor's office.
Among her first acts upon assuming the seat of power was to remove an old chair from her State House office that had been used by Woodrow Wilson when he was Governor of New Jersey.
Gov. Jim Florio, whom Mrs. Whitman defeated in November, had retrieved the leather chair and the oak desk Mr. Wilson -- a fellow Democrat -- had used during his years in the State House after someone donated the set to the state. Mr. Florio often pointed out to visitors the historic significance of the furniture.
But Mrs. Whitman sent the chair back to storage on Wednesday, her first full day in office. The new Governor, a Republican, dismissed any suggestions that the decision was based on partisan politics.
"That is one of the most uncomfortable things I've sat on in my life," Mrs. Whitman said. "I cannot believe that Governor Florio sat on it."
